content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												A fantastic turn-based squad tactics game. Premise of Xcom is simple. You're in charge of a secret organization that's at the frontline of defending our world from an alien invasion. To do so you must train an elite team of able soldiers and give the invaders a fight they'll never forget.Gameplay consists of a variety of elements. The main aspect are the combat missions where you move each squad member on an isometric grid in a turn-based format. Enemies come in a good variety, each one having their own strengths and weaknesses, and all having a smart A.I. Taking cover and using teamwork are essential to winning the battles. Your soldiers are all expendable and die permanently if killed in combat. Where this is not a big deal when you lose rookies, you really want to take special care for your higher levelled people (gladly they also have a higher chance of simply being K.Oed and able to be revived with a medic).The combat is pretty challenging a lot of the time and gets you thinking tactically, even on an Easy difficulty. There were a few instances where I felt that the difficulty spiked a bit too sharply. Those were mainly regarding the main story missions. I think you're supposed to really take your time preparing for those, because the game doesn't have levels and the like that tells you how powerful you need to be in order to handle these missions, so it's easy to go in too soon without realising it. Moreover, the game constantly highlights main story objectives as high priority, which is also very misleading, because it makes you think you have to do them as soon as possible. Aside from main story missions, there are many optional missions. Some require you to simply clear out an area off hostiles, others require you to shoot down a UFO and then send a team to finish off any surviving invaders, and at times you also get missions where you have to rescue as many civilians in an area as you can whilst aliens are trashing up the place.Aside from combat missions, you also have to do some management behind the scenes. That mostly involves deciding what tech to research, how to outequip your team, as well as launching satellites over specific countries, each one giving you their own bonuses, and overall monitoring the level of panic on each continent and making sure it doesn't go into the red zone. In essence, there's a lot of choice on how to advance through the game.I was quite surprised by the high level of presentation in regard to story cutscenes, voice acting, and things of that nature, considering that most tactics-based games usually have a very minimalistic approach regarding these aspects of a game. The music is also pretty amazing (particularly the squad selection track, which is my favourite).Xcom is very good at sucking you in and making you really feel like a commander who has to make difficult decisions and look after his people. I'd highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys squad-based tactics games or any games with turn-based combat.

This sucks.ATTEMPT TO PROTECT THE EARTH FROM AN ARMY OF ALIENS THAT THE CONCEPT OF CLOTHING IS COMPLETELY NEW TO THEM, BUT COMPLETE DOMINATION IS NOTSAVE COUNTRIES THAT WON'T FUND YOUR OPERATION IF THEIR LIVES DEPENDED ON IT (oh wait, it does) FROM AFOREMENTIONED ALIENS THAT CAN HIT YOUR SOLDIER FROM A RIDICULOUS DISTANCE AWAY AND IMMEDIATLEY HOSPITALIZE THEM FOR WEEKS (or, alternatively, immediatley kill them) CAUSING PANIC AMONG YOUR STRONGEST SOLDIER, CAUSING THEM TO BE UTTERLY USELESSGAIN MONEY IN THE SAME WAY HEADHUNTERS DO: BY SELLING DEAD BODIES. THE MILLION DOLLAR-WORTH LASER SNIPER ISN'T WHAT THEY WANT, THEY WANT A MUTILATED EXTRATERRESTRIAL CORPSEWITH THE "ENEMY WITHIN" EXPANSION, SAVE LIVES IN THE AMERICAN WAY: BY FIGHTING TERRORISTS THAT ARE JUST AS POWERFUL AS A CYBERDISC BUILT BY THE FBI WHO CAN:-Request backup from an infinite supply of soldiers-Do operations faster than you can build an aircraft-Fall from the air the same way aliens do, with no physical damage whatsoever, despite falling from who-knows-where-And carry more blood in their bodies than a MutonSTARRING:-HOPELESS ODDS-CHEATING AIs-RESEARCHERS WHO DON'T RESEARCH-ENGINEERS WHO DON'T ENGINEER-SOLDIERS WHO SUCK AT THEIR JOB-SOLDIERS WHO ARE DECENT AT THEIR JOB (sort of)- THAT ONE EPIC SNIPER WHO BASICALLY RULES XCOM-INCONVIENIENT TERROR MISSIONS-WORTHLESS COUNTRIES WHO DON'T FUND OR SUPPORT YOU-A BARRAGE OF STUPID HAIRSTYLES- THE HONEST TRAILER GUY (wait, I meant the Council dude)NOT STARRING:- ACTUAL FUNDING- THE ABILITY TO BUILD MORE THAN ONE SKYRANGER- THE ABILITY TO SEND MULTIPLE SQUADS TO MULTIPLE PANIC SITES- INTELLIGENT TEAMMATES WHO WON'T TRY TO MURDER THEIR SQUAD- FAST RESEARCHXCOM: ENEMY UNFAIR

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												The original X-COM is one of my favorite games ever, one that I have played through many times. I found the tactics in this game to easier than in the original (especially in the beginning), but the base management side more challenging to figure out, which is good (WAY too easy to make easy millions in the original). I LOVE the "chunky" aesthetics of the game that are a throwback to the original's look, and I've even taken a liking to the change from time units to Final Fantasy Tactics style combat; it really helps the game move along at a nice pace without changing the feel of combat very much. I always used to leave enough time units in the earlier X-COM's to move behind cover and crouch after a shot, so I am pleased that this whole sequence of ducking in and out of cover to fire is built into the game's cover-mechanic. The alien's getting a free move when you see them does not bother me in a thematic sense (they're on "free-move-overwatch" I guess), though it is sometimes immersion-breaking, since you know you cannot be shot at until you "activate" a group of aliens. A bit different feel than the original, due to unseen aliens not shooting, and XCOM soldiers being MUCH harder to kill.Anyways, I LOVED IT. I haven't encountered the bugs I've seen others complain about, fortunately, and Firaxis has somehow made this game even MORE addictive/compelling than the original, with that same "just one more turn" feel that the Civilization series has. I totally see the complaints about the camera with multi-level maps, though; it's really terrible!Also, it feels a bit more scripted than what I was expecting, both in the strategic level (3 uninterceptible abduction missions at the same time) and tactical level (aliens don't move until encountered).

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a turn-based tactical RPG, which can be played in single-player campaign mode or in multiplayer mode. Released in 2012 and using the UE3 Engine, Enemy Unknown takes place in a future where aliens have invaded earth and you are the last line of defense. As the commander, you direct soldiers turn-based style to eliminate alien threats, secure objectives, and more. At the end of each mission, prior to the start of the next, you have the ability to use do research, and create new technologies, as well as handle your finances. Visually, I think the game looks pretty good for being 3 years old. The fog of war is well done, and there are multiple difficulty settings to give players even more of a challenge. I played on Impossible mode, as well as Ironman mode, with all the special features turned on to make the game as challenging as possible and it worked. The AI is great and can present a challenge to those who rush in, forcing you to actually use tactics to clear objectives. Enemy Unknown also has an expansion called, XCOM: Enemy Within, which adds a variety of content. The Elite Edition contains all DLC Content and is the best deal if you are interested in picking up this game. I'm not a huge fan of turn-based gameplay, but this is actually a really great game, nicely done, and worth paying for.

number of helpful: 24 of 28 people (86%) found this review helpful8 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
 Want to know how PTSD is like? Then just play this gameYou bought this game thinking it was your average tactical strategy squad-based shooter. Until you realised this is an actual war and every soldier that returns home in a coffin is another blow in your already shattered heart.Enter XCOM, or Extraterrestial Combat Unit, an organisation funded by all the goverments in the world with the sole purpose to defend Earth against the alien invasion. Your job as the man in charge is to guide this organisation to victory through research, experimentation, building your base and commanding your troops in battle. Do well and the nations will make it rain on you with them precious dollars. Do poorly, and the nations will pull out, leaving you with reduced resources to fight.Every aspect of the game is all about making the right choices, as there's no such thing as fully upgrading everything. Will you keep a soldier in battle to upgrade his skills or will you pull him out to undergo psychic training? Will you buy more satellites to spot alien aircraft faster or will you buy more interceptors to deal with the ones you find? Everything has a price to pay and tensions will rise very soon once the main bulk of the game reveals itself. Combat-wise, as your soldiers take part in more missions, they get more experience, which allows them to unlock certain skills. It's a well-made system, because it allows you to tailor your troops as you see fit and adjust them to your playstyle. You can also rename your soldiers and change their appearance. Later in the game, you will have the option to unlock their psionic powers or turn them into cyborgs for greater efficiency. All these combined, give a sense of personality on each soldier and you will feel differently about them, mostly sympathetic. That means that their deaths can leave you in a state of sadness, since you know that from now on you will only see them in the dead troopers' records. And that's the game's magic, you will develop a bond with the men and women that are ready to sacrifice everything for victory.The missions are pretty difficult, especially in higher levels, requiring careful planning and tactics to pull them off. The alien enemies have different races, skills and weapons at their disposal, meaning that each enemy requires different approaches to defeat. You will always have the feeling that the aliens are two steps ahead of you and you are struggling to keep the organisation alive between demanding nations, alien spaceship assaults and dogfights on the Earth's atmosphere. It's brutal, harsh and unforgiving, granting a huge level of immersion.The game looks beautiful, colorful and well-made. By the time each mission finishes, the map will be full of debris, exploded cars, crushed walls and dead bodies (alien or not). Your soldiers look incredible in their special battle armors, even if some players might find them slightly cartoonish. It really does a nice job giving you a feel of the battlefield as you see the firefights and explosions everywhere. Better yet, even though everything can be used as cover, that means cover will often be destroyed by gunfight, leaving an unpredictability factor in the game, forcing you to think on the fly to save your precious soldiers.On the downside, the fact not all your soldiers can't reach the highest point of their abilities, means you won't have much room to make the most out of their abilities. You rarely will see a trooper fully-upgraded, let alone one with all his psionic powers mastered, for example. This is, in my opinion, a major failure of the game. True, it adds a "survive" feel to the game, but you will never feel overpowered and badass against the aliens. Despair and anxiety are realistic factors, but overdoing it is just not gonna work that nicely.Now excuse me, I got to bury a soldier that looks like my nasty boss. Huh, this game has good moments after all...RATING:Gameplay: 8/10Presentation: 9/10Story: 8.5/10Unique Factor: Progression System: 9/10OVERALL: 8.6/10

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												I really don't know what to write about XCOM: Enemy Unknown. One one hand it is a great tactical strategy game with some cool features, on the other hand it seems to be either unintentionally broken or designed so horribly that it basically makes the turn-based gameplay pointless.Visually XCOM is great, mostly. The designs, weapons, armors, vehicles and bases in addition to most of the aliens are really nice looking and have variety to them. The human characters, mainly the male soldiers are rather unnerving in appearance. The female soldiers are mostly ok and the story characters work well. The music sets the mood and there are some good standout pieces (especially the "Ready for battle" song).Now, I know that the franchise is a meat grinder of sorts, fighting tooth and nail to win one battle at a time with the ever-looming threat of making that one bad call and getting a TPK even on a regular search and destroy mission. And I am fine with that.1. Not being able to choose the class of your soldiers when they start ranking up. You would think this is an OK feature and perhaps if it worked well enough it would be. Now it is completely random (or at least I haven't found out how to affect it through my own actions): I started a new game, played the first few missions and leveled up my squad only to find out that 2 of them became snipers, one went to become a heavy and another an assault class. Ok, so early in the game that is not a big problem but when I bought an additional squad member position to my team and picked the next rookie to go on a mission things went from "silly team composition" to "how does this even work": I now had 3 snipers in my team in addition to the heavy and assault. A basic abduction mission is easy to handle even with an uneven team but when I have to race against time to save civilians of disarm a bomb and three of my squad members can't move and shoot/overwatch at a low level is a big problem. Sure, I could have picked other rookies and started to level them up but once you play few missions and every perk you gain when leveling up is of great importance, you rather choose the ones you have as high level as possible to ensure that a TPK doesn't happen. Especially since the panic levels increase fast in the first hours of the game.2. Me see evil; me no shoot evil. I have come to learn that unless you have a 100% chance to hit a target, you will more than likely miss. It doesn't matter if the percentage is at 90; out of 10 shots with 90% probability to hit the target, your soldiers will hit maybe, just maybe, half of them. Even if the target is standing in an adjacent square. And what is absolutely baffling to me is that your soldier can stand only one square away from the enemy unit that is standing in the open and your soldier's hit percentage is only 65.I witnessed a case where 4 of my soldiers were surrounding a Muton (the big green hulk) that was hiding behind a one square sized cover (an alien artefact that needed to be salvaged so no rocket launchers). The soldiers were positioned so that only one of them wasn't flanking the enemy unit aka the cover was between them. The other three soldiers were one square away from it, flanking from the sides and behind with no cover )this would mean a red shield if it was a player controlled soldier). It took all four of them to bring down the Muton that had already lost half of its HP. Two of my soldiers, the one not flanking and one of the flanking soldiers missed and the rest to managed to hit and kill the Muton. Now, if this was to happen the other way around, 4 enemy units surrounding one of the soldiers, the soldier would have been killed instantly, no misses. It is as if the aliens have a naturally better chance at every shot they take, no matter how good my soldiers' gear is.Also, when an alien like a sectoid is half the map away from my soldier (that would have maybe 10-15% chance to hit the sectoid if it was the soldier's turn) and the sectoid not only hits my soldier who is behind a cover and deals critical damage, I call BS. It seems that when the distance grows, the likelyhood for my soldiers to hit the target diminishes, fairly quickly I might add (which in itself is logical). However, it seems that no matter how far the enemies are, they are more than likely to hit you, no matter the elevation difference. Also the "higher elevation boost" for soldiers, especially snipers is ridiculous. I have only once seen it give any advantage and that was when the sniper was only few squares away from the enemy unit that wasn't behind cover and even then with the S.C.O.P.E. the hit probability didn't rise to more than 80%.3. Bullet trajectory. A minor but most irritating and definitely a design flaw in the game is the way bullets, plasma, lasers and whatnot fly when someone is shot. If the game calculates the hit/miss before the actual animation is shown, it would be nice to not see bullets or other death rays to hit a target and then see "Missed" in the notification. I mean, how hard is it to program the animations to "miss" when the statistics state that the shot missed the target? It is really confusing to see my soldier take hit from a volley of plasma and then get "Missed" when I was already mentally prepared to see the soldier die. It is just bad design.4. Statistical cover and visual cover. Sometimes it seems that no matter how well in cover you are, you get hit. I don't fully know how the cover works, perhaps full cover is nothing more than "a crit denier": you take hit but don't get hit with a crit, similar to "hunker down". Sometimes the bullets and whatnot seem to hit the environment, sometimes they travel straight through it and hit the target. It is rather difficult to place a sniper in a good position to overwatch when you can't tell for certain if a wall is just there for level design purpose or if it is actually a wall/cover. One time my sniper was in a place I never would have expected for him to be able to shoot anybody but surely enough he just calmly stood up and shot an enemy unit through a couple square thick spaceship wall.5. No free aim. This might seem a pointless nitpick but I think that removing the possibility to shoot other than just visible aliens is a silly thing. The game has destructible environments, the rocket launchers and grenades have free aim and there are features in the maps that can become environmental hazards for both the XCOM and the aliens.6. Overwatch works some of the time. The idea of overwatch is important if one wants to survive the missions and more than once it has saved my squad. However, I find it ridiculous that every soldier shoots at the same time if a target comes into their field of view. Once I had 3 soldiers, 2 assaults and a sniper take a shot at a single target: the assault with a plasma rifle slaughtered the target, the second assault and sniper therefore shot at nothing remarking "I've missed the target" which is funny since the target was already rendered into atoms. Oh, and most times, if the target isn't less than 5 squares from the soldiers, they are more than likely to miss, even if the target is in the open.7. Enemy movement on my turn. How this feature got through the QA is beyond me. How can you make a turn-based strategy game when the enemy units always get a freebie when you spot them? Wouldn't it be more logical that they move around the map even when you have not yet spotted them instead of creeping in one spot and then scattering around like cockroaches when you finally spot them? I find it immensely bad design that they can move to a cover and then take a full turn after the player has completed their turn. Many more times than I want to remember, I have spent my actions covering my units while assuming the enemy coming from the darkness only to spot them with my last soldier and see them reposition themselves flanking me and then have a turn to TPK my team.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown and its addons are de facto re-issue the game UFO Defence game 1993 year edition. Established Firaxis Games and published by 2K new game turned out pretty not bad. The basic details and the scenario were simply transferred from the 1993 year game: as the war with the aliens, turn-based tactics, tactical role-playing elements.   The mission of the player is protection the planet from alien attacks, their operations on the ground and in the air. For ground operations under player control will be a special detachment. It is replenished by hiring for the money, so long as you have money and you will have recruits. But a large number of detachment on base  senselessly because the operation can only use a limited number of soldiers 5 in the original game; 6 in addon Enemy Within. After successful operations soldiers who took part in the operation may be promoted in rank then become available new options and opportunities. The game has 4 classes of soldiers, -heavy infantry, support, assault, sniper and unique class - psionic - a soldier who has psionic abilities. The soldiers of different classes differently armed and have different skills. What classes to use depends on the player and his chosen tactics. Battle goes step by step: the player and the enemy take turns. During the battle each fighter can perform two actions (move / open fire / reload weapon / etc.). To win, the player has to fulfill the mission goal (to clean the area from aliens, rescue civilians or hostage). Enemy are various forms of aliens - their number, skills and capacity increases according to the game walkthrough. To destroy alien aircraft,  XCOM need to buy aircrafts, but unlike the recruits its construction takes time.   The player has a secret base. In a bunker is a research center, engineering department, a command post, a hangar for XCOM aviation, satellite control center, barracks, etc. The player decides which conduct research, what structures build, what type of equipment use for soldiers who will took part in operation. Project XCOM financed by 16 countries. Due to aliens attack, if XCOM ignore countries request of help, country can leave project. If 8 countries leave project - player lose.   Since the game is turn-based tactics not possible not to pay attention to the entourage of battles in XCOM. The battles with aliens take place throughout the planet and the question remains, why the location is almost indistinguishable from one another. The same cars, houses, people in Beijing, in London, in Cairo, in Lagos. This is pathetic, seems what game was created not a company with over 100 man crew, but several people who raised money on kickstarter.   Despite some disadvantages, the game still came worthy sequel to the original game of 1993.    7/10

												This game like to play with your emotions, you have a favourite character or characters, you root for them and hope they will go the distance and win out right and save the world form the alien invasion, you let yourself believe that it’s going to happen and it seems like its going to happen, your so close to being the hero and then out of nowhere, it happens, it all seemed like a blurr, it happened so fast Out of nowhere your favourite character is horribly murdered right in front of your helpless eyes, you cry and ask yourself what you could have done different, but it doesn’t matter it won’t bring them back, then finally when the initial shock of what just happened has passed, you open your heart again to new characters, you learn to love again, before it happens all over again, again and again like a vicious never ending cycle, until you find yourself crying under your bed 11/10 would defiantly cry again under my bed again

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
I'm supposed to be getting my sleep schedule back to normal but this one game keeps kicking my♥♥♥♥♥XCOM delivers an interesting advanced game of chess, with your peices being the soldiers you raised from the ground up, with your opponent being the invading aliens. There are many factors that can determine the battle's outcome, such as what gear you've researched, what buildings you have produced, how you combat the aliens such as ducking behind cover, how accurate your soldiers are, how much willpower they have from previous battles and more. This game gives you many hours of packed fun, from just playing the standalone game (There is DLC but I have not played it yet). There are some nice RPG elements in this game as well, seeing that you can name, customize, nickname, and give your troops a personality and look that suits you. Oftentimes you may possibly find yourself 'save-scumming' from having many of your troops die or an error you felt was a grave mistake, though not encouraged you just simply can't help it.You also have the freedom of choice in this game, which adds to the roleplay, since you are the "Commander" of XCOM, you have the ability to make many MANY choices that determine the organization's and the planet's outcome. Not all choices are created equal, some may be hard, but it's all about instinct.In a nutshell this is one hell of a game, I love it, and I don't think I can get much sleep for the next few weeks. Help.- RIP 'Cookie', you were a great medic, a damn good one.

number of helpful: 20 of 24 people (83%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												This is a fantastic strategy game with a couple minor flaws. Firstly, let me say that I love XCOM. I owned the original UFO Defense for PC and PlayStation, Terror from the Deep, and Apocalypse. I played many reboots including Afterlight and some community made versions as well. This game comes the closest to remaking the original and adds a few nice elements in its own right.Ill list off the bad first. This game is RNG hell! Try this scenario. You’re down to your last move and have a half dead Muton waiting around the corner. You wisely saved your crit happy, shotgun toting, assault run and gun soldier. You confidently streak towards your adversary with only a slight degree of separation as you stop moving. You check your aim, breathe a sigh of relief at the 98% hit chance. You fire away only to find your Muton buddy laughing furiously as you miss. How did I miss at point blank distance with a shotgun!? Next turn my emboldened Muton friend slaughters my cross eyed soldier with one quick shot to the face. This in turn causes a nearby rookie to freak out and panic. He begins shooting my colonel in the back causing her to bleed out. From this point on in your life, 99% will never be a sure thing again. Now here is the good. Excellent challenge. This game forces you to think ahead and plan accordingly. Do you think you mastered the game? Try classic or impossible difficulty with ironman enabled. And if that’s not enough try out the long war mod. Both tactical and base management layers offer enough strategy and replayability to keep anyone that likes strategy games entertained for at least two playthroughs. Now add all the alien lore discovered by engaging new aliens and base side research and development, and you have one engrossing experience.Graphics and sound are fantastic. The game presents in an isometric top down orientation for the tactical aspect. In between turns you can sometimes hear the ominous movements of moving aliens or mortified screams from unsuspecting civilians. Environments are very detailed and there are enough unique maps to not see any repeats on a single play-through. Music is great, but still doesn’t beat the PlayStation soundtrack in my humble opinion. I highly recommend that any person wanting to experience a great turn based strategy game pick up Enemy Unknown and at least the expansion Enemy Within. Despite the RNG issues, the game is a solid, well thought out attempt to make XCOM relevant again. Fraxis did this game some justice for both stalwart XCOM veterans and new players alike. XCOM 2 has already exceeded my expectations as well. I however think this game belongs in anyone’s collection.

But if you want to see a fairly faithful recreation of the original XCOM series in three dimensions it is certainly worth a look; or even if you never played the original XCOM games then this is an excellent turn based, squad level combat simulator with a fairly comprehensive turn based RTS system housing that.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Firaxis has made an absolutely wonderful modernization of a classic strategy game. The deep and evolving gameplay is among the best I've experienced in a game like this, along with the fact that everything feels extremely polished and crafted with a a great deal of love for both the genre and the original game.XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a worthy tribute to its progenitor and hopefully the start of something brand new for players who've been dying to get a good squad-based strategy game that lets them not only think, but feel as well.To say that XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a phenomenal remake would be selling Firaxis' monumental accomplishment short. The developer hasn't just managed to capture the spirit of the original; they've also tweaked, trimmed, and innovated enough to deliver the freshest, most engaging strategy game in recent memory, if not ever.Even if you don't like strategy games, if you love action games and have an open enough mind to try out something a bit slower-paced, you will be rewarded with one of the most thrilling, thought-provoking, and heart-pounding games of 2012.Amazing tactical complexity, satisfying strategic depth; slightly dodgy ending, but your own stories are more important anyway. A modern classic.If you played the original, then this is a no brainer purchase; if you haven't, then you are in for a lot of gameplay hours that will both challenge and enthrall you.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												This remake of the 1993 X-COM: UFO Defense, an obtuse and painful but ultimately satisfying game, attempts to bring UFO Defense into the 21st century while also improving on the original game's intentions. Sadly, (or happily depending on your faith in such an endeavor) all of these changes present a double-edged sword. For every system Enemy Unknown improves - and they are solid improvements - something of the freedom or atmosphere of the original is lost. Some sacrifices are small but expected, such as the way you've built your base not having an effect on base invasions (a feature that itself was only added to the remake with the Enemy Within expansion). Others are a bit more surprising, such as the total change in atmosphere brought about by taking the original troop limit of 14 down to the much smaller squad of 6. Limiting the number of soldiers on the field at a time means that each individual is more valuable and stands out more readily which is also bolstered by an increased level of customization. I found myself even more attached to my Enemy Unknown soldiers than my UFO Defense regulars and as that attachment was one of the biggest joys of the original, it's hard not to consider that a successful change. However, with only 6 soldiers gaining battle experience at a time, any casualty is devastating, meaning you can no longer afford to send a group of bright-eyed red shirted rookies into a situation as you, an experienced commander, know it is unlikely they will survive. So that sense of constant Pyrrhic victories, of losing three men to breach a downed UFO and eliminate the final alien, are lost to gain a more beloved solider with a richer player-made story. This difference encapsulates the transition between the two games. While UFO Defense focused on the greater conflict, with individual soldiers representing little more than a resource, Enemy Unknown focuses on those called to fight and how this conflict affects them. The overarching narrative hasn't changed much, but the change in perspective makes for a unique, fresh experience.  That being said, Enemy Unknown can stand (and fall) on its own as well. The terror of a completely unknown threat and the slow unveiling of what it is you're fighting and why it's fighting you is satisfying without depending on the crutch of name dropping the original's enemies. The unlikelihood of any one shot being 100% certain in accuracy or damage forces the player to come up with backup plans and to deal with the unexpected, keeping the player on his or her toes. Sometimes, however, the unexpected comes not from an intended monkey wrench, but from an obtuseness in the game's mechanics. After completing two full games on two different difficulties, I still have a very poor idea of what a soldier will or will not be able to see and where. This disastrous flaw could have easily been corrected if I had the option to see from the soldier's point of view. Graphical glitches are also relatively common leading to a rushed and unfinished feel which is only compounded by the expansion, Enemy Within. Meld - a resource introduced in the expansion to fuel the new gene modifying and MEC trooper initiatives - both adds a new time element to missions and sticks out as completely artificial. Again this issue seems like it could be simply resolved with a bit more story relevance and/or more logical placements. The 'abduction' mission type seems equally artificial in that they always occur in threes, leaving the commander to choose only one site to defend while leaving the others to their fate and causing panic across those continents. The player is left with no solution to this 'one step forward two steps back' situation nor is there any explanation for why that's so. Which leads me to my biggest complaint about Enemy Unknown: The whole experience feels like it's on rails. Not only doesn't the alien invasion operate on its own independent timescale (a theme which is repeated with the aliens I meet in the field), but it doesn't even seem like anything I as the player do has an affect on how the invasion plays out, past the basic win-lose proposition. Due to this design direction, some story elements can't reach a satisfying conclusion. For instance, the comparison between the alien's situation and XCOM's current trajectory never pays off. The aliens seem to have undergone some great cruelty which is played up from the beginning as being both inhumane and the reason they're so effective, but there is little to no consequence for the XCOM project visiting the same cruelty on its own soldiers to match the enemy's results. This is possibly the most interesting story this setting has to tell and yet it's simply pushed aside once the situation is realized. Stumbling blocks like these keep this exciting, ensnaring game from achieving the greatness it seems to be aiming for. But if you're prepared for a little (or a lot) of that 'what could have been' frustration, it's not the worst way to spend a good chunk of your time.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												More thrilling, terrifying and suspenseful than any turn-based game has the right to be. You'll grow fond of your soldiers- too fond, perhaps, as they're only ever one unlucky move away from a gruesome and unfair-yet-also-annoyingly-fair death.The closest thing to it I believe would be the Heroes of Might and Magic series. It is a game of two halves. About a fifth of the time is spent on the overview screen, the rest in suspenseful battles against lurking aliens.When you're not on the field, you level up your base and choose how to prioritise research and funding. Do you invest in new alien tech? Do you hire new soldiers? Do you launch satellites to keep the world peaceful? It's not as punishing as I would have feared. You're not going to dig yourself into a corner by choosing the 'wrong' decisions. In a way you're simply choosing how you want to fight your foe. There's enough depth and complexity to keep you going until the end of the game and you'll want to play it a second game to see just how different an alternative approach can be.And then there are the battles. You gradually advance your troops across a variety of different battlefields, trying to scout out the enemies whilst remaining safe enough to withstand their retaliation. These adventures span somewhere between 10-30 minutes each and are all gripping and beautifully done affairs. You'll get angry when your characters miss an easy shot, but will squeal with glee when they somehow hit something through 2 walls and a car window. It really is something to behold.The down-sides? The graphics aren't too good and yes, it is annoying when your characters die. It almost makes you want to re-load- BUT DON'T DO THAT! That removes the fun.Xcom is a fantastic game. Get it.

Posted: March 22
												First off, I'd like to say that I was never into strategy games; but only because of the simple reason that I SUCKED AT THEM. The last real turn-based strategy game I played was Heroes 3 Might and Magic, and even that I failed to play above casual level.So when I saw all the reviews about this game, about how unforgiving it was in difficulty, even at a bargain sale price I had to think about my purchase 3-4 times. For once, I played a game with all of my expectations fulfilled. I started the game and looked out the window on a beautiful Saturday morning (4:00 am) and continued playing it until I realized it's been almost 24 hours after.This is probably one of the most PUNISHING, RAGE-INDUCING GAMES, anti-perfectionist games I've ever played. It's so sadistic it will drive you half-insane while playing it. I LOVE IT!!! The difficulty and learning curve even on EASY for casual gamers is not forgiving especially if you are new to the genre like me. I've already given up on 100% this game (Impossible Difficulty + Iron Man mode), but fun enough to keep trying. This game makes Dark Souls Series look easy, and that's something special.This game certainly changed my view on strategy games in general, which I originally avoided.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is an immersive, tactical, turn-based, resource management oriented and unpredictable strategy game. It's bloody amazing.PROS:+ immersion(you care about your soldiers and the missions at hand)+ squad customization(both the looks and the combat skills)+ difficulty+ randomness(the legendary 95% hit chance misses)+ you are in full control of XCOM project's developmentCONS:- little bugs and glitches here and there, they are more of an annoyance than a flawIf you are into tactical combat, finding yourself in scenarios in which odds aren't in your favour and the difficulty is fair- instabuy. There's a lot of replayability value thanks to the Ironman mode(the game saves automatically after each turn, what's done is done) and the Second Wave(after your first playthrough, you can customize some of the gameplay elements, tinker a bit to make the game a more personalized experience); moreover, there's a multiplayer component, so you can test your inner tactician when battling live opponents.Save our planet from the alien invasion and become the saviour of humanity.XCOM needs you."Good luck, Commander."

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown (and its almost necessary expansion pack, Enemy Within) has been out a while now, so I don't feel I need to go into specifics as to how it plays, as it's pretty common knowledge by now. So let me just get this out of the way: I absolutely hate this game.I understand that it's meant to be challenging, to give the player a feeling of impending doom, as if all life on Earth hangs in the balance. I understand, too, that there is a good deal of risk-taking involved with the tactical side of the game; it becomes necessary to run your soldiers through enemy overwatches in the hope that one perfect flanking route can break open a drawn-out, bloody battle. And I understand that death is a part of the game, and it often comes swiftly and cruelly to even the most experienced soldier.But let me tell you, it gets REALLY old. It gets old to see what is supposed to be a world-class soldier whiff a shot on a stationary enemy less than 10 yards away. Conversely, it gets old to see your enemies land across-the-map, one-hit-kill shots on soldiers in full cover, causing a chain-panic and reducing the remainder of your squad to whimpering, blubbering infants. It especially gets old to have to utilize cover and think heavily about your squad's positioning, only to have enemies swoop in right next to you like their lives are meaningless, invalidating all that critical thinking you've done about where to place your troops, and land a flanking kill shot from a foot away. Anyone who has played this game knows all about missing 90+% shots that get your squad killed. Or having to gun down one of your favorite troopers that you've had since the start of the game because some jackass Sectoid mind-controlled him. Or getting jumped by Chryssalids on turn 1 of a terror mission - I could go on.Ironically, the sense of dread and despair that the designers intended to bake into XCOM works a bit too well - when I finish a mission I don't feel accomplished or rewarded, I'm just glad that it's over. May I ask, is that good game design? To just breathe a sigh of relief that nothing major happened to make me want to rage-quit? To me, it isn't good game design: it's frustrating and unfulfilling.Let me at least say that for the most part, I like a lot of aspects of the game: the chunky action-figure character design, the atmospheric music, the ant-farm strategic view, the system of progression and unlocks that allow you to improve your base and squad with seized alien technology. I even like the genre that this game falls into as well, so I'm not deliberately trying to find fault with what is, to me, a good formula for a fun game. But it isn't fun. I've yet to get more than 15-20 hours into a single campaign before throwing in the towel in complete disgust. I periodically come back to the game to see if the medicine is as bitter as I remember, which is why I finally feel like I need to put my feelings into words, so I can let this game rest. Even the vaunted Long War mod does little to fix what is ultimately busted game design. If you are a glutton for punishment, this game might be for you. As for me, I'm putting this one back on the shelf for good.EDIT: If you bothered to read this to the end and you still somehow find this review unhelpful, leave me a comment stating why. I realize that I'm dumping on a lot of peoples' favorite game here but my "Not Recommended" rating was not given without a lot of thought and many honest attempts to give the game a chance (I would hope that much is obvious with just over 100 hours on the logs). Your choosing to find the review helpful or not should reflect on the quality of the review, not on your opinion of the game. Thanks.

Posted: March 20
												Enemy Unknown is a good turn based strategy game that has great base management which is in my opinion the highlight of the game. Trying to keep the panic level down for all of these countries you are trying to protect is a very deep and fascinating mechanic because there are so many factors that go into it like the satellite coverage, intercepting ufo’s, having to choose what country to help out while ignoring another because there is not enough time for both etc. Customizing the loadout of your soldiers, choosing which class you want in the field and what upgrades you want for them is very compelling as well as researching and building new equipment for the soldiers and upgrading your base etc. The turn based gameplay itself is well done as well. This is another one of those type of games where I enjoy playing in the background while listening to podcasts, videos and music because I can’t see myself being enthralled and captivated with this kind of gameplay for a long period of time because this genre is not really my thing but I wanted to give this game a shot and I’m glad that I did. 8/10 (Great)

content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												Col. O'Brien, Codename "Gold Eyes", Female, Sniper.Veteran of the XCom Project, one of the first set of XCom Soldiers.Started impressively along with her buddy "Nuke", Male, Heavy.Became the most popular and most skilled soldier in the whole project.On one mission, she lost one of her longest friends, codename "Burst", Female, Assault.Psionic Labs saw her psionic potential and trained her.Became a Gold-Eyed, Flesh-Piercing, Brain-Controlling, and Loving soldier.She remained a wonderful person inside and out despite her abilities.When the day of the Final Battle finally came, the best XCom soldiers were gathered.They fought bravely and ferociously throughout the battle.Then there came the final room.With "Gold Eyes" in the middle of the entrance.And the strongest Psionic being in the Alien army on the other side of the room.Staring at each other, eye-to-eye, brain-to-brain.She remembered everything that the aliens have done to her friends and to all fellow humans.She scoped like she's never scoped before.Aimed straight at the head, and fired. Twice.At the defeat of the great Alien army, the ship was turning into a black hole.Gold Eyes realized that she could save the planet and her friends along with it.So she used her Psionic abilities to push her friends away back to the Skyranger and back to the base.Drove the Alien Mothership upwards away from Earth.And then... Boom.It's a story made popular among books after the Alien invasion ended. "Nuke" and the others spread it proudly while remembering the heroic acts of their old friend.In loving memory of Col. O'Brien, Fearless Soldier, Piercing Sniper, Mind-Controlling Psionic Warrior, Honest and Kind Friend, A True Hero, and a wonderful human being.Even as a player, I was devastated by this event. I could never write enough of my experience in my review, I felt the characters in every mission they went through, as if they were actually talking to each other. And I was truly commanding them and having conversations during missions. Made a connection that was broken at the end. But, it was totally worth it.10/10 - An experience that every IMMERSIVE gamer MUST HAVE.

number of helpful: 10 of 10 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												Cons:- Some 'random number generator' frustrations because of the way 'chance to hit' plays a big role in the game.  At 75% chance to hit, you can count on missing multiple times every couple of battles, which usually results in a teammate dying.  (And even though the game is kind of designed to let characters die now and again, it's actually such a big penalty that you do NOT want it to happen).  Even at max, 95% chance to hit, you'll get the occasional 2 or 3 in-a-row miss that drives you crazy.  Save often so you can quit and reload when someone dies.- It's possible to ruin the game for yourself early on through the base management (the Sim City-ish bit).  I can't remember what it was, exactly, but one thing you can invest in results in the aliens levelling up.  Invest too much too early, and you'll be facing deadly aliens while you're still at low levels with no cash.  At that point it is literally impossible to win.  Definitely look up a couple of FAQs before you start, so you can avoid this.Pros:- Absolutely, utterly, everything else.  - The storyline is brilliant.  Intrigue, conspiracy, side-stories that tie in well with the main story, and gameplay and character and facility development that is heavily tied into the storyline. - I was really surprised that the sci-fi alien attack setting was really well done.  Enough human development and intrigue focus that it didn't feel overly 'Star Trek-ky' or anything.- Base and facility development isn't my kind of thing, but it was actually quite enjoyable in this case - more about levelling up aspects of your team than really micro managing everything Sim City style.  There was one thing related to how you level things up to avoid (see above), but otherwise it seemed secondary to the actual missions and battles.- A good amount of variety amongst the types of soldiers you can get, with such different abilities that you really utilise them in different ways.  This really plays up the strategy aspect, as you decide which combinations of soldier types to use each battle.- Having soldiers get injured, so they can't join missions for a while, is a great idea.  It forces you to play with combinations you might avoid otherwise, which adds extra variety and depth to the game.- The abilities... and then the super duper awesome abilities that you won't believe you get later!  (Hint: If you read any FAQs, don't trust them when they say you need to focus on one set of the two super sets of options that come available.  You can afford to invest in both, and it's MUCH more fun to have both).- Quite a good range of mission types and alien types keep the variety going.- Other stuff that I can't remember or can't tell you for spoiler reasons.The cons are pretty big, but you can avoid one if you read up on it a little and reduce the other by getting into regular saving habits.  I did both, and I honestly think XCOM is the best game I've played in years and years.  There are some other great games (like Divinity: Original Sin) that come close, but this edged them out because... it is simply THAT cool.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Never having played the original XCOMs, I got my newbie butt handed to me more than once during my playthrough of this, and it was great fun even when I kept losing to my own silly mistakes.The game is fairly straightforward and simple to begin with and naturally dives into more difficult territory later on. I played it without the expansion my first time through, not to get overwhelmed with research, engineering, and options. And for me that was definitely the best thing to do, because the base game has droves of stuff in it to keep you invested.The hours flew by like so many overconfident Interceptors and pregnant Skyrangers birthing my soon-to-be-sorry-or-promoted Alien Death Squads of dashing, grenade-tossing, laser-wielding soldiers onto the battlefield, again and again. Good times.If you have a hard time grasping WHY a certain action is better than another, watch the brilliant Youtube videos of Beaglerush playing it on Ironman Impossible. You will still mess up at times, but just watching a few minutes of those videos took the game from being "pretty cool" to being "an absolute joy to play and finish". I'm looking forward to crush (and being crushed by) my alien friends in Enemy Within (and, heaven forbid, The Long War mod).So, what are you waiting for? Earth needs you, soldier, get ready to flan-...I said flank! Not you, the assault guy, not the...Oh dear, not more enem- Okay, he's gone, rookies are cheap so I don't care, now what do I have left to work wit- ANOTHER ONE!? Okay, I'm getting at least one dude back to my base...*Teammate panics, shoots second to last guy, then gets shot by an alien himself*Okay, what did we learn from this? One more try, then. Just one more. You got this.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												Probably one of the best, if not THE best turn-based tactics games out there. Before I start with the good, I think I should look at the bad.First thing that comes to my mind for what's bad about this game is its value for money. The Xbox 360 and Playstation 3 have what's essentially a Game of the Year edition (dubbed XCom Enemy Within: Commander Edition) which comes with the base game, the Elite Soldier cosmetics, the Slingshot Pack, and Enemy Within, all for an MSRP of how much you'd pay for the base game on Steam. Because of this, you're better off waiting until March 4 for the Complete Edition (Essentially the Commander Edition for PC)Another issue i have with this game is that it does not illustrate your soldiers' line of sight. More often than not, I found myself moving a soldier to a piece of cover where I would think has a good shot at an alien, though I end up wasting his or her turn due to a lack of line of sight. This is even more of a nuisance for players who enjoy using Snipers with the early-game Squadsight ability.And now for the good: While it's a difficult game in its own right, it certainly has enough content for several playthroughs. While you may get intimidated by the fact that you're often outgunned, you'll learn to get used to the combat. However, shooting aliens is only half of the game.The other half of the game consists of the XCOM Headquarters, where you will need to research new technologies, arm both your soldiers and aircraft, shoot down UFOs, and manage global panic. Oh, and because you'll find yourself dealing with simultaneous abduction events, you'll find yourself having more problems with global panic than the actual combat, but this doesn't necessarily make the game unfair, as the resources to maintain panic are reasonably accessible.The final verdict: GET THIS GAME

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												It has been a long time but Xcom is back. Still a third person strategy game. Compared to the original there is a lot less to manage at your xcom base and mission preperation. Feeling a bit dumbed down but much easier for new players. I welcome the change but could of had a bit more options at the xcom base. Character customization is nice but could of had some more options. Combat and gameplay is extremely crisp and fun. If you are not in cover and flanking correctly you are getting your♥♥♥♥♥toasted. Enemy designs are spot on sounds and wepons sound energized! This xcom offers difficulty modes which further help new players to the series get accustomed and vets get their♥♥♥♥♥♥wet with unforgiving difficult. 2K continues to uphold excellent 50's themed games and makes me wish I lived back in that time period spot on clothing and areas. There is a decent amount of gameplay here but you are punished for taking your time getting some requirements for other missions and taking every side mission for extra xp and items. Feeling like you are on a timer the whole time you will feel rushed half way through the game ruining the experience. There are very little cutscenes though the ones that are there are perfectly fine. I will say this is the worst ending to a modern gen game I have ever witnessed. After everything me and my crew went through for a 10 second ending. YES A 10 SECOND ENDING. I felt slapped in the face. Makes Mass Effect 3 forgivable. In the end Xcom enemy unknown leaves you wanting more in every area of the game. A decent start to bring the franchise back but they need to do a lot of work to the next game to restore its place among the best strategy gamesFinal Score 7.25/10

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
Summary“That's XCOM, baby!”ReviewXCOM is a game that tests your understanding of probabilities.  If you think it should be impossible to miss three 75% chance shots in a row, or that a 95% chance is a guaranteed hit, then you're going to have a bad time.  This is a game that will punish you for your mistakes, mercilessly grind your successes under its heel, and basically conspire to beat you at every turn, leading to a tense, addictive experience that will knock you down and keep you coming back for more.  It works because while the game is brutal, it's fair, which has inspired fans of the series to coin the phrase, “That's XCOM, baby!”The premise is this: the earth has been invaded by extraterrestrials, and in keeping with the trope, they are aggressive and more technologically advanced than us mere humans.  The XCOM project is an international organization, and you, as its commander, are given the unenviable task of protecting earth from the hostile invaders.  Failure to diligently carry out this objective will result in member nations panicking and pulling funding, which means fewer resources at your disposal and eventually defeat if enough nations leave you high and dry.Gameplay happens in two phases: base management and missions.  Your base is depicted in a really cool cutaway view, showing your facilities deep underground.  While it's not the most functional presentation, the attention to detail is amazing, and you can zoom right in close and see what your personnel are up to.  It's purely cosmetic because all of the real work happens in menus, but it's still fun.During the base management phase, you can visit the “Situation Room” to get an overview of how close member nations are to panicking, assign research and construction tasks to your science and engineering staff, maintain your fleet of interceptor aircraft and satellites, hire new recruits, customize and train your soldiers, and expand your facilities.  It's a balancing act because you have limited resources, and each task takes a period of time to complete, so it's important to prioritize your most critical tasks first.Once you've organized everything to your satisfaction, you head to Mission Control and click “Scan For Activity” which advances time, completing your various projects and discovering alien activity around the globe.  Sometimes there will be multiple simultaneous attacks, but since you can only respond to one of them, you again have to balance various considerations, such as the expected difficulty of the mission, what sort of rewards you will receive upon successful completion, and how close each nation is to bailing on you.  This is when the real fun begins as you dispatch your troops to deal with the alien menace.Before launching a mission, you have one last chance to fine-tune your roster of soldiers (initially four, but you can eventually have up to six) and their equipment, and then it's time to head out to the field.  Missions take place in a three-quarter perspective turn-based arena with you and the aliens alternating turns, and each unit gets two actions per turn (however, using a weapon will end that soldier's turn even if it's their first action).  This is a perfect realization of Firaxis' “less is more” game design philosophy, because each action you take carries so much weight, and it keeps the pace of battle fast and exciting.  Some people criticize this portion of the game, saying that it's too easy to leapfrog your soldiers from cover to cover, putting them in “Overwatch” which gives them a free shot if the enemy moves into their line of fire, and simply waiting for the aliens to come to you, but this isn't necessarily the best or most effective strategy.  Sometimes you need to be more aggressive, especially during abduction missions where you have to kill the aliens faster than they can kill innocent civilians; then there are the time-limited “meld” canisters you'll want to collect which appear as part of the Enemy Within expansion (which I strongly recommend).  Furthermore, “Overwatch” comes with a to-hit penalty, so there's no guarantee you'll take down the enemy anyway, and even with your most carefully laid plans, things can fall apart in spectacular ways, leading to your soldiers being injured – meaning they'll be out of action until they've healed – or, worse, killed.  It's amazing just how quickly the tables can turn, so it's always important to stay on your toes because sometimes even a single mistake can cost you the mission.As your soldiers participate in – or perhaps I should say survive – missions, they gain experience and are randomly given a specialty such as sniper, support, heavy, and so on.  As they continue their careers, you can choose from a variety of special abilities like smoke grenades to make it harder for your enemies to draw a bead on your troops, or allowing your sniper to target any enemies within another soldier's line of sight.  You can even customize your troopers' appearance, nationality, the color of their uniforms, what sort of head gear they wear from full battle helmets to stylish fedoras, and even give them personable nicknames.  All of this is ultimately a cruel tease, however, because it seems like just as you start to become attached to your individualized soldiers, they get brutally killed in a hail of gunfire and their names enshrined on the Memorial Wall where you can revisit your depressing failures whenever you want.Ultimately, XCOM is a vicious slog to your own inevitable defeat at the hands of a superior foe – there's a reason the sequel takes it as a given that the humans lost the war – yet despite it all, I love this game.  As I said earlier, it's brutal but fair.  Yes, there are times you're at the mercy of the “random number generator” gods, but the majority of the time, if you lose, it's your fault.  The reason people think the game cheats is because they remember their losses, like that time they missed two 95% chance shots in a row (and, yes, that is statistically possible), but they forget their wins, like the time they took a desperate gamble on a 40% shot and got a lucky critical.  That's XCOM, baby!The presentation is excellent with attractive, detailed visuals and solid sound design.  I especially like the “action cam” that is occasionally triggered during missions and gives you a ground-level view of one of your soldiers taking out an alien (or alternatively, an alien taking out one of your soldiers), or showing one of your troopers kicking down a door or vaulting over a counter.  It's a nice touch and happens infrequently enough not to wear out its welcome.  On the Linux side, Feral once again has done an excellent job giving us Linux fans another top-notch game.I would also strongly recommend buying the Enemy Within expansion.  This is a proper, old school expansion pack rather than a soft sequel in that the new features are seamlessly incorporated into the base game.  You get access to more soldier upgrades, more maps, more missions, more enemies – basically a more complete and fleshed out XCOM experience.Good luck, Commander.

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2013
												Remake of one of the best games ever made!Xcom is an isometric 3D  strategy game with turn-based combat. It has streamlined or removed some aspects of the original game, for better or worse. To me the changes are mostly all positive. Game still feels familiar enough to appeal to many of the veterans. Xcom gameplay consists of two parts, the tactical combat on the field and little bit of base management. In base management you get limited options to build laboratories, workshops, power generators, satellite uplinks etc. with their different benefits. You can purchase different kind of perks with games currency, you can research new tech, manufacture new items and gear in engineering and sell items you acquire on missions on black market. The combat itself is really fun, you have different classes of soldiers and you can level them up by completing missions and shooting up aliens. With levels (promotions) you can choose one of two special abilities depending on your soldiers class. Different classes are sniper, support, assault and heavy. There is a multiplayer option but it's a bit lacking. You can only play 1vs1 matches with your custom made squads. Somekind of co-op would be nice. Firaxis games really is the master of turn-based strategy with Xcom and Civilization. I recommend everyone to get the expansion pack Enemy Within, even for the first playthrough. Since it doesn't add new campaign but implements new storyline in the orginal games campaign. It also comes with new tech and some new enemies. Another recommendation would be playing with Iron man mode on, when every death of your squad is permanent. Since then game autosaves and you cant save manually. It really adds some great tension to the game.An amazing reimagining of a classic that works really well either on keyboard and mouse or a gamepad![Score: 95]

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												As turn based strategy games go, XCOM is a fun one. Aliens have invaded, and it is up to your secret military organisation to kick them off this rock. And you do that with a combination of clever tactics, superior firepower, autopsy reports, and interrogations.As you capture and torture more alien visitors, and as you study more of their tech, you can seriously upgrade Earth's defenses. For example, at the start of the invasion, you have fighter jets, with basic missiles. Later on, your pilots are flying the Firestorm, highly advanced fighter ship which is more or less alien in origin, and can be equipped with such awesome firepower as the plasma cannon, or the fusion lance.Your weapons and armour similarly are upgraded as you progress through the research tree, starting with basic weapons as you might find these days, upgrading to lasers, and then plasma weapons.So, what are you waiting for? Go kick some alien butt.

												I have mixed feeling about XCOM. As a gamer who played games in early 90s allready and played the first XCOMs when those were brand new. After i played Enemy Unknown i had a feeling that this isnt what i expected.I bought XCOM long time ago and i must say that i found the price of the DLC outrageous later, especially because it actually added what i expected to be in the base game. Since this experience i dont buy brand new games until they have expansions out and they have GOTY or complete packs available. I miss the 90s and early 2000s when internet not existed or was used only by the minority of the population, because game DEVelopers had only one chance to release their product so they released complete products. Nowadays none of the AAA games complete, if i play any of them i have empty feelings, i feel that something is missing, in sequels i have a feeling that "omg this was in previous version, why not in this" ofc those coming with DLCs but this feeling ruins my entertainment.In this case i missed that aliens dont invade my base and a few other things, dont missunderstand that, the game was ok, but when my first playthrough ended, i was like: "ok, that was it? hmmmm am i rushed through or really that was it?"Do i recommend the base game? yes, if you not played any original XCOM game, but if you dont own the game i suggest the complete pack with DLC (i still find it outrageous that complete pack cheaper than buying the DLC for those who bought the game before, i promised, because of this, that ill never buy DLC but suddenly i got it as gift).Do i recommend the game with DLC? yes, its awesome, no emptyness feelings, the game got what should have been at release, this what we should have gotten for the price of an AAA game.The game is pretty hard and challenging, i liked it, need to plan every movement of your units, i felt some classes are useless, i actually preferred only support and snipers for my crew because supports can explore area and avoid getting hit with ligthning reflexes while exploring and snipers can eliminate enemies from long and safe distance.Base Game: 3/10 for me at least, its my opinion.Game with DLC: 10/10 original XCOM feeling, i wasnt able to stop while i played.I encountered still a few BUG in the game but usually quiting game and reloading fixed those, so nothing serious.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												This game really is not anywhere near as good as people think it is. I would promise you that at least 90% of the people who have praised this game have not actually played it in a true Ironman and Classic playthrough. And I want to make two poiints here: Why the game fails as a game, and why it fails as an XCOM game.Why it isnt an XCOM game:This game is simple, and by that I mean REALLY simple. Xcom enemy Unkown plays like a really old board game(think Monopoly/Risk), the ruleset is extremely simplistic and leave such a large gab to chance that almost all decisions you make are irelevant.Most people(even those who dislike this game) do not seem to understand this as they complain about 'bugs' that cause shooting through walls, floors, and other things. If you actually play this game and look at the ruleset applied it becomes clear that those were never bugs or oversights, this is simply how this game works. 'Props/Cover/objects/ground' never exists in this game, it all applies a very Warhamer/LOTR/40k logic, but simplified: If you have line of sight on an enemy you can shoot at it, only you and the object matter, the hit calculation is PURELY created by the different effects on a unit.(aka, if he is in cover you get -40% on the hit chance. What is the cover and how is it actually position and what about the 5 other things obscuring the view? Like I said, board game logic.As such the shooting through a wall was never a bug, it simply is that the ruleset has no consideration for anything but the 3 or so objects used in the calculation.(That is why there is no free shooting, 'bullets' do not exist, that is why explosions always do the same damage, through walls or not through walls. That is why all cover works in a very binary state of existing or not existing.)Why am I rambling on this? The people who played the old Xcoms and say this has the spirit of xcom are utterly wrong, Xcom (as silly as it sometimes was) was in a way  a simulation. It tried to "simulate" squad combat, based on a ruleset that was as 'reaslitic' as would be possible while being fun. If you looked at something and thought about how it would work based on your reasoning then most of the time  it would react the way you expected it to. Bullets would travel, if they missed or were shot at a bad angle they would travel in an angle away from where it meant to go, if the bullet hit an object it would damage or destroy the object, an explosion would damage objects, if the bullet can travel the path and is shot in the correct angle it WILL travel the path. Expectations were formed on your understanding of how things would interact, not simply by the very (often binnary) ruleset given to you.This game has nothing to do with XCOM besides the skin and that both are a Turned based strategy, their fundemantal game design is different and as such it fails to be an XCOM game.Why is it a bad game even on its own terms?As said, it plays like a board game would, which can be fine, I like board games...It plays like a bad board game.A board game will give the player a defined set of rules the player has to adapt to in order to overcome a certain problem. Almost any board game ever will be forced to fall back to the concept of luck as certainty on everything will become boring.But the job of any good game is to give the player a multitude of meaningful obtions for allow him to minize the randomness of the dicethrow to such a level that he can confidently predict the outcome based on the rulest the game uses.This game fails to do that across the board.Why? Because just about every single thing you can do has simply has far too little actual impact on the game. Cover can either lower your chance to be hit by 20%, or 40%. Which might not sound like so little but considering that the whole game is cenetered around the concept of cover and by extension of it flanking, it means that flanking is not a nessesary move, cover simply isnt reliable as it is. Compared to other such games(Warhamer/LOTR/40k) where a wall would be a wall and it would give you 100% cover, and flanking it would give you 100% more of a chance to hit.(small cover would amount to something akin to 50%)Add to it that just about every unit in this game has 60 to 75% aim, and the fact that the 20% and 40% is a simple reduction(not a multiplcation or such, simply: 75% is your aim, -40% is cover, 35% chance to hit. And 1 hit mostlikely means dead) and you quickly find out that hiding behind a wall has very little actual power, at which point it becomes clear that  the direction of engagment is rather a minor detail.What about height?Well, the game gives you a set boon for being 'above' an enemy, but do to its very simplistic nature that 'Above' is often rather wonky.An enemy can be in 'high' cover, getting a 40% defense boon while being two floors below you(meaning you could easily shoot over their 'high' cover as it is not as tall as the object you are standing on) While you are in 'low' cover, still two floors higher.In the end you will both have the same odds of hitting each other and even if you have 'high' cover while being on a roof, all you got is an extra 20% hit chance.Do you see the general theme? Anything and everything you do moves the hit chances up or down by such minute amounts that they really have very little impact. Throw a smoke granade(of which you got 1 per mission in early game) and you get 20% more cover for two turns. In what sitersations is a 20% shift really that important?Because often those 20% is all you can change when it comes to winning or losing your 10 hour long campaign.The dice throwing is also made much worse by the fact that all engagments are very small scale, while in a game like Warhamer you would throw 30 dice and 30 units, you throw 5 or 6 here, of which any can decide the whole game. The more dice the more likely things will even out to be reasonable odds, here they never do.So, playing this game pretty much amounts to playing a extremely simple(to the extent of being almost completely binary in logic) board game that doesnt even have the curtesy to let you infulence it. It gives you a lot of strategic options but most of them will have such minor impacts on the dicethrows that the most important strategic advice for this game is 'never trigger more then one group at a time'(As implied by that, the game is also full of really bad design decisions which I won't even touch on as those are commenly complained about)Besides that it is worthy to note that big oversights were never fixed in this game even though the expansion 'fixes' it. The example being that there is no button to easily disarm all your troops so you can re-equipt things.(Which is a UI oversight and should have been patched, not an expansion feature).Look at Xenonauts, look at this and give it some thought, you'll figure out why I called this game 'simple' and a 'bad board game'.

number of helpful: 12 of 16 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6
												Let's talk about "Enemy Within", shall we?With the Enemy Within supplement/DLC, the flaws of the XCOM game are addressed, and it finally becomes what it deserved to be: a really great, turn-based strategy game.In its original form, there weren't enough maps, and the missions felt samey: a repetitive grind to build a party that could take out the alien invaders main ships. The improved game introduces Exalt, a group of UFO cultists who are working to undermine the XCOM project and bring the aliens to Earth. The cultists are not very powerful, but they provide some much-needed variety. With the DLC in place, XCOM is complete, and it's worth playing. Buy the whole bundle in a sale.Replay value is limited, as the story will always evolve the same way, but it's a good story, and some of the additions (like where your base gets attacked) elevate it from 'nice idea' to really nice game. It's surprising that 'Enemy Unknown' came out wih so little variety (shot down UFOs always find a wooded area to crash in?) but that problem is a thing of the past. Get 'Enemy Within' and you'll be a very happy Earthling.

number of helpful: 22 of 35 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												"XCOM: Enemy Unknown" is an eligible descendant of a blockbuster strategy series "UFO". It responds to roots with piety and conscience. Yet, it's a completely different game - and I think I know the reason. It is a victim of new age in game design. A casualty of "fit to casuals" tendency.If you want a clear picture, imagine a cute girl. She was born to sweet-hearted and smart parents. She is nice by nature, as they say. She has no problems with seducing almost every guy in her class. And then she goes to high school, where somebody occasionally points to our girl that she is too fat to be popular. Or too witty. Whatever. Our girl is too good to not abide those stupid marketing rules. And then comes diet. No fat. No protein. No books. Only to look "decent" compared to the so-called high school elite.See, she's still real pretty. But very skinny too. And she never allows herself to be really clever. Never slips more-than-one-word-a-second from her mouth. She doesn't smile now.Or maybe she doesn't smile just for me? Let's take a closer look at her.First thing we see is a very cunning make-up. Visuals and sounds are great, all those movie-type cut scenes in game are fascinating, and some of them bringing good memories for those who have seen the original UFO game.Next thing we'll be involved is a sharp turn-based shootout with unknown lifeforms, rational and deadly. We gotta think tactical to overcome it, one wrong step and your soldier will die in vain, making others stunned and shocked, just to be shot in the next turn.Those two parts, visuals and chess-like tactical shootouts are dominant. A primo. Sales hook. Love the game for those - and you won't be disappointed. But if you are a geek like myself or just remember good old UFO ... let's go further.Next, we see a kind of a micromanagement system, a strategic part of game. There come the bad signs. See, economical part of "XCOM: enemy unknown" is anything but realistic. It's manageable, balanced... but dull and frustrating. Most players will spend more time personalizing suits of every soldier in squad than in "strategic" part of game.Next… we see restrictions. The most powerful military alliance in the world have only one transport plane, for six soldiers maximum. So if aliens are striking in three places, we can secure only one of them. Two others will be infected. That’s cadaverous feature, reflecting to both size of invasion in contrast to human forces AND modern gamedev tendency to "make moral choices”. X-com organization can deploy only one aircraft at the time to shoot even a Battleship or Carrier type UFO. Only if it will be shot down, they let you send another… but even a heaviest UFO can outfly our interceptors. X-com can’t directly hire engineers and scientists – it relies on small grants from council from time to time. .. And so on, and so forth… So. It can’t be compared with previous games ‘cause they're still way ahead in all terms, except for graphics quality.But, returning to our girl portrait, maybe she still deserves to be loved, if only for small things? Not exactly. Her flaws are not brackets that can be turned down sometime. It’s in the thinking. A new age child, never heard of "Depeche Mode". 21st century big media project. That’s not something you'll want to spend life on. All she wants from you is a decent lunch in restaurant, sweet talk with her … and she’ll spend a night with you. Maybe even a week or month – she’s still a good girl from good parents, remember? But no love. No hard feelings. As SWAT says, “we move in, and we move out”.It’s not a game “from fans to fans, 4 fun”. It’s a product. AAA Product. Fine by looks, working well for its price, engaging at multiplayer… but definitely not a sleep-taker. Not a masterpiece. Pompous and shiny money-taker, that’s my decision. 7.5 out of 10.
