content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												X-Com Enemy Unknown is a rare type of game that only come's around once in awhile. It is gripping, crafty, and terrifying. An engrossing, deep turnbased combat game, married neatly with a real time strategic base mechanic makes this one of the standout titles of 2012.   X-Com is a successor of the classic X-com titles from the mid to late 90's. While this new title has been developed by a differrent company, Firaxis, they have managed to preserve what was so enthralling about X-Com and the alien threat. With a new engine,powered by Unreal Engine 3, Firaxis brought X-Com to a new generation with slick graphics and fresh gameplay.    X-Com has two main layers. The first is the "meat" of the game, which is the tactical combat. Players are tasked with squads between 4 to 6 elite soldiers, each with varying skills and abilities that are unlocked as they get kills and survive more missions. A range of custumizable options are in the game, such as changing their appearance or names, and choosing different skills as they become available. On the battlefield players are faced with the ever imposing alien threat, which is intelligent and ruthless. The aliens have many different species, which act as the classes. From the lowly sectoid to the fearsome muton, players will be constantly challenged with ever increasing numbers and powers. All the aliens feel very distinct, and the ai does avery good job of keeping players on their toes. They will use any advantage they can get,be it suppression and flanking, or simply ganging up on one man, and will remorselessly destroy the unprepared squad. Thankfully X-Com has a few tricks of their own. As players progress, new armour and weapons become available, such as the S.H.I.V, a mobile weapons platform that replaces a soldier in the field and can act as agressive mobile cover, or the skelton suit, which allows soldiers to use a grapple hook to reach elevated positions. Perfect for getting that sniper in for the kill. Late game will players will see even more advanced alien technologies be adapted for your soldiers use, and even delve in to phsycic abilities.      The second layer of X-Com is the base management. This is where players are tasked with monitering global panic, issuing promotions to vetrans, researching alien technologies, and contructing a fortified base from which to launch operations. It is here that all new weapons and tactics become available, so it is crucial to manage X-Com's limited resources wisely, as one mistake could leave you  without the proper weapons or technology to survive the increaing alien menace. As permadeath is in the game, players must strive to keep their soldiers equipped with the latest and greatest if they hope to achieve victory. Missions will occur at random and vary from seek and destroy, a timed bomb diffusal in which the player must find and diffuse bombs scattered around the map before an alotted amount of turns, to Vip escorts. Each mission takes place on a randomly chosen map, so no two playthroughs are the same.   X-Com Enemy Unknown is a a fantastic title that will challenge and entertain, and I highly recommend to all types of gamers.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												An amazing tactical game, with plenty of strategic gameplay as well!Tactical aspect of the game is top-notch, with a huge variety of maps to fight at. And as XCOM features humanity’s struggle against a “coalition” of invading alien species, the enemies you face highly vary in both abilities and tactics. Similarly your own soldiers belong to one of four distinct classes, each with different set of perks that determine soldier’s role in battle – and being able to choose between two perks at most ranks give further customization to your soldiers within given class.Tactical battles aside, the game features strategic gameplay as well: between battles you research new technologies, build up your base, plan your satellite network to minimize panic spreading across the world, and overall decide where to apply your very limited funds.Graphics is astonishing: both environment and character models are very well designed, and game provides a lot of cinematic-esque close up shots on characters to show that off.In short, XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a must-have for anyone who likes tactical games!

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												First up. I have never played a strategy game that I really liked. I got this for free when I pre-ordered Bioshock Infinite, along with Civ 5 on GmG. I tried Civ 5 first, but really couldn't get into it at all. So I am only now giving this game a fair chance. I literally said to my best friend that this was the last strategy game that I was going to play if I didn't like this one.This game though...This game is great! I can't fault it so far. It sort of feels like a game of chess in a lot of ways. Nice graphics and art style too. Actually, the visuals and music remind me of Deus Ex, which is great. It sounds like the same composer to me.There are also a lot of familiar voices, which is actually kind of distracting, because I am trying to figure out where I know the voice from and not concentrating on what they are saying...The council guy sounds like the narrator from Screenjunkies 'Honest Trailers' lol (It IS him!) :DHaha, and I guessed the other one right too! It's the Dharma Initiative guy from LOST! :DHa! again! It is the Deus Ex Human Revolution composer too! :DAnyway, the gameplay and strategy elements are very engaging. You need to plan your moves and take good advantage of cover while getting your squad into position.Then there are squad member promotions, weapons upgrades etc. which offer some interesting choices. The engineering and research aspects are very interesting too. You need to prioritise what to develop, research, build etc.At certain points you have to choose where to go and who to help, which causes panic levels to go up in the regions you don't help. So you have to manage panic levels too.There is a lot going on here, a lot of re-playability, and very satisfying gameplay. I am finding it quite addictive so far and I am glad that I have finally found a strategy game that I like. This is definitely helped by the way the game is designed and the intuitive, easy to learn UI, which is a big reason why I haven't liked other strategy games that I have played.So yeah, very cool game so far.

												The true beauty of this game comes from renaming your soldiers after your friends and watching them die because of your recklessness.That aside, it's a pretty darn good turn-based tactical RPG. The music keeps the situation tense and engaging during fights and helps deliver the needed ambience outside of it.All in all, Do I recommend it? Of course.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												XCOM : Enemy Unknown is a turn based 3D top-down shooter based on a grid system with RPG elements thrown into the mix.The approach this game has taken seems a little more unique than other turn based combat games. It's a turn based chess match that goes on between you and the computer. Throughout the game you command a base and can research aliens for better technology or understanding, add new departments/building to the base that in turn effect production or improve fire power, and train new units. Such things like plasma snipers that are much more accurate, or jet packs to move efficiently. This is essentially the RPG element that adds an extra depth to the game without it jumping simply level to level. Not all technologies are guaranteed to be studied or recovered. If you do too much damage to an alien, you can very well destroy the body and the weapon. When pursuing the aliens, you have the option to choose which country to intercept them in. Obviously depending on who you've helped will determine their stance with the XCOM organization. Every time you end your turn, there could be an invasion, it could simply stay quiet, or there could be a chance for one of your fighter planes to intercept an alien craft. In-game when fighting, you have the basic choice to move a character, tell them to take cover and keep their head down, attack, or be prepared to attack a moving target. The lastly mentioned option is extremely helpful when making advancements in dangerous or unknown areas. The game does a great job notifying you of movement patterns and the amount of cover available at certain areas. Graphics are absolutely on point when it comes to this game. It's not the greatest or finest of graphics, but their choice of style absolutely goes with their theme. Sounds are appropriate for the setting, and sounds of aliens can be heard. If they are heard, characters do react to that sound. I must commend the guy who did the camera angles in this game, absolutely well done. The camera zooms in and let's you see (over the shoulder) what the characters see. Overall a good game and can be very difficult at times if you make the wrong move (so save a lot with multiple slots)! It was a fun game but I felt after playing a good campaign there wasn't much else to play. Challenging a buddy to a shooting chess match is always fun though.For what it's worth, I hate turn based games. I managed to make it through this one and actually came back to finish it. RATING : 7.7/10Gameplay B Story / Campaign B+ Visuals / User Interface B Sounds / Music B Replay-ability B- Overall  B

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful11 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												XCOM—Enemy Unknown is the best turn-based game about immigration. How should we treat the immigrants? Should we kill them?Your immediate response may be: “We should not kill all the immigrants.” Understandable pity. But what if the immigrants are destroying our cities via their plasma weapons? This game, XCOM: Enemy Unknown, answers that question; in such a case, we must create a multi-national, multi-gender special forces group with which to kill the disgusting invaders.You see, in the game the aliens enter our atmosphere--UNINVITED--and start stealing our women and shooting our men. And for this reason, the commando organization is made--XCOM. XCOM’s elite soldiers fly to the gas stations and grocery stores and office buildings of our pure Earth, in their jet-version of the V-22 osprey, and shoot the aliens. It is..beautiful. Like Mozart.I love how the game slows down whilst you see an alien take its final bullet, no longer able to withstand human fire. Do you know the film The Matrix? Of course you do. Imagine, though, that instead of Neo dodging bullets, it is outer space foreigners slowly getting torn to pieces by our Made on Earth bullets; the yellow, green blood spewing from the bodies. Cross over the ozone layer without a valid passport now, alien! Oh! You can't? Why? Is it because you are dead?But it doesn’t stop with bullets. XCOM eventually gives your troops laser and plasma weaponry, which replace your metal rounds. And they are worth it, so worth it. The laser and plasma are red, green, and bright. They make the killings like Christmas Eve at night. I actually get the shivers thinking about it. Mmmm, yes. I have..so many memories of the glow, bursting through immigrant bodies. I love to just...close my eyes, and conjure up memories from this game. They are so beautiful.I almost forgot the explosives. Grenades and rockets fling the xenos’ bodies like rag dolls. Unfortunately, though, the game doesn’t slow down and focus the camera on their flying corpses.You can also capture the aliens alive. Three times you HAVE to do this. I didn't like those parts.If you decide to get this game, you should do so right before a vacation begins. I couldn’t stop..hunting after it began. ALSO, you should get the Enemy Within DLC with the base game. Doing so will let you turn your troops into large, mutilated, killer robots. They lose their humanity, yes, but that’s okay; it helps you kill aliens at a faster rate, and with greater force.If XCOM’s aliens came in peace, then I guess it would be okay not to kill them all. But as the game shows, the aliens do not come in peace. When the real aliens land on our planet and start taking away our jobs, we should follow XCOM's example.9/10

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
 A masterpiece and a leap forward for the turn based strategy genre Title: XCOM Enemy unknownGenre: Strategy, Turn based strategy , Aliens.Developer: FiraxisPublisher: 2K games The Story: The plot is simple.Aliens are♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and want to invade our planet to experiment on humans, after that take over the planet and terminate all resistance.You are the commander of a global Elite defenseforce called the XCOM project. Your job as commander is to exterminate all alien threats. Chase them away from the earth. You have some advisors with you. The Chief engineer , the Chief researcher who give you explainations to what is happening and sometimes give commentary and tips. And officer Bradfort. AKA captain obvious.Find the aliens, cature or kill them, research their bodies, use their own technolagie against them, wipe them out and send them back to where ever they came from. Simple but greatly executed in this game. The gameplay:  This is a turn based strategy game. which means: you take a turn and move your characters, then the enemy does the same. You react to the enemy which keeps it fun and suprising because you dont know where they are based in the beginning. you have to search the area with your soldiers until you run into the aliens. You squad consists of 6 soldiers. (4 at the start of the campaign) and different classes ( Assault, Sniper, Support, Heavy) You can choose who and what you want to take into battle. When you take control of a soldier and move him/her around you have a couple different options. Your soldier can only move a number of tiles every turn. This depends on your soldier's abilities ofcourse. Every class has different abilities and weapons to choose from. Back at base you have a overview of your entire base. Which you can expand underground. you have to be careful with your finances and where you invest them in. You have to research alien technology so you can adapt to the enemy. The mechanics in the game are solid. Customize your squad their abilities the colors the names  its enough to choose from. Its really enjoyable to name the soldiers after your friends and family. You actually care more about your soldiers that way and you mourn them when they die. If you want more custom option there is a DLC pack for more options. Graphics, performance Its nothing really outstanding but it looks great for a turn based strategy game. Im not a huge graphical fanboy but I do appreciate good graphics which this game delivers. dont get me wrong, its not amazing looking but the graphics do the job for making the world seem believable when you are fighting the aliens on random generated maps. The game has some flaws like the turn not ending, but its nothing game breaking. It just works fine with full 60FPS and no stuttering or anything like that. Conclusion & Final verdict This game is a damn well executed turn based strategy game. The mechanics and micromanagement are solid and the game runs well without any issues. It is a remake well done.Everything in this game ranged from great to amazing. I even bought the complete edition with all the expansions. The replay value with this game is great, the story is fine and the battles at higher difficulty asked for a even more careful approach. It gave a fair challenge. For me it was a great time playing this and my final verdict for XCOM Enemy unknown is an amazing 9.5/10 A almost perfect remake  Do you enjoy turn based strategy and tactical combat? Pick this game up. you won't regret it.  Good luck out there Commanders! Want more recommendations? Come see our reviews on our favorite upcoming games! Follow UltraShock Gaming's group curators here!

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												I will always have a soft spot for games that are as easy or as difficult as you want them to be. XCOM Enemy Unknown and the expansion Enemy Within are with every single inch of their being, as easy or as difficult as you want it to be.Granted the slower paced combat can be a bit of a slog, doubly so on the larger maps late game but I like the slower paced combat. It lets you carefully consider your options. The only negatives I can think of gameplay wise is that the (starting) continent bonuses are wildly unbalanced against themselves. Also if you get a bad layout of the Geoscape, there's nothing you can do but grit your teeth and get through it.The Geoscape and how you gain resources for it through combat feel very organically linked to one another. I like the gradual ramp up in difficulty. The game isn't going to wait for you to be ready for nasty curve balls if you take too long or if it just decides to throw mission after mission after mission your way. Keeps you on your toes and no two playthroughs will be identical.Oh, and some advice if you're new to the game? Cycle out your soldiers - even if they aren't wounded. You're going to need contingency plans. Lots of them.

number of helpful: 20 of 33 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Are you and Anime fan or a whovian? Yes? Well here is the game for you:Featuring both England AND Japan you can now dress up your soldiers to be kawaii sugoi Doctors w/ guns! References: Guns(Doctor Who and animes feature guns!), Aliens(Doctor Who and animes feature aliens!) and of course Japan and England.Jokes aside, XCOM: Enemy Unkwown is the newest sequel in a long line of strategy classics.  This time it has been simplified to make it more accessible, or at least that's what everyone says. I can't really confirm that as I haven't played the older titles. Let's see how it holds up to the legacy.Visuals: The game looks very good, especially for a strategy game, however with the visual fedelity of both game and the impressive cutscenes we also have some problems due(probably due the Unreal Engine). Textures load terribly slowly even for the Unreal Engine. The frame rate also seems to suffer due to the engine, however I am not sure about that.Sound: Sound design is actually quite good. Music, sounds, voice acting and of course the general composition of those challenges some AAA movies as it reminds of Alien, and other classics.Gameplay:As already mentioned, gameplay is quite simpe. Now, don't get me wrong XCOM is one of those game that is easy to grasp but you WILL get anal probed trying to master it. As it is a standart TBS you move your soldiers in your turn and get #rekt when the enemies turn comes. You have equipment, a small set of skills and different weapons to fight the ET threat. All quite standart but fan. Maybe you have already guessed but difficulty is kind of a thing in this game. Like in BF3 it's also quite weird. Basicly a "difficult mission" can range from "stomping enemies to the ground" to actually "a bit diffucult", then we have "very difficult missions" that can again range from "this makes me sweat a tiny bit" to "oh my god where do those elite mutons come from?". I would recommend to pick the easy difficulty for unexperienced players, normal for TBS veterans and normal+ for XCOM veterans.Playability:This games biggest problems are it's bugs and the aggro-system. You have multiple game breaking bugs that can scramble saves, block your turn(good luck if you haven't saved), etc. And also quite a few glitches.  What I mean by "aggro-system" is the moment in-game where you encounter enemies. That can be random, not only will saving at the beginning of a mission not mean that the enemies come from the same directions(which can be both good and bad), some times you will just be overwhelmed by enemies that throw themselves at you from nowhere.Final Verdict: A fun game when it isn't frustrating as hell. Play this if you are a fan of the originals and want a lighter version, or if you want to get into the genre. I would say that it takes some influence from Starcraft 2, so maybe if you like a combination of SC2s style and a TBS with a faster pacing in a "Battleground: Earth" atmosphere then buy this.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												Strategy games not your kind of thing? This game will change your mind. It's an extremely fun turn-based strategy game with a cool cinematic action cam (that you can disable if you don't like that sort of thing or if you want to speed up the gameplay a bit). There is also a little bit of "base management", where you decide how things operate at your HQ. It fits into the larger theme of this game where choices have consequences. While the game can be challenging, it is definitely not hard to learn. Throughout my entire playing, I never got bored of it because as you progress throughout the game, you get new weapons, new enemies, new abilities, etc. and have to adjust your tactics correspondingly. I only have the base game and no DLC, and I've barely touched the multiplayer (only played a minute or two before I remembered I had to go to work, this game is that addicting!), and I would still nonetheless highly recommend it. I heard the Enemy Within DLC adds a lot to the game.Some minor issues I have with this game is that the user interface seems to be designed with consoles in mind. The camera control is a bit wonky, especially when the camera is backed up against the edge of the map or it's really high up. You can pivot your camera 90 degrees but this only allows 4 different rotations of the camera. Since XCOM 2 is being designed with a focus on PC, these shouldn't be a problem. The text is too big, and generally this isn't a problem UNTIL information boxes that can't fit all the text have it slowly auto-scroll down after a time limit (and they don't let you scroll yourself). Also, another problem with the large text info boxes is that they sometimes get in the way "free-aiming". Things like grenades, rockets, and Rift. An example would be this picture: 


XCOM: Enemy Unknown 
A Screenshot of XCOM: Enemy Unknown
By: Anomalous Qualia




You can't see the blue mouse arrow but it is approximately in the center of the circle. Unfortunately, that's overlapping with the text box. Not just that, but "free-aiming" can get very difficult to control some times. My recommendation is to just move the mouse slowly.Sometimes you can't see how my red health bars enemies when you're selecting a(n) enemy to fire at and they list hit chance and crit chance. Can be a minor annoyance when you're trying to select the enemy with the most HP to shoot at, or the least or just any certain amount.Trying to finely control elevation can be difficult. I'd say 99% of the time the higher you are, the better (unless doorway arch is blocking your view), but at times I can either choose a fairly low elevation to hover at with my Archangel or Hover SHIV, or go around to the very top of the building (so that you're standing on or hovering above the ceiling), which is definitely not what I want.Selecting teammates who are hovering through clicking on them can be quite difficult (i.e. Archangel armor or Hover SHIV)There also seems to be the rare line-of-sight issue, where you clearly have a direct shot at your enemy but the game doesn't think so, see these 2 pics:


Wut. Looks like they didn't design this level for SHIV 
A Screenshot of XCOM: Enemy Unknown
By: Anomalous Qualia







XCOM: Enemy Unknown 
A Screenshot of XCOM: Enemy Unknown
By: Anomalous Qualia




Also, sometimes this game tabs out and switches to my desktop. Not much of a problem because I can switch it back but hopefully this gets fixed in XCOM 2.Not many people seem to play the multiplayer :(I wish there was a way to "un-equip all" soldiers so that I wouldn't have to search through my barracks to find who had that last SCOPE or plasma pistol, or whatever piece of gear. I heard this got fixed in Enemy Within though.

												This game is pretty much the new gold standard for how to do a remake well: trash all the old annoying stuff, keep what works without gutting the gameplay.Still, I should voice what few nitpicks I have with the game:1.) This is still one of my favorite games ever, and it'll probably be one of yours too.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
												If you're ready for your life to be over (at least for a while, we can all stop when we want right?), then give this jawn a shot. Many improbable criticals and flanking shots later, you'll feel the hate flowing through you like a Sithlord. At the same time, nothing beats running your defense force through invaded territory like a xenophobic terrorist. Pull off dirty guerrila warfare strategies against your oppressors by demolishing cover, Scanner-melting faces with headshot lasers and eventually completely out braining the aliens with the latent psychic abilities of your soldiers. And when you lose your carefully personalized soldiers in a cruel and unfortunate twist of fate, you may just hold your own personal funeral for "CrackShootLiteral" or "StraightUpBanger" in your own domicile, IRL. Ten out of ten for an outstanding and immersive experience.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a tactical round based Strategie Shooter set in the (maybe not so) distant future. You have a team of soldiers and have to complete missions like freeing hostages, destryoing alien ships, killing specific leaders etc. You will be send out to those misisons from your base - a hug eunderground bunker that can be upgraded, enhanced and used for researching aliens and equipement. You will also recruit new soldiers, cure them when they are hit and launch more satelites to get more money. The gameplay is cover & percentage based which means every action you do has a % of succeeding or failing. You can improve your chances, but not having a 100% chance can always result in the death of one of your soldiers. The missions are different and repetetive at the same time, since you basicly always run from one cover to another and shoot at enemeis when possible. Nontheless the overall package is incredibly good. Upgrading your base and soldiers while trying to not let the world fall into panic and trying to leep a positive balance - a real challenge. I enjoyed the game quite much, despite the rising difficluty . I have yet to be able to finish the game, because of a personal problem - i can't let my soldiers die, and i hate failing missions. This made it impossible for me to succeed in the very late game, resulting in me quitting it over and over and over again. Discouraging, but not the games fault.Overall: Fully recommended. The game contains so many hours of good gameplay that it is really worth going for it. I would, however, advise you to buy the full package (Enemy Within) to be able to make full use of it's potential.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												As a former Mac user now Linux, I have come to love Feral Interactive. They are responsible for a vast amount of Mac ports, from Borderlands and Deus Ex: Human Revolution to Lego Batman and Worms 3D. The release of the Linux port of XCOM: Enemy Unknown is their first Linux release to date. Feral Interactive's Linux native port stands up well and plays smoothly at the highest settings. This is a very high-quality port and showcases the great work that Feral do. Expext more high quality Linux ports from them!Now more about the game:It's been years since I've played the original XCOM on my 386 computer, but I still vividly remember the hours of fun I had filing my team out of our landing craft to do battle with the alien hordes.While my memory of the specifics of the classic XCOM are a bit hazy, I can tell you that all the major elements that I remember are fully intact in XCOM: Enemy Unknown (XEU). You get to do loads of research between missions, you can scramble jets to intercept UFOs and most of all, you get to send your team all over the world in turn-based combat with the aliens in your patient quest for new technology.Despite the similarities to the original, it is immediately apparent that a lot of thought and polish went into the development of this new game. --Your teammates can go up in rank as they gain more experience. Best of all, more experience means more abilities, but even this is not linear as you are often stuck with a choice of abilities, both almost equally tempting.--Prepare to die a lot, but the Soldier Memorial adds a nice touch and encourages you to be more careful with your strategy to prevent further losses.--Being able to view the "anthill" of your base and excavate new areas gives you a great deal of satisfaction between missions.--There are short load screens, but they are integrated so well that you hardly even notice them (in particular the spacecraft cinematic when you fly to or from an engagement).--Having people at headquarters that actually talk to you reminds me a bit of the advisors in the Civilization games.--But perhaps some of my favorite things about XEU, are the global threat alerts and council meetings. Through both of these, you really feel like you are part of a global effort to defeat the aliens, not just America vs the Aliens. As you'll soon find out, aiding other countries is crucial to getting ahead and keeping the aliens at bay.As for negatives, I really have nothing but a nitpicking. The graphics are more practical than they are pretty. You won't be ooh-ing and aah-ing at anything, but at least you'll never mistake an alien for a pile of rubble.One final note, although the game is rated "M", my experience (about 5-6 hours worth) has been absolute "E", minus a little animated green goo and blood. There is an option to turn off "squad language" which is where I imagine the bad language and the "M" rating lie. So parents should have no problem with having their kids play this game if it is set up properly.In an age where some developers seem to favor style over substance, it's nice to see a game that remembers its roots. I've put hundreds of hours into "graphically bland" games like Civilization, the original XCOM and Final Fantasy Tactics. I foresee that I'll be putting quite a bit of time into this game as well.A must play/buy for all Linux gamers!

content:
Posted: June 13, 2013
												There are very few games like XCom Enemy Unknown made today. Strategy games apart from sims are far and few between, especially made by AAA studios and publishers. This game was no different, as it took a very long time to get developed since the publisher originally wanted to make it a first person shooter.Instead what we got is a delightful return to form for the series. XCom Enemy Unknown is a game where you play as the commander of a team that specializes in stopping an alien invasion of the planet Earth. The game is a turn based strategy game and heavy in things like cover and approaching carefully. Your squad of soldiers likewise is heavily customizeable, and as you complete more missions they grow identities of their own.What amuses me is how the game likewise punishes you for failure. There's a setting in the game called "Ironman" mode which disables quicksaving. What this does is force you to either restart an entire mission from the start, or bite the bullet and move on if one of your favorite squad members dies. Because you can only level up soldiers by completing missions, this mode makes you play extra carefully so you can get everyone out alive.Enemy Unknown is a refreshing change of pace from the nonstop first person shooters we get every few months. A title that injects a little humanity into an otherwise drab and faceless genre. Where your unwilling to make redshirts out of your pawns.

												I'm 40 hours in now, and I can't get enough of this game.  Not only was it interesting from the get-go, but even after 40 hours, I still feel like I'm learning a huge amount of information in every playthrough.  Exceptional quality in this game.It hits the nail on the head when it comes to turn-based, tactical combat, and I can only hope it's popularity breeds more games of the same genre, as I feel we're lacking in that department lately.  Fans of turn based games should most definitely check this out, but there's enough elements of strategy, base-building, and decision making to draw in gamers of many sorts.  Even though you have access to a refillable roster of recruits (each one costing you in game $$$ of course), you begin to get attached to each one.  With them being fully customizable, you really get a sense of brotherhood with them.  Watching them perform well in combat will leave you cheering at the computer screen, whilst watching them miss an easy shot might leave you rolling your eyes, and insulting them like an old friend.  And besides, who doesn't like going into battle beside the likes of "Woody Hardcock", "Blackie O'Malley", or Ginger Grundle♥♥♥♥".  I'm just saying.  It's gold.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
												I got the game for Christmas and played a fair bit of it, to the point that I felt confident starting a game on classic difficulty with ironman mode activated. I started the game and was doing extremely well... until the stressfull atmosphere got the best of me and I stopped playing right before the alien base assault (sorry for the spoilers). Then I saw the announcement trailer for xcom 2 six months later and remembered how awesome the game was (and how awesomely powerful my assault soldier Sasha Boroso was). So, as any courageous man would do, I opened up the game again, chose my ironman game and booted it up. I wasted no time and headed right to the alien base as brave and heroic as ever. I entered the base, explored a little, and, finding no aliens in the immediate vicinity, relaxed a little and said to myself: "See! It's not too hard! Nothing to be scared of!". I opened the first door and found a floater that I could easily flank with Shasa Boroso's run & gun skill. So I rushed in... only to realize that there were 3 chrysalids right behind. They immediatly surrounded Shasa... and I was left with little choice but to go all in and try to explode them all (and hopefully not Shasa) with my heavy's rocket launcher. So, I crossed my fingers, closed with anger the game's warning about damaging a friendly, and shot. Well... the floater was killed (yay?) but the 3 chrysalids were still alive... AND SO WAS SHASA! So I ended my turn with glee and hoped that maybe it was lunch break for the aliens and that the chrysallids would simply turn and run off. IT WAS LUNCHBREAK! ... except they didn't turn... nor run off... Actually they, took turns munching on my precious Shasa that died and became a zombie. At that point my fingers lingered over ctrl+alt+del, but I grabbed hold of myself and said: "HEY! YOU'RE TOUGHER THAN THAT! THE EARTH NEEDS YOU!". So I killed the chrysallids with my heavy and a smile returned to my face. Yeah... but then Shasa's zombie came and killed my heavy with a 7 damage hit and poison (7! REALLY 7 AND POISON! CHRYSALIDS DON'T EVEN DO THAT MUCH AND THEY'RE ALIENS!)... Then I really got angry, closed the game through the task manager, and hoped it wouldn't have saved. ... But no, it had, and there was no reverting to autosaves since I was on ironman. So it was officially at that moment that I started to cry. And amidst the sadness, the pain, and the suffering, I realized that me abandoning earth was acually a good thing! BECAUSE IT SETS UP XCOM 2'S STORY LINE, WHICH WAS WHAT MADE ME START PLAYING XCOM AGAIN ANYWAYS!... now all I have to do is wait until November... and mourn Shasa

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												(I actually have closer to 150 hrs played, but it was before i added it on steam) XCOM: Enemy Unknown  is the revival of the classic "X-Com" series of turn-based tactical games, with modern graphics, utility and design philosophy. The game takes place in the near future, and gives the player the role of commander of the "XCOM Project". The game has two distinctly different gameplay scenes: the strategic and the combat screens. The strategic screen  gives you a manager-like control of your base, and lets you make decisions about what to build, what to research, what to buy/sell, etc. The combat screen  gives you control of the tactical, turn-based combat of your squad.The game starts out with basic terran equipment and Xenology, and the "story" goes forward only as you achieve certain milestones, which is an interesting way of progressing a game. Such milestones can be the capture or elimination of certain aliens or artifacts, or completion of certain research projects. In the long run, you'll see your base and your soldiers evolve from being small and weak, to being big and effective.There is too much depth and variation in this game to write a thorough declaration of features here, but rest assured; this game  will  challenge you, if you let it. There are however fans of the old games who state that the new game is lacking in features, compared to the classic games, and they would be right. What the game lacks in quantity, it makes up for in quality.  Less is more, gentlemen .If, however, you are one who appreciates quantity over quality, I would recommend the varius DLC's for this game, especially  "Enemy Within" , as well as a community-made module called "Long War". I must warn you though: Both the DLC and  especially  the mod will make the game  incredibly  hard, so i suggest postponing the installation of "Long War" until you have clocked at least 20 hours of the game. 20 hours goes by with the blink of an eye as long as you enjoy turn-based , tactical, manager, base-building, role-playing, sci-fi  games.There is also a 1v1 multiplayer mode, which is only the combat screen, and lets the player choose their units from a pool of both X-Com and alien  (and EXALT, i believe?) , but i would again recommend you to postpone that until you are more than familiar with the game.Buy it for: Its excellent single player experience, as well as feeling like the saviour of mankind.Pirate for: To see if it's actually something you might like, especially the DLC's.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Not being a fan of strategy games, I was skeptic when buying what would become my all-time favorite game. Now, first off, this is not Real-Time Strategy, this is Turn-Based Strategy, and the only previous experience I had with such titles was tabletop games, and Pokemon. So I gave it a shot.The game is set during the begining of a war with extraterrestrial beings. You are made Commander of the Extraterrestrial Combat Unit, XCOM for short and lead a global effort to push back the invasion. With a Council overseeing you, and people being abducted every day, this is no easy task.How do you stop the alien menace? The gameplay is mainly divided into two parts: all of the gameplay that happens at the base (i.e. sending air support, investigating alien technology, changing your soldiers' names and looks, promoting soldiers, choosing countries to support, and expanding your base) and the gameplay that takes place in the battlefield, with your international squad of customized elite soldiers (i.e. moving them, shooting at aliens, recovering resources, saving civilians caught in the cross-fire). Both parts are incredibly well done and very fun to play.Now, when I say elite soldiers you might think this is easy, but make no mistake, this game is unforgiving, sometimes to ridiculous extents in higher difficulties. It should prove a challenge to beat the game even on Normal, as countries stop giving you their support and the world crumbles around you. And, as it is no longer common in most AAA games, death really does matter in this game. Do you have a Sniper Major who you spent hours costumizing, giving medals to, promoting and always saves your team? One lucky shot by the enemy and you have him no longer. If you like intelligent, highly customizable, hard but enjoyable games this one is for you. And don't even get me started on how good the DLC is.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2013
												Anfangs war ich skeptisch, weil ich das gute alte X-Com damals auf Amiga 500 gespielt und geliebt habe.Es war perfekt für mich, wenn auch heutzutage nicht mehr grafisch up-to-date.Ich kaufte mir also im Sale dies Game für zehn Bucks in froher Erwartung, ein echtes X-Com mein eigen zu nennen.Was soll ich sagen?Das Spiel macht Spaß.Die Grafik ist absolut in Orndung und die Schauplätze liebevoll designt.Es macht Spaß mit seinen Soldaten den Sektor zu erkundne und gegnerische Aliens auszuschalten.Doch was gibt es taktisch her?Man beginnt beim Avenger, der einen zum Schauplatz gebracht hat und inflitriert das Gebiet mit seinen Soldaten im Rundenmodus.Es gibt verschiedene Klassen an Soldaten.So gibt es den Sturmtrupp mit Sturmgewehr, den Sniper, der auch von hinterletzten Winkel Aliens plattmachen kann, Supporter und Psi-Soldten, die den Mind-Krieg betreiten können, ganz bewährt im alter X-Com Enemy-Unknown-Manier.Die Schlachten machen Spaß und sind zu keinem Zeitpunkt unfair.Das Spiel ist eine gelungene Adapation des Klassikers, einzig alleine (achtung Spoiler!) die Tatsache, dass es nicht zum Mars/Cydonia geht um den Endboss kaltzumachen stört mich.Stattdessen wurde hier ein "Tempelschiff" generiert, auf dem der Kopf der Alienbande ist und den es auszuschalten gilt.Ansonsten ist eigentlich alles beim alten geblieben..die Forschung, die Werkstatt und der X-Com-Rat, der einen subventioniert, wenn man erfolgreich Terrorangriffe tilgt oder Ufos-Abschießt.Das Spiel ist sehr linear, aber das ist nicht weiter schlimm.X-Com Enemy Unknown macht Spaß, wenn man auf Taktikspiele steht und abgehärtet ist gegenüber Niederlagen.Kauft es und vielleicht sieht man sich ja mal im Multiplayer, um gemeinsam ein paar Projektile in die Gehirne der Aliens zu treiben.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												XCOM is a study in problem solving. If you want to return to your base with all the soldiers you brought with you, you better approach every enemy engagement with plans A through G. Because every so often, your decorated psychic genetically enhanced Sniper rocking alien tech with 250 kills under his belt will miss his 98% chance headshot, and you'll have to improvise from there.The whole game is incredibly engrossing. You will catch yourself playing just "one more turn" for a few hours at a time. You will become attached to your squad of superhuman yet still vulnerable soldiers, and legitimately grieve when your mistake causes one of them to die. You will whisper a prayer of thanks to RNGesus when your Assault successfully double taps two ~25% shots as the last action in your turn to win the mission. If you're looking in the store debating about XCOM 2, buy and experience this masterpiece first. Definitely worth your while.

												(I actually have closer to 150 hrs played, but it was before i added it on steam) XCOM: Enemy Unknown  is the revival of the classic "X-Com" series of turn-based tactical games, with modern graphics, utility and design philosophy. The game takes place in the near future, and gives the player the role of commander of the "XCOM Project". The game has two distinctly different gameplay scenes: the strategic and the combat screens. The strategic screen  gives you a manager-like control of your base, and lets you make decisions about what to build, what to research, what to buy/sell, etc. The combat screen  gives you control of the tactical, turn-based combat of your squad.The game starts out with basic terran equipment and Xenology, and the "story" goes forward only as you achieve certain milestones, which is an interesting way of progressing a game. Such milestones can be the capture or elimination of certain aliens or artifacts, or completion of certain research projects. In the long run, you'll see your base and your soldiers evolve from being small and weak, to being big and effective.There is too much depth and variation in this game to write a thorough declaration of features here, but rest assured; this game  will  challenge you, if you let it. There are however fans of the old games who state that the new game is lacking in features, compared to the classic games, and they would be right. What the game lacks in quantity, it makes up for in quality.  Less is more, gentlemen .If, however, you are one who appreciates quantity over quality, I would recommend the varius DLC's for this game, especially  "Enemy Within" , as well as a community-made module called "Long War". I must warn you though: Both the DLC and  especially  the mod will make the game  incredibly  hard, so i suggest postponing the installation of "Long War" until you have clocked at least 20 hours of the game. 20 hours goes by with the blink of an eye as long as you enjoy turn-based , tactical, manager, base-building, role-playing, sci-fi  games.There is also a 1v1 multiplayer mode, which is only the combat screen, and lets the player choose their units from a pool of both X-Com and alien  (and EXALT, i believe?) , but i would again recommend you to postpone that until you are more than familiar with the game.Buy it for: Its excellent single player experience, as well as feeling like the saviour of mankind.Pirate for: To see if it's actually something you might like, especially the DLC's.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												X-COM: UFO Defense was a terrifying and terrific game that was well overdue for a modern update, and what better developer than Firaxis to take up the charge?XCOM: Enemy Unknown (and Enemy Within) offers a modern take on a great theme: aliens have arrived and they're taking over the Earth. They're going to succeed, unless you, the player, stops them. The player takes over the role of The Commander of XCOM, a last-ditch international cooperative force of the best of the best of humanity's soldiers, scientists, engineers, and pilots. Your squads of soldiers will be deployed on missions to recover alien technology, defeat alien terror attacks, and uncover the mystery of the invasion in hopes of ultimately thwarting it. This side of the game occurs on a turn-based tactical combat layer that will be familiar to those of you who've played the original, or even games like Final Fantasy Tactics and the like. For a good chunk of the game, the aliens have better guns than you and are often statistically superior, so your soldiers must make good use of cover and positioning to overcome that challenge.The rest of the game (research technology, training soldiers, building equipment/facilities, managing aircraft) occurs on a base management strategy layer. It's a fairly light take as far as management games go, but it gets the job done, and there are multiple ways to go about things. You need to deploy your squads, aircraft, and launch satellites in such a way as to minimize global panic and keep your benefactors (countries) on your sideOne of the best parts about XCOM is that it mirrored facets of the original well: the game can be deadly. You can lose your campaign, and then boom, game over, the aliens won. A tactical battle can quickly go awry, resulting in you losing your top squad of soldiers and forcing you to field newbies once more. This terror is best exemplified in the game's Ironman Mode, which only allows a single autosave file, and the game autosaves with every single turn. Lose the campaign, and your save is deleted. Combine that with one of the harder difficulties (Classic or Impossible), and difficulty junkies will surely get their fill.All in all one of the best strategy games to come out in the past decade. The expansion (Enemy Within) and other DLC (Slingshot) add more missions and options to the game in a great way. A must buy for tactical/strategy lovers and a great "first strategy" game for newcomers, though they may want to start on Easy or Normal.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												With its very engaging and interesting tactical-strategy gameplay, XCOM can easily suck several hours out of any TBS fan. Especially if you're into sci-fi or challenging games.Although some older fans might argue that it is not on par with its predecessors, the overwhelming majority agrees that it is a very enjoyable reboot of the series nonetheless.That is not to say that the game is without its share of flaws, some examples are the relatively heavy reliance on random seed number generator (%) that can easily make some players flip tables and laptops alike as well as a few bugs here and there which you may or may not encounter along the way. But here, what suffers the most is the story. Don't go into it expecting an amazing plot, it is nothing out of the ordinary in that regard.However what this game lacks in plot, it makes up for in gameplay... a LOT. Not only is it addictive and very replayable, the level of satisfaction upon taking on harder challenges and succeeding is outstanding. XCOM's very appealing design, fresh graphics and immersive atmosphere supported by a fitting soundtrack are all positive points that add up into how easy it is to devote a lot of time into it.The macro-heavy part that is base management is very entertaining in its own right and the micro-heavy squad tactical action missions never get old. There's a good variety when it comes to the battle system, enough to keep things interesting and at the same time not so much that would make you feel overwhelmed, along with being fairly simple and intuitive.Sending a squad of badasses into a dark battlefield, heavily outnumbered and making them prevail through sheer decision-making and a bit of gambling has never been more fun.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												One of my favorite games of all time, XCOM: Enemy Unknown successfully combines deep tactical gameplay and RPG elements into a single, glorious package.  Due to recent extraterrestrial attacks, the XCOM Project has been activated and you have been appointed as its commander.  Your duties include directing the initiative's research, sending order to the engineering department, selecting and hiring the best soldiers for the job, and commanding said soldiers in battle.  You'll also be building and modifying satellites and aircraft to provide intel and defense against the alien threat as well.As the war progresses, the alien invasion forces will become increasingly dangerous.  New alien types with more advanced equipment and abilities will show up throughout the war to catch XCOM offguard.  Fortunately, this is where your research department tips the scales in your favor.  After eliminating an enemy threat you will acquire alien materials and corpses that your scientists will be able to study.  Common results from these studies include new gear options for your soldiers, additional aircraft and air-based weaponry, new facilities to build in your base, and more that will further your cause.  I was always very excited when my research resulted in a new piece of gear based on alien tech that was significantly more efficient than what I had previously used.In addition to improvements to their gear, your soldiers will gain promotions as they acquire experience in combat.  Each of the four classes has a unique tech three that they will progress down as you see fit.  Each rank allows you to choose one of two options that will offer new abilities to use or passive buffs to the unit's overall efficiency.  One Heavy soldier may be built around specializing with his rocket launcher, another might be entirely focused on maximizing their machine  gun capabilities, and a third might have a combination skills from both skill lines.There are two other aspects of XCOM that I feel need to be mentioned in addition to the standard mechanics: Second Wave and Long War.  Second Wave is a menu full of options that is unlocked after having completed the game once.  These drastically change the mechanics of the game and include changes such as a semi-randomized skill tree for your units where one, or potentially both, of their options for a particular rank offer skills that are not usually allowed to that profession.  For example, you might have an Assault trooper who has an advanced talent with medicine that is capable of healing their allies for significantly more health, an ability that is usually Support-only.Long War, on the other hand, is an unofficial mod created by players who saw the opportunity to futher improve an already great game.  Though there are plenty of mods out there, none that I have seen can come close to comparing to the ambition shown in Long War.  I won't go into the details here but I find that it improves almost every aspect of the game for me.  If you're interested, read more on it here:    http://www.nexusmods.com/xcom/mods/88/?There are very few people that I wouldn't recommend this game to.  The variety of difficulty options makes it an enjoyable game whether you're a more casual player of if you're a hardcore masochist (I'm looking at you Impossible/Ironman).  The mechanics are great, the atmosphere is fantastic, and everyone who I've spoken to who has played has had numerous stories to share that are a lot of fun to hear.  Just remember, you'll be losing a lot of soldier that you've customized grown attached to.Now stop reading and save the world from the alien menace, Commander!

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												A great turn-based strategy game with RPG elements. There are many aspects I like about this game, including the combat mechanics; although the game can occasionally seem unfair (how could I miss with 80% hit chance?), it is actually a well-thought out system that works very well for the most part. I like how there are two different play modes - one is the on ground combat, and the other is managing your base. Think of the management aspect like a simplified Civ game. You are responsible for hiring scientists and engineers, building specific rooms, managing finances, hiring soldiers, deciding which soldiers to genetically modify, to name but a few. I also like the way each solider type (heavy, assault, support, and sniper) have their own tech trees. They are slightly limited, but enough to keep it interesting. The expansion adds plenty of content, such as new missions, weapons, and enemies.  Negatives are fairly minor. I feel there could have been more environment types (they get very stale after a while). Animations are sometimes a bit off, not enough to ruin the flow of the game, but they are noticeable. There is one enemy where their turn takes way too long, and can be irritating to wait for it to finish, especially when you are looking to load to a previous save.Overall, a fantastic turn-based strategy game. Certainly one of my favourite stratey games. If you are late to the game like I was and enjoying good strategy, I recommend buying this ASAP.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												The multiplayer is mostly garbage (Clearly was shoehorned in, you'll hear the sounds your opponent makes  through fog of war regularly. Not as a "I hear something!" unit alert, you'll just know exactly what's going on. You'll also see doors open through fog of war), the story is completely worthless, and it doesn't have as much randomization as the original X-com but it's still a pretty good game.Much more boardgame-like version of X-com with the 2 actions instead of time units, and the way soldiers largely improve through skill selections instead of improved stats, but it's still quite a good game. Biggest flaws are the over-reliance on scripted missions (Council missions where you're fighting the same alien type 99% of the time, no matter when you are in the game, and the few story missions) and complete lack of randomly generated maps. You'll quickly see repeats from the map pool, and even though enemy placement and composition are randomized you'll find yourself using the same tactics over and over again.Despite the flaws, gud gaem.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
I despise AAA titles, but WOW is this fun. The whole thing is just so well done. It manages to capture that purely addictive fun of the original X-COM, with adding crazy updated graphics and easy-to-navigate menus. This title skillfully eliminates some of the more tedious parts of the original game, and keeps only the good stuff. Team management has never been so fun.Pros:+Hours pass by and it seems like only minutes+Awesome modern graphics that pretty much can run on toaster (all things considered)+The best parts of the original series, with all the tedious parts scrapped+Lots of options all around: from soldier customization to how you view the battle (minus camera options, see Cons)+Lots of extra DLC to keep you busy forever, and not to mention a sequalCons:-Compared to how well everthing else is done, the camera is terrible. You can only view from 4 different sides (8 would be nice; analogue would better - I mean whats the holdup?)-You cannot change the angle of the camera, either. It feels too 'top-down' for me. Needs like a 15 degree shift.-Lots of DLC, but then again, this translates to lots of money. They have a great product, and they know it;)For my Steam friends: If you have not experienced the pure addictiveness of X-COM, you are missing out. At least grab this on a great sale (should be plenty considering the sequal is coming out). This game literally created its own genre. Side note: I recently also played and reviewed Xenonaughts, which is an awesome spiritual predecessor of X-COM. I would love to ultimately root for the indie underdog and say that title is the best, but unfortunately Enemy Unknown takes the cheese for best modern X-COM game.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
 "Good luck, commander." Disclaimer: I'm not good at this game. So maybe you should keep this in mind.TL;DR:Pros: The game is very challenging, but that's what this game is all about. Managing your base is pretty easy if you get the hang of it, but still is very important. The variety between your troop's classes and the alien races are great, and you won't get bored by them. Overall, it does a exellent job at being a great turn-based strategy game.Cons: The ending is not satisfying. It could have been so much better. If you want to get the full experience, be sure to buy the XCOM: Complete pack, or else you will miss out on a lot of things.XCOM is a beloved franchise with a long long history. UFO: Enemy Unknown was the series' first game ever, and it has over 3 sequels. Then there was a long period of time, then XCOM was announced by 2K games, a FPS take on the series. After a stream of hate, Firaxis Games announced XCOM: Enemy Unknown, a remake of UFO: Enemy Unknown, and the FPS XCOM was renamed into The Bureau.When I first heard about this game, I didn't really care. After all, it was a strategy game. But after playing Sid Meier's Civilization V and a lot of other great strategy games, I thought I should give this a try as well. And oh boy, that was a right decision. The Civilization fanchise is known for its 'one more turn' tactic, and even though XCOM is not by Sid Meier(he did help with the project), XCOM also does that, and honestly, it's not a bad thing at all.In XCOM, you play as the Commander of XCOM, a paramilitary organazation who is being funded by the Council(basically UN) to stop the evil aliens from destroying the Earth. You must manage your resources to engineer new equipments for your troops, research new alien technology, and go out in the battlefield to control your mans and fight against the aliens.Each man has a 'class'. This class is randomly decided, and all of them has unique skills as well as unique perks and more skill that they can earn as they level up. These classes are Assualt, Support, Heavy and the Sniper. All of them are very important and unique, and some of them even has special weapons that only they can use.Managing your base isn't too hard. If you know some stuff before you started the game, you might know what kind of alien technology you should research first, but other then that, it's pretty standard.But the meat of the game takes place on the battlefield. This battles are turn-based strategy game, where your soldiers will go out and try to eliminate the opposing alien forces. Sometimes, depending on your situation, additional objectives will be added.These alien forces are not just one alien race. They are multiple races, and they are abducting humans and is destroing mankind with an unknown reason(pun intended). Each alien races have special powers and some of them even have powerful weapons, and most of them has their own role in the battle field.The Mutons for example, is the main infantry of the alien forces. Armed with heavy armor and deadly plasma rifles, they are trained for combat and is always ready to kill your troops.The Thin Mans are not really suited for combat. They are infiltration units, who looks just like humans. Even though they are very fragile, their eyes are very good, and unless you're behind some good cover, the Thin Mans will most likely kill you.As time passes, the plot will move along. You start to make the aliens desparate, uncover the aliens' unknown objectives, and in the late-game, you will finally meet the masterminds, the alien race who was plotting all of these plans.The game obviously gets even more challenging- oh yeah, I forgot to mention this, but this game is really really hard. Like, really really hard. And it gets even more hard! But that's the point of this game, and you can get better at it.After all this, you might ask: "This sounds interesting, but is the game any good?". And the answer is: Yes, this game is awesome. It does everything right. But there are some negative parts that I need to talk about.The ending is not satisfying. It really doesn't explain anything, and the impact wasn't that big either. I think explaining what happend after would have been much better, or just changing the ending entirely so it's more satisfying.This game has an expansion pack called XCOM: Enemy Within. It adds some new classes, new aliens, and tons of other stuff that will make the game a LOT more fun. I suggest buying the XCOM: Complete pack which has all the DLCs and Enemy Within to make the experience lot better. If you only buy Enemy Unknown, you will definitely regret it.XCOM: Enemy Unknown does everything right to be a great turn-based strategy video game, and I'm happy to say that this game's final verdict is 8/10. But here's the punch, if you bought the XCOM: Complete pack, it deserves an 9/10. You will definitely get a lot of hours sinked into this masterpiece, and you won't regret any of it.

content:
Posted: January 1
												XCOM. The franchise that launched a thousand memes and probably ten times as many blood pressure problems. The game that it's said your soldiers are just as likely to shoot their own cover as they are the enemy you told them to hit. Well, let me tell you right now that's not true.They're much more likely to do that.So here's the deal. XCOM is (and always has been) a turn-based, squad-level, brutally tough tactical sim. If you're all about commanding massive armies in the defense of Earth, move on. We're going to ask you to protect the planet and we're going to give you four people to do it. Six if you pay us enough. When you get right down to it, XCOM is the antithesis of the tank philosophy. It demands surgical application of force, and done so that your limited forces are able to work together. Once you hit mid-game, that's the only way to survive. Players who bring a sledgehammer to this game are going to end up beaten senseless in short order. You need a scalpel. And lots of luck. On the positives side, it's a beautiful game. Everything from maps to UI is detailed and well-rendered. Everything you see makes sense (well, most of it, anyway), and it was put together with care. The tactical simulation is top notch and is essentially a game of chess where the pieces don't move one at a time. The level of forethought, planning, and tactical finesse the game requires of the player is a refreshing change from the "shoot at everything, bulldoze the level" approach many games take. And if you take the time to develop your tactical skills and fight smart, you'll be rewarded. Not richly, maybe, but rewarded.On the flip side, XCOM continues to be notoriously skewed against the player. The RNG hates you, and there are all kinds of invisible fetters that are tinkering with your die rolls, meaning that 80% chance to hit probably isn't. That whole "90% chance to hit - miss three times in a row" meme isn't joking; it'll happen. But that's part of the process; if your tactical plan is resilient enough to accomodate that kind of bad luck, then you'll come through. If not, well...time to recruit some new troops.As a particular bonus, customization is a big deal in XCOM. Building your base is entirely up to you, as is the equipment loadout carried by every one of your troopers. No automatic decision system is going to trip you up. You can even rename your soldiers and give them nicknames. And after your sniper misses his FIFTH 90+% shot, you'll get a certain amount of satisfaction in nicknaming him "Elmer Fudd."This is a game for the chess players of the world, not the CSGO crowd. If your idea of tactics is to Leeroy Jenkins it, the aliens are going to have you for lunch (possibly literally). But if you like thinking about your combat and applying complex tactics...welcome to the fight.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												I've spent a lot of time on this game, and I keep coming back to it. It's a challenging, engaging game, no doubt about it. It's easy to get hyped up on XCOM 2 (ETA: less than a month as of review), but this game has charm. Sure, stuff like forced failure in the form of abductions and unusual glitches mean the game isn't perfect. But no game is. It's hard to describe the feeling I get from playing XCOM, because it is like no other game I've played. It's not forgiving. RNG will get in the way every day. Your soldiers will die. You will cry. But you will get up, and try again. You will get better, and try again. And you will strike at increasingly higher difficulties, hopefully achieving the venerable I/I run. The fact that this game pulls no punches means that every action, every death, and most of all, every victory, means something.They've digged up an old game from the grave. That means there's changes from the good old UFO days. People that liked the old UFO games may not like this one. It definitely changes a lot. There's no more TUs. Inventories are streamlined. You can only have one base. But I played the old UFO, and I loved it to bits. I played this reboot, and I loved it to bits. So it's not correct to say that nobody who played the UFO games will like this one, because I did. For old veterans of the franchise and newcomers alike, I must wholeheartedly recommend.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												I have played this title in PS3 before, and it had suck numerous worthy hours of my life.As soon as I got my new PC (only have laptops before) I decided that this going to be a must have game and, again, it sucks hours of my time now and for foreseeable future as I haven't got Enemy Within expansion pack yet.One part of the game is about management; you're running a base, funding research, building new weapons, managing a fleet of fighter craft and generally trying to keep a small number of rich and powerful funding nations happy enough to keep on funding you.The other half is tactical game. You're taking a small squad of soldiers out into the field for turn-based combat. There are several class of soldier with their own specialty.Both part equally weighted and well crafted to make you rush for more dose; a little game before you go to work, after you get home from work, and when having dinner as you can play it when having your meal.And oh.. I bought Elite Soldier Pack DLC just because its on sale, knowing that it wouldn't add anything essential. But boy.. I never knew that making the soldiers look like Power Rangers could be so fun!! The Slingshot DLC also add more customization to the look. Get the DLCs when they're on sale. When they're not, I think the price is a tad to much.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												Probably the best turn-based strategy game I've played. I bought XCOM during the autumn sale, thinking I might find some enjoyment in playing it, but now that I've invested almost 30 hours into it, I wouldn't have regretted buying it for the full $39.99 price.Personally, I think it's amazing. It's so in-depth - everything is thought through. For a turn-based strategy, a format that you wouldn't expect to have any depth, this game has a developing storyline that keeps you wondering, scientific research descriptions and interesting character interactions in cut-scenes, and I've personally found that I get so emotionally attached to the characters in the game. The soldiers in my squad aren't just units on the screen, they're people, with their own personalities and special abilities. They each contribute to the team in their special way, and even though the game doesn't GIVE them personalities, they are somehow still formed just by playing the game and using your imagination.The graphics are very nice, the interface is complex, but easy to learn and adapt to, and the turn-based battle field is multi-tiered and very fun to play in.I would STRONGLY RECOMMEND this game. 10/10.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2013
												This is a really tight, well made squad based strategy game. Everything about it is well made. The graphics, the plot, the gear, the combat, the enemy progression, the difficulty scaling, it's all pretty much perfect. It's also easy to play how you want to play, with options that allow anything between an old school xcom 'half your squad dies from friendly fire after a rookie panics' game to some sort of action move where aliens die in their hundreds and nobody on the good guys side gets scratched.The early game is suitably hectic as you struggle to build gear and satellites and run missions but that trails off towards the endgame where you can pretty much slaughter any aliens that stick their heads up, and the heart thumping sense of 'oh god not more attacks not now oh god' pretty much vanishes and you can get to the end of the tech tree way before the final few missions. The missions themselves are pretty good, with a healthy amount of variety so it doesn't get stale. The only issue I had was with the expansion pack storyline and the main game storyline - the xp one kicks in late and lasted longer than the main game storyline did, so I was stuck twiddling my thumbs staring at the big red GO FIGHT THE END BOSS button while I waited for more of the expansion stuff to happen.The support cast are all pretty good, and honestly they are all much more fleshed out than I would have expected considering they are stuck in a few soundbites and cutscenes, but they do add a lot to the game, even if you never do quite shake the suspicion Vahlen is a little bit too into dissecting things alive.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2016
												Having played both the original campaign and Enemy Unknown, I have to say that this is a very well done strategy game. I wholly recommend getting Enemy Unknown and passing on the base campaign, as it adds several new kinds of missions that help to give a lot more variety than the original set of missions. The objective of each mission is basically the same regardless (kill all the aliens to win the mission), but it's really a lot of fun.It's quite difficult to overcome the temptation to save scum, but going full ironman sounds downright terrifying. Expect to lose a lot of soldiers, especially good ones. I probably missed out on a lot of the experience the game has to offer with even the lightest of save scumming.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												XCOM EU is a Turn-Based Strategy, this is a sequel to the latest X-COM series, developed by Firaxis Games, the guys behind Sid Meier's Civilization This game has long campaign and a good one, even on the hardest difficulty, its fun at time Gameplay For gameplay, it's like CIV. but it focuses more on turn-based ground combat uses an isometric 3D perspective. The player controls a squad of between one and six human soldiers or robotic units as they hunt the aliens on the map and attempt to complete other objectives dependent on the mission. It has few frustrations like the enemy AI gets a free-move everytime your units meets up with them Level Design Map layouts are not randomly generated, but enemy placement is has a wide open area to move around and explore, But at time enemies can shoot through walls, and sometimes your unit could not find the enemy behind the wall  Verdict Overall, it's a good game, but it's full of frustration in-terms of AI, but if you're the type that can handle it

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												For me,who have never tried any turn-based game before,this game instantly conquer my soul the second I played through the tutorial. Decision,yes,there are lots of them.Even more comparing to most rpg games. (I know they're in a whole different genre but I feel like I need to point that out.). From the matter like when are we going to manufacture a single armament,to the thing such as how to positioned every single soldier in combat to be ready for any kinds of ambush.Every mouse click counts. Literally.The AI in this game is a bunch of fearless dense b-tard.They just don't know when to stop. There have been many occasion when I'm in a tight situation and can't help but yell, "Why can't we all get along together and be at peace!?!?". The nearly unpredictable AI is what you'll love and hate about this game.This game is about how you deal with the different situation at the same time,learn from things that just happened,and most importantly, learn how to move on from it.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												There is a specific reason why I write this review so sure of my opinion after only 2 hours of play. That reason, my cyber friends, is that I love you. And XCOM is on sale. And you should GET IT, like, RIGHT ABOUT THE ♥♥♥♥ NOW.When it first went on sale, it was way too pricey for me. When the price went down, I had other games to play. This summer sale, I didn't plan to get it, but when I saw it's on sale, alongside the The Bureau sequel (get both for 7 € or equivalent in dollars in the next 18 hours or choose XCOM: Enemy Unknown alonside DLC Enemy Within and DLC's for 9 € or equivalent in dollars), I said to myself - it's now or never, man. Now or never. And am I so glad it's now.XCOM slams you in the middle of galactical war - it's humanity VS traditional depiction of aliens - it makes you wanna watch "Mars Attacks" and "X-Files" marathon. Now, the game is pretty simple to get a hold on, yet impressive and pretty hard to be perfect at. The core of the game is tactical combat in the vein of turn-based strategies. You move your squad, turn after turn and you shoot if you have any action points left. You need to deal with objectives which are mainly - survive and kill the aliens, but also extractions, bomb defusals, tecnology capturing etc. Beside 70+ missions that you get in original game, you also gave a great deal of work to do in your base: you need to build and upgrade your facilities - your engineers stand to produce deadly weaponry for you, your scientific labs are exploring alien technology and making it useful for humans, you're hiring new soldiers, you're constructing new base options. You also need to get your soldiers in shape. Some of them panic. Some of them get wounded. You need to treat 'em right. Imagine your base building as something you've already seen in CIV games, in a way - your collagues are something like your advisors and your work with them is something like building and technology tree unlocking in Civilization games. No wonder, it's Firaxis game.You upgrade, you build, you train your squad, you make rookies learn to kill and you weep in pain and despair when your soldiers get killed because in this game, the war and death are eternal, and only thing you have is a memorial wall to remember the fallen.XCOM oozes in traditional SF atmosphere; it's an turn based strategy game of epic proportions and generic, although great story that will keep you hooked for many hours (I can already feel habit building up inside of me).And it has a multiplayer I haven't even tried yet.So, what to pick? I've picked XCOM + The Bureau. You may want to pick XCOM Complete with DLC's, but I couldn't resist The Bureau's setting.The bottom line is this: it's not only a great strategy game, it's A FANTASTIC GAME, whether you like strategies or not.GET IT. You'll thank me later.
