content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												Brutal and downright-diffuclt, XCOM: Enemy Unknown's isometric, turn-based strategy gameplay serves as a barometer not just for the sequel to match -- but also as a standard for other games. With frenetic sequences down a narrow aisle with four Mutons suppressing you down or having a Sectoid Commander mind-controlling your soldier without any retaliation, you'll find yourself knee-deep and swimming in pockets of endless fun and gratification as you go from calm to subdued within seconds. The skills and perks are a great way for the soldiers to level up, granting you various better equipments when you research weapons and armor. The game's core is very simplistic but yet engaging and compelling for those wanting that strategic itch. I decided to play for an hour but that escalated into something else. XCOM: Enemy Unknown is brilliant and challenging -- but that's what makes it fun and amazing.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												XCOM is one of those games that does a few things really, really right, and the rest of the game (problematic though it might be) never has a chance to get in the way.  I forgive its cartoony character models, lack of voice accents, and sometimes questionable hit detection and A.I.  Everything else is a blast and a half.Encountering and understanding the alien threat is a gradual progression and continuous improvement over the course of the game.  The way the story flowed seemed very logical, even-handed, and motivating.  Working with the military, engineering, and scientific wings of XCOM was unique and interesting.  Turning your band of merry warriors into legendary powerhouses, nicknames and all, was as anticipatory as unleashing them in the field.The scathing difficulty, even on Easy, is apparent throughout; if you're gung-ho, your soldiers will die.  Period.  I liked that, having a challenge requiring tact and discretion.Or, y'know, you could always just rush forward with an Assault, spot vision of every enemy, and have your Snipers Double-Tap everything, lol.Shouldn't be passed up.  9.5/10

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												If you are into anything slow paced and like science fiction a bit, you should try this game. This game was a total surprise to me, got it free from a friend and when I tried it the first time, I totally got sunk into it. Now after bying the dlc packs and Enemy Within, I feel that this game is as complete as it can be. Sure some things could be better, but I don't think this needs anything added. This is the reason I think that there's no point for waiting a next installement.The game consist of two parts, base building and tactical turn-based shooter. The base building makes your team better in the field, and your team in the field makes your base better and clients happier. Both phases feel important and interesting, and failing on either will make you essentially fail in the other part. Although both parts forgive some failures, the difficulty curves during the game a lot, so if you don't keep up, you will most likely lose. Because the difficulty curves properly, the game feels constantly challenging and one cannot just stop caring about minor stuff, although the base building becomes less of a challenge while the game goes on.Best part for me was the games atmosphere. It shamelessly hangs between cheap science fiction and militaryhype, and makes a great combination. Graphics fit in and there are only few very minor bugs. Voice acting, music and sound effects are all great that just add to the atmosphere.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												STRIKE ONE, THIS IS CENTRALGreatly reccomended not only for its suspenseful gameplay but also huge replayability. Turn-based grid tactical battles, along with a more meta overview of your headquarter operations, provides rollercoaster campaigns where you will inevitably bond and part with your highly customizable squaddies.The reason I state high replayability is due to:- Varying difficulty levels, - "Second Wave" options which change mechanics for drastically different strategizing (e.g. lower health= lower dmg, higher crit chances, more random damage)- FANTASTIC DLC/Expansion: Enemy Within. - Popular mod titled "The Long War" which adds ridiculous amounts of brand new content for a longer and harder campaign when you've exhausted the base game+expansion.- Great community to discuss strategies and share modsA succesful campaign in the base game will likely take over 10 hours, but you will typically not succeed on your very first try. Even with the announcement of XCOM 2, this prequel is certainly worth it's pricepoint and can potentially give you dozens of hours of entertainment.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												There's a reason why this game is a top seller. game of the year, and on my favorites. I rate games on several factors: music, sound effects, graphics/art style, game play, difficulty options, learning, replayability, stakes, and story/dialogue. I then weigh that to the price of the game.The story is so compelling and something I absolutely love. Earth is under alien invasion. In order to face the threat, the forces of Earth ally. There's many places that need help, and you cannot pick all of them. Hopefully you can gather knowledge to further your tech to aid in the war. I love how the US works with China and Russia and other countries.The music of Mass Effect reminds me of the music from XCOM. That's one reason why I liked Mass Effect and why I LOVE XCOM. This ties into the stakes. The stakes are high! Alien invasion. There's only one planet. And the music expresses how this is a war for survival. And I felt it. No matter what there will be casualties.Stakes ties into the story and difficulty. The planet is under attack! And if you choose the ironman difficulty. If someone dies, they're dead. So every choice you make matters, and may or may not result in a injured or killed squadmate. Or a failed mission.There's a lot of learning in this game. I've played it on Ironman. And I have started the game over, a dozen or so times.The graphics didn't blow me away. But the art choices did. The lighted lines of the alien canisters to the look of a sectoid or muton. The color pallete of a soft blue with black and white gives a futuristic vibe. And the UI is quite intuitive. There's personality! The skyhawk has a no sectoid paint on it.Gameplay is where the game really shines! I love tactical strategy based games. Final Fantasy Tactics, Fire Emblem, Shining Force, Shadowrun, etc. And this game has it. Combat will take a long time. Each movement will be calculated. Is there enough cover? Can I flank without getting flanked? How much will moving to this spot increase/decrase my to hit %?Replayability. The game has it. You can beat it one way, maybe following a specific strategy or losing a few council members. Or you can make an attempt at not losing any members or only using a specific class. I've played this game so much and everyone I've told about it has loved it. I'm sure you will too!

content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												I first encountered xcom as a demo on xbox360. I also used to be a person who did not like the idea of turn based strategy games. Then I tried xcom, and fell in love with this game so much that when I got a computer I bought it on Steam too. What makes this game so good in my opinion? This game takes time to learn. You will make mistakes and lose. When you do not allow yourself to make the same mistakes and learn from them, the more you play, the better you will get. What I like most about xcom is the fact that when I first started this game, I was clueless. This is my first turn based strategy game. As I continued to play xcom, I became better and was able to finally beat classic difficulty with ironman mode enabled. This game requires you to make hard choices that are not always clear. That is why I like this game so much. It requires you to think about every choice you make in the base management side, and in the turn based tactical combat side. Every choice you make in base management has an upside and downside. The combat layer also has hard choices as well, requiring you to adapt and have backup plans, should your initial plan fail. Trust me, you will learn to hate this game and love it at the same time. The tutorial does a nice job of teaching you the basics, but it does not teach you some of the more unorthodox strategies that you have to learn on your own, or learn it from other players. Even though this game does have some bug issues from time to time, the main reason you will learn to like this game is simple. It will never be exactly the same twice. EVER. My main advice to new players or first time players of xcom, is to take your time. Patience and planning ahead will always be your most deadly weapon in this game. I hope that anyone reading this can give this game a chance as I did. I can honestly say that I do not regret playing this game one bit. If you like turn based strategy games, this game will give you a run for your money.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is still one of my favourite games of all time. Sure, it is turn-based combat and if you really tried, you can find a few faults with it, but the gameplay is tight, fun, brings across the combat from what I know of the original xcom very well and is very engaging and rewarding.You play as the commander of the XCOM project. An organisation built to defend earth from the encroaching threat of alien invasion. In the base you arrange for a whole host of things to happen; You sort out your soldiers (hiring, dismissing, equipping, promoting, skill selection, customisation etc), your research projects to get better stuff, interrogations of captives, your base expansions, building and improving of equipment, taking requests from other Countries, selling alien objects, sending up satelites etc etc. So basically, you do lots of stuff. It's deep, engaging and you honestly do end up getting absorbed in everything which all ties up nicely and affects your soldiers in the field.The field operations are turn based assaults, rescues, area securing and other various missions (depending on dlc or not) which take place in different areas which you do get to see a few times, but are infrequent enough and varied enough to still be interesting. The aliens you fight are nicely varied and gradually get more difficult as the game progresses and the whole thing has a nice tie-in with the base gameplay. You capture aliens, alloys, meld (dlc) and sometimes even soldier units in the field, then use those in the base to make more stuff, which then helps in the field next time. It's smooth, intuitive and really engaging.There are flaws, naturally. Sometimes some of the abilities seem a little abstracted from the map geometry and units can sometimes see or even shoot through walls at times. The randomness of the ways you can get resources can be a limitation if you're out of funds for this month and seriously need to start building more stuff, but it does not affect gameplay negatively to a huge extent.Overall, XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a fantastic game, with a good story, immersive gameplay and great mechanics. It is fun and interesting, which in my book, is a big plus these days!

content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
A Well Done Remake! [KAMGUSTA's REVIEW]I had high hopes on this remake because I had some great times with the original classic trilogy. After playing it to the end I must say that most of my hopes have been satisfied.They took all that made great the previous chapters and included into this new game: the graphic is very nice, the combat system is turn based, you can expand your HQ by building new facilities, you can upgrade your weapons and technologies, you intercept and board alien spaceships, your team skills advance as they level up and you can stun and vivisect the aliens! What could you ask more?Well, to be honest there are a couple of things I would liked to be addressed: the enemies spawn "magically" and adopt not so clever strategies; it is too easy to overpower your team with flying suits, plasma cannons and psy powers; you can only build 1 HQ and team members have their nationality random choosen (the last one is not a great deal, but won't you trust more a male american assault team than a female indian one...?).The things that really ruined my happiness are the ending coming after an average of 30 hours and not even a single HQ defense mission. Sadly the replay value is also quite low even if there are different levels of difficulty (there are no incentives in finishing the game twice if you fully completed the first run as I did).I guess this also means the Enemy Within DLC is a must buy.Best played with Keyboard and MouseRecommended Buy Price < 25$Score 8/10

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												I was first exposed to XCOM when apocalypse was released back in the 90's. I actually bought it at Electronics Boutique while skipping school and proceeded to play it for an entire day without a break.  Similarly, XCOM:EU took hold of me and didn't let go. It's extremely well polished from a graphics POV and the music score does well at driving your emotions depending on what you're doing.  While at home base there's a pulse pounding track running to make you feel lke you're doing something important.  While on the battlefield the track switches to a more eerie, ethereal selection as you investigate a crash.Graphics wise it's not meant to look realistic. I read a developer interview and it was mentioned that they wanted the characters to look/feel like action figures and that is exactly what they achieved.  I did feel like the environments were still detailed enough for me to enjoy what I was looking at.Gameplay wise, without dragging this out too much further, you honestly do end up telling yourself "Just one more turn" or "just one more battle".  Before you know it it's 2am and you have to drag yourself to bed to dream about it.  I only had a few reservations about the game.  In apocalypse, base placement was a big part of your success.  You had a city to build bases in and determine your coverage area versus in EU, you just pick a country for your home base and then build satellites to cover the rest. It's a strategy element I did miss even after I stopped playing apoc over a decade ago.Second, when you get into the harder difficulty levels (e.g. Impossible), it can take a lot of attempts to get your game moving forward. Meaning, I felt like I needed a lot of luck to progress for my shots to hit when I needed them to and to be dealt a lucky random mission that provided me with the resources/soldiers I needed.  One disclaimer, I'm certainly not the most talented player and yes "impossible" does imply that it may well be for some people.  Overall, awesome game.  I really hope to see more XCOM in the future!

content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												Xcom enemy unknown/ Enemy withini had been searching for a game for the past 5 years  that had really good Team based Turn Strategy/Role play, coming from Riviera The Promised land, Yddgra union, Fire Emblem (pre-game Cube), Rebel Star, Tactics Ogre, Final Fantasy Tactics, i knew from the first day Xcom came to steam, this would be my game!. A game that has Role play value through character creation and Story  is a real seller for me, along with tight Controls and minimal glitches and pretty much well thought out mechanics.The game has squad based Tactics, research to upgrade your units, recruitment drives, Science research to integrate alien tech into your Project, Increasing difficulty, random events, DLC that expands on all this, along side Alien variaton, a TON of maps, and Almost full customizability of each character you recruit, these options are  hair, Armour, faces,colors, helmets, and Voice nationality.Does it have replayability? yes sir, with features like Second wave and Classic/Ironman modes yes sir or madam it does!THese help vary your troops on how they grow, the abilities they get, and provide extra challenges and or advantages, along side to adding Handi caps to aliens and or making it so you cannot save or reload, what you get is what you get, you fail, you cannot reload.But thats all the good, how about the Bad?****1. Sometimes, (RARE) The camera gets stuck and it cannot be moved or no actions can be done, you must re-load your save (in ironman mode you cant do this)2. 1 or 2 enemies in a full play through will Teleport from beyond the map into the Dark (glitch) then respawn infront of you the next turn.3. I think its a current problem, but Bio electric skin should only be put onto 1 character for it to work fully, having more than 1 person in the squad with bio-electric skin will need you to have the whole squad to be within 2 squares of each other for the ability to work for 1 character.***** 1 and 2 only happend to me once in 3 play throughs of the game, its safe to say its really rareThis game is a must buy with the DLC if you are into Turn based Strategies, fully replayable, and into Alien Devastation, this game really does make you feel almost powerless against the aliens...but only you can make the diffrence between winning it for human kind, or loosing it...

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2013
												The aliens have invaded Earth and XCOM, a secret project created by the Council of Nations, becomes our planet's last line of defense. As its commander, you will have to manage everything, from research, recruitment, building projects and deciding where to intervene in the world against the invaders.I never played a previous XCOM before, so that shouldn't be a problem if you haven't either. On the other hand, I must warn you that this game is very hard and pretty unforgiving. Getting your team completely wiped out for a little tactical mistake is a common thing. There is also an ironman mode, where everything you do is irreversible, giving it a rogue-like experience, plus with the permanent death of your squad members and excellent soundtrack, the grid turn based battles can get pretty tense.In the end, XCOM is a serious candidate for game of the year! Everything in it is great, from the tactical and engaging battles, to the base management and world affairs and the difficult decisions it presents to you. A must buy!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2013
												Before I even started playing XCOM: Enemy Unknown I was sceptical, as not many developers out there can produce a masterpiece when it comes to turn-based strategies... But when you put Firaxis behind the wheel, the geniuses behind Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri, you're bound to have a success!! And XCOM: Enemy Unknown is so much more than that! What really gets you into the game is not the awesome and compelling storyline, or the brilliant combat and cover system, or the tons of upgrades and research, or the customizability of your entire squad, but the actual remake of a game that has been with me since my childhood days and they really nailed it perfectly! From brilliant kill cams to riveting action cut-scenes as your soldiers moves from cover or flanks an enemy to barely dodge an incoming plasma blast; this game is as perfect as you'll get to any other reboot. It is extremely forgiving to newcomers of the XCOM series and/or turn-based strategies so if this is your first time then look no further, you'll have one hell of a fun ride! I must admit though that near the end, 30 hours or so in, it did start to get a bit repetitive with the alien ships and panic missions, but the game happened to end not even an hour afterwards with the final mission so I must admit this was perfectly thought out. Not too long, nor too short, and definitely worth every cent and second spent on the game. A thoroughly and unforgettable experience!

Posted: January 17, 2014
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is one of the 10 best games I have ever played (that would be as far back as 1982:), and one of the top 5 PC games I've ever played.  If you like tense, turn-based strategy, this game is for you.I spent 9 months (I don't get so much game time any more) playing it (culminating in completing it on Ironman Impossible:) on XBOX, and bought a PC specifically so I could it play online versus other people (or currently, other person).I don't find many games that make me want to punch the screen when stuff goes wrong, or jump up and down when stuff goes right.  XCOM is great for that!It can be a little glitchy, but as it is turn based, you can and have to just suck it up - Enemy Within (which I have for XBOX) fixes some of the glitches.Check out the Zero Puntuation review: Yahtzee hates almost everything, and even he liked it.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												This game is a modernisation of the classical 'UFO : Enemy Unknown', and does rather well in re-inventing the theme. Some features have been re-designed, and the game has effectively been made less complicated, and more graphically enchanced. It is a shame to see the cap on trooper being 6, as on the previous version it was 12 with the skyranger and 24 wth the avenger. The game would be much easier with disposable troopers, and the game really needs a dlc to take the entire scale up, as until within, no maps were very big, and the game was limited in things to do. Having said this, Within adds the needed extras, but even with the scaled up maps, it still leaves a lot to be desired. In short, the previous game (1995) is £2.99 and this is £10-20. Take your pick, but the first is undeniabely more difficult, but at the same time very interesting. Basically, Xcom is a more basic version of what was once one of the most complicated, anticipating, and amazing games, but Xcom does hold a certain amount of dignity, but is not what it's older brother is.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2016
												Jake Smith was a simple but powerful solider. He lived a normal life fighting aliens with his mate Roberto Sancheese, until, we began to take the aliens and research them. All of a sudden Jake's life was thrown into anarchy. Jake was given gene implants to his eyes and a sniper to make him super accurate, and Roberto's limbs were sliced off in order to make room for a MEC suit (mech). Together they killed hundreds, if not thousands, of aliens. That was, until, one fateful night the commander ordered Jake to rush onto a roof to provide cover. BAM. The roof was full of Muton alien super-soliders. They slaughtered Jake leaving his wife and child upset. Roberto promised to Jake on his deathbed that he would look after his only son, Jake mk2, like he was his own. Jake Mk2 joined XCOM only to be made quick work of by the aliens, as he was such a low level and the commander was so far through the game. Roberto promised to Jake mk2 on his deathbed that he would look after Jake mk2's only son; Jake mk3. This cycle repeated itself until Jake mk7 finally was promoted and became the best sniper XCOM had ever seen. It was like the older, more simple times, where Jake and Roberto would kill countless aliens. Together they shrekt the aliens.10/10 would kill generations of the same family again

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
[This is a review in Bahasa]Note: Review ini berdasarkan XCOM:Enemy Unknown atau base gameuntuk review full game(include Slingshot DLC dan Enemy Within) di update sesegera mungkin karena OP nya masih bingung mau download 7GB sisanya dimana xD *alah*------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------A Little Story of The Great Commander LibiralDay 1"Lapor pak, Alien menyerang bumi di berbagai negara. Kita harus bagaimana?""Panggil komandan Libiral ke sini dan aktifkan Proyek XCOM""tapi pak..""tapi apa?""Komandan masih belum selesai download nya""*plak"Day 2"Baiklah Prajurit, Alien itu sudah sekarat serang alien itu dari sisinya agar ia tidak dapat bersembunyi di balik tembok itu..""Siap Komandan"...."Saya sudah di posisi komandan, dan mempunyai ketepatan 90%""Bagus, Habisi Alien Itu!"," Dengan ini Jepang seharusnya aman untuk sekarang""Lapor Komandan""Ada apa?""Tembakan saya meleset""*plak"------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------REVIEW SINGKATHalo komandan,apakah anda sudah siap untuk memimpin pasukan khusus XCOM untuk menangkal invasi alien ke bumi? Apakah anda sudah siap untuk kehilangan waif-..pasukan karena satu keputusan yang salah?  Apa anda mau mencoba bermain catur dengan latar 3D Map dimana bidak nya adalah Pasukan Khusus dan Alien?This is your game.Kelebihan :Strategy yang menantang Grafik yang ciamikMembuat frustasiCustomisasi yang luasMap yang strategisAtmoshphere yang menghipnotisKekurangan :Story terlalu simpel dan sangat berpotensi untuk di perluasMap terkadang repetitive/berulang-ulangPlayer agak terbatas pada cerita------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------APA SIH XCOM ENEMY UNKNOWN?XCOM : EU adalah Turn-based Strategy game(Strategy dengan sistem permainan yang bergantian) yang di rilis 2KGames dimana kita mengambil peran sebagai Komandan organisasi gabungan antar negara yang bernama XCOM, dalam usaha untuk menangkal Invasi Alien ke bumi. Di sini selain memimpin pasukan khusus di setiap misi nya, player juga mengurus segala kepentingan di markas mulai dari Riset untuk peningkatan prajurit/Pesawat tempur sampai urusan pembangunan di dalam markas XCOM.GRAFIK DAN SOUNDXCOM Enemy Unknown berbasis Unreal Engine 3 yang mana untuk game genre strategy Engine semacam ini sangat memuaskan mata. Efek suara mulai dari Senjata, Voice-over, sampai backsound sangat memanjakan telinga. Atmosphere yang tercipta memberi sumbangan besar untuk game ini.Bahkan di awal cerita dan beberapa lokasi, atmoshpere nya bisa membuat player berfikir 2x untuk memainkan game ini malam hari.STORYPada dasarnya story di XCOM EU hanyalah moving timeline. Tapi disini kita akan terasa membangun cerita kita disini, melatih pasukan dan bertempur bersama mereka membuat sensasi tersendiri yang akan(secara pasif) berhubungan di akhir cerita GAMEPLAYDengan menjadi Komandan/Pemimpin dari Proyek XCOM ini player harus menjaga agar Teror Alien di bumi(10 Negara?) tidak berkembang. Player secara garis besar akan dapat/harus:- Memimpin Markas dan Pasukan khusus di tiap Misi - Melakukan Riset Teknologi- Melakukan Pembangunan MissionUntuk misi, player akan melakukan Scan di Ruang Control Utama untuk melacak lokasi UFO atau menunggu laporan Penculikan oleh Alien. Setelah menemukan atau mendapat laporan maka Player akan mengirim Skyranger ke lokasi yang bersangkutan. TETAPI, untuk misi penculikan player hanya boleh memilih 1 dari setiap 3 Laporan Penculikan yang ada yang berarti Player harus memilih dengan tepat agar Teror tetap terkendali karena kalau sampai Teror di suatu negara melewati batas maka Negara tersebut akan mengundurkan diri dari Proyek XCOM yang artinya akan mempersulit player karena pendapatan untuk kebutuhan XCOM akan berkurang. Riset/ResearchPlayer harus melakukan riset agar dapat menyamai atau bahkan menandingi Teknologi Alien. Mulai dari melakukan Autopsy mayat Alien, Menciptakan Senapan Plasma sampai membangun Jet berteknologi Alien sangat dibutuhkan demi menandingi kemampuan dan kemajuan teknologi Alien.PembangunanMembangun Markas XCOM menjadi Markas Organisasi paling maju sepanjang sejarah manusia adalah hal yang menyenangkan dan membuat frustasi. Dengan tampilan "Rumah Semut" yang dapat zoom-in/zoom-out player seakan melihat kehidupan kecil yang sedang berjuang melawan kehancuran mereka dari balik kaca. Selain pembangunan ruangan dan kebutuhan tenaga, player juga dapat(diharuskan) membangun Satelite agar dapat memantau tiap negara yang masih berdiri dan dalam perlindungan XCOM.CustomizationLagi, untuk game yang bergenre strategy XCOM EU mempunyai Customisasi yang sangat luas. player bisa mengubah nama, suara, ras, rambut, warna armor yang digunakan pasukan secara individual. In My Opinion ini sangat sangat membuat kita semakin masuk jauh ke dalam dunia XCOM EU. Bayangkan, membuat karakter seperti teman/pacar lalu di suatu misi mereka jadi makanan Alien? yup, Galau Confirmed~.Final Verdict8/10Untuk kamu yang suka tantangan dan khususnya strategy games cepet-cepet beli game ini. Worth every receh yang ada di celengan ayam kamu.Footnote: Ini adalah review pertama OP dengan bahasa Indonesia, maaf bila ada percampuran bahasa yang baku dan tidak baku. Segala masukan dan saran akan sangat di hargai bagi OP yang masih berkembang ini.Sebenernya gak ngerti juga kenapa ada yang mau baca sampe bawah sini, tapi terima kasih xDMau diskusi tentang game  atau Review ini? silahkan ketik REG (spasi) Libiral *plak*

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												A striking, fresh and faithful reboot of a classic game- made immersive and engrossing with elegant design, appealing graphics, and non-wonky interface. XCOM challenges you to do it all: make tough tactical choices with your squad, and strategic ones with panicky nations around the world. There's nothing like that primal scream you let out when your hand-picked assault element gets vaporized, or when your rooftop sniper picks off a Sectoid Commander like a bolt out of the blue. Sure, there are weaker elements, like the air intercepts, limited maps, or simple dig'n'build antfarm base, but they're ourweighed by the appeal and challenge of This fun, well-built game.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												If you like turn based strategy games, this game is for you. Even after I've played through this game, I continue to come back and play it, even months between playthroughs. It is kinda glitchy with a mouse and keyboard, I'm not sure if these get fixed with the controller or not. Its a hard game though, if you dont want to try, dont play XCOM. You have to try, you have to think you cant just rush a turn, the game will punish you for it. The one thing that is infuriating with the game, is the game is true with its percentages. 99% is NOT a garentee. You have a 1% chance to miss. Its possible. I cant tell you the amount of times iv'e had a 99% hit chance, and missed, leading me to lose the game or something. Of course, this happens about 1/100 times. So its not super common, but its definatly clear that just cause your percentage chance to hit is high, doesnt garentee the hit. This fact might ruin the game for some people.

												God DAYUM this game fun and addictive. This goes out as one the best games ever made. Gameplay revolves around turn-based strategic shooting with various classes to fight various aliens. After you kill or capture these aliens and loot them of their belongings, you can use them to unlock new weapons, armor, and other things to make your squad more badass. Mulitiplayer is great. Not only can you use soldiers but you can also use alien forces as part of your squad. My favorite part about the multiplayer is that when create a custom server and enable "Infinite Skill Points," you can add 6 Cyber-Discs to your squad and listen to your opponet's derped reaction as he or she shouts "OH MAH GAWD, YOU NOOB, I HATE YOU, SCREW THIS GAME I QUIT" as he or she rage quitsGet this game A.S.A.P. or at least try the demo.Side effects may include: Becoming anti-social, loss of job, loss of girlfriend or boyfriend, massive drops in grades at school.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												Quite an engaging little game, this is.As a first-time XCOM player, I must say that Enemy Unknown is one of the better turn-based games I've played in a while. I spent a great deal of time hoarding my resources and hiding within my labs in order to obtain the most high-tech weapons, just because I tend to get rather attached to my troops; having to gun down your most powerful commando after he's been zombified by a Chryssalid is a disturbing prospect. Even with the game getting disappointingly simple and trivial once you've got your entire squad at maximum rank with the best skills, the biggest weapons and the highest psi (the only squad deaths coming from my own carelessness or from a completely unacceptable critical kill), XCOM: Enemy Unknown is definitely something I enjoy playing and supporting. Currently on my eighth game with no plans of stopping for good coming anytime soon. P.S: XCOM: Enemy Within makes the whole experience even better, by the way. Get it!

content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												Like Strategy/Tactical Games? Get this.Like Science Fiction Games? Get this.Fan of any Civilization game? Get this.This game is a beauty on the computer. The gameplay was good. The only problem is a few bugs with the camera system. Either buy this at a store or when it's on sale, that way you don't waste as much as just buying it from a Target or Walmart.Ok, the story line is set with your computers current date. That is the day of the invasion, you send Delta-squad in to respond to a distress call. Then your whole squad dies and there is one survivor. You are given your first major choice.  Where to settle your base. Each with a minor boost early or late game. Then the game gives you a satalite and a location to send it to. Then the real game starts.Gameplay you ask? It runs like a RTS game, you go here and reload your gun. But you go there using a speical abillity and kill that Sectiod. Four classes your soilders can use, Sniper, Heavy, Support, and Assult. They each have a pro and con. You level up your selected crew that you brought on a mission, to the rank of Colonel.Multiplayer, gives you all of the units from the main game, with a point limit.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												In XCOM: Enemy Unknown, the earth is gradually coming under attack from extraterrestrials seeking to kill us all. As the head of the XCOM project, a secret organization funded by nations throughout the world to fight the aliens, you manage your squad of soldiers on the ground in turn based tactics, the direction of your research labs (better armor or better weapons?), and even general base-building (Should I go with more research labs or a power generator?). Decisions, decisons.As time goes by, the aliens will step up their offense, sending down a variety of aliens from the dreaded tank-like mutons to the spider-like zombie spawning Chryssalid. But shall you prioritize the correct research, you'll get better weapons to combat the ever-growing threat. The combat in the game as I mentioned, is turn-based tactical, as you control a squad of 4 (at the start) performing a search/destroy mission. You soldiers level up as they perform missions and kill aliens. They can be promoted into one of 4 classes namely Assault, Support, Heavy, and Sniper. Each with their special abilities. As your men level up, you'll begin to feel for your men, each with their own unique nicknames. You could even rename them in to your friends if you like! But be careful though, if you don't get your men into cover, they will die. Alot. XCOM is an unforgiving game where emphasis is based on being aware of your surroundings and efficiently using cover. The game is best played on Ironman mode where the game overwrites your save file with each turn you make, so if you lose your colonel, well, you can't go back in time to reverse that poor decision you made. The game is made by Firaxis, makers of Civilization series, so you can expect a top notch quality game. 5/5 GOTY 2012Edit: It's even better if you could get the expansion for the game, XCOM: Enemy Within. Just released a month ago, it features a whole new variety of maps (so you won't replay the same map for the upteenth time.), more enhancements for your men featuring the power-fist wielding mech suit (to punch those darn aliens!), genetic mods for your men to become something like Captain America! And a whole new enemy faction; Exalt. These buggers want to use alien tech for world domination, akin to an evil version of XCOM. They can sabotage your base, steal your credits etc. But you can take them out later in the game. XCOM Enemy Within also mixes it up with a whole new alien resource to collect when on the ground; meld. They can be used for gene mods and building mech suits for your men. But be careful though. These things self-destruct after a certain number of turns, thus mixing up the combat! RIsk = Reward baby!XCOM ENEMY WITHIN is highly recommended for enhancing your XCOM experience! It's easily one of the best DLCs out there this past year. 5/5As usual XCOM is not for the faint hearted. Missed that 95% chance shot with your sniper, and getting your men killed the next turn? That's XCOM BABY! Have fun Commander!

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												In XCOM: Enemy Unknown players are tasked with running a military base who's sole purpose is to defend the Earth from alien attacks. The base view is presented in an ant farm style, which allows you to explore the structure of your base as though it is a living system. Unfortunately in this iteration of XCOM satellite uplinks/nexus are so vital to your success (especially on harder difficulties) that you are forced into a fairly standard base makeup. If you don't focus on getting your satellites up, you will almost certainly lose.The main focus of the game is the battles, which on the whole are interesting and tense. Cover is vital during tactical battles, and if you do not use appropriate cover on harder difficulties you will quickly lose your valuable soldiers as often times taking one hit means death. Forcing yourself to use Iron Man difficulty or otherwise not reloading your saves is almost certainly the most interesting to play the game and means that losing a soldier is permanent. But it's this chance of permanent loss that brings so much tension and excitement to the battles. There is nothing like the joy of nailing an alien on a 25% chance shot and save a squad member's life, or the sting that comes from missing a 97% shot you thought for sure was in the bag. Soldiers rank up from battles and learn more and more abilities as they do. Successfully completing missions and killing aliens you can recover their technology in order to research it and further improve your soldiers. The visual upgrades your soldiers get from new equipment is probably one of the most appealing aspects of the game. Seeing a loved soldier move up from standard gear to become a future soldier with glowing guns and sleek armor is fantastic.Unfortunately in the battles the AI opponents do not follow the same rules as the player units until they are 'activated' by coming into field of view of your soldiers. Until they activate they are essentailly one 'unit' and will teleport around the battlefield (outside of your view usually) into positions of varying believability. For instance one time I cleared a building by killing all the sectoids within, and then my soliders heard a sound coming from the neighbouring building. As I stacked my soldiers up on the doors and prepared to breach the building they suddenly heard sounds behind them. I sent them back to the first building only to find more sectoids had teleported onto the ones that I just killed, and were no longer in the building my soldiers heard them in only two turns ago. Another case of this is when my rookie soldiers began to panic and hunker down, I once had a group of sectoids teleport in the middle of my soliders! They quickly took cover on every side of my soldiers and were flanking from so many angles that there was no chance success at all. Another way in which the game 'cheats' is during some missions (usually 'council' missions like escorting VIPs or defusing bombs) aliens will simply drop in from the sky. They'll either drop in out of view, behind you, in perfect sniping positions, at your flank, at all of your flanks... in other words, pretty much anywhere. There is a pattern to when they drop in, but there is no warning, or rather the warning comes as they are dropping on top of you which kind of renders it useless.While there are certainly some problems and questionable decisions in this reboot, overall it is a very worthy successor to the original. XCOM: Enemy Unknown kind of screws up the base building by railroading you into satellite focus, and the tactical battles by cheating the rules your soldiers are forced to follow. On the other hand they enhance the experience by allowing your soldiers to learn interesting abilities when they rank up, including some interesting equipment and enemy types, and just making the game much shinier and easier to play.Overall it is clearly one of the most solid strategy games on Steam despite it's flaws. It is one of my favourites in my collection and I'm sure that will only be reinforced by Enemy Within.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												Being one of those people who played the original X-COM on the PC, four disks containing four megabytes of VGA glory, naturally I had already set a very high bar for this game in my mind.  Was Firaxis up to the challenge?  I saw the early reviews and was prepared for disappointment.  Only one base?  The ant-farm is just a cheap gimmick!  Where did managing my action points go?  A two-move turn system?  Gah, why did they have to dumb down another great game for all the clueless mouthbreathers that need to get off my lawn, dagburnit?!But then I played it and something unexpected happened: I liked it.  I liked enough to work past my initial skepticism and play more... and then I liked it even more.  The class system, which I originally thought would just be annoying, actually added to the game because I was no longer sitting around with a calculator & micromanaging my TUs.  Instead I was playing some kind of NeoTokyo chess game with giant bugs and lasers.  The pace was perfectly set to the "action cam" shots" - which, again, I originally thought of as just a cheap gimmick but in the end really added a sense of immersion to the game once I got into it.Likewise, though I was down to a single base that single base had enough going on it to still keep me engrossed in what was happening there.  Soon I was glad that it was the only one I had to worry about, because I had my hands full and was loving it.  The graphics, while cartoonish at times, nonetheless gave my soldiers a real sense of personality.  Most of all, and this is something one rarely hears about a video game, the dialog and voice acting was excellent all around.Yes, it had a few minor flaws - limited maps and a few compeltely scripted missions - but they were far outweighed by the sheer number of things that were done right.  Just when I thought they had finally done real justice to the X-COM name they went around and topped it with Enemy Within.Let me put it this way: Enemy Within will make your inner nine-year old explode with joy.  The first time I had a mech-trooper power-punch a Chryssalid through guardrail and clear off the side of a highway I decided that one scene was worth every penny of that particular DLC right then and there.  It's like they took everything that UFO Aftershock did wrong with their failed attempt at making mutants and cyberaugmented soliders, ran it through some kind of genius machine and out popped the Right Way to Do It.So take it from a lifelong X-COM fan and certified skeptic: Don't let fears or hesitations about this incarnation hold you back.  This is a true X-COM game and you won't regret buying it.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												9/10If you're new to the franchise, give this a shot, get the demo, grab the game in a sale, you won't regret it.Look at that long list of awards?They didn't happen by accident, bub.If you're a die-hard fan of the original XCOM, or Terror From the Deep, this one will come as a surprise. Treat it as a new version, the first alien war never took place... Yeah, I hated when they did that to Star Trek, too.It's simple, and easy to get into. A LOT of decisions have been taken out of your hands, but there are new choices too. It's a lot shorter that the older version. But really the first one was pretty grindy in a "I'm killing bugs while I wait for my new suits/ship" kinda way and a lot of TFTD missions were just "get out of the triton, see Lobster, RUN! Get to da choppa!" (right? be honest, now) How many good soldiers did YOU lose on missions that were strategically low value? In this one they ALL count. Now, chryssalids look as scary as they should, terror missions are tense, R+D comes at a sensible rate. The move/action system is an interesting challenge. No more taking a step at a time until you see a bug, or a shot from one. you choose a destination and commit to it. If that location turns out to be unsafe, bug out or duck!

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												XCOM: Enemy Within is not going to persuade anyone that didn’t enjoy Enemy Unknown, but for those that were looking to get more out of their XCOM, Enemy Within is a fantastic addition and highly recommendable. Ultimately, there are only tiny complaints. Graphical glitches do remain from Enemy Unknown and happen from time to time, EXALT is really not scary at all after the initial reveal, there aren’t a whole lot of extra maps for regular missions and although the new alien enemies are nice they don’t offer a whole lot extra and seeing even more types would then have been great. On the other hand, the simple addition of EXALT does nicely shake up the game and the extra council missions are incredibly fun to do. The MEC class is a fantastic addition that is definitely satisfying to use and offers new strategic options, the Meld resource is a good extra goal to chase after, and the numerous extra research, foundry and of course gene mods are certainly a welcome addition that only serve to make this already highly enjoyable game that much better. content:
Posted: November 11, 2012
												I'm normally not that into strategy games, especially when they're turn based. Somehow they feel slow, and I just want to unwind without thinking about things too much. But Xcom managed to pull me right in. It succesfully mixes turn based strategy with a bit of management, and,... guess what ? It's great fun !Xcom uses a certain graphical style, which reminded me a bit of Team Fortress 2. It's not super detailed by any means, but I still liked the clean look of things.The combat is brilliant, with the camera zooming in when a certain action is taken. It makes the combat feel exciting. Completing missions and killing enemies will level up your soldiers. You'll learn to take care of them, because when they're a higher level some of their abilities might just save you and your squad.The story is nothing special, but the way the whole game is executed is just amazing. You'll have to make some difficult choices (concerning building certain items/facilities and the missions you choose to accept), none of which are right or wrong.The sounds and music also add to the atmosphere of the entire game.Also, for a single-player game it's surprisingly lenghty as well. It should take most players well over 20 hours to complete, especially if you mess up your first few games (like me). Highly recommended ![Rating: 90/100]

number of helpful: 55 of 105 people (52%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												As the player you control Xcom a superregional military force armed and funded with the purpose to eliminate extraterrestrials. The countries that fund Xcom each desire you’re services and as they get attacked it falls on you to resolve whatever situations arise. The aliens will attack three countries simultaneously and since you only own one transport ship (no matter what) you may only respond to one in every three attacks. When this occurs you will weigh the rewards and aid the wealthiest or most convenient country… the other two countries will “panic” and if neglected for long enough they will quit Xcom and withdraw a portion of your monthly funding… Heres the kicker… every time a country is left unaddressed in a crisis their panic level will rise by 2…. However every other country on the same continent will rise by one!  There are a few game mechanics that allow you to delay you’re inevitable defeat but nothing to out rightly stop it. You must beat the game before you lose eight nations.So to recap1. You will buy aircraft in sets of four at a time and you can have a hundred soldiers on standby but you can only own one transport ship and therefore can only respond to one third of all alien related crisis… Also the transport ship only seats six at a time… when upgraded….2. Countries will inevitably quit, when they quit you cannot provide any incentive to bring them back into the fold. You will lose when eight countries quit because no paramilitary group can perform efficiently without the support of Argintina, Nigeria, Cairo, South Africa, Brazil and three other second world (I’m feeling generous) nations.That’s the premise. What about the game play?When the aliens “attack” a city you usually get there after they have inflicted the maximum amount of damage they can given the ordinance at their disposal. You’ll walk through urban areas and note that despite a few corpses they are completely depopulated. The only sounds emanating from the city are non specific alien growling, I found it strongly nostalgic and reminiscent of Doom. Now the kicker is that the aliens aren’t engaged in any particular activity when you discover them, in fact they don’t actually exist on the level at all until a member of your squad reaches a predetermined point. Once you step on the games invisible red wire poof! a plethora of alien life appears. They promptly interrupt you’re turn and fan out and occupy the best defensive or offensive positions. Since the game is ostensibly a strategy game you will scramble for better cover or attempt to flank them… only to get counter flanked by a second or even third group of spawning aliens.Here’s the fun part. The aliens cover more ground then you, they have more support skills and offensive abilities then you, they have significantly better aim then you, Before long they get guys that are tougher than yours. They even “wallhack” and will target members of your squad that they haven’t rightfully seen. The first rule of Xcom is that the aliens outnumber you… on earth.The core gameplay of any turn based squad strategy game is ultimately going to be about cover and how well cover is integrated into the actual game play. Well heres the word. Most enemies are able to traverse great distances on ground. Some of them also have abilities that directly negate or ignore cover. “Thin men” can spit venom over obstacles to hit soldiers they haven’t seen. Floaters can fly off the map and reappear at its opposite end ext. In this game cover is over rated. You’re guys are going to be shot through walls, cars and hills. In turn You’re guys… earth’s last hope and the super elite of every nations military will consistently miss shots on enemies  in plain sight on level terrain with no hint of obstacles or cover in the way.  Recap1. You’re soldiers are all near sighted. They can see for maybe thirty yards on a clear day, not counting obstacles. This game mechanic is done to hide the fact that the aliens will spawn at designated locations just outside you’re field of vision. 2. The Alien AI is rudimentary at best. They will occupy defensive features… If they spawn right next to them3.. The strategic nature of the game is purely aesthetic. If you attempt to fan out and flank them you will only spawn more aliens and get caught in a cross fire.  In conclusion. Turn based strategy games are a niche genre and companies that cater to a niche get catered to by the niche. There is no logical need for improvement and their first priority is rightfully to keep their fans happy. An outsider will play this game and realize very quickly that while they thought they were taking home a strategy game they were actually getting a glorified version of Russian roulette, a random number generator. While it has great aesthetic value, strong writing and passable voice acting it brings very little to the table that wasn’t present in the 90s and relies very heavily on mechanics that have been defunct since the days of John Romero… There are a number of mods that seek to improve Xcom and fix many of the aforementioned quirks but it’ll be many years before I give Xcom a third chance. Until then if I get a strong urge to play a turn based strategy game I’ll return to 1997’s Final Fantasy Tactics which still stands at the top of the genre.PS: *SPOILERS* The enemy is the aliens.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												I want to recommend this game so badly. It is absolutely a fantastic game and there is a good reason why it is so widely recommended. HOWEVER, I encountered so many rage inducing bugs and glitches that I cannot, in good faith, recommend  XCOM: Enemy Unknown. Enemies appearing out of thin air and killing nearby squadmates, a bizarre glitch that happens when you try to perform an action and then reload your weapon causing you to have to reload the mission, because you then cannot perform any further actions, and finally percentage values for aiming that are inaccurate. (I missed three shots that were 100% back to back to back). The saddest part is that, according to fans, many of these issues are solved if you fork out the cash for the expansion. It's not worth my keyboard, mouse, or a hole in the wall from these rage inducing issues. Considering I purchased the game years after release there is no chance that these bugs will be fixed unless I want to pay for an expansion that supposedly fixes these issues.

												This game is brilliant, however if you wish to get the biggest bang for your buck buy XCOM: Enemy Within alongisde this for maximum enjoyment. The ending was interesting, but I will go into more detail in a spoiler tag. There is destructable terrain everywhere. The weapons are lovely and the classes slot together perfectly. Armour upgrades can all be specialised to the units (e.g. use armour 1 for the sniper, 2 for heavy, etc.) without much thought, but still with a lot of precision. I can't actually think of very many downsides. Everything is really good.The ending however; (Spoilers below. Mouse over for words, skip to ignore)Double-tap the end boss in the head with an elite sniper and the boss dies. Although there are all these aliens around the main device, you can just ignore them, kill the end boss guy, and win the game. That was kind of disapointing. However, I got one of the coolest deaths ever on my mecha guy. Had him punch one of those big robots to death, only followed by another peaking around and blowing him up. He died a heros deathBuy this and help me get the SHIV renamed the "Armed Roomba with a box on it."

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												First off I'm not a fan of turn-based games but XCOM really blew my mind.The gameplay is just so well made with it's cover system, the weapons and what damage they do to the environment and how you feel connected to your soldiers.As each soldier has their own nationality, facial features and names (facial features and names can be changed) it makes every single one stand out and sometimes you'll do anything to keep them alive. There's also an option that prevents you to save during missions which will make you think twice about what move you're going to make as every single mistake can change everything during a mission.There's 5 classes (6 in enemy within) all with their own very important roles. Each time they level you get to choose a perk in their skill tree, normally each class has their set perks to choose from but there's an option that makes the perks random so you could end up with a soldier that has a perfect set of perks from different classes.XCOM also offers the ability to build up your own base, do research and create items and weapons and it's more or less up to you in what order you want to do things.The Enemy Within expansion gives you a new class, a heavy cyborg/mech kind of class aswell as implants for regular soldiers that will boost them quite alot.The missions in The Enemy Within are the same as in Enemy Unknown so if you think you'll only be playing the game once I would really recommend getting the expansion right away as it offers alot more options to your playthrough.Even if you're normally not a turn-based gamer I would recommend trying this game, you won't be disappointed.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
													XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a Turn-Based Strategy game centering on squad-level tactics. You are in command of XCOM, an organization devoted to fighting off the threat of alien invaders. Your mission is to protect the Earth from this invasion, stopping alien abductions, terror attacks on population centers, and otherwise keeping everyone from panicking and defunding your project, gradually accumulating superior weapons and technology from the aliens so that you have a fighting chance.	Overall, the game is quite strong; the macro-level stuff is fairly addictive in its skinner-box techniques as there is always something new which is going to come just around the corner, and the combat-level stuff works well enough, though it is not perfect either. On the whole, it really makes you want to play through the whole game, though at the very end of the game it may end up feeling a bit strange; there comes a point at which you are really in control of the situation and the earlier desperation goes away, and about that same point the research starts really drying up, meaning that if you take too long to finish the game, it could potentially get a bit dry; the last couple missions before I beat the game were the weakest in the game simply because I had figured it out and there was little threat from the game at that point.	Still, I played through and beat the game in three or four sittings, which is always a sign that a game has you hooked.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2013
												I've played the series since they first appeared and I'm an X-Com fan, you may take my recommendation with a grain of salt :)The first one (UFO Defense) was a blast. It is one of my most treasured games of all time. It involved a LOT of micromanagement, from the "which kind of ammo" for certain weapons (explosive, incendiary, armor piercing...) to buy (yes, you need to actually buy ammo), to the soldiers selection based on the stats (recruitment involved). You even have to hire scientists, engineers and so on. And then you have the "proper" game, the action. OMG, it was difficult, but really addictive.XCOM EU is a different game, not just the same one with better graphics, easier interface and "dumbed down" micromanagement. No. A different animal. A beautiful and different animal. Is more focused on the action (TBS)... and its really well executed.I like to play it on a slow pace, enjoying every bit of it. Right now, I'm around 30 hours, and maybe 50% complete... and I'm not tired of it AT ALL... can't stop playing it. You have to understand that 30 hours is a lot to me, because I can only play about an hour per day (if I'm lucky)... and add my backlog to that... 30 hours is really good, I really have to love the game to reach that.If you liked the original X-Com, trust me, you'll love this one. Maybe you'll miss some aspects, but you'll like all the new perspective. If you don't know the originals, don't worry, you'll love this one even moreFiraxis did it once again. Bravo!

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												I have a love-hate relationship with Enemy Unknown. I Love tactical squad based games, and the story elements (Not that there is much of a story here)through the campaign your first time around feel pretty good. It gives off a good sense of progression. However, between the bugs, glitches, and percentage based attacks, I found myself wanting to strangle my monitor and many many occasions. If you can get passed the (game-breaking) bugs and don't mind the luck based attacking I definitely recommend iron will once you get a feel for the game. I think this type of game should be played that way, but I can't recommend the harder difficulty unless you need something to push you toward suicide.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												This is a remake of the popular XCOM game in the 90's. Although I was not able to actually play that game and was only able to watch videos of it over the internet, I still see how a good game it was before. Fast forward 2012 and we now have XCOM: Enemy Unknown, the remake of the original XCOM, Which I bought from this website. This game will give you different kinds of emotions while playing it. You will feel fearful of these aliens who tries to invade and kill your squad members. You will feel tension with the different member countries of the council due to the politics it entails as they ask for assistance with these invasions. You will feel stressed out on which upgrades you need to do first, but you will also feel satisfaction whenever you upgraded something and is extremely useful for your next missions.and lastly, you will feel a bond and attachment to your squad members which will be with you through thick and thin, from being a novice up to the time they really pack a punch. One wrong decision may spell the end for your squad member and you can never bring him back. This is the epitome of strategy. You will never be successful without thinking everything through. You will enjoy this game with all its rich content, so try it out and don't leave the enemy remain unknown.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												In short, this is a worthy successor to the throne, whilst creating its very own in the process.Being a veteran of the old X-Com series from Enemy Unknown (1994) to X-Com Apocalypse (1997) with a touch of the spinoffs like Interceptor, it would be humble of me to state that I'm a fan of the game, its universe, and the genre it resides in.Admittedly, the news of a new X-Com game was a mixed blessing to my eyes. We all wanted the original to be remade in next-gen glory. What we get now is an honest homage of the original, lovingly reimagined for today's audience complete with its focus vs aliens (with a majority returning with a reimagined and even cooler look), turn-based squad tactics with global defense strategy on top, and in my eyes, more than a worthy successor to the throne that X-Com sits on and moreso, becoming its own thing. This is why I refer it to XCOM, instead of X-Com of old.I would highly recommend this to anyone who loves strategy (SRPG/TRPG-style like FF Tactics would feel at home), loves emergent stories from your experiences (that favorite soldier making a valiant last-stand to save the rest of his squad will stick to you far longer than a ham-fisted voice-acted cutscene that many other AAA titles try to pass off as something important), and loves to play the odds, which are always stacked against you.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												Overall 8/10It doesn't quite recreate the atmosphere of the XCom of old, but it is a thoroughly enjoyable experience (and yes, the Enemy Within expansion is a must have.Pros:- It's an excellent tactical combat game- The graphics, while a bit dated, are ok at understanding what is going on in the field- No major bugs at least after the latest patches- You do get attached to your soldiers- Nice variety of scenarios and techsCons:- Building the base with the right setup, launching satellites in the right order are a bit too important in determining whether you are going to win or not. It's pretty much a tactical combat game, so that shouldn't be the case.- If you play with a decent tactical sense, you'll end winning "too soon".- Higher difficulty just gives you less "money", not smarter opponents (Again, it's supposed to be a tactical game, not grand strategy).In the end, this is a very solid game, that will provide some great fun and even some good memories.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												Yes, this game was made by the same guys who made Civilization. Yes, you will say "just one more turn/battle/other increment of play" until you realize you've been playing longer than you meant to. But that's a good thing.XCOM is divided into two sorts of games. There's the management portion, where you manage your XCOM base, research new technologies, launch satelites, destroy UFOs, manage you (initially very small) budget and try not to let the worldwide panic go up too high. This portion of the game starts out fairly challenging, with multiple countries in states of panic depening on your choices and a limited budget that you must decide what to do with. However, this challenge soon becomes non-existent. Late in the game you end up no longer facing the choice of which of two countries to help, and panic seldom goes over a single bar. Though to be fair, this really only happens when you're completing all of your missions without fail.The other portion of the game is the tactical combat portion. In this part you send your squad of up to 6 soldiers into specific missions. This part remains engaging throughout. It plays like a turn-based, cover-based shooter. Which is an interesting mix. Later in the game you get more abilities for your soldiers, which creates some interesting choices. Facing a new type of enemy can be interesting as you don't know what kinds of things they are capable of (will they do heavy damage? Mind control your soldiers? Do damage to you if they die near you?) though that effect wears off when you've seen all there is to offer. Death for your soldiers is permanant, but in some cases you can save them by getting them a medikit when they fall.The two portions of the game are engaging on their own, and feed into one another nicely.I do have a few gripes with the game though. I wish when soldiers went down they would ALWAYS be able to be revived with a medikit, as it seems to be based on chance now, and can be frustrating. Late game can be a bit unchallenging as well, but that's really only an issue if you're just grinding to max out your levels before the final battle. (Which is easier than I thought it would be, so grinding isn't recommended anyway.) Even when doing that though, a wrong move can still mean death for your soldiers. The ending is also kind of... meh. Lots of questions left, few answers. It does leave things open for a sequel though. I highly recommend this game if you're into thinking-type games. If you're looking for another mindless shooter where you blow up aliens... look elsewhere. Great replay value as well, with multiple difficulty settings.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												I made a review of this game a while back and at the end of that i said something on the lines of "the game in its current state is 6/10, 8/10 if patched properly."And take a quess what i would give right now. 5/10, but numbering is subjective to the reviewers own personal scale, lets try something i know everyone remembers. The dreaded school-grade system.Before plastering the grade all over your faces, i might as well recap some of the main problems in this game.On the GAMEPLAY side, it is simplified greatly. Mostly for the console ports, this means little-to-no modification of squads inventory. Unless you count changing the off-hand items and body-armour, which i dont mind you..Movement and actions, are done by spending two (2) Action-Points. Now this sounded questionable to me the first time i played the game, but afterwards i came to the conclusion, that it is actually a good decision. It makes combat and strategic planning more questinable, knowing whether moving a soldier in that certain piece of cover (Il get to that point later), Protects him from any enemies that might appear behind the corner. And some of mote frantic combat bits are also made more tense with the finite number of actions you can do. Although, the game has a terrible tendency to CHEAT. Yes the AI cheats like a Free-to-player on mobile devices who got his hands on his moms credit-card.Multiple times, the AI takes an impossibly accurate shot. Through several walls and straight into the face of soldier who was in heavy cover and while in the tactical screen before going to combat, the AI decides to introduce three squads of baddies out of the blue, after you move one soldier just 5 meters (or the blue movement-indicator). This caused me a great pain when i decided to do the obligatory Ironman run. My poor assault specialist moved to a piece of cover i thought was safe at the time and suddenly 3 squads of Mutons appeared and pretty much circled the poor fellow. And as they circled the guy, the Mutons kept looking at eachother as asking "Who brought the lube ?"And the vaguely-referencing to-intimacy situations didn't stop there, there were multiple other similiar happenings all the way throught. Argh.. i cannot talk about it, it gave me PTS.What else?... Graphics.Graphical quality is console-level. And by that i mean early Xbox360. Bland and boring, low-resolution and just overall... Meh.And while on the subject of graphics, i need to bring up the Unreal Engine. It does this game no favours. I'm trying to think game that came out at the same time as XCOM and used Unreal as its engine. But my brain draws blank. Unreal Engine has its quirks, and for some reason i always see glitches when playing XCOM, even today as i Rage-Quitted another Ironman session due to the AIs cheating ways.... The camera goes spaztic randomly, pointing in random directions getiing stuck in some places and generally being broken.And there is whole another bag of delightfull glitches always hiding somewhere. in case you didnt know im playing the base game, since Enemy Within cost a bit too much on release and when it actually was on sale i had no money. So im not entirely sure whether the bug-fixes were in the expansion, following the CapCom way of balancing with its fighting games, or do i just have an obsolete version or do i need to re-install the game again, for the umpthteenth time... Nope its up-to-date.Oh and another minor nitpick. The randomly forgets its set Graphics options. Out of the blue, just like that. b*llocks to that.Writing this is making me angry, not because of the game per-se. (Kinda funny that last word, it means A*SE [*R] in Finnish)Im angry because the game is just.... Just.... ADEQUATE.Alright you simpletons, better explain it properly:The game is a decent re-imagining of XCOM, but its buggy nature and other minor problems makes it lose its value as an XCOM game. The Original, which works just fine since it uses DosBox. Has more options and i just realised why i disliked this game, the forementioned lack of options on what to do and the finite resources thing.I cant go on about this, otherwise il be here the whole forthnight.. Suffice to say, XCOM lacks in all aspects that made the original good.But as a game on its own, i can recommend it.But, but, i would still ALSO recommed trying the original, i know its clunky as all hell and the AI blinsides your soldiers now and again, but after a while you learn how to deal with that and adapt accordingly. Something that the remake kinda lacks i might add.Alright, time for the obligatory grade thing.. lets see..Semi-solid remake, hell amount of bugs and glitches even after "Patching", AI cheats like a motherf*cker..Got it.C+When you think about it, you know why i gave it that grade.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												For those who criticise this game for not improving upon much except the visual presentation since the original series I have my own personal opinion on whether this game is worth getting or not. This game adds tons of entertainment with the ability to customise your own soldiers that start of as raw recruits until you eventually rank them up ot Colonel. You get such a close tie to your soldiers that loosing even one of them really hits you hard. You are able to customise their abilities upon them ranking up as well as customise their outfit appearance, general appearance, name, nickname, equipment etc. Although people criticise the price of the DLC's the Enemy Within DLC really adds a lot for the beginning and mid elements of the campaign with a new foe with it's own units, covert operations, base siege, two new aliens and some custom items with balances and changes to the game play itself. I am on my 9th game whiles writing this review and i finally have got satelite coverage over every continent with the only exception of having lost Africa to the alien invasion. If you like strategy, base related games, real time strategy along with alients AND EVEN ZOMBIES then definately check this game out as it has a lot of replay value. I can easily see myself getting up to 100 hours of game time when i have already played around 75 hours on this game. One of my best games ever! :)

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												Forewarning: this review assumes you will be buying the Enemy Within DLC along with the base Enemy Unknown game. While it isn't required, you'll be missing out on some of the content described in this recommendation if you only grab the base game.XCOM, a game in which you lead a paramilitary extraterrestrial combat unit of the same name, is a hybrid of two different game types; on one hand, you have the tactical turn based combat pitting your squad of soldiers versus the invading alien force in various missions to counter their incursion onto Earth, with your troops often outnumbered and outgunned. On the other hand, you have the strategic research and development aspect that takes place at XCOM HQ in between missions, where you'll analyze and adapt alien technology for use by your soldiers, who will also gradually increase in combat effectiveness the more they're exposed to combat.While your soldiers will begin with simple conventional body armor and ballistic firearms, as the war and your arsenal of adapted alien technology stretches on into the later months of the year, you'll be presented with various options to further improve their equipment and skills, with access to tools such as flight enabled power armor and camouflage suits that blend your soldiers in with the environment, genetic enhancements that allow soldiers to leap onto buildings from ground level and emit bioelectric waves that detect invisible enemies, or even augment them into mech troopers equipped with miniguns and flamethrowers. All in all, XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a very well crafted game that will test your skills and tactics in a variety of environments and situations, and can easily provide hundreds of hours of gameplay.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2013
												Think strategically or die. That is the motto you live by in this awesome reboot of the long ignored but never faded title. After your first fight you get to head back to base and begin customizing soldiers the way you want, even so they are named after and resemble your friends and family, giving you just that much more investment in their continued survival. But soon the fights become more intense with choosing between moving your characters to better positions or taking the risk to stand your ground and fight. The enemies you face get progressively harder as you advance through the story (unless you're on a harder difficulty then then they get harder no matter how much you've progressed) and all of them have different ways of fighting you off. The tension is always up to 10 and goes to 11 on those times where you're outnumbered, outgunned and running low on medikits. Even if you make it back to base the tension does not let up. Different countries start to panic and threaten to leave the council that fund your operations. You live or die on the choices you make on a shoe-string budget. You even begin to sell off important assets just to make it a few more days. This game is concentrated intensity and it will have you biting your nails and praying for just one more well-placed shot/credit/day/less panic bar/engineer/scientist/mission/movement tile/round all the way into the wee hours of the morning. Buy this game and don't bother looking back.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												XCOM is quite simply one of, if not THE BEST, squad turn based strategy game I have ever played. Players take control of the commander of the XCOM project, a multi national funded organization formed to stop an extraterrestrial threat. Players have limited resources to prioritise over micro-managements in between missions.XCOM is great for a number of reasons, one of which is how well it makes the missions connect with the time back at base. Having to make the decision of whether or not I want to spend my last few credits on a satellite to then launch over a country before they pull out, or use them to fund for my whole team to have laser rifles to take on what I know is going to be a tough upcoming mission certainly does capture the pressure of being a commander in this world.What's more, the missions themselves are a ton of fun, and actually do require a lot of thinking and strategy - which is something I'm often dissapointed about in turn based games, squad based or not - especially later down the line when the bigger, tougher aliens are introduced and you've equipped your team with JETPACKS!Speaking of the team, I have almost formed a bond with them, something that only the Walking Dead games have been able to achieve. The stuff that you've gone through with them, watching comrades die and relieving yourself when you manage to rescue at least a few of your squad members from a tough mission, all adds together to create a friendship with completely fictional characters with no personality or backstory.Of course, no game is perfect, unless it's Portal. XCOM does have a few issues. For starters, Chryssalids are way too overpowered. The Chryssalid hive mission in the fishing village in the DLC, XCOM: Enemy Within, is just taking the♥♥♥♥♥♥ The Muton Beserkers being able to move when it isn't their turn is a little dumb and the panicked state doesn't make much sense to me.If I were to give two point of recommendatio for this game it would be this:1) Don't buy this game if you don't like difficult games. Admitedly we're not talking Dark Souls level of hard, but still pretty damn unforgiving.2) Play it on ironman. This means you cannot revert back to older saves if you have decided the mission's gone♥♥♥♥♥♥up. You HAVE to live with your decisions. I played the game for the first time on ironman and, while I did restart the whole game from scratch, I didn't regret it.And you know what else I didn't regret? Buying this amazing game.
