content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Slingshot is a pretty good and cheap addon. Dosn't have the scope of enemy within, but contains three nice but heavily scripted missions, a free (pretty nicely statted, but not customizable unless you use long war mod) unit for your barracks, and some other misc things. My only complaints are:1)  The story is kind of nebulous at places and makes heavy use of a macguffin you never really learn the identity of directly, though I think you get it to research as a reward at the end? I'm not really too clear at this point, so maybe I missed mention of it. The character you meet has neat dialogue and is a fresh face to add to your growing ranks of 7-eleven employees with guns, but his overal identity is kind of weak and relies heavily on mystery and viewer inference. 2)  It's less 'Slingshot' and more 'Aliens fall from the sky' DLC. You'll know what I'm talking about if you play it. Kind of pulls a 'doom 3 mid-end game' the entire time in nonsensical ways, at heavily scripted locations and triggers. Maybe the aliens are researching gigantic slingshots as a viable troop deployment option?3) The end mission of this DLC feels like it should have a lot more significance to the main story then what it actually ends up having, and the exterior design of the last level doesn't really.. match anything you've seen before in any xcom game and looks out of place. I can't clarify that without spoilers, but the interior design looks more xcom-y then the outside 'shape'.I guess it kind of vaguely resembles the dos xcom terror from the deep ones..?

												This game has taught me to not get too attached to your soldiers, as they can die at anytime, if you make the slightest wrong move. :)Its really challenging to complete, but once you get the hang of it, theres nothing more satisfying than killing those Alien scum ! :DThe replay value is great, and the difficulties are actually difficult !So, in some ways; This is a turn-based strategy games answer to "Dark Souls", except that this gives you no option to retrieve what is lost ! And I have only played vanilla so far, but there are also mods, so I guess the replay-value is even greater.But I have to say, as a final note here: Do get the "Enemy Within" expansion, and play that, as that adds alot more to the vanilla campaign, and it made my experience of the game better.Good luck, Commander! Remember, the Council is watching!

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
 “Two possibilities exist: either we are alone in the Universe or we are not. Both are equally terrifying.” An Excellent turn based strategy game.Managing your base is fun and intuitive, leading your soldier  to their death  to battle, even more so. At first, the game will beat you mercilessly, but, as you will research new technology, you will be able to give the aliens a nice face to face with their own plasma weapons. The difficulty curve is well dosed so you won't feel overpowered often unless you play on easier difficulty (Wuss). randomly generated missions keep thing interessting and the scripted ones up the stakes!You will get attached to your little squads, you will buy nice gear for them, choose a nice color for their power armors.  Then you will have to watch the game send the hulk smash them into pieces, or get transformed into zombies that their comrades will have to put out of their misery.A good filler while waiting for the 2 :)9.5/10

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												Even if you dont like turn-based games, this is not like the others.This is a really fantastic strategy game, where decisions not only come from your head but also from your heart. Losing a very experienced soldier who was under your command since the beginning makes you feel bad and sad, since you didn't only lose a good "piece in chess" but also a very unique personality who you will not see again.In the beginning, your technology is only about traditional rifles, shotguns and grenades while aliens have more advanced weaponry and seem to have better troops than you do. But you will catch the aliens in technology by doing autopsies, capturing and interrogating them and studying the UFOs you shot down, which leads to better technology and weaponry... etc for you.The game has exciting visuals, great voice-acting, fitting music and magnificent gameplay. It's a real shame if you never get to play this game because it's a must get for all who prefer strategy games.---------------------------------------------------------------------------Only bad thing: FIX YOUR MULTIPLAYER DAMMIT! I feel like the game developers haven't done enough to develop their multiplayer. Like: Why you can't do co-op missions with your friends?

												I played this game on release day without any background of the previous iterations. It quickly became one of my favorite games. It is so addicting that I kept telling myself that I’ll just play 1 more mission but end up playing 5 hours straight. On my initial playthrough, I lost several soldiers and a few countries but managed to beat the final boss handily. When the expansion came out, I played the game again but it felt so good like I was just playing it for the first time. I recommend that you play the game with the expansion as it adds a lot of options that makes the game so much better. A few years later, I saw the game was on sale on steam so I bought the entire package, played the game again and felt awesome even though it was my 3rd time. This is one of the best turn-based strategy game I played in a while. It is so addictive that you will lose hours of sleep in exchange for awesomeness. The only drawback is its easier late game.9/10

												Had a squad with a few funny looking people, the one leading them being Carlos. We touch down on a small town, where everything is quiet. Too quiet. I move part of my squad forward, Carlos being one of them. Unfortunately for me, I was an idiot and moved Carlos a bit too far, using up both my moves with him. And thats when I saw it.A Berserker. My first berserker ever. The giant red beast just towered over us, coming closer every missed shot my snipers took. Then it was their turn. The Berserker takes two steps, and then slams Carlos into oblivion. All that work. All the times we've been through. Carlos Rodriguez dead. A tear falls from my eye onto the 'c' key of my keyboard.RODRIGUUUUEEEEZ!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!10/10 10/10 5 stars 100/100 A+ Made me feel for a guy with a stupid moustache /10

content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												X-Com: Enemy Unknown is an excellent tactical/strategy game by 2K Games. The basic story surrounds the idea that aliens are invading earth and you are the last, best defense. A spiritual re-imagining of a classic, X-Com takes squad-based combat and mixes it with resource management. While in the base view, you play the role of the Base Commander that must manage research, base construction, and troops. When aliens attack, the game switches to an excellent turn-based combat mode.Both the base management and the combat are excellent and offer enough challenge for even the hardest core strategist. The expansion X-Com: Enemy Within deepens the original game by adding genetic modification, Mec’s, and another opposing faction. The highlight of these new additions is easily the Mec’s, which made me smile for an hour the first time I deployed one of these monsters.X-Com: Enemy Unknown is a wonderful game that is well worth a purchase and I recommend it completely.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2013
												Go buy this game.Oh wait, you're here to read an actual review. So here it is:This game is incredible and you should go buy it.Okay, okay, I'm just messing around.XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a game that caught many by surprise much like the aliens that invade Earth in this remake of a little game called UFO: Enemy Unknown, or XCOM: UFO Defense, depending on where you've played it. But instead of being a total disaster and the end of all of humanity as we know it, this game instead makes you feel empowered and makes more meaningful choices than games that would use the word "choice" as one of their bullet points. Not only that, it manages to stand out in a world dominated by First-Person Shooters.XCOM is a Turn-Based Strategy game. While to anybody with a short attention span might find that idea utterly slow and boring, the game is anything but. The game gives you unprecedented control of how to defend the Earth from the alien menace ranging from prioritizing appealing to the Council that funds your project, to devoting your resources to supporting your soldiers on the ground. There's an addicting cycle to the game when you get new resources from a mission to put into researching some new gadget or weapon, then testing it out on the field and getting more resources to make even better equipment, and even better, the game's difficulty curves beautifully to your progress. There's also a great sense of satisfaction when you make a tactical or strategic error, then learn from it to improve your tactics in the long run and be a much better commander. You'll feel a lot smarter and a lot more bad♥♥♥♥♥when you turn your defeats into victories.There's also something novel this day and age about a game you can "lose," and not just get a "game over" screen and load back a checkpoint to keep playing to some predetermined end point.Now hopefully by this point, you're convinced, but if you're still unsure, check out the demo and see what the game is like for yourself.

												Turn-based Strategy at it's best.If you intend to buy I'd suggest getting the complete version so you can have both XCOM Enemy Unknown and Enemy Within. XCOM: Enmey Within is the expansion and makes the game much better maybe dare I say twice as good. I did buy them separate and had a blast with just Xcom Enemy Unknown but now i have the expansion it's like a new game again.Lot's of replayability, you can customise your troopers how you wish. Missions can get a little tiring but they do have so many it'll never seem like a carbon copy of the last mission --- especially with the addition of the expansion Enemy Within.Highlyy recommend if you like the turn based strategy genre. If you've played the previous Xcom games this version does them them proud.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												This could be a fantastic game. So many of the elements are done really well. Research and base management are cool. The upgrade options and squad management are interesting mechanics. The pacing is really well done and everything feels like part of its own universe that's dynamic and lived in.Unfortunately the game has two major shortcomings in my opinion. First, in a game full of choices, nothing seems particularly meaningful and you're never really introduced to the consequences of say, selling a bunch of alien corpses instead of keeping them for research. A lot of things just feel like extra buttons to press for more fluff. A lot of it is quite enjoyable and rewarding fluff, but fluff nonetheless.The second, and much worse issue, is the tactical combat. There are a number of issues I find personally annoying and a couple that I feel really break the game to the point of unplayability. RNG plays far too big of a role in combat. Hit and miss chances don't feel at all intuitive and seem like the product of really lazy math and coding work on the part of the developers. Unloading an LMG clip at a hovering drone out of cover 5 ft away and totally missing not only seems unrealistic, but spraying all the bullets 2 ft to the left in a perfectly straight line seems really clunky in a modern game. For a game that seems to want to reward flanking, coordination, and aggressive play, the way that enemy aliens spawn and interact with the squad seems unnecessary and often bizarre. Making a good positioning decision might activate one of two alien squads and leave you totally outnumbered. The incredibly limiting 2 actions/turn instead of an action point system often means your soldiers seem totally incapable of doing anything significant during their turn. A completel overhaul of the tactical combat is what is needed to make this a truly modern, functional game.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Xcom is a very divisive title just because it wears the title and legacy of the original. I fully approve of this makeover, it's in many ways streamlined in a good way. Kind of what Mass Effect (2) did. You can even play comfortably with a controller except that the game can be still as brutal and gripping as the ´94 one, especially in Ironman mode. Turn-based tactics that don't feel like micromanaging a sidejob, while the situations and tension can still make you crap bricks. Permanent death for your favorite soldier still hurts. The expansion Enemy Within has an excellent pile of extra choices and content on top, but I'd recommend getting that only for later playthroughs, the game's beginning is hassle enough in vanilla already if you're playing first time. If you want to obsessively control every single bullet that goes in every marine's clip, there's always the original or Xenonauts for you. I'm enjoying making just the larger decisions here.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												XCOM is quite simply one of, if not THE BEST, squad turn based strategy game I have ever played. Players take control of the commander of the XCOM project, a multi national funded organization formed to stop an extraterrestrial threat. Players have limited resources to prioritise over micro-managements in between missions.XCOM is great for a number of reasons, one of which is how well it makes the missions connect with the time back at base. Having to make the decision of whether or not I want to spend my last few credits on a satellite to then launch over a country before they pull out, or use them to fund for my whole team to have laser rifles to take on what I know is going to be a tough upcoming mission certainly does capture the pressure of being a commander in this world.What's more, the missions themselves are a ton of fun, and actually do require a lot of thinking and strategy - which is something I'm often dissapointed about in turn based games, squad based or not - especially later down the line when the bigger, tougher aliens are introduced and you've equipped your team with JETPACKS!Speaking of the team, I have almost formed a bond with them, something that only the Walking Dead games have been able to achieve. The stuff that you've gone through with them, watching comrades die and relieving yourself when you manage to rescue at least a few of your squad members from a tough mission, all adds together to create a friendship with completely fictional characters with no personality or backstory.Of course, no game is perfect, unless it's Portal. XCOM does have a few issues. For starters, Chryssalids are way too overpowered. The Chryssalid hive mission in the fishing village in the DLC, XCOM: Enemy Within, is just taking the♥♥♥♥♥♥ The Muton Beserkers being able to move when it isn't their turn is a little dumb and the panicked state doesn't make much sense to me.If I were to give two point of recommendatio for this game it would be this:1) Don't buy this game if you don't like difficult games. Admitedly we're not talking Dark Souls level of hard, but still pretty damn unforgiving.2) Play it on ironman. This means you cannot revert back to older saves if you have decided the mission's gone♥♥♥♥♥♥up. You HAVE to live with your decisions. I played the game for the first time on ironman and, while I did restart the whole game from scratch, I didn't regret it.And you know what else I didn't regret? Buying this amazing game.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Slingshot is a pretty good and cheap addon. Dosn't have the scope of enemy within, but contains three nice but heavily scripted missions, a free (pretty nicely statted, but not customizable unless you use long war mod) unit for your barracks, and some other misc things. My only complaints are:1)  The story is kind of nebulous at places and makes heavy use of a macguffin you never really learn the identity of directly, though I think you get it to research as a reward at the end? I'm not really too clear at this point, so maybe I missed mention of it. The character you meet has neat dialogue and is a fresh face to add to your growing ranks of 7-eleven employees with guns, but his overal identity is kind of weak and relies heavily on mystery and viewer inference. 2)  It's less 'Slingshot' and more 'Aliens fall from the sky' DLC. You'll know what I'm talking about if you play it. Kind of pulls a 'doom 3 mid-end game' the entire time in nonsensical ways, at heavily scripted locations and triggers. Maybe the aliens are researching gigantic slingshots as a viable troop deployment option?3) The end mission of this DLC feels like it should have a lot more significance to the main story then what it actually ends up having, and the exterior design of the last level doesn't really.. match anything you've seen before in any xcom game and looks out of place. I can't clarify that without spoilers, but the interior design looks more xcom-y then the outside 'shape'.I guess it kind of vaguely resembles the dos xcom terror from the deep ones..?

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2013
												Go buy this game.Oh wait, you're here to read an actual review. So here it is:This game is incredible and you should go buy it.Okay, okay, I'm just messing around.XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a game that caught many by surprise much like the aliens that invade Earth in this remake of a little game called UFO: Enemy Unknown, or XCOM: UFO Defense, depending on where you've played it. But instead of being a total disaster and the end of all of humanity as we know it, this game instead makes you feel empowered and makes more meaningful choices than games that would use the word "choice" as one of their bullet points. Not only that, it manages to stand out in a world dominated by First-Person Shooters.XCOM is a Turn-Based Strategy game. While to anybody with a short attention span might find that idea utterly slow and boring, the game is anything but. The game gives you unprecedented control of how to defend the Earth from the alien menace ranging from prioritizing appealing to the Council that funds your project, to devoting your resources to supporting your soldiers on the ground. There's an addicting cycle to the game when you get new resources from a mission to put into researching some new gadget or weapon, then testing it out on the field and getting more resources to make even better equipment, and even better, the game's difficulty curves beautifully to your progress. There's also a great sense of satisfaction when you make a tactical or strategic error, then learn from it to improve your tactics in the long run and be a much better commander. You'll feel a lot smarter and a lot more bad♥♥♥♥♥when you turn your defeats into victories.There's also something novel this day and age about a game you can "lose," and not just get a "game over" screen and load back a checkpoint to keep playing to some predetermined end point.Now hopefully by this point, you're convinced, but if you're still unsure, check out the demo and see what the game is like for yourself.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												First off I'm not a fan of turn-based games but XCOM really blew my mind.The gameplay is just so well made with it's cover system, the weapons and what damage they do to the environment and how you feel connected to your soldiers.As each soldier has their own nationality, facial features and names (facial features and names can be changed) it makes every single one stand out and sometimes you'll do anything to keep them alive. There's also an option that prevents you to save during missions which will make you think twice about what move you're going to make as every single mistake can change everything during a mission.There's 5 classes (6 in enemy within) all with their own very important roles. Each time they level you get to choose a perk in their skill tree, normally each class has their set perks to choose from but there's an option that makes the perks random so you could end up with a soldier that has a perfect set of perks from different classes.XCOM also offers the ability to build up your own base, do research and create items and weapons and it's more or less up to you in what order you want to do things.The Enemy Within expansion gives you a new class, a heavy cyborg/mech kind of class aswell as implants for regular soldiers that will boost them quite alot.The missions in The Enemy Within are the same as in Enemy Unknown so if you think you'll only be playing the game once I would really recommend getting the expansion right away as it offers alot more options to your playthrough.Even if you're normally not a turn-based gamer I would recommend trying this game, you won't be disappointed.

												For those who criticise this game for not improving upon much except the visual presentation since the original series I have my own personal opinion on whether this game is worth getting or not. Posted: October 13, 2015
												A game with real consequences, permanent death and no save scumming. Seriously, the game determines all outcomes for a turn before you make it to prevent you reloading a save to try to hit again, so you will always miss. The numbers are randomized each move you make though and there is an option before starting a game to turn save scumming on to randomize every time you reload but I don't recommend that.If you turn on Ironman mode then the game also saves periodically and prevents you from doing so so all your choices matter and will be carefully reflected upon, this I also recommend!Don't let my hours fool you, I've spent at least 200 hours on this game but on disc before I had the chance to get it on steam. Definitely absolutely one of my favourite games and game types, not enough games like this that are as well and expertly made. Very keen and optimistic for Xcom 2 which comes out very very soon!

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												An overall qualifier for this recommendation: Squad and base-building games are something I adore, and this rather skews my predisposition to XCOM towards the positive.That said, it's one of the finest examples of these genres and turn-based combat and tactics games in general that's out there, in my opinion.  Your squad is deep and varied, tech and research provides gear that changes up your options and approaches, and the presentation and story are done in a compelling and involving way; it's not hard for me to develop attachments to my individual soldiers, especially with campaign options that allow each to have a unique skill tree.All of the things I like about this game are further enhanced by the Long War mod for it-- more equipment, more challenge, more character builds with more compelling and balanced options, and more varied technology to uncover.  If you're a fan of base building strategy and turn-based tactics, this one deserves a look-- buy it with Enemy Within, its fully featured expansion pack that greatly improves the campaign experience and lets you train psychic humans using alien tech, among other things.  Defend Earth.  Purge xenos.  Good times.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a turn based strategy game. In March of 2015, aliens invade Earth. The only thing that can stop them is XCOM, a paramilitary organization that can only deploy one 6 man squad at a time. This game serves as a reboot to the XCOM series. Bear in mind that I have not played the older XCOM games. Pros: +Deep and tactical gameplay. Flanking and methodically taking out the aliens is very satisfying. +The engineering/science system. These allow you to upgrade your soldiers and give them a fighting chance against the aliens. +Some truly memorable missions. The fishing village and the dam missions in particular are great.+Good variety of missions.+Good variety of aliens. Some of them are truly terrifying (as in they can oneshot your soldiers).+Multiplayer mode.+High replay value. There may only be 4 classes, but each class has a variety of different skills you can utilize. +Live by the RNG, die by the RNG. It feels great when one of your soldiers hits a clutch 35% shot.+Enemy Within (expansion) makes the game so much better. More enemies, more missions, and the cybernetic/genetic upgrades are awesome. Cons:-Trying to navigate elevations (such as in buildings) can be a serious pain. It feels like every little movement of the mouse will send your camera up or down a floor.-Lag when berzerkers charge and after certain moves in multiplayer.-The free aiming system for rockets/grenades is terrible. -Live by the RNG, die by the RNG. One time, I had a sniper miss a 99% chance to hit. -Not a fan of how aliens get a "free move" when they first see you. I feel like this punishes flanking. This especially sucks when this happens at the end of your turn. A way to circumvent this is to never extend your front line at the end of your turn.Despite my complaints, I had a ton of fun with XCOM: Enemy Unknown. It is a truly great game.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2013
												A brilliant re-boot of a classic franchise, XCOM: Enemy Unknown puts players in charge of a shadowy mulit-national task force charged with defending Earth from alien invasion. There are essentially two games here; the first layer tasks players with strategic base management. From here, they will research technology, diplomacy, base and equipment construction, and personnel. The second layer of the game is the tactical turn-based squad battles. Some battles give the player certain assignments, such as escorting a VIP or capturing rather than killiing a hostile. Each shot counts, and failure could mean the permanent loss of agents. Each decision made, whether in the strategic map or the tactical battle map feels genuinely compelling. If you are a strategy fan, you don't want to miss out on XCOM.:EU!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												Even if you dont like turn-based games, this is not like the others.This is a really fantastic strategy game, where decisions not only come from your head but also from your heart. Losing a very experienced soldier who was under your command since the beginning makes you feel bad and sad, since you didn't only lose a good "piece in chess" but also a very unique personality who you will not see again.In the beginning, your technology is only about traditional rifles, shotguns and grenades while aliens have more advanced weaponry and seem to have better troops than you do. But you will catch the aliens in technology by doing autopsies, capturing and interrogating them and studying the UFOs you shot down, which leads to better technology and weaponry... etc for you.The game has exciting visuals, great voice-acting, fitting music and magnificent gameplay. It's a real shame if you never get to play this game because it's a must get for all who prefer strategy games.---------------------------------------------------------------------------Only bad thing: FIX YOUR MULTIPLAYER DAMMIT! I feel like the game developers haven't done enough to develop their multiplayer. Like: Why you can't do co-op missions with your friends?

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2013
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a 2012, turn-based tactical strategy game released by Firaxis Games (the company that is responsible for the well-famous Civilization franchise) and published by 2K. Enemy Unknown is a remake of the classic 1994 game of the same title. Enemy Unknown takes you into a long and brutal journey to fend off the alien invaders and the hefty responsibility to command your troops to victory. The game was a huge success to Firaxis Games. This review will also extend to the expansion pack, Enemy Within. Is Firaxis Games’ vision of XCOM a true successor to the original franchise?The story is very simple. The aliens invade Earth and you play as the Commander, who leads the XCOM organization to fight off the aliens via commanding your troops and facilitate limited resources to your advantage. One of the main features for the game is character customization that brings in strong, “emotional” investment to your created characters. Admittedly, I found the character customization limited but it did little to prevent me from caring about the created characters. A few reasons why a person would be invested in fictional characters. Field promotions and experiences in combat will put you in intense situations. The feeling of victory and triumph or the tragedy of mission failure and a character’s (or characters’) sudden death will put you in an emotional ride. Such emotions makes this game very addicting. The game brings a good challenge to the player and the difficulty levels are appropriate for any player who have some experience on understanding basic tactics or “complex” strategies to win over the enemy. The best features for the game are the unpredictable nature and improvisation to withdrawal from battle or fight to the bitter end. Even with “common sense”, aliens can hit you based upon chance and random critical hits. The commander’s (or your) decision will determine if your soldier will fight another day or take a huge risk to kill the biggest threat to your squad. The game certainly has some of the best features, but there are some minor annoyances and criticisms that needs to be addressed to potential buyers. First, I find Dr. Moira Vahlen a tad annoying due to her “accent” or the voice acting for the character. Second, the game’s unpredictability can be a turn-off for some players who felt “cheated” by sudden critical hits on your soldiers. Essentially, the outcome of each mission is based on a “gamble”, hoping that the enemy won’t hit you or at least won’t “cheat” on getting a sudden kill shot on someone who has full health. Honestly, I like this unpredictability but not for some players. The map designs are “limited”, meaning that there is a chance that you will play the same map design more than one mission. Since the missions can take place in anywhere on the world, there are no “cultural distinction” on any maps. For example, if the mission takes place in Egypt, China, Germany (and elsewhere) there are no cultural icons or specific cultural features in the maps that take place (besides the introductory mission in the Slingshot Pack)Lastly, the spoken languages are very limited and disappointing. The game only offers English and various European languages (like Spanish, French, Polish, Russian, etc). Ironically, the addition for European languages comes from the expansion pack, Enemy Within. Worse, the European languages pack comes from the base game (for European players who played in his or her native language) only to be packaged to the expansion pack for American audiences. Since XCOM is an international military and scientific organization, the lack of more languages (Arabic, various African languages, Japanese, Korean, Mandarin and Cantonese, and various others) in the game was a bitter disappointment to me. XCOM: Enemy Unknown and its expansion pack, Enemy Within, is worth your money and your investment. An excellent mod, The Long War, raise the replay value into new heights and is a worthy addition for any XCOM player to have (depending if you want a very brutal and a marathon campaign). The game’s optimization is very good mainly because the system requirements is very affordable for any PC player at this point of time. However, this game might not be everyone’s favorite cup of tea if the person does not like turn-based combat. Regardless, the high replay value, intense firefights, and emotional attachments to your created character makes this game unique. A must buy for any PC gamer even with the minor issues at hand. This game has my highest recommendation.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
 “Two possibilities exist: either we are alone in the Universe or we are not. Both are equally terrifying.” An Excellent turn based strategy game.Managing your base is fun and intuitive, leading your soldier  to their death  to battle, even more so. At first, the game will beat you mercilessly, but, as you will research new technology, you will be able to give the aliens a nice face to face with their own plasma weapons. The difficulty curve is well dosed so you won't feel overpowered often unless you play on easier difficulty (Wuss). randomly generated missions keep thing interessting and the scripted ones up the stakes!You will get attached to your little squads, you will buy nice gear for them, choose a nice color for their power armors.  Then you will have to watch the game send the hulk smash them into pieces, or get transformed into zombies that their comrades will have to put out of their misery.A good filler while waiting for the 2 :)9.5/10

content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												Having just finished XCOM: Enemy Within, i felt i should write a quick review.First of all, i think UNKOWN and WITHIN are brilliant games. Fun and challenging with great content.Specifically, to discuss the "expansion", Enemy Within... There is significant additional content. I loved the new council missions, the side quests, the new options to upgrade / alter your own soldiers - they all added a lot of depth to an already fun game.However... crucially *minor spoiler to reduce chance of disappointment for others* -> it is the same overall story arc. It is NOT a new game. It is an enhancement to the original. As long as a player is ready for this, and focusses on the differences, the set piece missions, the new upgrades, then great. anyone expecting more will not be so happy.All in all, though, I would still recommend it!cheers,Potatoheed.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2012
												Just finished my first play through on classic difficulty. A big fan of the original game this version had a lot to live up to. Good news is I really enjoyed it, they did a far better job of remaking the game than I expected. It's difficult to compare games that have so many years between them. Okay it doesn't get some things right but it does others better. Overall a brilliant game and other than the original there really is nothing else quite like it. Customising, naming and upgrading your troops. Building your base and facilities. Managing the different countries needs and going into battle in visually lovely and destructible environments. All the little details, like seeing your solders in the bar, in the drop ship and on the memorial. It all added up to lots and lots of fun.   I know I'll go back to it after a break. Play it on harder difficulty with ironman mode on.9/10

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												One of the best turn based strategy games in existence, hands down. If turned based is your thing and you haven't played this, you are missing out.It's got a story that keeps you interested and really wanting to push forward. In depth turn based combat that while on harder difficulties will completely change how you approach a fight. Unit, squad, and base advancement that will not only improve its capabilities to push your tech further, but your soldier as well.. physically, genetically, and mentally.This "World Army" created by corporations, governments, and private investors has its own interesting aspects, especially in the grand scheme of the story. And by far my favorite part is turning on the languages for the different countries for your soldiers, makes the depth of it even better, though I do wish there were more languages.On the downside, the AI can seemingly get some pretty insane RNG crits on your soldiers even on the easiest difficulties, and the end game is determined pretty heavily on how you play your hand early on. But this is also a good thing if you really like making that choice and sticking to it.All in all, get it, you wont regret it unless you hate turned based strategy games. And for those who get it and beat it, try downloading and installing "The Long War" mod for the game, it will pretty much triple the amount of play time you get with the game and add a ton of fun new things to it.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												A must buy re-imagining of the classic XCOM: UFO Defense (US) and UFO: Enemy Unknown (UK/EU) from the 90s; this edition has the unusual distinction of taking a classic, reimagining it and possibly making it a better game.Run the worldwide anti-alien response team by building bases, shooting down UFOs and command gun battles on the ground. The game has a strong story with a good research tree that keeps the challenge real. The DLC is worth having with the Enemy Within adding a bundle of interesting content.The only flaw with the game is that the 'on the ground' battle sections can get a bit repetitive if you aren't testing new toys your scientists have dreamed up in the field, but overall the combat is much more enjoyable than previous incarnations by seriously reducing the amount of micromanagement.I wouldn't recommend buying it with The Bureau which was a more poorly received console shooter which is only worth buying with 90% off.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												For me as an X-Com: Enemy Unknown/UFO Defense veteran, this game is comparably easy to manage and the combat system is easier to learn. However, even if tactical parts are stripped down to a certain extent, this remake isn't anymore a simple remake. It's a remaster or a reboot; it has a rather good story line, it adds tons of gameplay features to consider being really good design choices, it got rid of bothering features like the air combat system (which had an awesome music track in the original nonetheless) and of course it has considerable visual/audio overhauls. This game stays true to its root(s) in a degree that it indeed is comparable to the original game (which is a really rare achievement for reboots) but, in my opinion, blows it away with so many additions that it beats the classic masterpiece. This game sets a new standard for this genre.Veterans, if you think it's too easy for you and I'd see where you'd be coming from; it offers many options to increase it's difficulty. If it's just to set the difficulty higher as a whole or to enable the Iron Man mode, where you play it a lot more like a rogue-lite (permadeath, auto-saving-only) or maybe enabling more randomness. You pay a bit freedom in this game (freedom of base locations i.e.), but you get so much more.I highly recommend this game to anyone slightly interested in TB-Combat.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												X-COM:Enemy Unknown is one of those really good turn based strategy. Half of the game is spent planning, researching and building in the X-COM HQ and the rest is spent out on the field. However neither fells like a gimmick on the other. In the base you'll feel either excited to use your new tech, or terrified that you could lose more soldiers. In the field you'll long for the time when you can get back to base hopefully with a full squad. Since mission are, for the most part randomly generated it has a huge replay value. While the story is a little lack luster there are some good moral moments and the gameplay makes up for it.

Posted: January 10, 2014
												A faithful and competent update of one of my all-time favorite games.   Sure, some elements of game play are inferior, but most are improved.When recommending a game, I always consider these three factors.  1.  You're not playing a hairless quasi-male floppy-eared freak.    2.  It's a sensible story based in western-thinking logic with no poor translations into English from some other language.  3.  You get at least one chance to shoot something in the face with a shotgun.In XCOM: Enemy Unknown, aliens are discovered and the people of the world band together to kill the s#it out of them.  What's not to like?Turn-based strategy game.  Good AI.  Buy it.  Play it.  Make sure you restart your game after the tutorial.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												Keeping this short and sweet, I think that XCOM: Enemy Unknown (with OR without Enemy Within) is one of the best strategy games in years. As good as games like Total War and StarCraft are, turn-based strategy with a small squad was always my preference, because what actions you take feel like personal choices, making every single decision you make on and off the battlefield a tough one. And BOY, do they get tough. If you have paitence to loose time and time again, then an experience on the rewarding levels of Dark Souls awaits you. XCOM reminds me a lot of games like Fire Emblem, Advance Wars, or Tactics Orge, but it sprinkles some western elements into it as well as some sci-fi giving it a unique identity of its own. Overall, this game ends up culminating into a big pile of difficult, stratigec, rewarding fun. And honestly? I wouldn't have it any other way.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												I was hooked on the original X-COM: UFO Defense when it first came out way back in the day, and since then I've put in a rediculous amount of time into it. When I heard about XCOM: Enemy Within.. I was excited, but extremely worried it would suck. However, after putting in over 20 hours into Enemy Within, I can safely say it's far from a disappointment. For the most part, it stays true to the UFO Defense formula, with more modern features added and the like. The whole game is less complicated than the original for the most part, which isn't really a bad thing, especially for people who're new to the series and want to give the game a shot without having to spend hours reading and figuring out how everything works. I can't even think of anything bad in this game. The only "complaint" I'd say I have is I wish the campaign was a bit longer.. however, it's still decently long. Not to mention, as long as you're not doing poorly, you can ignore the final mission and keep playing for a good while. It doesn't force you to finish the game right away. All and all, I could go on about how awesome this game is. If you liked the original X-COM games, then I can almost guarentee you'll love this one. And even if you've never played any of the X-COM games.. this is a fantastic choice to start out with. Heck, I've never even been a big fan of strategy games.. but this series is just so amazingly well done and addictive. Honestly, I think as long as you don't hate strategy games, then most likely you'll enjoy and appreciate just how great this game really is, along with the rest of the series. At the very least, give the free demo a shot!

content:
Posted: March 25, 2013
												Fun game, I really enjoyed the squad tactics and the way things have a 'real' feel to them in a science fiction game.  My only gripe with this game is that snipers seem to be extremely accurate, but until the late game, anyone with a rifle can't hit the ground by dropping the damn thing.  Moral of the story:  Bring at least two snipers on your fireteam.Final verdict, awesome game.  Worth the money without a doubt, and getting it for free with Bioshock Infinite just made it all the better.EDIT:I had to change my opinion of this game with Enemy Within.  While I greatly enjoyed the vanilla game, getting half my squad killed off by freakin sectoids in the second ground mission while they were in cover made me rage quit.  I started a new game, lost 4 guys to critical hits (all four shots) from SECTOIDS (the lowest enemy) while they were in low cover on HIGH GROUND.I really do enjoy the vanilla game, but the expansion diffuclty on flipping EASY ramps up so hard and so fast that it isn't even fun.  It's like the game wants you to quit, uninstall, and then kill yourself.EDIT 2:I really want you all to know that I really did want to enjoy this game.  I tried so HARD to enjoy it.  After writing the preceeding I decided that maybe it was a chance of fate and so I decided to not only fire up another game, but install a mod that takes away the "Alpha Strike" that the AI gives itself by allowing the aliens to move to cover after you encounter them.  Even with this advantage, on mission freaking ONE the opening mission of the campaign after the tutorial they killed two guys on my squad from INSANE ranges with ♥♥♥♥ing pistols (Sectoids) on turn freakin THREE.  Know what?  Done.  I wish I could get my money back for this xpac.  It's really giving me that old feeling I'd get when I would play Starcraft back in the day and I would just.. know.. that I was playing a cheater with a multiplayer trainer.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2012
												It's not classic X-COM and you might be disappointed if you are looking for a graphically updated carbon copy of the original--- one of the best games ever known to man.This game is far simpler and faster-paced. It makes good use of cover, flanking, and suppression mechanics that weren't part of the original series. The actual tactical gameplay is more of a mix between X-Com, tabletop DnD4e, and every FPS that involves a lot of cover. The devs said they wanted it to feel like a tabletop while still being a fun single-player experience. That's more or less what we got.So yeah, XCOM is not X-Com.On the other hand, this is probably the best TBS title in the past ten years. It is beautiful, fast-paced, and fun. Ironman on "impossible" difficulty was terrible for my nerves and I loved it.9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												I like this game. It tells a story on its own. It is hard - given the right options. When you know how to play, I recommend Iron Man and difficult. It is intense to lose a soldier, you are already very familiar with, but it gives you the right kicks to think and protect and plan properly. Without the load option, you will always commence and never retry the same difficult situation over and over again. Sometimes evacuation becomes a valuable option, to save what is left of your team. And there is the uphill fight, when your experienced soldiers are gone and you need to rely on s.h.i.v.s to get at least some resources for consolidation.Well balanced strategy-game, easy to learn, fun to master.10/10 will fight with s.h.i.v.s again.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												XCOM is a grid-based tactical game with some fun unit management.  A grid is a two dimensional field in which everything is partitioned off into tiles which all take up the exact same amount of space and have the same shape.  Each tile is arranged on the grid such that it's position in relation to all other tiles is exactly the same as any other tile's position in relation to the tiles that surround it.  Grids can continue on in any direction for as long as they need to.  You can think of grids as a sort of pattern that can be extended or cut short (made shorter or longer), but the pattern will stay the same.  Grids do not need to have a consistent shape, but the patterning of the tiles does need to remain consistent.  If you are still having trouble grasping the idea of grid I can suggest some additional reading:Metric Spaces by Thomas Wieting (2013) [people.reed.edu/~wieting/essays/MetricSpaces.pdf]The Amazing World of Grids by Harold Svenberg (1957)Grids and Lowest Level Computational Methods by Paul Moore (1989)http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Gridhttp://etc.usf.edu/clipart/42600/42677/grid_42677_lg.gifIf you are still having trouble grasping the concept of grids I suggest you go back and re-read my introductory paragraph with the knowledge that you now have from your additional readings.  Yeah, I realize that that's a bit of a cop-out but I'm kind of at a loss for how to explain this any more clearly to you.  I really thing that you must be overthinking this, a grid is not something that you normally have to explain to people at all.  Even with children who do not know what a grid is you can show them some examples and they'll get the basic idea.  I mean you certainly don't need to be some sort of grid guru just to understand what I'm going to be saying in this review.  You really just need a basic understanding and some common knowledge.Sorry, I think I came off a bit condescending there.  Let's try this again.  I know you can get this if you just take it slow and try to think critically.  Grids are made up of tiles, tiles are arranged inside of the grid in a constant pattern.  Really the tiles are just subdivisions of the area that the grid covers, a way of splitting up the space into many different parts that all have the same size and shape.Now come on, don't be so hard on yourself, I KNOW you can do this!  You've come this far and I can't let you give up.  I want you to think about grids for an hour each day until you finally have a firm grasp on the matter.  All I ask is one hour.  Return once you've completed that for me, and good luck!Well congratulations, you did it!  I know this road must have been long and hard for you but I think that you've achieved something truly remarkable.  I'm proud of you and I encourage you to be proud of yourself.  You've worked hard enough, go ahead and take the rest of the day off, as a present to yourself.  You've earned it!  Then once you've rested up get out there and seize the day with your newfound familiarity with grids!

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown...pfff...more adecuate name is  FRUSTRATION and SUFFER simulatorPOSSIBLE SPOILERSLet's take a look on some aspects of this game.Just my conclusions.A.   I've been customizing my entire squad for at least 30min, given them most advanced tech so far. They were just like the expendables even mustache was there. But 2 rounds later half of them was gone, some fuc.... fagg... with a few crapy friends took them out like they were nothing.        Lesson learned....no emotional relationships=no customization B.  If you think everything is going according to plan.....you are absolutely wrong. I'm still suffering psychic breakdown when my entire New Team was turned into a zombie horde.        Lesson learned...never ever help Washington...C.  In the moment you encounter new enemy game changes from strategic shooter to awful slaughterhouse of elite soldiers .    Lesson learned...magnesium is a mineral that helps stabilizing blood pressure in your vains and prevents from heartattackThese are just few of Pros within this glorious gameThere is just one big problem i'm still thinking about...you can't nuke the mothership like in INDEPENDENCE DAY...ahh...i wish i could nuke'em allTotal conclusion...if you find joy in ever lasting trauma and psychic torture this game will suits you. If not ...you may find joy in slaughtering invading aliens and protecting our motherland. Post trauma included, lousy troopers as well. And never name your precious sniper Taylor Swift ....i've achieved some painful scars when she left me ...stupid floater...    10/10 IGN aprove's    : never felt like this before happy and frustrated in the same moment ....must have9-10/10 D. Trump's astonished  : this solves everything

												(8 out of 10)Remake of the old XCOM: Enemy Unkown from the early 90's which was one of my favorite tactical strategy games on the Commodore Amiga.This remake is surprisingly good. Once you learn how to play you always want to finish a mission to gather enough items for resarch from shot down UFO's or just to know how the story unfolds. The graphic is mostly below current standards, the last mission is a drag and the once randomized levels from the old one is replaced with premade maps, but aside from that it a very enjoyable game.

Posted: July 21, 2014
												X-COM: Enemy Unknown 91/100... How do I love Thee? Shall I count the ways (that was Shakespearean prose right there)... I grew up with the original X-Com and subsequent sequels; I grew up with the great game developer Microprose. I grew up in the golden age of OG (original gamer) gaming, DOS prompts, configuring your memory so you could play the games you wanted, back then it was not easy to play the games you owned. But, you found a way. But onto this new game, X-COM: Enemy Unknown; the spiritual successor to X-COM: UFO Defense. It is a great game that plays how it should. It has all the markings of a Grade-A , 2014, 3D-Powerhouse, plus game mechanics that have been lost to players for almost over two decades…that’s 20 years. If you Play this game, you will not regret it. My hours played is only since playing on my Laptop, I have beaten the game on Xbox-360.

												This game is a must ownPro:Few games scratch the surface of what this game is able to do. It is incrediably addictive, and has many great elements. For one the perma-death system is great. It is something that gives you the sence of nervousness as one of your best soliders is put into the frey of battle. content:
Posted: April 14
												Once, I was playing on Normal Difficulty on Vanilla Enemy Unknown. I was on my fifth-or-so mission, and had two star snipers, Sergeants Boris Smirnov and Irina Sokolova. Both were Russian, and both were total BADASSES.Then, lots of hours later, I was invading an Alien Supply Barge. I had Colonel "Ice" Smirnov and Colonel "The Black Widow" Sokolova tagging along. I sent Sokolova out to cover our backs, as her sniper rifle could kill stuff from​ afar. After an initial firefight, Sokolova was reconning a bit behind my main five squad. She heard a sound a bit to her left, and guess what-About three Mutons were waiting for her. She was incapacitated within a minute.I went into total panic mode. I called the entire squad to rescue her. Smirnov used his grappling hook to provide sniper support and pick off the mutons. I had Colonel Park, my support guy and designated medic rush to her aid. I had my assault guys be the spearhead for the entire rescue operation. I had my heavy close behind.Sokolova was gonna die in two turns. By that time, 3 of the 5 mutons were dead.Sokolova was gonna die in one turn. All of the mutons were now dead. Park rushed to Sokolova to revive her.But alas, even when he dashed, he couldn't​ reach her in time.Ms. Irina "Black Widow" Sokolova, 46 kills, 24 missions bled out the very next turn.I stared at the screen in disbelief.Then I shouted Sokolova's name. I had grown attached​ to her throughout the game. It pained me to see her dead.This is the kind of thing the game will do to you. Indulge yourself and play it.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												If you came here looking for a classic x-com game, you came to the wrong place. The aliens may be the same, and in fact I'd say they did a good job of updating all the aliens to be something new and unique, but this has almost none of the traditional x-com charm and difficulty. Everything is based on a very simple cover system... either you're in cover, or you're not. You don't shoot in the direction of enemies, like you do in the original games, but rather you shoot at a single enemy, and either you hit, or you miss. If you miss, you might get lucky and blow up their cover.The game operates on a mob group system. Aliens are in groups, and if they spot you, they get a cinematic in which they run in to cover. This means that if a group of aliens has not seen you this turn, they will not shoot you during their turn, so the threat is minimal. Even at the start of the game, you're fielding a squad of 4 guys vs. many aliens. Later on you go up to a whopping 6, making the aliens feel very weak... how are we even losing this war?All that said, if you take away the xcom, the game is a functional TBT. It's fairly decent, and can be quite enjoyable. If you're looking for x-com, skip it and go buy xenonauts, or go help out with any of the open source fan projects out there. Sadly, the game is also riddled with bugs. Sometimes you will be unable to shoot an enemy, even though they can shoot you. Sometimes your troops will end up walking somewhere they can't go, resulting in them being stuck for the mission if they can't fly. There's many others, especially in multiplayer, so only get it if you're interested in TBT. It's a good introduction of the genre to those who wouldn't normally play such.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												This is a review for the XCOM along with all the dlc's, so that means XCOM: Enemy Within.So far, this game is fantastic, very unique gameplay compare to basic turn based strategy games. Variety of options included for those who wants a challenge or simply prefer the game easier. This game does have a multiplayer as well, but I have not yet tested that out, the singleplayer however, is simply amazing.The game involves you controlling a squad of members, taking cover and strategic positions on the battlefield while attempting to make tactical decisions focusing on objective as well as keeping your squad alive. There are several classes as well, base classes are Assault, Support, Heavy, and Sniper. You can genetically modify those classes or even machin-nize your soldiers to make them exceed farther. As game progresses, the game also requires you to research and construct facilities in order to advance in both tech and more of overall diplomatic control. One of the game's biggest element are countries under the council, as aliens attack, you would be force to make decisions that pro's one of the countries but con's the other countries, ultimately influencing the panic level. When a panic level hits 5 bars, a country would likely to leave the XCOM project, making it so they no longer can fund you. When a certain number of countries leave XCOM, the game is over.Graphic: 8/10Explanation: The performance is very well done, and I do enjoy the action-figure type of graphic, the FPS caps at 62 for smooth, that isn't a problem for me. However, I believe there's space for graphic improvement, overall a 8 which is pretty godo.Plot: 7/10Explanation: The game does have pretty good plot overall, however, XCOM in my opinion is one of those games where you play for the gameplay and the research, spending time trying to find out why aliens are attacking. So plot is less reliant when it comes to overall feel.Gameplay: 10/10Explanation: The gameplay is absolutely amazing, first of all it's pretty unique compare to modern day's games, it combines RTS aspects with turn based TRPG. Really polished, always neat stuff to look forward to, and overall if you enjoy strategy games, I would say you would like this as well. The sci-fi theme is a plus for me.Replayability: 8/10Explanation: This is more sort of my current feel with the game, with Second Wave (Additional Game Options) I would certainly not mind replaying a game maybe twice for a different route and a different result, as for others I can certainly see less replay value for them. I would not rely however, on multiplayer for replayability over singleplayer.Overall: 9/10Conclusion: Great game, if you are considering or wondering rather or not to get this game, don't think about it, add it to your cart right now. I got it during the steam sale from around $25 along with all the dlc's, which was a steal, at full price it is very well worth every penny. One thing I would say is, don't get too attach to your squad, they will most likely die hehe.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												An excellent tactical strategy game that controls great with a controller or keyboard and mouse. This is like a modernized version of the original XCOM from the early - mid 1990's. This game is a combination of "Men in Black" with the space marines from "Aliens". It can be fun for unexperienced gamers and if you want a real challenge you can turn up the difficulty to match the original game's difficulty. Also, if you want to unlock everything, you can spend many hours of gameplay just to do so. I also recommend getting the expansion "XCOM: Enemy Within" because it adds more enemies, more technology, mechs, bio-engineered soldiers, and  a few other surprises. It also adds an enemy human faction, but they seem to be very easy to beat most of the time. If you find the gameplay fun from the "XCOM: Enemy Unknown" then the expansion will be enjoyable too.You are the only line of defense against the alien invaders. Be prepared for the onslaught.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												This game is an absolute masterpiece. While not a direct update of the original, and lacking some of the strategic depth (base building for defense, multiple bases, etc.) the meta game is addictive and satisfying - giving you that "just one more turn" feeling.The tactical combat is the best I've ever seen (and I play a lot of strategy games!). With all the classes and equipment, multiple levelling up paths, and particularly the Enemy Within content (genetic modification and cyborgs - hells yes!), you always feel like you are getting more powerful - and the enemies difficulty scales up with you!My only complaint for Xcom original harcores is that the line of site and mind control mechanics are a bit rough around the edges (if you try to storm entrenched aliens from above, you're going to have a bad time!). And one final thought - even though I am a PC-first gamer - you have to play this one with a controller. UI is so much slicker and more precise (especially when moving in tactical battles) - and you have to try zooming in on your base and see your soldiers hanging out and training - never even figured out how to do it with keyboard and mouse!Both main game and Enemy Within are must buys for any strategy gamer!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												XCOM is a serious game that takes itself seriously. Between trying to manage a base and trying to win battles out on the field of combat, the entire experience comes together beautifully. Its not the type of game I can play day, as its actually quite stressing at times, yet its the game I find myself picking up again and again. Its challenging, bordering on needlessly brutal, but its the type of game that inspires you to get better and play on harder difficulties in order to overcome even worse odds.If you find yourself wishing that strategy games were less about who could click the fastest and spam the hardest, and offered a more tactical, thoughtful approach, then this is the type of game for you. They don't make too many like this anymore, and I wish they did.I am impatiently waiting for news of a second full game in this reboot series. Firaxis, you hit gold with this one - do it again!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown offers a lot of fun for fans of turn based, tactical game play. It has good level design, interesting game mechanics, with smart(ish) AI that can offer you a challenge. You will get emotionally attached to your squad of heroes as you level them up and unlock new technologies. You will weep and want to through yourself from the highest building when they get slaughtered by Mutons or mind-controlled only to be turn on your own guys.My only real critique of this game is that the maps aren't procedurally generated, thus you're sure to see the same maps over and over, with various permutations in terms of enemies encountered - but this isn't enough to develop the one-size-fits-all strategy you can develop for each map.Graphics: 6/10. Offers some visually pleasing graphics, but won't blow you away like games running on the latest Unreal engines.Story: 5/10. It's a generic story of "Aliens invade Earth and we need to stop them. ZOMG HOW DO WE DO THAT? I know, let's form an elite team of heroes to take on the entire invasion."AI: 8/10. If you make a mistake, the game WILL punish you - severely. Though once you get your squad to higher levels with better equipment the game does get dumbed down a bit.Game Mechanics: 7/10. Interesting game mechanics, from the turn based strategy to the macro management of your base to the micro management of your squad.Overall: 7.5/10. Fun game, with a multitude of different modes, but the same maps over and over gets old, fast.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												XCOM integrates a lot of interesting features and systems into its gameplay. I was looking forward to playing it for its tactical turn-based combat system, but found myself having more fun with the base management, research and engineering system. However, it does not come without any faults, I encountered numerous bugs, ranging from the non-saving options menu (that I have to re-configure each time I play) to buggy in-game user interface. The meat of the game, tactical turn-based combat, was an OK experience (Line of sight system isn't perfect, sometimes an alien is right in front of you and your soldier can't see them, I didn't enjoy the Overwatch mechanic, and randomly activating 3 alien camps with one movement is not fun). The best part of this game is the squad system, you get to customize and outfit all your soldiers;  there being different classes, abilities trees, weapons and equipment.Sidenote: I do criticize Firaxis for releasing XCOM: Enemy Within as a standalone game on consoles, but on PC you have to buy the $32 base game XCOM: Enemy Unknown before you can play the $32 Enemy Within, which is just the same campaign as XCOM:EU with some extra missions and updates. I would recommend XCOM: EU, but buy Enemy Within only if you like the base game and if it goes on sale.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Possibly the most organic dual-mode game that has come out in the past few years.  The strategic mode leaves you researching and contructing a bunch of toys to use and looking forward to the missions where you'll get new resources and things to research, and the tactical missions leave you with new enemy after new enemy and all sorts of items to bring back.  It evokes the feel of the original very well.  I'm not the biggest fan of the change to a much more colourful and Fisher-Price type look of the tech and in particular the weapons, which all look like childrens toys, but otherwise the visual look and feel is implemented very well and perhaps just as importantly consistently.  The game just gels very well together in terms of gameplay, visual design, and sound design.  The production values are high and so is the fun.  The only real thing I felt was a misstep other than some elements of the visual design is the difficulty.  While the original could be tortuous sometimes and some scaling back was probably neccesary in today's gaming market, the game is actually pretty easy on all but the highest difficulty, as long as you stick with troops with good stats and stay on top of research and production of new weapons.  One of the disappointing things for me in that regards was the chrysallids.  In the original they were Aliens-inspired creatures that would zombify your men or civillians, and when you killed the zombie a new chrysallid would emerge.  It made things very frantic when you saw one.  Comparatively, the new chrysallids look and feel very different.  While they do have an instant-kill melee attack (the originals actually didnt, except insofar as they hit like a brick s**thouse), the zombies are mostly unthreatening enemies and there's no extra chrysallid when you kill them.  It effective neuters what was one of the original games greatest threats, because of how quickly a chrysallid could ambush and spawn more chrysallids.Those gripes aside, its an engaging and well-done game which remains a time sink for me to this day.  The only turn-based strategy game in the last decade which has had me going "just one more turn"

content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												There's a stereotype that games make you turn OFF your brain, and are a mindless slug through mundane, disengaging setpieces, This game is a living, breathing, tangible contradiction to that claim. In this part turn-based startegy part base management game, you protect Earth from an invading alien force. Sound familiar? Just another alien game? Rest assured, this game is much more than it appears to be, and is a rare treat for tose looking for a game that pushes you cognitive abilities. I have never felt my brain go into strategic-overdrive as it did when I played this game. Fair-warning, this game does NOT hold your hand, and to avoid losing (that's right, you can LOSE a 20 hour game) you'll have to be both quick-witted and an effective  base manager. Only those who conduct the proper research, manage resources and money efficiently, smartly equip their soldiers, and maintain their relationships with the countries in the XCOM council will succeed in their turn-based skirmishes, where players control up to six marines to eliminate the alien threat.The duality of this game is one of its strengths, as the ground battles and the base management go hand-in-hand. Didn't invest in the titan armor research? Well I guess your soldiers are going to perish an unnatural death down on the ground. Failed to protect a member of the council on an important mission? Well I guess Nigeria is pulling out of the XCOM project and thus cutting its funding. Speaking of failure, that is also another one of the game's strengths, and something you'll be deeply terrified of. You can name and customize your soldiers, and eventually you become attached to them (think pokemon), arming your favorite guy to the teeth and giving him a badass nickname. And these soldiers will go through Hell, facing a mulitude of different alien classes, each with completely distinct looks and effective strategies to use againts. However, your precious characters can die permenantly in these missions if you don't do everything with clockwork effiency. That same urgency extends to the diplomatic side of the game. If you screw up to many times, enough nations will leave the council and you LOSE. This sort of challenge is rare in modern games and is a welcome revival.All in all, if you're looking for a exhilerating game that engages your brain, tis one's for you.

												Pros:- Mechanics- Varied strategic possibilities- RPG elements and upgrade paths- Variety of maps- Combat & variety of enemies/weapons- Base management- Overall gameplay- Replay value- Balanced difficulty and Iron man modeCons:- No sneaking up on enemies (without specific armor)- Some starting location bonuses are quite trivial- On higher difficulties, the small margin of error will be forcing you to be VERY careful and keep  stalling behind cover, which may become a bit tediousReally, a great game: if you like turn-based strategy games, upgrading your squad, managing your base and progressing through a game with ramping up challenge level towards the endgame, you're gonna love this game. Additionally, this game actually has a quite good replay value being a single player game, due the fun, tactical gameplay and randomly-generated missions and different maps.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												XCOM is a serious game that takes itself seriously. Between trying to manage a base and trying to win battles out on the field of combat, the entire experience comes together beautifully. Its not the type of game I can play day, as its actually quite stressing at times, yet its the game I find myself picking up again and again. Its challenging, bordering on needlessly brutal, but its the type of game that inspires you to get better and play on harder difficulties in order to overcome even worse odds.If you find yourself wishing that strategy games were less about who could click the fastest and spam the hardest, and offered a more tactical, thoughtful approach, then this is the type of game for you. They don't make too many like this anymore, and I wish they did.I am impatiently waiting for news of a second full game in this reboot series. Firaxis, you hit gold with this one - do it again!

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												This game is an absolute masterpiece. While not a direct update of the original, and lacking some of the strategic depth (base building for defense, multiple bases, etc.) the meta game is addictive and satisfying - giving you that "just one more turn" feeling.The tactical combat is the best I've ever seen (and I play a lot of strategy games!). With all the classes and equipment, multiple levelling up paths, and particularly the Enemy Within content (genetic modification and cyborgs - hells yes!), you always feel like you are getting more powerful - and the enemies difficulty scales up with you!My only complaint for Xcom original harcores is that the line of site and mind control mechanics are a bit rough around the edges (if you try to storm entrenched aliens from above, you're going to have a bad time!). And one final thought - even though I am a PC-first gamer - you have to play this one with a controller. UI is so much slicker and more precise (especially when moving in tactical battles) - and you have to try zooming in on your base and see your soldiers hanging out and training - never even figured out how to do it with keyboard and mouse!Both main game and Enemy Within are must buys for any strategy gamer!

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												A priceless gem. In this day and age, finding a modern tactical game that feels really smooth yet holds the best old games have to offer and doesn't hold any hands, is something really noteworthy.In addition to tactical gunplay and overlying mechanics that feel really live and authentic (including that your soldiers *will* die, no matter how high they've levelled up), there's cool "hub" management going on, where you build different facilities that benefit differently, R&D weapons, aircrafts and other equipment. And all resources actually have huge worth here, no inflation like in other games.Cool game if you're ok with games actually giving you something to decide, not hold hands through a magical journey.And the alien-xenophobic setting is pretty cool, haven't seen that much after the x-files.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												X-Com: Enemy Unknown is not quite the easiest game to get into and not as self-explanatory as it could be, but the four things it is should be more than enough to warrant a recommendation. It's unique, it's intuitive, it's absorbing and it's a hell of a lot of fun. The game is essentially a strategy RPG where you have to plan every move you make meticulously and with attention to military squad and cover tactics, but you have to manage the back end as well. Engaging in a bit of building and management simulation akin to a 4x game to make sure that your troops are able to keep up with the enemy's technology levels. It's incredibly engaging to pull off a perfect mission, or have to make difficult decisions where one side of the game has to make sacrifices for the other. The game can be very unfair or even luck-based at times, but it's easy to get back into and it can make hopeless battles if not fun then still engaging and rewarding on a more personal level (in an emergent storytelling sort of way). Consider this one a strong general recommendation, walking a perfect line between accessibility and compexity.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												XCOM is more than just a turn-based strategy game. You begin as a mostly weak military organization set to keep alien invasions at bay. As you complete missions and capture and examine aliens, you can research and acquire their technology to make yourself even more powerful. Begin with a group of rookies shooting with cheap assault rifles and end with a team of elite soldiers with plasma weaponry, advanced armor that lets you climb up walls, and psionic abilities to decimate alien opponents.Investments and time management are a necessity in normal mode and absolutely critical in the game's famous "Classic" mode, which requires several difficult decisions and sacrifices to complete the game successfully. XCOM is a fun and challenging time on its own in this respect apart from the already excellent combat system.XCOM: Enemy Within is also a great "true" expansion to the game that adds lots of great weapons and story content. It's a hell of a lot more relevant than today's cheap DLC injections into every video game. Try Ironman Mode for an extra challenge. Every decision you make sticks to one auto save, so you can't reload if you make a mistake.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Possibly the most organic dual-mode game that has come out in the past few years.  The strategic mode leaves you researching and contructing a bunch of toys to use and looking forward to the missions where you'll get new resources and things to research, and the tactical missions leave you with new enemy after new enemy and all sorts of items to bring back.  It evokes the feel of the original very well.  I'm not the biggest fan of the change to a much more colourful and Fisher-Price type look of the tech and in particular the weapons, which all look like childrens toys, but otherwise the visual look and feel is implemented very well and perhaps just as importantly consistently.  The game just gels very well together in terms of gameplay, visual design, and sound design.  The production values are high and so is the fun.  The only real thing I felt was a misstep other than some elements of the visual design is the difficulty.  While the original could be tortuous sometimes and some scaling back was probably neccesary in today's gaming market, the game is actually pretty easy on all but the highest difficulty, as long as you stick with troops with good stats and stay on top of research and production of new weapons.  One of the disappointing things for me in that regards was the chrysallids.  In the original they were Aliens-inspired creatures that would zombify your men or civillians, and when you killed the zombie a new chrysallid would emerge.  It made things very frantic when you saw one.  Comparatively, the new chrysallids look and feel very different.  While they do have an instant-kill melee attack (the originals actually didnt, except insofar as they hit like a brick s**thouse), the zombies are mostly unthreatening enemies and there's no extra chrysallid when you kill them.  It effective neuters what was one of the original games greatest threats, because of how quickly a chrysallid could ambush and spawn more chrysallids.Those gripes aside, its an engaging and well-done game which remains a time sink for me to this day.  The only turn-based strategy game in the last decade which has had me going "just one more turn"
