content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												Games have changed tremendously since I was a child in the early 90s. Then was a time of experimentation, freshness, and a lack of corporate handlers ready to strangle the life out of anyone who dared to be a rogue. I could chalk these recollections up to nostalgia and my young age at the time, but I don't think so. It was really different.Today we've settled into a stale rut of standard genres: RPG, FPS, Sim, etc, and they all rehash the same principles, the same ideas, over and over. It's a stinking pile of zero innovation, a soulless churning out of reskin after reskin where gamers are forced to eat up the latest iteration of crap distributed by *insert mega publisher here.*But X-Com is different. It feels new. Unique. And above all, it feels fun. After sinking a few hours into the game and becoming absorbed in its intricacies, I realized how I had almost forgotten that word in gaming. There hasn't been a game like it since the originals on floppy disk. And chances are if you're reading this than you're too young to have played them back when they were a big deal. So pick this one up. Sure, it would be unfair to say that games never attempt to innovate anymore, but the vast majority of those that do just aren't GOOD. This isn't a bad thing- anything that deviates from the status quo will be met failure more often than success. But X-Com is the outlier. In recent years (read: the last 15 or so), the only games that have accomplished similar sentiments on my insides are gems like Eternal Darkness or Total War or MechWarrior when they were first released. Games that felt entirely different and had never before seen mechanics that just worked. Take note, that is some good company to be in.X-Com's one drawback is the cheesiness. It runs so rampant throughout the game that I not only smell it, but taste it. But we all enjoy a little bit of cheese every now and then, and like a good Frenchman, the game manages to erase its stench with the cologne of absorbing gameplay.I won't get in to the nuts and bolts of the game. I don't want to ruin it for you. Especially if you were too young to play the first. In a world of jaded gamers, sometimes the best route is to hear a game is awesome and then play it yourself. That way, you can be surprised once again. Take it. It's an experience rare enough in gaming these days.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												An excellent tactical strategy game that controls great with a controller or keyboard and mouse. This is like a modernized version of the original XCOM from the early - mid 1990's. This game is a combination of "Men in Black" with the space marines from "Aliens". It can be fun for unexperienced gamers and if you want a real challenge you can turn up the difficulty to match the original game's difficulty. Also, if you want to unlock everything, you can spend many hours of gameplay just to do so. I also recommend getting the expansion "XCOM: Enemy Within" because it adds more enemies, more technology, mechs, bio-engineered soldiers, and  a few other surprises. It also adds an enemy human faction, but they seem to be very easy to beat most of the time. If you find the gameplay fun from the "XCOM: Enemy Unknown" then the expansion will be enjoyable too.You are the only line of defense against the alien invaders. Be prepared for the onslaught.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												XCOM is a solid if frustrating strategy game that makes you really squeeze every last drop out of every available resource to win the missions it keeps throwing at you.But the real strength of XCOM is when you name the generic soldiers you recruit as your units. Naming them makes them stand out as individuals rather than drones and makes you genuinely invested in them.I high recommend it because it's so well designed to draw out those moments where your best team is getting slaughtered and you're on edge every single time it's the alien's turn, wondering who you might lose next.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
-Quick Review-XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a Turn based strategy game, which prioritizes on micromanagement skills, coupled with sound field decisions and employ's many rogue type elements. In short: it's a Sci-fi strategy game.-Detailed breakdown review-Story:  You're the worlds primary defense against Alien Invasion, you are the leader of the XCOM Project. Your job is simple: beat the aliens. But accomplishing that task isn't so simple, you need t keep the world nations calm, research technology, and then have your engineers create whatever the scientists have cooked up.Game Play: Game play is where this game really shines, the graphics are fun to see, it's easy to implement many unorthodox strategies, you get to customize your base, but the most important investment of your resources will be in weapons and armor.It is very important to emphases the difficulty of this game; unless you happen to be some military genius or a natural at this game (either could be true, and you still need to save before and after each battle) you will need to save your progress and reload from that save state. On the easiest difficulty the aliens will have no problem blowing up the poor S.O.B. you left out of cover because you misclicked... Trust me, he/she will be dead or in uselessly low health.By the end of this game I had recovered a terrible habit/condition... called "Save before you do anything". I developed this habit while playing Pokemon and Knights of the Old Republic. Upon playing this game I was saving before and after every battle.Achievements: There are the standard achievement type: Beat the game, beat the game on the hardest difficulty, do this unique thing while playing the game. There are also DLC achievements, so you will need to own the DLC if you want to get 100% completion.Conclusion: All in all, I have really enjoyed this game, and will definitely be spending more time working on the harder difficulties. This game can easily be put in the top Tiers of Strategy games that were developed in 2010-2015.To recap: Story - Interesting, not really the selling point, but doesn't take away from it. Gameplay, very good - much micromanaging. Achievements, 50-60% easily obtainable just from playing, the rest are rough or DLC.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												define: ambiguousXCOM is a good game. And it could be soooo much better. Enter: a mod for the rescue.The game offers a strategical management-layer with a time-compression feature and turn-based tactical missions in which you have to fight aliens with your squads. This combination works well and keeps you coming back. It starts great: there is a lot to do (research, building equipment, managing your soldiers...), the slick interface is doing its magic, you get your first valuable veterans, your abilities increase and everything is new and shiny. Nice pace and a good sense of progression.And then you notice the first oddities: the line-of-sight system is a joke. This game creates its very own reality and logic, but it's easy enough to adapt to this. You will get a feeling for this weird reality. The cover system works despite being laughable at times and being far from realistic.This game has countless little weaknesses. The strategic layer suffers a bit from being extremely streamlined. The game is keeping you busy with artificial difficulty and urgency. The panic system is erratic and a big cluster♥♥♥♥ of frustrating randomness. I did not feel threatened by aliens assaulting Earth but screwed by the developers. The late-game is lacking in content, as if they made the game and then cut away the "Enemy Within" expansion. It's disappointing and left me behind unsatisfied.Still I highly recommend the game despite all its weaknesses. It's a flawed gem and it can really suck you in. The tactical missions are exciting and reward bold moves just as much as they have a tendency to punish you for not being careful. Here eliminating the randomness becomes a satisfying challenge (destroy the cover first, finish off the enemy AFTER). It gives you perks and equipment to react to new threats and keeps things interesting. On the strategical layer the rigid schedule of scripted events makes for a more beginner-friendly experience. Many people will appreciate the ease that comes with a somewhat predictable course of events. Like it always is: the strengths of the game really highlight the weaknesses. And at the end of the day it is among the limited number of games i have finished more than once without ever being bored. Just don't expect a faithful recreation of the old XCOM games.The expansion addresses the lack of content, but most problems persist. All that being said: I highly recommend the mod "Long War" (EW required!). It overhauls the game in many aspects. It will give you a much deeper experience. It turns XCOM from an "Invasion Simulator Light" into a well thought out strategy game with a great sense of consequence. It forces you to think and actually punishes you for messing up. But it also gives you the chance to undo your mistakes. And suddenly you really feel like you are defending Earth against terrifying aliens. It's what veterans crave!

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												XCOM's focus is on single-player and in this day and age is a good thing! The long campaign is challenging enough on Normal, with a big leap in enemy threat and movement on Classic - both of which are enhanced immeasurably by Ironman mode, which removes the temptation to save-cheat. The last difficulty level, Impossible, rightly so, your soldiers will die, a lot! This game is a winner. So much craft has gone into its atmosphere, into small details that together add enormous depth and flavour to the world: the occasional conversations overheard while fiddling around in the base; the mission loading screen, which gives you a view of the troops inside the carrier, fidgeting and tapping their feet in transit; soldiers acquiring nicknames after a few missions; the memorial room for fallen warriors, with a cork board of photos on the wall, which records their names. Near the campaign's end, there's a direct tribute to the original game's designers, the Gollop brothers, accompanied by an achievement called 'On the Shoulders of Giants'. It's a beautiful touch, a nod from one development team to another across the generations. They have something in common now. In their own time and place, each made a fantastic game called XCOM.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												I've never played the XCOM franchise before this game so I cannot compare this one to it's predecesors and neither can I judge the franchise as a whole, but I WILL tell you that this is an amazingly fun strategy game. As you can see from the store page; you are the leader of a worldwide anti-alien organisation and it's up to YOU to keep your troops alive and save the planet from their invasion.IN SHORT:GOOD+ The gameplay starts of quite simple but get's more complex and incredibly hard later on, especially on higher difficulties! Great game to just step into without any prior information. No manual needed.+ First playthrough took me over 40 hours to beat.+ Simple but engaging story. Aliens invade earth and you're going to stop them. Characters are a bit stereotypical, but the voice acting and music make it all very endearing and fun.+ Atmosphere is incredible for a top-down turn based game. You really feel the pressure of surviving and trying to complete your objective with little to no casualties. Every decision feels heavy and important; they really nailed that feeling here.+ Mission variation. There is not a whole lot of it, but the many different maps, scenario's and objectives make it a fun experience for most of the playthrough. Might get a bit repetitive later on if you're trying to max out everything in your base though, expect to do some grinding for that.+ Overal Quality. It's a very polished game with good graphics and great interface. The tutorial is short but sufficient and the rest speaks for itself.+ Creating and customizing your own team is SUPER FUN. There arent a billion options to choose from but it's fleshed out enough to make you spend some time trying to recreate you best friends as supersoldiers! + The Enemy Within DLC is actually worth buying. It's not as great of an expension as say the Elder Scrolls games. But still a bunch of extra content worthy to give the game another playthrough or two.+ The aliens are cool and unique. They all have their own strengths and weaknesses and figuring out how to deal with them best while doing scientific research about their bioligy feels as if you're really fighting an unknown enemy that you're slowly starting to understand better.+ Quite long. Quite hard. Expect to spend a lot of time on this one.NOT SO GOOD- Since this is a turn-based strategy game where your chance to hit is a roll of the dice, expect to get frustrated sometimes when your sniper with 95% accuracy misses 2 shots in a row. Can feel unfair, especially on higher difficulties.- After all aliens and weapons are introduced the game goes on for quite a while. More unlocks or enemies would make it feel less bland and repetitive near the end.- Though there's quite a lot of dialogue in the game, expect your collegues to repeat themselves a bit too much through the course of the game.- Though there is some variation in the missions, there are basically only 3 kinds: Exterminate all forces, save civilians or disarm the bomb. It's enough variation for the beginning of the game but can get really bland if you're playing too long in one sitting. I suggest taking breaks from this game so it feels more stimulating.- Story begins and ends rather abrubtly with little to no explenation to motives or origin of the aliens. - Even though I said earlier that the Enemy Within DLC is fun, it's also kinda bland without it. All the most awesome stuff like Mechs and and Geneticly-Enhanced soldiers are within the DLC so buying this game without it seems like a waste and you'll never want to replay the vanilla game again without it.- Even though Multiplayer let's you take control of aliens as well, there's not much reason to stick around after you've finished the single player campaign. I know some people LOVE the multiplayer though, so this is just my personal opinion.And that's it for XCOM, I hope this review helped you out! If you have any questions be sure to leave a comment!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												Games have changed tremendously since I was a child in the early 90s. Then was a time of experimentation, freshness, and a lack of corporate handlers ready to strangle the life out of anyone who dared to be a rogue. I could chalk these recollections up to nostalgia and my young age at the time, but I don't think so. It was really different.Today we've settled into a stale rut of standard genres: RPG, FPS, Sim, etc, and they all rehash the same principles, the same ideas, over and over. It's a stinking pile of zero innovation, a soulless churning out of reskin after reskin where gamers are forced to eat up the latest iteration of crap distributed by *insert mega publisher here.*But X-Com is different. It feels new. Unique. And above all, it feels fun. After sinking a few hours into the game and becoming absorbed in its intricacies, I realized how I had almost forgotten that word in gaming. There hasn't been a game like it since the originals on floppy disk. And chances are if you're reading this than you're too young to have played them back when they were a big deal. So pick this one up. Sure, it would be unfair to say that games never attempt to innovate anymore, but the vast majority of those that do just aren't GOOD. This isn't a bad thing- anything that deviates from the status quo will be met failure more often than success. But X-Com is the outlier. In recent years (read: the last 15 or so), the only games that have accomplished similar sentiments on my insides are gems like Eternal Darkness or Total War or MechWarrior when they were first released. Games that felt entirely different and had never before seen mechanics that just worked. Take note, that is some good company to be in.X-Com's one drawback is the cheesiness. It runs so rampant throughout the game that I not only smell it, but taste it. But we all enjoy a little bit of cheese every now and then, and like a good Frenchman, the game manages to erase its stench with the cologne of absorbing gameplay.I won't get in to the nuts and bolts of the game. I don't want to ruin it for you. Especially if you were too young to play the first. In a world of jaded gamers, sometimes the best route is to hear a game is awesome and then play it yourself. That way, you can be surprised once again. Take it. It's an experience rare enough in gaming these days.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												I'm a huge fan of the original XCOM and I consider it to be possibly the best game of all time. The mix of tactics and strategy, the ability to scare the daylights out of you, with tough missions and excellent rewards meant it still has a place on my hard drive ven today.So when they decided to change up the formula for the new XCOM, I was apprehensive. When I first played it, I thought it was good but not great. It just felt like it was missing too many tactical options. So while the game was certainly well done and a fresh new take on the series - while still remaining true to the turn based roots and source material - I felt it was missing something. I simply felt constrained by the tactical combat options. But it still is a solid game on its own. Just not a great one.But with the expansion, this game feels complete. It's still not as good as the original, but it stands on its own two feet and is a great gaming experience. The combat is the central part of the game and it's generally well done. There are irritants of course, but it's good - and once you get deeper into the game with the meld options it becomes fantastic. You can build your squad of soldiers and really shape your approach to combat.Plus, the production values in research, manufacturing and the overall story are pretty darn good too. These "add on" components aren't very deep, but you are forced to make difficult choices. Do you use that meld to boost your sniper or create a walking tank? Which nation do you sacrifice and who gets coverage from the alien invasion? Which mission do you go on? Do you try to save that soldier in a bad position or do you let him die? Meaningful choices are in every part of the game.Now you might ask what's the expansion versus the base game and why did it make it so much better? I'll leave it to you to get the feature list from the store page. But in my opinion it wasn't so much the quantity of what they added but what was added gives players enough options to really approach the tactical battles the way they'd like. Do you want super-soldiers? Or do you prefer tough guys enhanced by Aliens-style exoskelletons that can punch an alien through a wall? There are two big flaws in this game to me:1. The missions aren't always interesting enough. There's an early one involving a ship (that floats, not flies) that's incredibly well done. It's tight, tough and gripping. But that's the only real memorable mission in the game which is too bad. They could have done so much more with crafting some more interesting missions.2. I hate that when you find a group of enemies they call get to run for cover before the fighting starts. It's a "gamey" decision that detracts from proper planning by the player. Still, these are fairly minor warts given the fun I had with it. In my book the base game is solid and good. The expansion takes it to another level. It's still not as good as the original, but it's worthy of the name of the title and the best game of this style since the original.  This title - with the expansion - belongs in any gamer's library. Highly recommened.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												I cannot recommend this game. This is after having beaten Classic Ironman, too.As much as I'd like to enjoy it - and my god with the way everything is presented and the theoretical fun that you could have, I sure want to... but I simply cannot.Play through the game on normal difficulty, and you'll find that the game is way too easy. Step it up to classic, and throw in ironman too to make this game into somewhat of a challenge (and arguably the way it should be - with ironman) and you'll find yourself consistently fighting against AI which it feels like is constantly cheating.LoS is garbage in this game, your units behind even full cover will regularly get devastated by the aim bonus given to aliens on higher difficulties (I must reiterate that anything below classic is easy as♥♥♥♥♥♥ while you find yourself unable to land a single shot, and the way enemies spawn in packs is probably one of the most idiotic things I've ever seen.The enemy gets free bonuses to make up for ♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI and adds what could actually be called artifical difficulty, LoS is broken as all hell, and the way in which enemies spawn FORCES a playstyle in which you take a half step forward and then proceed to try and bait aliens backwards into your overwatched squad - which is not only stupid and repetitive, it's down right bad game design.I'm rather disgusted I paid full price for this piece of trash. Buy Xenonauts instead for a much better experience in which the AI beats you through smart play, not cheating. Alternatively, Frozen Synapse if you're looking for turn based multiplayer.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												XCOM: Enemy Within does not fail to deliver another dose of your favorite edge-of-your-seat alien killing franchise. The technology expansions for the human race fuel tremendous replay-ability, that will drive endless hours of entertainment. The new technologies still need some tweaking with respect to utilization by the alien species, the human use patterns are very well developed and will greatly enhance your ability to construct strategies, squads, etc. The addition of the human enemy faction is also enjoyable, but also needs some development with respect to additional missions. Ultimately, the game is entirely worth playing, but the price to value ratio is much better if you keep your eyes peeled for a sale.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												Plunging me right into the action the game opens up with a mission, being plunged into somthing you're not expecting and especially when you're unprepared is XCOM's specialty. Through my playthrough of this game I was absolutely never bored as it constantly presented me with choices, including where to put my money into, should I research lasers or autopsy an alien, but some of the most important decisions are presented at missions where you have to decide which countries to save from the alien threat. I found the game very enjoyable and it definetly leaves a lot of room for it's players to improve making the easy difficulty a challenge for anyone unfamiliar with Turn-Based Strategy, and increases up to the impossible difficulty where it takes the brainpower of Einstein to get through a single mission. Any looking at this game for mechanics will not be dissapointed, you're always faced with decisions during battle, should I risk the overwatch shot and get a better position, take a low-percentage shot, or grenade and not recover any artifacts. In all XCOM is an incredible game with great mechanics, fantastic graphics, and an unforgettable soundtrack I would recommend this to anyone and also encourage you to pick up the Enemy Within DLC.

content:

Posted: November 26, 2013
												Ever played Final Fantasy Tactics? This is waaay better! Manage your soldiers, assign new abilities as they increase in rank, build their weapons and shoot some aliens! No two matches feel the same, as the AI offers new challenges every time: as soon as you begin to feel comfortable there comes along a new species, forcing you to rethink your approach. What's better is that there is no single way to play the game, but you have to adapt to your base layout and to your soldiers' classes. Immersive game world, very detailed but not hard on your computer specs, so it's always very smooth. Beyond base management, research and engineering the battlefield is the game's strong point, and I guarantee you'll think the AI cheats when your colonel misses a 95% shot, and you'll swear and shout at the screen whenever your squad faces unforeseen annihilation; you will cry like a baby girl when you meet the Sectopod! Yeah, it's that immersive.Also consider getting the Enemy Within DLC, it expands the game adding maps and features like genetic mods and freakin' MECHS! Worth having but pricey, maybe wait for a sale as the base game is fine as it is, and that's saying A LOT in these days.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												Before I had played XCOM, I always thought it was a rogue-lite that lasts 10+ hours before you fail. The difficulty of XCOM had always dissuaded me from trying, which I think more people would love the game if they knew the challenge can be manageable.However, and this is said after I've finished a 19-hr Normal game and tried 15-hr of Classic Mode (with modifiers like ironman), I don't always think the game is fair with its difficulty. It can be very unfair with broken mechanics,  UI/camera problems and a steep difficulty spike from Normal to Classic. I won't say the unfairness ruins the game because I want the challenge, but they are all issues. My ideal solution of a difficulty is one that has the AI behavior of Classic but the leeway you have in Normal mode. (Something I've heard is possible with the Long War mod.)An Important NoteI do own the complete edition of XCOM, so while I have Enemy Within I have not played it.  I wanted to evaluate the merits of Enemy Unknown (around 30 hrs) before I evaluated what EW adds to EU.Also, one note about the cosmetics'/council-missions DLC: Buy them ONLY if you care for customizing your characters but do not buy them individually (either buy the base-game or complete pack).What the Game Does RightWhat Firaxis does considerably well is provide a more streamlined, accessible game for a hardcore niche title. I have tried XCOM: UFO Defense long ago, so I have experienced what the old games demanded of the player. So while I see how the base management, item-inventory and squad-sizes are less demanding, I think the game's focus on squad-tactics, resource-management and the action of XCOM makes for a fun game in its own right.The best way I can describe the game is that it's a Civilization's take on XCOM. (Barren on plot, heavy on gameplay and the personal-stories you can have from the gameplay.) To my surprise, there is a considerable variety of missions--though you'll mostly get three: Exterminate, Extract and Escort--when you include the randomized council missions to keep the game refressing even after 15+ hours.Normal (Recommended) vs. ClassicIf you are new to XCOM, I would suggest you begin at nothing lower than Normal (with saves). After your first win, you should enable no saves to keep yourself from reloading every turn. (i.e. Reloading for maximizing probabilities.) The only worry you have in Normal is of overpowering yourself if you prioritize the base-management/squad-upgrades. You can easily take away the tension. The early-game difficulty returns after the alien base-assault when the game brings its heavier units.Easing yourself into EU is not the only reason to start at Normal. You should have no problem managing finances for the base and squad-upgrades, so you'll also learn what to prioritize. You'll also learn which autopsies and interrogations give you bonus "research points" for other research. (The research is very similar to Civ 5, except with required materials for study.)Basically, the normal mode is to familiarize yourself with the mechanics and the game's glossary of enemies, the armory, and bonuses. Classic Mode is where most would say the true game is found. Enemy behaviors are greatly improved--Thin Men spit acid, Floaters actually fly up to flank you, etc.--and the early enemies are more threatening rather than being forgotten. (Like the Outsider.)You will fail if you start in Classic, and even after familiarizing yourself on Normal you probably won't reach the Alien Base assault for a while. Even with many of the Second Wave modifiers for difficulty, the Normal setting never gets as interesting as Classic.   In order to get that far, you also have to learn the shortcomings of EU.More Trigger Warnings than Tumblr All jokes aside, the best tactic is to let the enemy spot you, not to trigger their location. It's also the first example of how EU breaks its rules for a consistent challenge.For whatever reason, every time you spot an enemy they get to scatter freely and then attack you at the end of your turn. (Sometimes the enemy will sit still and you must trigger them.) The best solution is to either scout ahead with someone ghosted or use trackers to spot them from afar and hunker down.I don't have an issue with constant the two-second cinematic. What I do have a problem is how your units do not react similarly to spotting an enemy.Another related issue is Overwatch. Because of the isometric camera, you have to hope that when the alien is spotted that they'll be within range. This could easily be fixed with a range-setting to make it more useful than a prayer on a battlefield.The battlefields themselves also have issues. Sometimes the free-aiming system can be misleading when it comes to altitude. The transitioning of floors can make some encounters hard to distinguish what you can and cannot hit. And aliens can sometimes hide in the one corner in the map with one entrance.The most obvious broken system is the aiming system of XCOM. It never feels fair for me or the aliens for how simple it is. I think the aiming calculation could be less infuriating with its hit-or-miss system. For whatever reason, a sniper-rifle is treated the same as a shotgun or assault rifle. Hit or miss with some critical chance for hits.Here's one suggestion: Instead of all guns acting the same, we personalized guns to have a certain tactic. For example, the shotgun could have a wider spread (3 tiles) with the central line-of-sight (1 tile) that does the most damage. Too far away, it'll miss completely; up close, it will do some damage which is better than missing. (Snipers could stay the same. Assault rifles, with a burst fire, could have some medium spread while heavies would have the most spread.)Lastly, and a real big issue for Classic, the Recruits.  I consider them broken because if you lose your classed units, then you've lost. Recruits all start out with poor stats/equipment (aside from one Squaddie perk). They are randomly given a one of three classes AFTER they get one kill (which restricts them from using any weapon). It just adds needless padding; worse, it can end the game there.An XCOMplimishment Despite its FlawsWhat I think EU succeeds in is providing a unique experience where you develop a love-hate honeymoon. It begins all tender and carefree until those damning issues make you want to quit or to give up. In spite of those issues, they never keep you from trying over and over again. thinking, "Some day I can look over all failures by accomplishing this one thing. It will be the one thing I've done right." Then, nine-months later you find that there's a Sectoid baby. You  dispose of it, and you are left pondering where did you go wrong and what to do about it now.Then you start it all over again. (Just like Cpt. Kirk would want to be remembered.)Enemy Within review: Steam Review

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												First off, this is a good game, it has solid mechanics and it is fun to play but there are problems (Disclaimer: I am a complete fan of the original)Having said that, it is a pale shadow of the mighty first game from which it takes its name (And even X-COM: Apocalypse) and it appears to be a syndrome that a lot of remakes suffer. The problem could be called "Streamlining" (Total War Rome 2 has this problem as well).1st is the research tree which is significantly smaller than the original. There is only one advanced Interceptor and very few weapons for it to research. The squad sizes are also very small (4-6) compared to the original so when you lose someone experienced it hurts a lot! (Losing 1 or 2 people in a mission early on can cripple your chances of completing it.) The maps are smaller and the mechanics of engaging enemies (Small groups that get their own "!" animation when you come across them) is disappointing.Base building has been made much less interesting since in the original your base could be invaded (and you could have multiple bases). The X-COM: Enemy Within expansion does actually have a base defense mission but it is scripted, happens once, and how you built your base does not come into it.Which brings me to my main problem with the new X-COM. I do not feel like the Commander of X-COM. In the original there were no scripted events, it was all organic gameplay. I made the decisions, I hired the scientists, bought the ammo, kitted out the soldiers in details and planned ahead and I was fighting for the Earth. This may sound dull but it added to the immersion.In the new X-COM the game plays out with 3 main characters and I feel incidental to the whole thing. I could just go put some slippers on and let them do it. You are hand-held and guided through every part of the game, constantly being told what to do, what you should do and what to expect by the "main" characters. This game is also much shorter in terms of the time taken to complete it. I just finished a game having shot down a mere 6 UFOs. In the original I would barely be seeing more than their initial scouts at this point. The ending is also very abrupt and jarring.So yes, this is a good game overall, it has some of the hallmarks of the original but overall it is a hollow shell compared to it, even with the expansion (Which I HIGHLY recommend). I am hoping that some of the X-COM indie games like Xenonauts ( http://www.xenonauts.com/ and early access on Steam ) can give me my real X-COM old-school fix.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												XCOM:EU is what changed my opinion on turn-based strategy games. I usually hate those games and find them annoying/boring. This game completely made me change my mind. The Earth is under siege... not by one kind of E.T.'s.. but by several, so that is a new addition to most alien based games/movies. You don't forcefully start in the US, like most Alien Abductions happen. You control a party of 5(then more) soldiers and fight against the alien hordes in turn-based combat. Each soldier can then level up after each mission they finished and gain ranks and classes. Be careful, your soldiers WILL die sooner or later. Use your Saves/Loads.>I'd give it a 10/10(pretty subjective but whatever)>Pros: New approach to Alien Invasions, interesting RPG elements, fun combat, challenging but not impossible, ability to build and progress your base.>Cons: Movement of some soldiers is visually tedious and ugly sometimes(cinematics as well), sometimes repetitive alien cinematics(always follow the same formula)

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Pros: It has some great strategic depth to it with turn-based squad battles, and customization of your troops is more fun than it should be.  The game does a good job of putting a lot of weight into each choice you make, because you really feel it when you lose one of your soldiers, and it sucks.  Other than the occasional RNG bs crit damaging one of your guys, or causing a pointblank shot to miss, the difficulty is spot on.  You can't just rush your guys around the map and hope for the best, you actually have to think about your moves and how to win.Cons: Story isn't much to tell, and is definitely not the center of the game.  There are a few minor bugs such as camera angles freaking out with the action cam, but nothing game breaking.  There is supposedly a bug in the last mission where the game will just hang up on the enemy turn (I haven't run into this myself, but I saw it happen on a livestream), but with the autosave happening every turn its more just a minor hassle to restart the game and reload the last save.Overall:  Excellent game, if you like turn-based strategy this is a must have.  While I have not played the original I have heard that it is NOT the same game, but that being said its worth it to pick up, especially on sale.8/10

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												I was gifted this game and I guess I let it sit unplayed for too long! It's a fun strategy game that I found myself pretty invested in after only about an hour. While a lot of people knew what they were getting into because of the original game, I was unfamiliar with it. The game is a fairly straightforward strategy game along with a base building element. You receive periodic funds and materials from missions to either upgrade gear for your soldiers, research technologies, and keep the world at peace with satellite coverage and UFO interception. The game does a pretty good job of making sure you aren't able (at least not easily) to do everything, so you have to somewhat plan out what you want to do in order to make sure things go smoothly.The way the campaign progresses in pretty neat. At least, I hadn't seen it before. The game will tell you a specific thing to research, or item to build, or facility to construct, but the game doesn't seem to give you a deadline to do it. If you wanted, you could just kept the game going forever. But at the same time, going for too long without being able to protect the council/countries means that you have to keep progression in mind. It almost seems a little like Persona, of all things.The core gameplay was pretty great, there is a ton on emphasis on positioning. Cover is basically the determinant of whether your unit will live or die. I lost 3 units pretty fast before I started being more careful. It's always really neat in these types of games to watch as units fall into roles and favorites become clear over the course the of the missions. I ended up with 2 snipers (which are fairly over powered, as everyone has probably heard) 2 supports, a heavy, and an assault. Each one ended up being used in a way that felt organic. I didn't need to meticulously plan, I just tried things to see what worked and what didn't and it all flowed so well.I wished class changes could be decided. Unsure why it had to be random. I had other issues with manual saves and weird locks up that happened if a certain outcome was forced (say, attacking two of the elites with a grenade, they normally have a reaction cutscene but didn't work with 2 of them). I also wished there were a few more things fixed in place instead of just random missions on procudural maps. The few that were there were pretty nice. Some more enemy variety would have been good too, couple annoying recolors with are just boring.On normal, the base game got a bit easy but the last mission certainly upped the difficulty. Once you know what works, you simply just repeat it every mission while spending your money at the base. For me that meant keeping snipers back, having a shotgun running around, and a tank absorbing blows while some medics pranced about. So the game loses a little magic at this point, but luckily this is right as the campaign was ending so it didn't overstay its welcome.  I am also hopeful that the expansion content will help some of these issues. I am certainly interested in trying it at some point down the road.

The problem could be called "Streamlining" (Total War Rome 2 has this problem as well).1st is the research tree which is significantly smaller than the original. There is only one advanced Interceptor and very few weapons for it to research. The squad sizes are also very small (4-6) compared to the original so when you lose someone experienced it hurts a lot! (Losing 1 or 2 people in a mission early on can cripple your chances of completing it.) The maps are smaller and the mechanics of engaging enemies (Small groups that get their own "!" animation when you come across them) is disappointing.Base building has been made much less interesting since in the original your base could be invaded (and you could have multiple bases). The X-COM: Enemy Within expansion does actually have a base defense mission but it is scripted, happens once, and how you built your base does not come into it.Which brings me to my main problem with the new X-COM. I do not feel like the Commander of X-COM. In the original there were no scripted events, it was all organic gameplay. content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												What could I possibly say that hasn't already been said already.Well... let's tell my story.When I was a kid, I fell in love with a game called 'Shining Force,' which some may have heard of, and others not so much. Anyway, it was a top down "tactics" game: you controlled a rag-tag bunch of Medieval fantasy-style characters on a quest to purge the darkness that had been unsealed. One of the main draws of this game (and one of the main reasons I'd still return to it in the present day) was its simplicity; you had options, but you mostly had to rely on formation and non-fog-of-war tactics to really succeed.While I did, as I aged, fall in love with other (console) tactics games for various reasons - Final Fantasy Tactics, Disgaea, Front Mission, Advance Wars - none of them retained the complexity of those of the earlier games in the Shining Force series (especially Shining Force II) by way of simplicity, but rather by way of introducing complex or quirky mechanics that, while amusing for the first few implementations, grew steadily into automotonic repetition... or by quasi-forcing you to grind your way to the top (You technically could grind in Shining Force, but you didn't often NEED to as much as you might in, say, Disgaea).Which brings me to XCOM. I'd been introduced to it indirectly by a number of YouTube LPers, and fell in love with the crazy antics and frustrations they experienced... especially the ones they inflicted on themselves by hacking into the game and ramping up the difficulty beyond even that of present-day Impossible mode, just for the challenge of it. When I later saw that there was to be a new edition (and even later, saw the amazing graphics of said edition), I jumped on the bandwagon as soon as I had the time and money to do so, and I have not been disappointed. XCOM will always keep you on your toes; unless you're a master at the game playing on Easy or Normal perhaps. I myself have not yet mastered this system (years of fuddled implementations of "flanking" rules are still wreaking havoc in my brain), but success in the game relies more on simple squad tactics than it does on any sort of weird crafting, class, or combat, or other system. You need to think ahead practically all the time on the field (and off), carefully cross terrain and explore the map, and hopefully only ever uncover a group of aliens when you can actually handle them in one or two turns. Every battle challenges you to choose the right strategies every turn, whether the best option is to play more defensive or more offensive, play economically or in more of a rushdown style (either of which can backfire horribly). And because dead characters are dead... not resurrectable as they might be in the more lightweight tactics games of modern day (save Fire Emblem), I actually tend to really "care" about them. Any alien that blows up my main avatar is going to die in the most gruesome way I can manage.Coupled with an amazing combat engine, XCOM also challenges you with managing the actual base of your operation (in a much simpler and streamlined fashion than in the original), which again challenges you to think about how you ultimately want to build your base, and when to build which structure, and when to do which research, and which items or weaponry or armor or accessories to purchase or upgrade... all on a budgeted income. Perhaps it's an odd thing to say, but the limitations imposed upon you actually help to drive the game, and help to make the game an enjoyable one. While I did enjoy the slight period in time that I could relatively ROFLstomp the enemy due to overpowered weaponry, I find I still have the ability to so long as I size up the enemy first and plan intelligently my assault... it just takes a bit longer to do so.I have not played Enemy Within... but I look forward to a purchase in the near future. Still, even without the expansion, XCOM: Enemy Unknown delivers... alien heads on a platter. Mmmmm. Juicy.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												"Ran out of Video Memory, Exiting!"Bug still breaks the game when I get to the alien base invasion mission.  This alone gives it a thumbs down.As for actual gameplay:1. They removed the ability to shoot wherever you want.  You used to be able to blow out walls and doors with regular weapons, not just rocket launchers.  You could shoot out a wall and allow another soldier to then shoot an enemy, or remove that enemy's cover.  Now you can't unless you want to level an entire house with a grenade or rocket.2. After getting to the broken alien base invasion that crashes to desktop, I still have no idea how cover works.  You get the little icons showing half and full cover, but half the time the aliens are shooting my people in the face through walls while I miss 95% to hit shots.3.  The aliens get to literally drop into maps where ever they want.  You could be going through a map perfectly fine and dandy, and then the game will drop random thin men and other aliens directly onto your positions, even sharing the same exact squares your players are on.  This has nothing to do with tactics, it's cheap RNG designed to punch your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in.4.  You never get the drop on aliens.  They get a free turn when your soldiers "discover" them.  So, halfway through a movement your soldier will spot an alien, and then your soldier pauses while the aliens get to scramble out of the way and take cover.  It's a free move they get each and every time, so instead of rewarding you for close quarters tactics like the old games, it's like you're discovering and pulling aggro on random enemies that always see you first.  I understand that moving soldier A who spots two aliens frozen in place (because it's not their turn yet) can set up soldier B (who hasn't taken a turn yet) to blow them up with a grenade or rocket (without the ability to see the aliens directly) could be seen as "cheap" but this used to be accounted to soldier A informing soldier B where the aliens are upon discovery.  Now it's just another facet of RNG that leaves you at a disadvantage to make the game more difficult than it needs to be.5.  The little "Blizzard" style World of Warcraft animations get annoying after awhile.  Every soldier and alien and robot is always dancing around doing some huge grandiose awkward animation that's so over the top it ends up silly and falling flat on the humor scale.  It pulls the wind out of any horror and despair the old games had.  Honestly these cornball dancing animations and the UI that looks like it was designed for an iPad seem to be something people either love or hate.  Well, I kinda hate it.  It's Diablo 3 vs Diablo 1.  It's PG vs Rated R.  I could go on and on but I'd rather track down a god damned solution to this idiotic video memory crash bug.  I can't stand devs that abandon stuff when it's still broken and they ♥♥♥♥ing know it's broken.

												First of all XCOM: Enemy Unknown is not like the classic XCOM. Is this bad ? In my opinion not. XCOM: Enemy Unknown is faster and action pumped as his ancestors. Most important for myself is, that the new XCOM has not so many Horror or shocking moments like for example when your solider is shot from the unknown. Now its only about strategy and action and I love it. Sure things like the old inventory or AP System are missing but after some time you wont miss it anymore.Let's get to facts like Gameplay, Music and Graphic.The gameplay for itself is very good and easy to understand. The tutorial will also show you the most important moves and strategies.The Music, especially "Deployment" is one of the best gaming music tracks. But not only  this one, the whole music is very good and matches to the individual situation.For such a game like XCOM, graphic is not the most important thing and sure it isnt but this doesnt matter. It is still good and supports the action.In fact it is safe to say that XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a very good game which every strategy fan should buy :-)

content:
Posted: November 30, 2012
												I have blaspheme a bit here by saying that I never actually played any of the original X-Com games which I realize are canon in the world of PC strategy , but if they are anywhere near as good as this game then I may go back and play them as well. THIS GAME IS BRILLIANT!! Totally innovative take on turn based strategy. With smooth swat style movement of your team across the field of battle, you really feel the impact of getting a kill when you need to and the pain of sacrificing someone when the mission comes first. Amazing gameplay mechanics for the strategy aspect and a great base building/management system for leveling up. You really feel the global urgency in the whole story flow, and the soldier customization allows you to start thinking about backstories for them. I almost cried when the Li-Lee brothers Bruce and Jet sacrificed themselves to save a fleeing V.I.P being escorted by Sarah Conner and Snake-eyes. This game is an equal contender with Dishonored for GOTY as far as I'm concerned. 9.75/10

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game, especially because I enjoyed the previous installments a lot. But as much as I'd like to, I can't recommend the game, simply because it's littered with bugs.PositiveThe core concept is really appealing and the story progression and visuals are nice and fitting. I also enjoyed the soundtrack by composer Michael McCann. These aspects might make the game at least somewhat interesting for extremely frustration-resistant players and/or fans.NegativeWhat I absolutely hated was the overall "wonkiness" of the turn-based system. My squads frequently got spawned mid-air, allies and enemies got bugged on ladders and floated above them, hit-chances felt completely random at times (in front of enemy with shotgun, 100% hit chance - does not hit), and I regularly had to quit and restart the game for various reasons.Sometimes I was unable to heal anybody (Medkit spray animation played but recipient didn't receive any HP) and other times I tabbed out of the game - don't tab out of the game. There's a high chance for graphical glitches to appear and a reload or even a full restart is necessary.And one of the worst issues I have with the game: Half of the time you can't open the menu, mostly during alien activity. You see the aliens move to positions you didn't anticipate or your squad just got fu**ed and you want to load your save and try a different tactic? First you have to wait a minute until all aliens are done with their turns. That's annoying and has no benefit.ConclusionAll of these problems add up and playing the game got really frustrating. I still want to finish it, however I'm disappointed with what I've seen so far. The concept in itself is great but the execution is just horrible. Thus I can't recommend this game, at least not in its current state.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												TL;DR: This game is 7/10.  But! old original game that this is ramake of, was 10/10 because it had much much richer tactics. Why?! This game compared to original:- lack of inventory screen of unit during battle (and also at all)- related: can not freely have any loadout, e.g. 3, 5, even 20 grenades, or 3 nades and 7 indenciary nades, and 3 pistols, or riffle and pistol and rocket launcher... it's all dumbed down to few classes plus few "buffs"- less weapons/items in the entire game- can not pick/drop/throw/pass to other teammate things in battle- can not do any combination of actions in turn, it's dumbed down to 2 actions usually walk, then shoot (sometimes 3 with some buffs)- I prefereed grid map more, in isometirc view, it's less cool maybe, but better for tactics- less advanced stats of each unit- less advanced shooting: usually just shoot, instead of aimed/snapshot/auto fire (some units can have buffs to do cover fire or snipe, but not all)- less advanced management of items in base- especially: there is just ONE BASE, so no way to have several bases, move squads between them, move items, aliens- can not destroy all map terrain !! :(- can not so nicelly set thing on fire and watch the fire spread- can not mine the terrain (put down trap mines at places where you expect enemy to come through)- line of sight of units is not shown, this is a very serious tactical problem! Does the guy cover this door with his sight or not? (In original it was more of fog-of-war thing, but it usually got that job done, because aliens are in undiscovered terrain - and also isometric map, and top-down map helped)- movement is done in 1, at most 2 steps. Instead of walking the say 15 meters step by step and seeing with each one what parts of map do you exactly see- missing map of entire battle (with marked units)- game chooses classes of your teammates, they are a bit random (e.g. small girl -> Heavy, bad aim guy -> Sniper, etc) and you can not change them or "multiclass"- aliens are spawned when you trigger a waypoint. it's a bit lame.But there is good too, just not in the areas that I wanted the most from this game:+ it is not Dos pixelart game (like original) + cool 3d graphical effects and♥♥♥♥♥♥br>+ another xcom based game, yey+ the dumbed down version will appeal to some players that are a bit more casual and would not play the game otherwise+ the "I hear noice from this direction" idea is good... but it replaces the missing "motion scanner" and longer range spotting enemies+ maybe seeing this game will convince you to look for the old game (and it's modern free open source re-write OpenXcom) and you will get to see the best game ever :)Quite good modern version of best game of all time [for me] the UFO: Enemy Unknown game from 1994 year (also known as "X-COM: UFO Defense" on USA market).But the original game from 1994 was much better, and it's modern free version OpenXcom is even better and free to download (I highly recommend)....So if you have a friend who must have neat 3d effects in his tactical/strategical game, or if you want to see modern take on same story with 30% of original gameplay capture - play this game.In origianl - you could destroy all terrain in any way, build base in any way, arm units in ANY WAY (inventory screen), do any kind of actions on teammates in any order, there was only action points per turn limit. You could e.g.: prime a grenede, walk 3 steps, throw it to teammate, step back, drop pistol on ground, arm rifle, kneel down and take aim and guard the door.Or you could fire 3 random shots to set a barn on fire, deploy smoke, go in, pick up your unconcious teammate, and carry him outside.All in one action turn.You could there build any layout, usually a team unit had 5-10 items on him plus armor.How ever, it's still a game more interesting then other modern tactical squad shooters... 30% of experience of best game ever [imo] is still fun. You could buy it, but I can not honstly recommend it seeing the lost potential to be excellent.If you prefer deep tactical games and want all the options, or if you come here because you played the original 1994 game - well then you will notice how this game is dumbed-down in comparsion. But you can always get the free remake "openxcom" game, and buy this one here too.

number of helpful: 105 of 205 people (51%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												The design of this game is laughably bad. The "spotted enemies get a free turn so often they can just move to flank/surround your squad and murder them freely in their turn" rule is enough for it to be shown in a circus to be poked with sticks and laughed at. The classic difficulty is not classic at all, it's just a losing game against rng roulette where aliens get instakill crits from maximum distance while your guize have 40% hit while standing two meters away, because "hardocre yo!". Due to the above the game can randomly just lose itself for you. Example: one of these mind-numbingly boring VIP search and rescue council missions. I spot the VIP. I have to approach him for him to notice me. I cannot approach him without triggering two thin men spawns (that get a free turn). After I approach him, I cannot move him to a place where he won't be hit with a poisoning attack. After he gets poisoned, he panics. After he panics, he gets one-shot by one of the thin men that literally fall from the sky behind my line in automatic overwatch. Mission failed. 8/10, would rage again.The tactical battle mechanics have literally nothing to do with classic UFO games bar the "secret organization fights aliens in turns" premise. Even the most basic stuff like being able to shoot whenever and at whatever you want is not there. Instead, the game carbon copies the core mechanics (one move-one attack instead of ap, no free movement, 4 slot "inventory", attacking through skills with "action camera" animations and so on) from the so-called tactical jrpgs. Which is not surprising, considering this is a console game after all.The strategic layer is more akin to EU, but of course horribly castrated with things like one base, one skyranger, one (scripted) alien base etc., because that's apparently what 20 years of advancements in gaming brings us.

number of helpful: 55 of 107 people (51%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												This game is beautiful.  It has a dramatic soundtrack and solid voice acting.  The base design and combat mechanics are wonderful ... with a few soul-crushing game-killing flaws.tl;dr, I'm glad this game was gifted to me.  I can't force myself to finish it or buy the expansions.--The two action points are a grand improvement over the original x-com ... but restricting their use in any way was a mistake.  What if I want to fire first and then move or reload?--The AI mobs should NOT get a free movement the moment you spot them.--Why the hell can't I build more than one actual base and/or develop enough teams to respond to more than one terror attack at a time?  You're pitting me against arbitrary mechanics, not my ability to fight aliens.--All equipment held by an alien explodes if the wielder of that equipment dies ... are you kidding?  You know, you could've just adjusted the economy to account for me picking apart all the stuff the AI's drop and it wouldn't have felt like you were intentionally screwing me here.-- Why can't I specify what class of trooper I'd like to recruit?  The class system is cool, but it's crippling to have to fight a few battles with a guy only to find out he randomly rolled a class I do not need at the moment and be forced to give him the boot.

Posted: May 11, 2014
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a must for anyone. It's is both difficult, fun, and easy to get sucked in. I'd say the best reason why I like it is the fact that it's not a FPS (2011 and 2012 was nothing but shooters) and it was keeping me glued to my chair. The good is that it's easy to understand how to play, no 2 games play the same (so it's got high replay value), and it's challenging. The ailens will use the same stradegy as you. Use cover, flank you, and take you out as quick as possible. But with every play comes interesting results. You can fight to gather resources for weapons and armor for your troops along with building your base and Earth's defences.The cons are that at times it can be glitchy on occasions. I've seen a few that were odd but nothing bad. But while XCOM is challenging it's also unforgiving. One screw up on a battle will basically force you to restart your game. I've had to restart 6 times so far but I personally can deal with that.If you are a XCOM fan or a tactical game fan I highly recommend XCOM: Enemy Unknown. It gets a 4.5/5 in my book. And with that, good luck Commander!

Posted: April 1, 2014
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown achieves a perfect balance between resources and choices.  At almost every level you have a difficult decision to make.  You want it all, but have to prioritize.  Offensive or Defensive technologies?  Research doesn't do any good without Engineering, but how do you balance which type of facility to spend your money on?  You get more requests to help than you can respond to - which countries support (in the form of money, research and/or engineering) can you afford to lose?  Do you build a well-balanced squad comprised of one of each type and manage their unique benefits in the fight or build smaller fire teams that can break up and bring more direct pressure on the enemy?  Don't forget about air force.  You need satellites to know what is going on in a country, but that doesn't do much good without the interceptors to bring down the enemy aircraft.  No time to cope with the buyer's remorse from whatever decision(s) you just made because it's another alien attack.  Loading out your squad, again, is a delicious balancing act - your options a direct result of your earlier decisions.  The turn-based squad warfare is the core of the game and where you really feel the weight of your decisions.   You can tell the environments are hand-crafted and a work of beauty to dissect for the best opportunities to get position on the enemy.   The destructible environments, somewhat randomized enemy spawns and the occasional soldier with low willpower panicking and losing control keeps the combat experience fresh.  The "action cam", music and voiced soldier responses are implemented well and keep you immersed.Really enjoy the promotion of soldiers and the consequence of them getting wounded in battle, or even permanently killed.  As they experience combat they increase in ability and have more options for you to augment their capabilities.  It is a sad moment when a character you brought up from rookie, and over the course of 7 or 10 missions, promoted to Captain is killed in action (especially when you have customized the names of your soldiers to match you friends).It is probably the greatest compliment to a game when the only critic is that you want more.  As is with this game.  On one hand, I wouldn't mind a deeper tech tree, more facilities to construct, more countries to protect, more varied weapons, an extra soldier or two in my squad, larger maps, more soldier customization, etc.  On the other hand, I don't want any of that because I don't want to risk the perfect balance they have achieved.The most satisfying aspect of the game is the ultimate result of being so well-crafted.  I really feel all my decisions have weight and consequences.  From being on the ground ordering a veteran Assault soldier to move to a flanking position - hopefully safely drawing enemy fire so other units can move up, but possibly getting wounded and being unavailable for the next fight - to making the high-level decision on which country to favor over another.  In my opinion, one of the greatest games ever made.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												So maybe you're not a fan of strategy games. Those weird kids are always talking about how they formed a trading agreement with Queen Elizabeth for sugar and rum while sanctioning Ghandi only to find out he researched nukes before you and they lost 1000 hours of precious planning...Forget them for a moment and realize XCOM:EU is very personal. There are no nations or sanctions or embargos...There's Earth and the little green (grey) men who decided to mess with us. You will start with a small group of soldiers and they will do as they're told. And they will succeed. But you will be detached until you reach a mission where you just barely scrape by because your wonderful French sniper who was surrounded and alone for three turns managed to not get hit once but crit'd every assaulting enemy. You are just glad they survived because they are one tough cookie and you couldn't image what you'd do if they fell and were lost...This kind of attachment grows out of XCOM and it quite honestly shows why the game is so great. It's smaller unit tactics grow on you faster and makes you care more.

Posted: August 4, 2013
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a really deep turn-based strategy game in which you have to defend the whole world against an alien invasion as the commander of the XCOM project which has been initiated to stand against the extra-terrestial threat.Sounds easy but the core gameplay in combination with the unforgivable Ironman mode makes this game truly one of the best experiences in its genre.The graphics are solid with a bit stereotypical yet not less amazing enemy alien and spaceship design, the score by Michael McCann is one of the things which makes this game what it is - always providing the best musical support on the battlefield and the gameplay is deep with the combat part and the base part where you have to manage the XCOM base with ressources, income and satellite support for member countries - so they can give you money and staff for further projects.The value is amazing and even after the second and third playthrough there is a lot to see!Don't miss out this gem of strategy gaming and my personal Game of The Year 2012!9.5/10

Posted: February 12, 2014
												Have you ever wanted to manage a government program whose funding is both lacking and revoked for irrational reasons? If so, XCOM is the game for you. Basically, this is two games in one a strategy game and a ridiculously frustrating turn based mechanic. I say that it is frustrating because every xcom player has lost a valued squaddie becuase of a shot witha  99% chance of hitting, missing. This wouldn't be so bad, if the consequences were not permanent. Ironman mode is the only real way to play, since otherwise you can just savescum and reverse undesirable outcomes. The strategy aspect of the game is not terribly deep, but still presents a fairly nuanced economy, that becomes much more difficult to manage at higher difficulties. It is worth noting that on ironman mode completely failed attempts are common. This game is unique in that you can lose and simply have to restart. This is no linear shooter with checkpoints, decisions have real consequences, and you can lose your entire program with nothing more than a string of bad luck. I know that I haven't made this game sound too fun, but I promise it is wickedly addicting. Permanent consequences and the ability to lose are sorely missed game mechanics in this day and age, at least to me. If you can accept that, this game will suck you in keep you on the edge of your seat, despite the gameplay amounting to nothing more than pointing and clicking.

Posted: April 10, 2014
												Arguably the best game I have ever played on any format.  XCOM is the first chapter in a series of turn based strategy games which later branched out into the not so successful space combat and first person arena before sensibly realising what it did best.  With an awesome polish and reboot for its Steam release it can't possibly disappoint any true sci-fi, role-playing, intravenous coffee drinking geek like myself.When you begin, you can play the game with its original Easy, Normal, Classic and Impossible settings, or you can initiate The Second Wave, which makes life a little more exciting by introducing variable damage, funding and troop abilities.With dramatic cut scenes and stirring sound track you take the lead as Commander of a mysterious and secret, yet government funded initiative to defend our wonderful ball of mud from the terrifying alien menace.  You are immediately thrown into the front line of an alien incursion and must fight off a Sectoid landing party which seems bent on human abduction and inevitable probing!Whether you are an XCOM Veteran or not, it is advisable to play the tutorial, as the Heads Up Display is very different from the original release and the attention to real world physics let's you do more exciting and dramatic things .After the first mission, you then decide what continent you will build your first base on and each area gives you a different bonus, like a higher percentage of money, cheaper building costs or instant autopsy.  So it's worth thinking about what boost may suit your gaming style.Ok, so it's not the most original concept and yes, at times, the complete stupidity of missing a giant monster with a machine gun at point blank range will make you scream; but no-one said running the Earth's last line of defence was going to be an easy job.  For me, these are issues easily glossed over and soon forgotten when you drool over the incredible detail, depth and playability of XCOM Enemy Unknown.  This is truly a game you can invest time in and feel a sense of achievement from, as you research life-forms, materials and strategies while developing new bases, air craft  and let's not be shy... kicking some alien butt.You can customise your team's physical appearance, uniforms and weaponry and with the fantastic A.I. you can develop your own style of combat as you immerse yourself in the incredibly dynamic maps.For a re-booted game that was originally released in 1994 by Microprose, this franchise has stayed true to its original form and not lost any of its addictive qualities.  I will take my time and savour the nostalgia that kept me awake for hours and look forward to playing the sequels: Terror From The Deep and XCOM Apocalypse.I can happily rate this game 9 out of 10, so If turn based strategy, tension-filled exploration, aliens and cool weapons are your thing, then get XCOM Enemy Unknown onto your machine now!

												Pros:-Very challenging (IRONMAN!)-Guaranteed to get you hooked-Easy & Normal mode are not too punishing for beginners (although you're still almost guaranteed to lose a few soldiers and council members)-Involves a lot of strategy and decision-making-High replay value, especially with those Second Wave options-Each playthrough is randomized-Troops' appearance, names, colors, equpment, etc. are highly customizable (this is one of my favorite things about this game)-Has room for emergent stories and will get you emotionally involved-MECs, gene mods and psionic powers, amirite?Cons:-Limited modding support-Occasionally has some game-breaking bugs that require you to force-close the game in order to fix-Maps, dialogues and some missions are repetitive-Lousy camera controls-Mid- to late-game becomes too easy (I hope they add more Second Wave options to make it more challenging)

Posted: November 16, 2013
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a turn based strategy game.As far as many of you know this game is a remake of the original X-Com games, and therefore there are two possibilities. One is that the game is bad and the second that the game is great, so the question is on which side is XCOM: Enemy Unknown.The story : well what can be said about the story ? you take role as the commander of the XCOM project that it is the last line of defense of the earth against the unknown ( Aliens )  enemy, your role is to lead you soldiers to victory, expand your base, make difficult choices, and of course to defend earth by any cost. The story itself is just a side bonus I guess. You won't really follow it and to be truthfully the game could be without storyline.Gameplay : This is where the fun begins, the gameplay is all about : researching the aliens, creating new technology and weapons, lead soldiers to victory by turn based tactics mechanics, carefully making decisions and the most important thing the difficulty of the game can be changed by the player, but it is recommend to play Ironman mode which doesn't allow you to load you last saves in order to experience the real meaning of making decisions.Bugs : There are a few "bugs" that will make the game to be a little awkward, the camera angle will make you see a wall when in reality you should see you soldier fire at an enemy, there will be sometimes a problem when trying to lead the soldier to the second or third floor. Other than that everything is okay.Sound : There isn't too much to say about the sound except that it is exactly how it should beGraphcis : What can be said about the graphics ? especially of a game that came out in 2012, I can only think of one word "Good"AI\Difficulty : This is one of the strong points that XCOM has, The AI is far from being stupid ( like in most FPS games nowadays ) and there are times when you will be utterly destroyed by them ( If you play at the more higher difficulty when you have no experience, like me ). The difficulty of the game is impressive, you may be asking yourself "what can be so impressive by the difficulty level ?" well let me answer you to that, the game accepts both casual\biggener or new to the franchise and accepts to the hardcore and experienced gamers to the X-com game. You can add some "mods" in order to make the game more challenging or easier it only depends on youSummary : XCOM Enemy Unknown is one of the best 2012 games, its challenging, fun, interesting and has infinite replayability. The game accepts both casual and hardcore gamers and is my personal recommendation to people who want to try strategy game ( when they didn't played even one ).  Overall I give this game a 9\10.

												This is a streamlined version of the original X-Com games but I absolutely love it. One of the few games I've had any interest in beating more than once. This is TBS done right though it's very hard to lose people if you play carefully. The ending is a bit of a letdown and the maps can get repetitive. The expansion is more of an addin. It adds a short campaign within the game and lots of new research/equipment as well as Mechs (which are just awesome) and the ability to augment other soldiers. Overall, if you don't have XCOM yet I recommend buying the expansion too. If you've already bought XCOM, you can probably pass unless you enjoy the game enough to beat it multiple times.

Posted: February 15, 2014
												A few caveats first: I am a casual gamer - I have played a moderate number of games, and most of them have not been completed.  I have played a few MMOs but mostly play non-MMO games in either single player or co-op modes.  Some of my fav games have been Lost Planet, Halo, Mass Effect, Need for Speed, Burnout, etc.  I like using a gamepad controller.  I don't generally like heavily detalied games and favor sci-fi and some balance between story / action.  So now you have some idea of my "GP" (gaming perspective).I LOVE THIS GAME. Not surprising b/c of sci-fi element. Story, voice acting, etc won't win academy awards - but is good enough to be enjoyable, if not a bit redundant at times.  Nothing is perfect - but I thought it was pretty well done.  I actually read most of the research conclusions, etc.  If not your cup of tea, just skip it. The thing is, this game has something for everyone.  Play it your way! And adjust difficulty to your liking.  Hate the story, skip it and turn off dialogue.  I am not a huge fan of turn-based strategy games, but I love this one.  I actually liked controlling the save system so I could play with different stratedgies.  And base management - IMO fine balance between resource management but not over-bearingly so.  Well done. Simple enough to understand quickly, but involved enough to give a certain sense of reality (well, to some degree - use your imagination :) to the game: You are the commander, after all.The game becomes easier to play the farther you progress - not that the alien waves don't become a little harder (sometimes)... which I like.  After all, the alien's didn't ask how leved'ed up you were when they arrived, did they? They were what they were - and you had to learn, adapt, research, build, get better !  So be careful early on and pay attention to resource allocation.Graphics: Good to better-than-good.  Fine for what the game is.Music:  Very well done - I thought it set the mood well. Voice:  Repetitive but ok - filled out the story ok.Controls:  I am biased - I like controllers - and they implemented gamepad control (xbox mode) very well.  Fairly intuitive.  Cannot comment on keyboard/mouse control.  Issues: Yep. Its a game.  Written by humans with limited budgets sold to a lot of people with no limit of preferences and opinions.  1.  Its a numbers game, with shot percentages adjusted randomly.  90% hit chance means you will miss 10% of the time (at least, by definition) - so don't think b/c you are 20 ft from the alien with a ranked-up soilder ensures you'll hit the stationairy target - you might miss.  But, sometimes you should then die, and it will miss also.  It evens out.  I guess. Didn't always feel like it. 2.  Repetitive dialogue.  Get used to it - or turn it off.3.  Reverse challenge model. Takes some getting used to. I actually agree with this model, just took some getting used to. Not really a bug ,,, just aggravating at first.  4. The tutorial portion is ok, but doesn't tell you everything. Some nuances of resource management will either need to be experimented with (might use save points first) , or read a guide or whatever.Note: I have not played the first XCOM game yet (plan to) so I cannot compare it to the original.  I also have not purchased the Enemy Within extension yet - so cannot comment on that either: I am looking forward to it. Last comment: Some games drive me nuts with save system and reply value on episode defeats, etc.  I screwed up a few times and had to replay long sections of the game.  I not only didn't care, I kinda enjoyed it again!  The only sad part of the game for me was the last mission - b/c I knew it was about over.  And then it was.  Sigh. Great game.
