Posted: March 9, 2014
												Pros:-Very challenging (IRONMAN!)-Guaranteed to get you hooked-Easy & Normal mode are not too punishing for beginners (although you're still almost guaranteed to lose a few soldiers and council members)-Involves a lot of strategy and decision-making-High replay value, especially with those Second Wave options-Each playthrough is randomized-Troops' appearance, names, colors, equpment, etc. are highly customizable (this is one of my favorite things about this game)-Has room for emergent stories and will get you emotionally involved-MECs, gene mods and psionic powers, amirite?Cons:-Limited modding support-Occasionally has some game-breaking bugs that require you to force-close the game in order to fix-Maps, dialogues and some missions are repetitive-Lousy camera controls-Mid- to late-game becomes too easy (I hope they add more Second Wave options to make it more challenging)

Posted: October 16, 2012
												Xcom is a game about strategy, good tactics and for those who really like a challenge with consequences to their gaming. It’s a reboot of a old franchise in new guise, where it's streamlined and modern without dumbing down on what made the original so good.You care and feel for the soldiers under your command, and cry as they get killed (by something you did or just bad luck). All while following a storyline that got a distinct feel of old Sci Fi Horror B movies, something i think really work in the game's favor. That said, for those that are not into the “classic” mode and every decision is final and no take backs, there is modes where you can save and play less punishing to your gameplay.As far as multiplayer goes it is a bit bare bones, if you have friends into it and want to take some turn based action there is some stuff to work with here. Issue is mostly the fact that it is point based, it has little customization value and overall it is kind of weak compared to other titles of this type. I would get it for its single player and then do MP if you feel like friends are up for it or just pretend it is not there.So, does it hold up to the old game? I think it is better, as I said earlier they streamlined the game to make it more accessible, easy to understand, a clear understandable UI and a good story to go with the attacks. You feel like you are fighting the good fight, you feel like every step could be fatal and you take your time to think through your actions to keep your men and the human race safe.You owe it to yourself to own this game and have it in your collection, so show the alien filth that this is our planet, and they are getting an eviction.

Posted: March 2, 2014
												Very good game, I'm a big fan of turn based strategy games and this feels like a nice follow on from Apocalypse that I played years ago.I'd image anyone looking to buy this probably has an idea of what they will be getting, so I though I would mention some of the negative sides of the game instead.Loadouts: The way your squad is balanced is a bit odd, essentially once you reach plasma rifles and better levels of armour the game becomes notably easier. It basically means you go from feeling too weak to arguably too strong for a large portion of the game.Hit Chance: Ok this one actually makes me really angry and is the reason I will never play on Iron Man. For whatever reason the devs decided that if your squad has anything below 75% chance to hit it basically means they have 75% chance to miss. However all levels of alien can more or less hit you flawlessly from 2 screens away. It makes me wonder if the developers don't understand how probability works but it happens consistently through missions and I have spoken to other people who confirmed they had the same problem.Cover: Yeah... I'm not sure why there are varying levels of cover. Either the devs didn't understand how cover works or couldn't be bothered implementing it properly. Basically full cover acts as cover, anything else is basically your squad closing their eyes thinking that means the enemy can't see them.I mainly wrote this to highlight the flaws with the game(and for a little rant lol), because they aren't mentioned much outside of the bugs for some reason. This is a great game and challenging as it is but I never like part of the challenge in a game coming from either the AI effectively cheating or from incorrectly implemented mechanics.

Posted: March 3, 2014
												Percentages mean nothing in this game:  99% to hit can (and will frequently) result in misses, so expect fury at how this game handles probability on too frequent of a basis for it to be just bad luck.  Its seeding mechanic also makes suggested "randomness" not really random since it is all predetermined when the map loads, where procedures occur based off of your actions instead of random response as it should be--it reduces the strategy and urgency in this strategy game with urgency in its story, imho, by forcing the random number generator to be more static.  Even when set to "random" it still is procedural, and by no means actually randomised.  I understand the devs' position on wanting to prevent players from reloading saves to make the same choice for better results, but I do not agree with it since the game's probability is so broken to begin with.  If they wanted to take a hard stance on development choices without protest, they needed to iron out the flaws tied to the decision.Still, I sunk time into it, albeit swearing all of the while.  Good game, it needs work which will never come, and it needs Steam workshop for mods made specifically to fix bugs and other problems that the devs will continue to ignore (these mods exist online already, but they are not integrated with Steam).  This game's problems are too outstanding for me to ignore despite what is good, and the shortcomings are too numerous to like this game more than it allows me to.  Buy it when it is on sale, because with no support and no Workshop, I do not feel that it is worth $30 USD, but it is absolutely worth $10 ish.

Posted: March 3, 2014
												XCOM Enemy Unknown was my introduction to the Team Tactics format, following a recommendation from a friend who played the originals.Highly addictive, challenging and rewarding. The graphics and animations are excellent (minus a couple of odd close ups), the gameplay is fluid. The action is intense at times, and in a way you can become quite attached to your soldiers, sometimes favouring some over others. In some situations, you may even have to make that near impossible decision of sacrificing one or two men so that the others can escape, or to save those last one or two civilians, which is never easy if the soldier in question is one of your best.There's base building, researching, soldier classes (snipers, assaults, heavy and support), using alien tech to make cool new guns and armour, shooting down enemy UFOs, rescue missions, keeping countries happy by protecting them, making them not so happy when you fail, everything to keep you busy and coming back for more.As for the Enemy Within expansion pack, that just makes a great game even better. It's pricey for what it is, it's usual price a lot more than what I would normally pay for expansion. But it does add a lot of new missions, maps, and even a new enemy so you do (almost) get what you pay for if you pay for it at top price (I bought it when the price came down in the sale).Highly recommended.

Posted: September 4, 2013
												XCom: Enemy Unknown isn't just a pretty remake of an older game but a throwback to games that presented you just enough information to enter the cycle of attempts, failures, learning, and finally succeeding. By not holding your hand and letting you fail, even during the course of a pitched campaign, it really sweetens your successes and gives you a sense of personal ownership over them that most modern games lack. From its tough yet fair challenge to the way that all of the systems interconnect XCom: Enemy Unknown is an absolutely fantastic game, and somehow balances what could have easily been an overwhelming palette of gameplay elements into one ridiculously engaging package.

Posted: September 21, 2015
												If you have ever played the original XCOM then you already have this in your library. And you should, because it's the best adaptation of the original since Terror From the Deep.If you've never played an XCOM game before, here's a brief description:The world is getting invaded by aliens and you're the commander of the team of soldiers from around the world sent to stop them.  This is a turn based strategy game, meaning that you'll take a turn and then the computer will take a turn.  You'll control a squad of up to six varied soldiers taking on a variety of mission types, all with the eventual goal of stopping the alien threat. Each soldier has one of several classes (like a Sniper or Support medic) with special skills for that class that make your job easier the more you level up.This is one of those games that you'll come back to time and again.  Since its release several years ago I STILL find myself playing XCOM.  In fact, I like this game so much I own it on my Xbox 360 as well.  XCOM is a ton of fun with great replayability.  I'd recommend this game to anyone who enjoys turn based gameplay with RPG elements.  It's a great strategy experience.

Posted: July 6, 2013
												I remember the old X-Com. The thrill of taking down the alien menace. The horror of a reaction shot out of the dark killing a soldier. The frustration of finding that last damn alien hiding in a dark room somewhere on the map. Those chuckles you got when you sent a soldier named after that bully from school marching to his doom in front of an alien firing squad.This takes the old X-Com we know and love and turns it into something...Well, new. The old aliens are back, with shiny new outfits and abilities, plus some new odds and ends to spruce things up. Take heed, though. This is a game where Chaos Theory comes into play. The smallest screw-up could lead to a Code Black. That said, for those of you who love nothing more than to see your alien brothers splattered across the ground, this game will be a real hoot.

												XCOM: EU is a throwback to an era of hardcore turnbased strategy games. While XCOM: EU maintains the IP of it's predecessor, the mechancis are vastly different. My favourite part of this game is naming the characters after friends and family, watching them gain experience, grow and equipping them with bigger more powerful weapons. 												I love XCOM and I think this is a worthy continuation of the series. The first thing I want to mention is the change in control scheme and how some people say its more casual. This game is WAY too hard to be considered casual. While there are some elements that I really hate (abduction missions come in threes and it is impossible to handle all three of them at once thus increasing panic. In the originals if you tried really hard you could go to every mission, it was hard, but possible. This game makes it flat out impossible. It's complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and I hate it) there are a lot of functions I really like. The soldier upgrades, satellites, council funding, skyranger bases, and the new options in second wave are all much improved. But the game eliminates action points and limits the player to two actions, vastly limits the soldiers inventory, and restricts the player to a maximum of six soldiers (the original had like, 16 or something crazy big).The game difficulty is about on par with the originals. I just played it and the game threw three different missions at me in one day. Half my squad is still recovering from wounds and the day before I took out an alien base which should have stopped more missions from happening for a while. This game will push you down and kick you until you stop moving.I still love it.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												I'm experienced with strategy games (hundreds of hours in Fire Emblem games), but I was brand new to XCOM. I had never played any of the prequels. I decided to give XCOM: Enemy Unknown and its full-fledged expansion, Enemy Within, a chance and I was not disappointed. Far from it. I am very impressed with the complex tactics that require one to combine aggression with caution in order to get the best results.I'm not going to lie - when I first started I was getting my butt handed to me on a platter even on Easy. But with some practice I acquired a feel for the cover system. Combined with the various tech upgrades, gene mods, psionic abilities, and MEC builds, the gameplay is incredibly deep and well thought out. Customizing the soldiers was an amusing pasttime between difficult missions as well.The thing I like most about the game is how it's uncompromisingly difficult at anything above Easy (thus providing tons of replayability in its challenges), but is rarely unfair. Sometimes you do have instances where your soldier misses what should have been an easy shot, but for the majority any punishment you take is due to tactical mistakes or overextension of vulnerable troops. My main gripe is that it's just a tad too easy to break the game with MECs. A team of 3 MECs, an Assault, a Support, and a Sniper can destroy anything and everything in their path (even the crazy-tough Sectopods) with little difficulty.I HIGHLY recommend this game for anyone that likes strategy games. It's a perfect combination of strategy (planning your weapon upgrades and modifications), tactics (in battles, like getting to Meld containers without getting ambushed), and management (loadouts and general customization). It's streamlined so it's relatively easy to pick up for a newcomer like myself, but at the same time is very challenging. Nothing in a strategy game is more satisfying than completing a really hard mission with no casualties.I wish I had picked this game up sooner.

Posted: May 18, 2014
												XCOM:UFo Defence.Now that name should strike fear into even veteran RTS gamers,if you are as old as me.This franchise was the staple of horror and fear and nightmarish scenarios for many people when it first came out in 1994.It was a brutally hard game,really unforgiving,and extremely likely to absolutely murder you the moment you made a small mistake.You felt like you were always behind in that game,until you finally got the technology from your hardworking scientists and engineers to stand toe-to-toe with the alien invaders.Horror and tension ran the game and you always were afraid of what would happen afterwards.And now.We have this.XCOM:Enemy Unknown. This game often seems to be overlooked for some reason,and i am unable to decipher why.But to the point.Enemy Unknown is a turn-based RTS game,You are tasked with the role of Commander for humanity's first and last defence against the alien invaders,the XCOM project. Your  job is to defeat your otherwordly invaders at any cost.Now,for the game itself.This game feaures 2 kinds of modes.Geoscape mode,which allows you to customize soldiers at the barracks, research alien technologies in the Labratories, and then build these items in the ENgineering Bay.This is also from where you will monitor the situation of the world and take mission requests from a group of united nations known as The Council.The other mode is the Battlefield.When an UFO lands,ALien Abductions are spotted,or aliens terrorize cities,your soldier are fielded onto whereveer the current situation demands.You will then control them with a Turn-based system to find aliens,neutralize them(be it lethally or non-lethally(Lethally,i prefer,curse those damn Berserkers)),rescuse civillians,,escort VIP's,disarm Bombs,or sequre important cargo.The game offers a good amount of different types of weapons,amrour and items to equip your soldiers with.Equip your squads with the best that humanity has to offer in conventional weapons,from shotguns,rifles,LMG's,SNiper rifles,and rocket launchers,add grenade sinto thee mix and with a pistol for a sidearm,and you are good to go..right?Not really.You will not last llong in the world if you rely on human weaponry.WHich also makes it important to capture or build alien weapons of your own.through the research systems,you will be able to research new technology for the engineers to later build in the form of  amrour that turns your soldier invisible, laser rifles,or the almighty Fusion Launcher,an auto-targeting(Presumably) plasma-fuelded warhead which will destroy everything within many blocks,be it cover,enemies,or your own damn team!But weaponry alone is not going to cut it for humanity's finest.You will have to rely on the world to aid you in keeping your soldiers alive.Aka you must find suitable cover for your soldiers to hide behind.Everything form boulders,trees,cars,walls, PLANT POTS!Pillars,and even UFO flight computers can provide you with cover which willl be your squad's main survival tactic. Aliens will utilize the same amount of cover as you do,with the exepction of more..feral aliens like the Muton Berserker and the infamous Chryssalid.However,all those things will have no say in the matter if you are not allowed to go a bit off the rails in terms of'realism'. Enhance your soldiers with 'Psionic Power'if they,in the game's terms'Gifted'.These powers will allow soldiers to damage,defend,de-rail enemy fire(Like Fortune's *Luck* in metal GEar Solid 2:SOns of Liberty)induce panic and disorder,or take contorl of an enemy's mind and use him against his fellow aliens-in-arms.As the game progresses,you will want to prioritize squad survival with better armour and weapons.Armours come in many forms,form what i said before,turning you inviisble,hhave grappeling hooks for height scaling,a jetpack,Psi-armour,which enhances Psychic soldier's already face-melting powers,or the almighty Titan amrour,which provides the best amount of health,and also Immunity to fire and poisons(Noteably from Thin Men)However,once you have reached the staple of technology in the game,you should never construct things like Carapace armour or Laser weaponry,as it becomes obselete in the long run.But the war cannot be won solely on our own soil. The sky is filled with bogeys,and it is X-Com's job to shoot these UFO's down with their Interceptors.Initially equipped with the traditional missiles at first,you must shoot these things down before they can reach their objectives.Then you get on the ground and assault them.But the enemy has no shortage of tech of their own. Creatures like the Psionic Sectoid Commander,Notiroius Cryssalid,or the devestating Sectopod tell you that the alien invaders mean buisness on a worldwide scale.Aliens are very likely to always outman and outgun you at every turn,yurning a potential mission sucess into a desperate scramble to get the hell back to your Skyranger,X-Coms aerial transport craft in order to save your soldiers(Or soldier,depending on how badly the escape goes).The enemies show absolutely no mercy on normal mode,and classic mode induces the same level of terror as the Original game from 1994 did.The game is more action-packed and cinematic then its predeseccor,allowing for immersion and the joy of being in a firefight(Although you only select what abilities a soldier can do).The Expansion pack,called Enemy Within,improves on a lot of these features.it also adds new feaures to the game.genetically modify soldiers to jump 2 stories,regenerate wounds,or allow electric detection through the skin,letting you find aliens without looking directly at them,or enhance the eyes to allow for etter shots after each miss.You also have the option of making a new soldier class,of which i will explain in a moment.You cna augument soldiers with the'Squaddie'rank by amputating their arms and legs to allow them to be fit into cybernetic suits known as MEC's.The MEC is a new soldier type in the game who is what it sounds like,its a mech,but with a living perosn insade.The operator has acess to a lot of abilities which cna be built upon with a new resource known as Meld(WHich is also used for genetic modification)to mount a flamethrower on the arm,allow for a high-powered Falcoon punch,prximity mines,grenedad elaunchers,and electromagnetic shockfields to shut down robotics or fry organics alive.Now,for the classic soldiers.Assault,which can be equipped with a normal rifle or a shotgun for CQC,and with traits to evade enemy fire or allow for an automatic'Reaction shot'when an enemy comes close.They are your team's main frontline comba tunit,alongside the mEC trooper.SNipers are your long-range attackers,able to fire from exxtreme range,and can often be the doom of even the toughest alien if left alone.Support does what supports do.they should carry medpacks with them to heal your squad,or provide smoke-grenades or combat drugs to enhance defence and attack.The heavy class carries the LMG and a rocket launcher to devestate enemy installations and ruin cover,exposing them to more accurate shots.They can also be outfitted with traits that can turn them into'tankbusters'or lock-down enemy personel with supressing fire,and are the general demoilition's expert of the team.The game has Multiplayer,as well.Jump into the role of humans or aliens,or just mix them togheter.But the Multiplayer has a lot of issues.Bugs,lag,and glitches seem to be offputting for several people,me included.As for how the general game feels,is it good?Without question!This Posted: January 27, 2014
												This scintillating adventure of Mankind vs. Aliens beautifully combines careful base management with tense turn-based combat in a concoction that always has you craving the next sip. With a pinch of randomisation, a few fully fledged DLC packs and some interesting difficulty modifiers up its sleeves, the single player alone has the potential to offer near limitless hours of gameplay. Despite being given nothing but a name and some stats, you’ll soon find yourself getting attached to the soldiers you recruit, train and command on the front line. The plot isn’t anything revolutionary for a game about fighting the threat of aliens invading earth. Gratifyingly though, the game doesn’t waste any of your time explaining or embellishing that which could be ascertained through gameplay instead.Before closing, I should mention these views come without any contextual experience of earlier games in the XCOM series. But regardless of how it compares to its predecessors, XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a masterpiece that has me entranced.

Posted: February 14, 2014
												best turn-based strategy game ever. remake of the former best turn-based strategy game ever.command an elite supranational paramilitary organization to counter an alien invasion.combat plays like an isometric turn-based tactical strategy game... the management between battles it what really sets it apart though. manage finances & base construction, reverse-engineer captured alien technology (including alien autopsies), upgrade & customize your troops, and then decide which missions to accept (sometimes at the expense of others.)  the difficulty curve is also rather unique in how you start out at a distinct disadvantage to the enemy.  the game rewards you for playing smart & punishes you for your mistakes.  this forces you to plan ahead to try and gain enough momentum to keep up with the game's scaling difficulty.  every decision makes you weigh the consequences of your actions.overall, a worthy successor to the original, both being among my all-time favorite games.

Posted: May 11, 2014
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a must for anyone. It's is both difficult, fun, and easy to get sucked in. I'd say the best reason why I like it is the fact that it's not a FPS (2011 and 2012 was nothing but shooters) and it was keeping me glued to my chair. The good is that it's easy to understand how to play, no 2 games play the same (so it's got high replay value), and it's challenging. The ailens will use the same stradegy as you. Use cover, flank you, and take you out as quick as possible. But with every play comes interesting results. You can fight to gather resources for weapons and armor for your troops along with building your base and Earth's defences.The cons are that at times it can be glitchy on occasions. I've seen a few that were odd but nothing bad. But while XCOM is challenging it's also unforgiving. One screw up on a battle will basically force you to restart your game. I've had to restart 6 times so far but I personally can deal with that.If you are a XCOM fan or a tactical game fan I highly recommend XCOM: Enemy Unknown. It gets a 4.5/5 in my book. And with that, good luck Commander!

												Plays a lot like Invisibe, Inc from Klei Entertainment, with combat taking the spotlight. Stealth? Nah, not really. Some little perks and abilities that make you harder to hit, even limited invisibility, but stealth just isn't a part of this game. Then again, that hasn't impacted my enjoyment in the least.I normally worry about a game's plot, believability, human connection, etc. Enemy Unknown has been a nice change from CoD's hollow characters and linear story. Imagine Halo 4, but your total empathy hovering around 3/5ths of what you felt when Cortana died.Going into a tough mission and bringing all your guys back out gives you an honest feeling of accomplishment. Just for one second, imagine you did something worthwhile with your life, no pressure, no excectations, and it took you a good day to do it. That's how I feel at the end of a battle.TL;DR I vaguely disliked Final Fantasy-ish combat, but this game has renewed my interest. Just when you think you have the world under control, some jerk with weird anatomy walks in and messes everything up. Buy it!

Posted: March 17, 2015
												3D humans-versus-aliens turn-based tactics game.In missions, you control a squad of 4-6 soldiers and engage in shootouts with a wide variety of aliens. Combat cleverly draws from the mechanics of some modern first-person shooters. Most units die very quickly - sometimes in a single shot - but you can greatly improve your soldiers' odds of survival by keeping them behind cover relative to the aliens' positions. The other combat mechanics are a nice mixed bag that will have you managing cooldowns, conserving ammo, and carefully aiming grenades and rockets. The game does have its flaws, though: it suffers from some annoying bugs, the interface design is poor, and some random events can feel rather unfair.Between missions, you assign abilities and equipment to your surviving soldiers, build facilities at your base, research upgrades, and send interceptors out to shoot down UFOs. The base-building mechanics aren't particularly deep, but they  do provide plenty of opportunity for customization.Very solid game: simple yet tactically challenging.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												I'm experienced with strategy games (hundreds of hours in Fire Emblem games), but I was brand new to XCOM. I had never played any of the prequels. I decided to give XCOM: Enemy Unknown and its full-fledged expansion, Enemy Within, a chance and I was not disappointed. Far from it. I am very impressed with the complex tactics that require one to combine aggression with caution in order to get the best results.I'm not going to lie - when I first started I was getting my butt handed to me on a platter even on Easy. But with some practice I acquired a feel for the cover system. Combined with the various tech upgrades, gene mods, psionic abilities, and MEC builds, the gameplay is incredibly deep and well thought out. Customizing the soldiers was an amusing pasttime between difficult missions as well.The thing I like most about the game is how it's uncompromisingly difficult at anything above Easy (thus providing tons of replayability in its challenges), but is rarely unfair. Sometimes you do have instances where your soldier misses what should have been an easy shot, but for the majority any punishment you take is due to tactical mistakes or overextension of vulnerable troops. My main gripe is that it's just a tad too easy to break the game with MECs. A team of 3 MECs, an Assault, a Support, and a Sniper can destroy anything and everything in their path (even the crazy-tough Sectopods) with little difficulty.I HIGHLY recommend this game for anyone that likes strategy games. It's a perfect combination of strategy (planning your weapon upgrades and modifications), tactics (in battles, like getting to Meld containers without getting ambushed), and management (loadouts and general customization). It's streamlined so it's relatively easy to pick up for a newcomer like myself, but at the same time is very challenging. Nothing in a strategy game is more satisfying than completing a really hard mission with no casualties.I wish I had picked this game up sooner.

Posted: January 19, 2014
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown and Enemy Within...The main reason I bought this game was it sat between RTS (Real Time Strategy) and FPS (First Person Shooter).It can either be frantic and quick or slow and tactical dependent on your play style more than anything else. It’s one of the only game I have found where your choices early on in the game impact you later on.  EG not building Satellite relays early may mean playing catch up later on.Is this a hard game?No not really, I know a lot of people that use the auto saves to undo a previously bad turn of play,Will I get a challenge?Yes! there are numerous difficulty levels which don’t just ramp health and damage but actually adjust the AI of the game, allowing the AI units more tactical freedom than rush and shoot(normal). There are also further unlocks once completed which make the game crazily hard ( similar to the games of its heritage)What’s the Multiplayer like?Not so good, it’s often difficult to get a good game online. Plagued with drop out bugs and glitches which respawn your soldiers, online is best done after the campaign. It’s also very difficult to find a good game! In my experience I rarely met any "decent" players online, often most players will leave the game as soon as they know they are beat and if they don’t leave they will make you aware they don’t like been beaten. Add this to the low number of players online and you come to an uncomfortable situation of playing a smack talking player repeatedly because no one else is online. One further positive/Negative is the pre-defined classes, each solider can use 5 or 6 further modifications once you have selected each class. Then you have guns, armour and accessories. The level of customisation is quite high which is also a negative, as mentioned above with it been so hard to get good games or games at all for that matter.... it’s difficult to find a squad of units that works for you. Graphics/GlitchesI rarely notice anything which slows down the frame rate of the game but graphical glitches are quite common, for example when some units die there ragdoll often stretches beyond what it should do creating elastically stretched units which bounce back again after it is quite comical unless it was one of your units then it’s a big bug bare! Often the cut scenes form from funny angles, this means that awesome sniper shot of you taking out an enemy Sectoid is actually a close up of your units head or a nearby wall... doesn’t ruin the game but doesn’t add much eitherImprovements?Better multiplayer, time penalty’s for leaving, 2v2,3v3 (Lack of MULTI-player), online AI 2vAI, Skirmish( Can’t play simple fights against AI), Survival Mode (how great would it be to have your units of say 3 players outlast entire armies of AI)Would I recommend this game?At the current steam price of £19.99 I would recommend purely for the length of the campaign. With a few play through its easy to clock up a 100 hours on this game without breaking a sweat. I would say Wish list this game, it’s always in Steam sales for next to nothing and if you get this and the expansion pack (Other DLC is alright (Slingshot) not sure it’s worth full price) then you will not regret playing this game.Further Update 24/09/2015Ive been replaying this with the LONG WAR MOD ( GOOGLE IT)LWM adds in similiar functions to Xenonaughts, massivley expands the game meaning one campaign can take over 100 hours to complete. LWM really sets a standard for what Firaxis need to achive in X:COM 2 . Do not the LWM is a mod, its not supported by Firaxis, noting this I had longer saves(seems to freeze but its jsut taking its time) but other than that its pretty good.  It also dosent update your Steam "Hours Played" thing sometimes.

Posted: November 27, 2013
												Enemy Unknown has its flaws and suffers from a tiny bit of "consolization" in terms of scope, depth, and interface, but it's still quite an accomplishment. After years and years of disasterous attempts to bring the X-com game style back into the limelight, this is most definitely the most successful. Though I personally don't think all of the changes to the original formula were good ones, XCOM stands on its own as a great game on its own merits.Enemy Within gets an even higher recommendation from me! It's a glorious example of Fraxis' ability to make "classic" expansion packs, while everyone else is lost in a sea of DLC. Instead of adding another world or story or anything, Enemy Within just makes the game more... everything. The additional game mechanics serve to further set it apart from any pre-established formula, while the rest is simply hundreds of little details that desperately needed a boost, such as map variety (the maps are numerous enough now that their presculpted nature is actually a joy), equipment variety (the game puts more "toys" in to give a better feeling of choice and playstyle), and soldier personalization (both in terms of abilities and appearance). My favorite thing of all, though, is a simple option (that I highly recommend!) at the beginning of the game which allows you to randomize the available abilities characters get to choose from. This is AWESOME and they clearly put a lot of thought into making it balanced, allowing interesting combinations without giving game-breaking overpowered situations or taking away vital skills that define the class types. It really gives each character more personality as you begin to use them for what you know they can do, not just their class types, and you don't need to rank a soldier up very far to begin defining a unique role. A few example of this that I've done, all with characters with only four or five abilities:- A sniper who gets massive bonuses if she's on a rooftop and has supressive fire abilites- A heavy weapons guy who acts as my team's best medic (usually a support role)- A grenadier support character who can carry multiple, more powerful grenades in addition to extra smoke grenadesSo, overall, I'd recommend the game! But now that Enemy Within is out, I can't imagine wanting to play without it.

Posted: November 5, 2013
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is an almost best case scenario of a modern, mainstream reimagining of the fantastic XCOM series from the 1990s. While some hardcore nostalgia fetishists might not like many of the changes and updates, I found the new XCOM to be incredibly fun, and stand on it's own as a new, yet familiar experience.You take on the role of the Commander of XCOM, a secret internationally funded organization that exists to combat a growing alien threat to planet Earth. You have control of many aspects of XCOM, including base-management, scientific research, some basic politicing, UFO interception, and most importantly, directing your squads in combat.While some elements that added complexity (and often frustration) in the original game, have been removed or simplified, the overall feel and depth of has been retained. There's a palatable sense of fear and being outmatched by your extraterrestrial enemy, in both the global geoscape, and the turn-based tactical combat. The game also doesn't avoid difficulty, and I recommend playing the game on Classic with Ironman mode on for a legitimate XCOM experience. I cannot stress the awesome atmopshere that game has, that seems to draw inspiration upon some of best elements of last generation's sci-fi (X-Files, Star Trek: TNG, Independence Day), while remaining entirely a creature of its own.There's certainly a few bugs, the little cinematic whenever you run into an enemy squad gets annoying quickly, and some of the criticisms about "dumbing down" for the modern console audience have a little bit of creedence on a few points, but overall this game feels like a great homage to the original, while being innovative and streamlined enough, to bring in new fans. And hell, any game that makes turn based tactical games sexy again is worth my support. Highly recommended to all strategy and sci-fi fans.

Posted: December 21, 2013
												As someone who is very fond of the likes of Final Fantasy Tactics and Tactics Ogre, I picked this up with little trepidation.In short, this is a turn-based strategy game in which you control a team of up to 6 soldiers in battles against alien invaders. It's quite easy to pick up while the aliens are ruthlessly efficient at murdering your poor soldiers. It's not a resource intense game to run (score if, like myself you rely on a laptop for your PC gaming fix) thankfully. Due to the small amount of soldiers you command compared to previous titles, you really have to think strategically in order to outsmart your extra-terrestrial foes. Using less important members of your squad as bait just isn't an option. I've sank quite a few hours into this as I feared I might. The aliens are nicely varied and require different strategies in order to be vanquished. The level and mission design is less so but this isn't a big problem. There are issues, however. These range from slightly irritating such as the frame rate dropping to single figures when a beserker moves to aliens spontaneously appearing behind your squad. There's also a high number of bugs, reportedly though I've only had to reload a level once. Overall, I'd consider this to be one of the best games I own. With the expansion out, there's no reason whatsoever not to pick this up if you enjoyed the older games, or have even a vague interest in using your noggin instead of the usual run-and-gun approach.

Posted: June 13, 2015
												This game is about taking risks.On the strategy layer the player manages the base building, research, soldiers and much more. There are a lot of things to keep track of and the game does a wonderful job by presenting the base in an ingenious “ant-farm” view. The complexity of the base and amount of things to manage increase each simulated month and the player is forced to make hard decisions what to prioritize. The game excellently builds up tension leading to a great finale.Core of the game is the tactical layer. The turn-based ground combat has a superb presentation and feels just right. Here the game really shines. Every misstep can mean death for a soldier and the failure of the mission and in turn more death and failures in following missions. But time is of the essence to collect the resource “meld” or disarming bombs, etc.  The best way to play this game is with iron man mode enabled (= no reloads), which means all decisions are final.  Never did I experience so much tension, drama and relief in any other game.

												XCOM enemy unknown is the best modern turn based strategy game. It has an excellent blend of base management and gritty tactical combat. It's a lethal game, where a tactical blunder means a dead squad member or a mismangement of resources leads to the loss of a country's support. XCOM starts off brutally difficult, with your soldiers clearly mismatched. However, as the game goes on, your soldier's training and equipment clearly outpaces the alien army. The disparity between your progression and the enemies makes the endgame start to drag, and the final battle is anticlimatic. XCOM enemy unknown (and I daresay it's essential expansion, enemy within) is a fantastic game that captivated me. It took me 3  days to complete the game the first time in 25 hours. If you're looking for a challenge, XCOM is the game to get

Posted: November 25, 2013
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a great, modern version of a cult-classic from the '90s. The earth is getting attacked by an alien invasion. The nations of the world found the XCOM to deal with the invaders - and you are the commander.The gameplay is divided into two parts - the strategic base building game, were you deal with developing new weapons, deciding what countries to protect with satelite surveillance or shooting down UFOs. The other part is the tactic mode - you send a squad of 4-6 elite soldiers to deal with the invaders. Turn based you move carefully, kill some invaders and try to take prisoners for further interrogation. Your soldiers progress in an RPG like manner in four classes: Storm, Heavy, Support and Snipers. Be carefull who you move first - one wrong move can kill a soldier you invested hours in.XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a game of decissions - do you buy a laser weapon or the better armor? When multiple cities get attacked at once - you have to decide which to defend, risking the other city and nation to get lost on you forever. You are the only chance for earth to repel the invasion. Use it - and have fun in a game I already spend 50 hours in.

												best turn-based strategy game ever. remake of the former best turn-based strategy game ever.command an elite supranational paramilitary organization to counter an alien invasion.combat plays like an isometric turn-based tactical strategy game... the management between battles it what really sets it apart though. manage finances & base construction, reverse-engineer captured alien technology (including alien autopsies), upgrade & customize your troops, and then decide which missions to accept (sometimes at the expense of others.)  the difficulty curve is also rather unique in how you start out at a distinct disadvantage to the enemy.  the game rewards you for playing smart & punishes you for your mistakes.  this forces you to plan ahead to try and gain enough momentum to keep up with the game's scaling difficulty.  every decision makes you weigh the consequences of your actions.overall, a worthy successor to the original, both being among my all-time favorite games.

Posted: October 12, 2015
												SO GOOD!...SO TERRIBLE! SO FRUSTRATING! The thing about Xcom is that the mechanics themselves are fantastic, they really are. The turn based squad strategy is fun, the overall research/building strategy is fine. The problem lies only in two elements: 1. Difficulty settings. 2. Random Number Generators. Let it be said, if you're fairly casual with strategy and you play this game casually on "normal" setting, the game is absolutely fine. No problems there. This review is not for you then, just ignore. That's just not for me. I recommend the game on this basis, that it works fine on normal and that the basic mechanics are well done. If you're very serious about strategy, you'll almost certainly find "Normal" difficulty too easy and "Classic" fitting in general (at least if you're only planning one playthrough). Sounds great, right? Could have been except for one thing: the variance on Classic. Everything is a roll of the dice, which is fine, but the variance is insane. You can do everything right and still lose the game in one brief moment of bad luck. I'll illustrate the problem with this one scenario that actually took place for me: Turn 1. Your squad arrives in the woods. You move them into defensive positions just in case you're being charged right off the bat. They're all in cover, they're all in Overwatch (guarding). Three aliens attack, the squad takes down the first one. The second one uses a skill that automatically deals 1 damage, it hits one guy. *BREAK* Let me here say that one damage is nothing, it really is nothing. So, the guy who got hit with the whopping 1 damage rolls a dice and panics. He panics by turning to his right and trying to execute his friend standing right next to him because... well, who knows. It's the standard panic reaction in this game. He rolls another dice and misses from point blank range. Just can't hit. Well, fine you think, but alas. Behind him is a seasoned veteran, a captain who has seen many battles. He rolls a dice too, he also panics. Now, he has taken 0 damage, he has merely seen one dude take one damage. Well, he handles panic in the same way and decides to execute one of his friends. He chooses your best solider (and medic) and nails her right in the back of the head with a critical hit, killing her instantly. End turn one. Turn 2. Bring up menu, quit game. Things like this just happen, they just do. You can restart the mission whenever they do, but it wears you out. Or it did with me. Worst thing is, they could fix everything wrong with this game so easily. 1. rebalance panic. 2. remove critical hits. Just those two things would limit the variance to a degree where the game would feel hard but fair. It's really all they needed to do and then the game would probably be a 10.

Posted: October 24, 2015
												This is not your dad's XCOM. A typically slick Firaxis entry, this is a re-imagining of the original that takes the bulk of the source and transports it into a sleek, cruel, narrative-led shell. The principles of XCOM are all here with some additions, subtractions and lot of careful streamlining. While some stand-out elements are missing (goodbye fully destructible environments), a lot of the things you would expect to miss are shown up as unpleasant memories that make the forefathers difficult to return to (weight-based equipment management, I'm looking at you!). It's a polished, shiny, occasionally eerie version of an old treasure that does everything it can to entice newcomers while somehow keeping the vast majority of the grognards happy as well. Only a few games genuinely earn a $30+ price tag, but I would not hesitate to recommend this at any time, let alone during a sale.

Posted: May 4, 2015
												So, this is my first time playing an XCOM game. I thought I'd give myself a challenge and try an Iron Man game on Classic difficulty. And a challenge I got! This game is brutal!Enjoying it thoroughly though. I think at 24 hours I've already got my money's worth, and I'm sure I'll be spending a lot more time with it in the future.*EDIT after 150 hours*Finally completed the game on Classic mode. After over a dozen of restarts and letting go of the Ironman requirement I'd set for myself...My overall opinion of the game hasn't changed much. Both the tactical- and strategy-layers are engaging and play very well.I do have some criticism as well though: I don't like the difficulty progression in this game. It starts out extremely hard. Your soldiers have paper-armour and pee-shooters for weapons. While the aliens you face use highly accurate plasma weapons. But you can catch up with the aliens fairly quickly and the game gets easier from there on out.In the last few missions my squad was completely overpowered. Most aliens didn't even get a shot off before I killed them...Still, I am looking forward to playing the game again. And this time I WILL beat Ironman!

Posted: January 25, 2014
												Excellent round-based tactical combat game. Had a lot of fun with it.Graphics are good, but not stunning, same goes for the music and sound effects. You have a lot of freedom in tackling the campaign, as I discovered at the end, because you can compare some of your stats (ingame days played, UFOs shot down, aliens killed, squad members lost, days to event X, etc.) to world-wide averages. I found this to be very neat, because if you want to you can analyse your own playstyle. I for instance discovered that I had very few ingame days played, but I took my sweet time within the missions.Nuisance 1: The interface of the game appears to be made for consoles, I would have liked a better adaptation for PC. It isn't terrible, but could have been smoother. More apparent outside of combat missions than within.Nuisance 2: The hotkey system is a bit annoying. There are (customizable) hotkeys for standard actions, but every time you use them the characters ingame reply with the same sentence every single time. Want to put the whole squad in overwatch? Get ready to hear the same words six times in a row. The alternative is using the character specific actions menu, where they don't reply to your commands and simply do as you ask. But they get swapped around all the time. Want to have a sniper moving to another cover, switch to pistol and go into overwatch? If you make the mistake of looking at his menu before switching the weapon you'll end up doing nothing when hitting 4, which is 'overwatch' in many cases. Now it's 2. Switch to a Heavy and now it's 3.

Posted: November 5, 2013
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is an almost best case scenario of a modern, mainstream reimagining of the fantastic XCOM series from the 1990s. While some hardcore nostalgia fetishists might not like many of the changes and updates, I found the new XCOM to be incredibly fun, and stand on it's own as a new, yet familiar experience.You take on the role of the Commander of XCOM, a secret internationally funded organization that exists to combat a growing alien threat to planet Earth. You have control of many aspects of XCOM, including base-management, scientific research, some basic politicing, UFO interception, and most importantly, directing your squads in combat.While some elements that added complexity (and often frustration) in the original game, have been removed or simplified, the overall feel and depth of has been retained. There's a palatable sense of fear and being outmatched by your extraterrestrial enemy, in both the global geoscape, and the turn-based tactical combat. The game also doesn't avoid difficulty, and I recommend playing the game on Classic with Ironman mode on for a legitimate XCOM experience. I cannot stress the awesome atmopshere that game has, that seems to draw inspiration upon some of best elements of last generation's sci-fi (X-Files, Star Trek: TNG, Independence Day), while remaining entirely a creature of its own.There's certainly a few bugs, the little cinematic whenever you run into an enemy squad gets annoying quickly, and some of the criticisms about "dumbing down" for the modern console audience have a little bit of creedence on a few points, but overall this game feels like a great homage to the original, while being innovative and streamlined enough, to bring in new fans. And hell, any game that makes turn based tactical games sexy again is worth my support. Highly recommended to all strategy and sci-fi fans.

Posted: July 12, 2014
												In XCOM: Enemy Unknown, you are waging war against an Alien Force invading Earth. You have to utilize limited resources to manage base construction, as well as scientific research and engineering projects to advance your team of soldiers into what is eventually a sophisticated military unit using hyper advanced technology.From time to time you are called upon to defend Earth from the invading Aliens, whether it be alien abductions in a major city or a UFO sighting. This is where the meat of the game is. You pick and choose soldiers who level up over time and assume roles like Sniper, Rocketeer or Medic, with permadeath mechanics involved.The game is really fantastic if you like turn based strategy games. There's a certain tense anxiety that comes from being pinned down by incredibly advanced, extremely dangerous aliens and hoping that one of your soldiers can pull of a shot that will shake up the situation and turn it into your favor. If you like the game, pick up the Enemy Within expansion as well, which is a comprehensive expansion pack that adds Mechs, Augmentations for soldiers and a new enemy faction.Shoutout to the Long War mod. If you feel like you've mastered the game, try Long War. It is a VERY expansive mod for XCOM: Enemy Unknown and XCOM: Enemy Within. It adds enormous amounts of content as well as makes an already difficult game relentlessly and extremely difficult. In my opinion, the Long War mod completes this already very fantastic game.

Posted: April 1, 2014
												Quick review: super fun modern day, turn based strategy game with some strong RPG elements. Highly recommend.Long review: This game is awesome. Just about every day for 3 months now, I have been opening my steam library and saying, “I’m going to play something new today” and then I start up X-Com again. I just can’t stop playing. Planning ambushes and assaulting Alien mother ships has just never been so satisfying.X-Com is essentially a turn based RPG set in modern day warfare. It utilizes a top down view to control a squad of customizable soldiers. Your team, equipped with the fanciest new gear, is tasked with meeting the alien invasion on the battlefield and pushing them back.  It goes beyond combat though. You have to manage your resources to keep the countries funding you happy and at the same time construct your own facility and research new technology so you can construct new equipment.  As with most games, there are scaling difficulties; in the case of X-com these settings truly range from very forgiving to extremely harsh, including an optional “ironman” mode in which you cannot revert to previous saves, making all decisions permanent when that mode is selected.I have to be honest, there are some definite low points for this game:  it has a boring and overly generic story with some downright bad voice acting to go along with it. The graphics were nothing impressive, and sometimes the animations glitch out and you end up shooting backwards, completely not facing your target.  Without the expansion, it was at times annoying to target aoe moves, as the ground target would bounce you screen around erratically.  However, for me, none of that was enough to detract from the pure enjoyment of the gameplay. I have logged like 100 hours at this point and I can’t bring myself to stop playing this game. The replay value is insanely high. There are tons of customizable options for subsequent play throughs, but even if you left all the options the same your game experience would be completely different. Not to mention all the additions the expansion brings to the table.I can understand that this type of game may not be for everyone, but if you have any interest in strategy gaming, this would be at the top of my list of recommendations. Also I won’t be writing a full review of the expansion, but if you enjoy the game, do not hesitate to get the expansion. It makes the game even more awesomer..er.

Posted: March 2, 2014
												Very good game, I'm a big fan of turn based strategy games and this feels like a nice follow on from Apocalypse that I played years ago.I'd image anyone looking to buy this probably has an idea of what they will be getting, so I though I would mention some of the negative sides of the game instead.Loadouts: The way your squad is balanced is a bit odd, essentially once you reach plasma rifles and better levels of armour the game becomes notably easier. It basically means you go from feeling too weak to arguably too strong for a large portion of the game.Hit Chance: Ok this one actually makes me really angry and is the reason I will never play on Iron Man. For whatever reason the devs decided that if your squad has anything below 75% chance to hit it basically means they have 75% chance to miss. However all levels of alien can more or less hit you flawlessly from 2 screens away. It makes me wonder if the developers don't understand how probability works but it happens consistently through missions and I have spoken to other people who confirmed they had the same problem.Cover: Yeah... I'm not sure why there are varying levels of cover. Either the devs didn't understand how cover works or couldn't be bothered implementing it properly. Basically full cover acts as cover, anything else is basically your squad closing their eyes thinking that means the enemy can't see them.I mainly wrote this to highlight the flaws with the game(and for a little rant lol), because they aren't mentioned much outside of the bugs for some reason. This is a great game and challenging as it is but I never like part of the challenge in a game coming from either the AI effectively cheating or from incorrectly implemented mechanics.

Posted: March 3, 2014
												Percentages mean nothing in this game:  99% to hit can (and will frequently) result in misses, so expect fury at how this game handles probability on too frequent of a basis for it to be just bad luck.  Its seeding mechanic also makes suggested "randomness" not really random since it is all predetermined when the map loads, where procedures occur based off of your actions instead of random response as it should be--it reduces the strategy and urgency in this strategy game with urgency in its story, imho, by forcing the random number generator to be more static.  Even when set to "random" it still is procedural, and by no means actually randomised.  I understand the devs' position on wanting to prevent players from reloading saves to make the same choice for better results, but I do not agree with it since the game's probability is so broken to begin with.  If they wanted to take a hard stance on development choices without protest, they needed to iron out the flaws tied to the decision.Still, I sunk time into it, albeit swearing all of the while.  Good game, it needs work which will never come, and it needs Steam workshop for mods made specifically to fix bugs and other problems that the devs will continue to ignore (these mods exist online already, but they are not integrated with Steam).  This game's problems are too outstanding for me to ignore despite what is good, and the shortcomings are too numerous to like this game more than it allows me to.  Buy it when it is on sale, because with no support and no Workshop, I do not feel that it is worth $30 USD, but it is absolutely worth $10 ish.

Posted: March 3, 2014
												XCOM Enemy Unknown was my introduction to the Team Tactics format, following a recommendation from a friend who played the originals.Highly addictive, challenging and rewarding. The graphics and animations are excellent (minus a couple of odd close ups), the gameplay is fluid. The action is intense at times, and in a way you can become quite attached to your soldiers, sometimes favouring some over others. In some situations, you may even have to make that near impossible decision of sacrificing one or two men so that the others can escape, or to save those last one or two civilians, which is never easy if the soldier in question is one of your best.There's base building, researching, soldier classes (snipers, assaults, heavy and support), using alien tech to make cool new guns and armour, shooting down enemy UFOs, rescue missions, keeping countries happy by protecting them, making them not so happy when you fail, everything to keep you busy and coming back for more.As for the Enemy Within expansion pack, that just makes a great game even better. It's pricey for what it is, it's usual price a lot more than what I would normally pay for expansion. But it does add a lot of new missions, maps, and even a new enemy so you do (almost) get what you pay for if you pay for it at top price (I bought it when the price came down in the sale).Highly recommended.

Posted: March 3, 2014
												The two main aspects of game play in Xcom: Enemy Unknown are tactical turn based shooting and resource and base management. Ok, not the most exciting sounding game play but both complement each other beautifully. Neither feels like a gimmick; both are well designed and thought out, actually require skill and foresight to be used strategically.You spend your time in the field, stopping aliens from destroy cities, abducting people and other unpleasant alien pastimes. Then take the resources you gained back to base, sort your squad, chose research, build equipment and facilities.However, the alien attacks, and other missions, happen at random; but are the only way to gain resources. Randomness in a core gameplay mechanic is annoying, but at the same time it gives the game an almost endless replay value.There aren’t really any main characters in Xcom: Enemy Unknown, there are only three characters in the entire game with names and faces. Yet, with the ability to name and customise the appearance of your soldiers you can make your own drama. I opted to name my soldiers after friends, watching them die on mass becomes a lot more absorbing.Xcom: Enemy Unknown is hard, and not for those who are new to the strategy genre. With the reliance on resources being spent well and your experienced soldiers not dying, one wrong move will rip out the foundations of everything you’ve built.The graphics aren’t mind blowing; they’re cartoony, but it gives the aliens a rich visual style. Combined with the sci-fi soundtrack it gives Xcom: Enemy Unknown a unique feel.If you like strategy, you’ll love Xcom: Enemy Unknown. If not, I wouldn’t recommend this is where you start, as the game can be unforgiving. It’s still one of the best games of 2012, it’s a classic game, from a classic genre, that’s been streamlined for the current generation.

Posted: April 2, 2016
												Xcom is widely known to be an exceptional game.I would agree absolutely with that general concensus that this is a really decent tactical strategy game.  I can almost see what this is based on and where it has come from.  This version too exhibits some really nice additions which allows me to say with absolute confidence that technology made this game better.  In saying that there are issues with this game's quality and its design, and irronically Firaxis are getting no better at making games that are flawless... and that is worth saying as these are integral parts of the game I can  see that don't work/don't give enough feedback/ or just are buggy as hell, and it doesn't feel like it will get fixed at all.The beauty of Xcom Enemy Unknown is that is has so many sides to it.  It is in everyway, like Divinity : Dragon Commander, where you manage your ship, build stuff, get reserach, monitor stuff, build more stuff  in between tactical battle mode.  This design is brilliant can offer so much depth I think, and Dragon Commander went a step further in many cases.  I will add that Xcom's implementation of that is no different and allows you to do all sorts, though from what I can see, if you dont get this stuff by a certain time in the game, the game seems to suffocate your operation... not sure about that exactly,  but it felt like I 'nearly' did and it cost me at some point throughout the game.  Whats more, as Dragon Commander's Political exploits are generally not required in your 10th game, alot of the stuff on here is not time draining and does NOT keep you from getting into what XCom is all about.  Combat.Combat is decent and has reasonable depth and certainly does not get overloaded with stuff.  Its seamless, nice to do and leaves you little to worry about in your decisions.  improvements of weapons are worth it, improvement of the skills of each soldier is worth it , and when you get to a stage in the game where some of you soldiers get 'extra skillls'?  It's definately worth it.  However when its late game and your waiting to 'get paid', battle mode does feel like a chore sometimes, it restricts progress.Each of the classes to some extent feel like they are worth using, though the best ones at the start feel weak at the end, and the weak classes at the start feel OP at the end.What adds to this is the camera system, when an order is made, the camera follows your soldier, or some cinematic view is taken.  This is not something I would comment as being essential, but as it doesn't break anything and it looks good, gives  the game a nicer feel, it defeintely is good overall and gives the game a nice sheen.Now what I don't like about Xcom: Firaxis, have had a few gmes I have played with certain bugs and broken functionality, Xcom is no different.  As amazing as Xcom looks, and runs, Firaxis clearly didn't get the engine right.. There is a serious issue with the selection of parts of the map that you are not looking at ... for example, I can be looking at the interior of a ship and then click inside to move, and the system will think I the roof tile (above)or lower floor(below), potentially screwing up tactics(yes which is the difference between something going horribly wrong!)and the game (Diablo Hardcore characters and poor connection come to mind, and yes you can play hardcore on this - no saves!). I guess there is a cure, if you are pretentous enough to challenge that assertion, as you will need to look carefully where the point is and where the path fidning trail is.  This generally means, you have to zoom out, rotate the view blah blah... all in all its a bit of BS.. waste of time and does takes from the game. This should not happen if you are not zoomed to another 'layer' in my oppinion, and I think that is just logical.  I think if Firaxis thought about this issue, then they could have included an undo move button function, but they didn't... There are other issues with seeing the range of your units and what they can attack as it is not clear at all what you can attack and what you can until you move that unit...Also as far as i can see, you cannot pick your squad, i.e. if I want to train up a bunch of noob soldiers instead of using vets , then I can't, it's simple... Well, I could of course make sure (the vets) all take mortal wounds last match so they are off in the infirmary nursing wounds, but nothing more from looks of it.  Then in addition to that, when they are removed from the squad without wounds, the equipment stays on the soldier... Sometimes those soldiers dont show up in the team for the next mission, so you have 1 soldier with no gear (perhaps returning from the infirmary)and another one in the barracks that you have to track down and strip of their gear, and you CAN'T switch them... makes for boring cheese and bad design if you ask me... and yes, some equiptment mid game is damn expensive, so it is important that this works!Science is a let down, like supcom2, once you researched everything, you have wasted money on labs and scientists are in-effect worthless, it is very dis-empowering, and as much as your squad is powerful enough and the rest is justifiably left up to you to be a good strategist, it still makes for something of an empty concept... Civ and Alpha Centurai had post science qualifications.. I think they could have added those in to make an intersting endgame of sorts, making science a worth while endeavour.The story was alright I guess and the game flows much like Unreal 3, so its not complicated, but its good, and the art design definately complements that with the idea of who the alien race really is and where your going.There are some bad parts to this game , and as many people will rave blindly with the 'horde', I feel its nesscessary to point out Xcom is NOT perfect.  However, as a game, I spent 50+ hours  on this and I could play it again.  It was generally fun to play, so I would say most of the hype is infact justified.I will add, that I would definately consider gettin Xcom 2 at near full price as I liked this one so much.

												I absolutely love this game. I could spend way more than a hundred hours on it and I probably will eventually. 												XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Enemy WithinRelease Date: October 9, 2012Strengths:-Originality-Good graphics-Good level design and gameplay-Nice ambience and atmosphere-Great replayability because of random generation of maps each time-Great story and characters-Excellent sound and voice acting-Character and team customizations-Resource management and economy based-Research technologies and build new weaponsLimitations:-Turn based so takes a lot of play time so RTS lovers may not like it-Limited DLC Conclusion:XCOM is truely one of the best turn based strategy games out there. You command a small but highly capable unit called XCOM to counter an Alien invasion. You can select, customize different classes of soldiers in your unit and also add genetic enhncements or cybernetic upgrages to them. Posted: August 17, 2015
												I don't often get hooked on games like I did this time. I bingeplayed this and dreamt about it for a week until I came through in the other end. Perhaps the whole turn-based "group of soldiers" strategy genre is still new to me..but I thought the game mechanics were really well made and intuitive. Cool to have everything in 3D too, makes everything look SO much more realistic than just having an above-view like in the original XCOM game (which was great for its time BTW).Good graphics, cool abilities for soldiers, fun and easy to manage the facility in between missions (and a suitable challenge keeping the money coming in), smooth gameplay mechanics, works natively in Linux, good music and atmosphere. If I have to think of anything negative it is perhaps a certain lack of character depth which perhaps also takes away from getting into the story. The main story line (battling the aliens) takes most of the space, there's not much time for chit chat and as commander you manage the whole operation proffessionally, instead of getting up and personal with the soldiers or, well mostly, with the facility bosses. Also..in the end, when all is supposed to become clear, the alien voice talking is sometimes hard to hear due to the combat noises.I'd give this 4/5. Addictive game! Perhaps even more so if you're into multiplayer?

Posted: June 25, 2013
												One of the greatest, most addictive and most fun games I've played in the last years. This is the kind of game that gives you a set of rules, a list of resources and a series of tech trees and let's you play with them, always forcing you to prioritize something, never being able to being good at everything and constantly elevating the level of challenges as you progress. It creates a constant panic environment where you are pressed to make compromises and you swear everytime you suffer any loss. Just DON'T play anything under "classic" difficulty.Problems: stupid teleporting bug still present which can ruin your perfect ironman game, the game story is not horrible but it is a bit underwhelming, at high difficulties losing a substantial number of squad members late in the game effectively means game over.Nor better nor worse than the original, just different (and incredibly good).

Posted: August 29, 2014
												If you are a kid this game will make you a man.Every decision you make in the battlefield will have consequences and most of the time deadly.You may start with a full equiped squad and seconds later find yourself left with only one alive,because you were flanked or mispotitioned and now you have to fight with what is left like a real soldier you have to readjust your strategy constantly.Tension is amazing in this game and consider that i never liked squad based games.Pros -Battles with real tension-Maybe the best artificial inteligence i have seen in any video game-If you don't use tactics you are dead-Great visuals and sounds accompanied with amazing physics-Even though story is almost non existent you will be quite eager to learn more about this unknown enemy as the game progresses-Gameplay is solid and addicting-Very nice set of upgrades and base management-Very challenging and unforgiving but never frustrative-Lots of maps and each one is well designed-One mistake in the battlefield and the odds can turn against you which makes every encounter awesomeCons-Camera issues-Poor soldier progresion system-Repetitive objectives-<90% missed> shots happen way too frequently-Poor tutorialOverall 9.5/10 a true masterpiece!

Posted: January 11, 2013
												My game of the year in 2012.  XCOM Enemy Unknown is a turn based strategy game that you will become so invested in throughout each playthrough (roughly 30 hours).  This game is hard and will strain your mind because of the tough decisions you'll have to make since not everyone will live and you won't have enough resources to build everything you want.  Seeing your soldiers grow (and die) is something you need to experience.  XCOM is a great buy for any strategy or sci-fi fan.Now with the new expansion, Enemy Within, there's yet another reason to play XCOM.  Enemy Within adds a lot of interesting features such as an enemy human faction as well as new ways to strengthen your soldiers.  Nothing beats a genetically enchanced sniper or a cybernetic soldier running around in a mech suit with a flamethrower and grenade launcher.  Buy both the base game and the expansion if you can!

Posted: November 16, 2013
												A crowning achievement of strategy, one of the best if not THE BEST strategy game I've ever played. Seriously, it even made me change my mind about turn based combat. It is unfourtunately not without it's flaws.As tense as it makes the game, the difficulty does get kind of silly, especially when the Aliens are able to turn your guys into zombies and throw floating machine gun things at you. This is happening just as you figured out you can research something other than second hand nerf guns.Speaking of weapons, everything other than the before-mentioned nerf guns both look and sound really cool. The laser sniper even does the Mass Effect folding gun thing. The aliens however start with plasma weapons and eventually go all the way up to the floating machine gun things I mentioned earlier.The alien types are all nicely varied, different strategies and weapons have to be employed to beat each one, even if they do get a little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t later on in the game.And now you can play it with giant robots and super soldiers I honestly don't know what could make this game better, maybe some way of rewarding soldiers who actually hit somet- oh wait, you can. The medals system is a cool way to provide passive buffs to soldiers without the need for gene therapy and can be transferred on to the Super Soldiers and Giant robots.I do have a few complaints with this new DLC though, Normal has been "balanced" I didn't even finish the base game, partly because it was so hard and partly because there were only like five maps in total that got really boring after a while. But now I'm about a quarter of the way into the game and I still haven't suffered a single loss, granted I am playing on normal whereas in the base game my manorexia wouldn't let me play on anything other than classic, which I've heard has been made harder, well the balances are probably for the best then.On the subject of harder difficulties, there's a new alien type that cloaks and strangles your soldiers, at this point they aren't anything other than a nuisance, because if you have everyone close together then you can just get him on overwatch as he goes to strangle the soldier. Unless he's gone for a sniper or someone that is for some reason completely isolated from the rest of the squad.The DLC also fixes a ridiculous amount of bugs and adds general polish to the game, soldiers can now speak in the language of their country, so we don't get Russians speaking fluent English in an American accent anymore, there are more customization options for the troops and soldiers on overwatch tend not to shoot through walls anymore.Overall, the base game and the DLC are absolutely brilliant, I would reccomend buying them both together and starting with the DLC though as that brings so many balances and fixes to the table it's not really worth it to play the base game anymore.

Posted: December 1, 2014
												Enemy Unknown is the latest release to bring back the classic X-Com series. This time aliens have invaded Earth and are generally up to no good, and it's your job as Commander to stop them.The game is turn based strategy through and through, although you do have to manage your base and your finances. You do this by keeping countries happy, which reduces panic, which in turn earns you cash. As you defeat the aliens you gain access to their technology which you can study and adapt to you own needs.Most of the game-play elements from the classic series make a return, meaning that you will have to manage your base, keep an eye out for alien craft, build whatever you need and control any research whilst keeping a tight grip on your finances. As you progress your soldiers will become more skilled and generally more powerful, and as your study continues and gain access to more powerful equipment.The game has multi-player too, so you can fight against human players as well as the computer controlled opponents. When you do send you soldiers to fight each player is given a “turn” in which to move or shoot. The the general rule is that you have to find cover, and then shoot back. Your squad has other skills which you can use to adapt to the enemy's strategy. There are a lot of different aliens to blast, some of which are quite tough, especially in groups.The game can be easily played with a controller or the more traditional keyboard and mouse. The game has a sort of way-point system which snaps to a grid. This works well for the most part, but the cursor can sometimes sort of “twitch” which means that your soldiers don't quite go where you want them to and crucially are not in cover. If you take you time and make sure it's where you want it before you click then it's OK.Graphically the game is quite attractive although a little simple looking. Having said that most of the action takes place from an overhead perspective, and there can be a lot of enemies on screen – especially in the later missions. The maps are not overly large, but are well designed and have many different features to take advantage of, giving you a lot of options during combat. Having said that there aren't really that many and you will fight in the same areas over and over – even if they are supposed to be different countries.The game should keep you busy for a while as there is plenty to do and an alien plot to uncover, but the small control problem and the limited locations can make it a little frustrating.

												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a HIGHLY recommended game for strategy players especially from the RTS genre. XCOM EU is based from the classic XCOM game and was remade especially for the modern players. Gameplay wise, this is more of a turn based strategy playing and planning for a good executions. This game is also very similar to the old Rainbow Six games such as Rainbow Six: Rogue Spear because of the squad based planning and customization like changing your squad's faces, body, helmet, armor, etc.If you love playing mind games like Chess or Games of the General, this game is highly recommended for you. Of course, you'll end up enjoying it so much that thinking is never been so hard to do. Your head will NEVER hurt in playing this game. 100% guarantee (unless you're frustrated in losing your "best friend").I really highly recommend it to you all especially for those who are NOT an RTS fan and turn based gaming. Storyline wise, it is a top notch but the ending is quite "predictable". Nevertheless, overall the game is worth to buy and worth the weight!Verdict: 8.9/10
