												A positively excellent game;You have your base to upgrade - Simulation (A big plus in my books)You have a force to deploy and use efficiently as possible - Turn based strategy.Combine these two things with aliens, robots and ufos, you get XCOM. Posted: July 16, 2015
												A go to game when you want to just sit back and relax. I love turned based games as the pacing is slow, no need to rush and with a good strategy everything comes together in the end. XCOM is basically a special unit that has been set up to counter an alien invasion. The soldiers that are recruited/involved are of both genders and of a vast international variety. You take the role of the 'commander' a faceless entity who issues orders on the battlefield to your 5 man unit while also juggling research/engineering/training back at home base. Starting off you have limited options but the game does well in introducing new features, the interface is user friendly and everything is well explained.As you get further in the game you have lots of options; Do you build a satelitte nexus? - So you can have full coverage over Asia/Africa?, Do you invest all your monthly earnings in Research&Development? You have to be careful as some countries might leave the XCOM program if the panic lvl stays in the red, diplomatic missions and satellitte coverage can help reduce this. Very enjoyable and i havent even looked at multiplayer yet. Thumbs up.

If you seek variation, a thrilling battle to fight, and decision between victory and defeat, go grab it as quick as you can. Posted: January 3, 2014
												While I loved Enemy Unknown, my main gripe was how repetitive things quickly b ecame without more indepth side quests and events. Enemy Within remedied it and then some. The inclusion of MEC and Gene Mod soldiers breaks things up to make things more interesting, and the skill tree changes made all classes more powerful in general.While the Exalt campaign was a bit underwhelming, it escalated into something greater after defeating them and the ending of the game felt all the more satisfying with the new named character Annette. Enemy Within adds a lot of great content that made it more satisfying to play through, and I recommend it warmly to anyone who haven't had a chance to play it yet. Buy both main game and expansion for the best experience.

Posted: December 27, 2013
												This game makes me rage.. But I love it!Firaxis studios' remaking of the older XCOM franchise is a great game all around without a shadow of a doubt. It has aliens, guns, global terror and addictive tactical play that I just can't leave alone. The premise is simple enough, you're an operative for the XCOM organisation, and it's your job to direct the forces at your disposal to best serve the interests of humanity in fighting off the alien menace (more on them in a mkinute). You do this through turn based tactical combat scenarios and a metagame of base management and decision making that overarches the main gameplay by forcing you to choose which options you want to research, what facilities you want to construct to better your force or gear, and which missions you want to send your recruits on to shoot the aliens to bits. At the basic level, that's what the game is all about really - decision making. It's why it works so wonderfully, and also why it will make you rage but keep coming back for more. The turn based nature of the gameplay means you can weigh the odds of different approaches as you go and take your time to figure out the various angles and opportunities you have at each point. Squad cohesion is important in mission gameplay, and a poor choice of action or missed opportunity could see you paying for it down the line with your squad members, when alien plasma fries them. It forces you to adapt and overcome your enemies, predict the outcome of your options and make the best choices, whether that involves a squad wide attack to wipe out the enemy or (occasionally) sacrificing one member to allow the others to move to a safer position or escape (though you'll find that this is a painful lesson when it's a high level unit with helpful abilities that you lose however). There's plenty to keep track of and experiment with too. Your different units have classes that affect their weaponry loadout (heavy units being armed with an LMG and Rocket launcher at the first level for example) and abilities that go along with them (in the case of the aforementioned heavy, suppression fire and usage of the launcher etc), so making sure that the different specialisations are utilised well is wise to be keep in mind while on a mission. You are free to choose who you want to field however, so if you find you don't really enjoy using a particular class or would rather take another sniper than a support unit for example, it's your choice. Outside of mission play the decision making is just as important if not more so. You'll create a base layout with facilities to upgrade or improve your arsenal and construct your gear between missions, and keeping appropriate facilities close gives benefits so juggling everything or putting one plan on hold to get a different module placed first can provide bigger bonuses down the line. The different research tiers as the game progresses ramp up in power quite nicely and are satisfying to play with when you finally get to top tier weaponry and armor (higher tier armors especially offering some interesting options in terms of gameplay, IMO). All important research unlocks all these goodies so taking advantage of your time at the base to figure out which projects you want to take next is the other main aspect between mission play to keep in mind - neglecting any one aspect ofyour squad's equipment can leave you underequipped for some missions but researching the alien tech and recovered corpses etc is also important so as to discover their weak points, making it a fine balancing act. So yeah, as the title said, it'll make you rage. When Corporal Bloggs pops his head round a blind corner only to get it melted by alien plasma fire unexpectedly you might want to shout, or swear, whatever floats your boat. But it's so satisfying to play that you'll just want to keep coming back to try again. Maybe Corporal Bloggs' brother will have better luck on point instead..

Posted: February 6, 2016
												Writing this right after I played XCOM 2 I find that this game holds a special place in my heart that can't be replaced.The base game is pretty good and can last you a while but may get dull after a few playthroughs with all the bugs that you may encounter. 8/10Enemy Within steps up the game so much with balancing, a new MEC class, and a great gene mod system that allows you to make your school mates into genetic super heros. Still a few bugs and quircks from the base game. 9/10Once you get Enemy Within and Long war, you find that this is the best traditional XCOM expirience out there. It's tough, mind boggling, diverse, and will make you rethink your strategy every month of the game. 10/10If you want some good old fashioned XCOM but don't want to go through the old system of OG XCOM then XCOM: Enemy Within along with the Long War mod is the way to go.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												XCOM is a hard game to describe to anyone without previous knowledge of the games.  It is turn-based Tactical-strategy-combat with some elements of RPGs, city management, and maybe just a bit of horror game thrown in, probably not that last one though.  This game is best described by comparison to other Turn based strategy games. It's like Final Fantasy Tactics with rocket launchers, Civilization with aliens, and Fire emblem with high powered assault and sniper weapons.The Enemy Within expansion is basically the same but with MORE, if you don't think your assault troops can take or dish out enough damage, you can take any old soldier and with some amputations, some meld, and bit of resources turn them into a walking mechanized powerhouse of destruction.  On the downside, the difficulty curve is all over the place, and there are some rather annoying bugs(especially in regard to some of the new enemies), most of which can be avoided by saving whenever you finish a mission and reloading if they occur.

Posted: February 1, 2014
												XCOM isnt your typical turn based game. It takes the turn based fighting of final fantasy-like games and adds an entire dimension of gamplay by including cover tactics, movement, and even a perma-death system. This game has the same hulky looking heros seen in gears of war but in a slightly less macho way. The gameplay forces you to pay attention to your every move and truly think if you plan on keeping your favorite soldiers alive. The only drawback to this game (and its a HUUUGE pain) is that the game only offers an auto-save feature if you play in a seperate game mode. This mode features gameplay which cannot be undone by loading a previous save. I have played XCOM for hours and forgotten to save, only to have my whole crew blown up by a vehicle or to have simply gone to sleep. This one downside reallllly takes away from the game. Otherwise, this is one title you do not want to miss!

Posted: January 5, 2016
												Wow, just finished my first full playthrough and loved this.Technically it is just a isometic, turn based strategy game with a rather cliche story and a random number generator (for chance to hit, enemy spawns, random enecounters/missions, etc.). What it feels like is you are risking a squad of your best, most skilled, and most cherished team mates. You don't know what's around the next corner (ha, seriously, not kidding on that one), but they believe in you. They trust to make the tough choices, the right choices, so they can help make the world a better, safer place from those alien scum that will stop at nothing to wipe out humanity. Oh and you also throw in a rookie with them cause you need him to skill up. (And why did my random 'class type' rolls mean I only got 2 support class but like 10 heavy's?!!!)Really enjoyed the tactic stuff (quickly learned that rushing into the fog of war is a BIG no-no). Growing attached to a few of my best. Killing the bad guy and saving my team with the last shot from the last person on the last move of my turn. Also, when you get the best weapons and gear and are taking the battle to enemy (thank you lab guys).Really no a fan of the way the random enemy spawn means occasionally you move the first guy like 1 step forward and suddenly every enemy on the map appears - aaarrrgggh! Or Missing with the last shot from the 3 person in a row. That's the random number generator for you.Also, it looks kinda nice, and you can whittle quite a bit time customising the look of your people.Overall, totally enjoyed.

Posted: November 16, 2013
												A crowning achievement of strategy, one of the best if not THE BEST strategy game I've ever played. Seriously, it even made me change my mind about turn based combat. It is unfourtunately not without it's flaws.As tense as it makes the game, the difficulty does get kind of silly, especially when the Aliens are able to turn your guys into zombies and throw floating machine gun things at you. This is happening just as you figured out you can research something other than second hand nerf guns.Speaking of weapons, everything other than the before-mentioned nerf guns both look and sound really cool. The laser sniper even does the Mass Effect folding gun thing. The aliens however start with plasma weapons and eventually go all the way up to the floating machine gun things I mentioned earlier.The alien types are all nicely varied, different strategies and weapons have to be employed to beat each one, even if they do get a little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t later on in the game.And now you can play it with giant robots and super soldiers I honestly don't know what could make this game better, maybe some way of rewarding soldiers who actually hit somet- oh wait, you can. The medals system is a cool way to provide passive buffs to soldiers without the need for gene therapy and can be transferred on to the Super Soldiers and Giant robots.I do have a few complaints with this new DLC though, Normal has been "balanced" I didn't even finish the base game, partly because it was so hard and partly because there were only like five maps in total that got really boring after a while. But now I'm about a quarter of the way into the game and I still haven't suffered a single loss, granted I am playing on normal whereas in the base game my manorexia wouldn't let me play on anything other than classic, which I've heard has been made harder, well the balances are probably for the best then.On the subject of harder difficulties, there's a new alien type that cloaks and strangles your soldiers, at this point they aren't anything other than a nuisance, because if you have everyone close together then you can just get him on overwatch as he goes to strangle the soldier. Unless he's gone for a sniper or someone that is for some reason completely isolated from the rest of the squad.The DLC also fixes a ridiculous amount of bugs and adds general polish to the game, soldiers can now speak in the language of their country, so we don't get Russians speaking fluent English in an American accent anymore, there are more customization options for the troops and soldiers on overwatch tend not to shoot through walls anymore.Overall, the base game and the DLC are absolutely brilliant, I would reccomend buying them both together and starting with the DLC though as that brings so many balances and fixes to the table it's not really worth it to play the base game anymore.

Posted: June 3, 2013
												Game was good. Not gonna say the game was great. It was just on the under side of great. Like... if Good was... 80%, and Great was 90%, and Perfect was 100%, this game is a solid 89%.THE GOOD: The game uses modern ideas regarding user interface to simplify a lot of the unnecessarily complex portions of the original game system *without significantly reducing quality*. That last bit is important. Dumbing down a system for the sake of making it simple is usually a disastrous move, but X-Com still feels pretty complex and strategy-minded despite simplifying the way in which your squads move and interact with the world. The added skill-driven leveling system is a welcome addition, and I found soldier and squad management to be a very enjoyable part of the game. Had a lot of fun.THE BAD: The simplification process removed a lot of the technical things you could do to improve your chances of survival. It is now much more difficult to remove cover from an enemy because free-targetting on most weapons was removed. Also, the removal of time units seriously limits the amount of off-turn defensive fire you can provide. Finally, the method by which you discover aliens was a nice effort but in my opinion, was very poorly designed. Aliens you discover immediately use free actions to get into cover, and then act on their next turn, but aliens will rarely, if ever, discover your squad if you are in a fortified position. This means that exploration is a very dangerous activity, and it discourages a player from using his squad tactically to flank enemies for fear of discovering squads of additional ones. In the end, the safest way to proceed is to simply have one of your squad run as far as he can at normal speed, then retreat back to a full squad on overwatch if anything is discovered. It feels a bit tedious and cheap♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and i felt like the tactical element of the game suffered somewhat as a result of the need to cheat the game to cope with the unbalanced discovery system. The maps also felt really small and linear in comparison to the original Xcom, so some of the suspense of exploring an open map is lost.THE UGLY: The random number generator is a vicious and implaccable foe in this game. There are some truly frustrating moments when it feels like cover has no effect and your soldiers are totally defenseless. As someone who has beaten this game on the harder difficulties and also Ironman mode, the best advice I can give you is: research and produce the highest level of armor you can as soon as you can. It will save the lives of your soldiers. Having the highest level officers possible at any given time is important.TL;DR: Game's recommended. Some of the facets of the old game are lost in the translation but I feel like Xcom gained more than it lost in the most recent incarnation. Looking forward to DLC/Sequels.

Posted: November 30, 2013
												Definitely recommend. Although turn-based, the game is fast-paced and immensely intense. Every decision you make is crucial in progressing, and any mistake is costly. If you turn up the difficulty, each match is exhausting yet very rewarding when you've won against the aliens. There're a lot of different modes too so it's not always just plain-kill aliens on site. You can also customize your soldiers to your liking, which is nice since you sort-of create an emotional attachment to the soldiers who survive, and you can make them all pink. When you're immersed in the matches, time flies by without you knowing it, and you can't wait to start another one. There's a little bit of a storyline which does get the game flowing well, but there can be more aliens. Graphics and animations are also very nice and detailed. PLAY IT

Posted: December 10, 2013
												Put together tactical gameplay with tense gameplay, and add in the strategy and beauty, and you get XCOM. While I haven't played the previous XCOM games before this, the tutorial gets you to know the game easily, and this is probably the best turn-based strategy game I've done so far, possibly better than Civ V for the fun. RNG can be a bit screwy at times, and bugs appear every so often, but this game is too good to pass up, especially when it's on sale.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												Firaxis has their turn-based strategy gameplay down to a science.  After years of honing their skills with the broad strokes of the Civilization series, the team has now scaled down to focus on the intricacies of battle   The core experience is divided into two parts: the turn-based squad level tactical game; and the metagame of equipment upgrades, skill trees, scientific research, and managing panic levels around the world.First, let's talk about the story.  It is standard videogame science fiction.  Creepy aliens abduct people, secret government ops fight back while upgrading their equipment with alien technology.  It does just fine and, most importantly, stays out of your way and allows you to "create your own stories" with the squad members you train.  I have never played the classic XCOM game, but brutal difficulty is a mechanic here.  Ideally, you play Ironman mode(where the game autosaves every decision, so soldier death is permanent).  I have yet to make it all the way through an Ironman game myself!  Regardless, name your squadmates after your friends or characters from movies and you end up caring when your maxed-out Colonel Starbuck gets their face ripped off by some fast moving critter with spikes for legs.Now the metagame.  You'll spend roughly a 1/3 of your time in the headquarters menus.  Everything is presented with a fairly clean interface and it gives you a number of options on how you might want to proceed.  Do I research alien armor alloys so my soldiers last longer?  Or do I focus on weapon technology and build laser shotguns?  Don't forget about saving some of that hard earned cash to increase satellite coverage!  It all feels compelling and definitely is rewarding to step onto the battlefield with that newly engineered plasma sniper rifle.  That being said, the game does demand that you prioritize certain research and building tasks in order to advance the story missions.  It also becomes apparent after a couple playthroughs how essential some of the upgrades are, breaking just a bit of that illusion that you can play absolutely any way you want.  The Second Wave options menu and Enemy Within DLC do expand on this area quite a bit though and provide some wonderful extra options.Finally, the tactics game.  Superb!  There is a fantastic balance between depth and accessibility.  Engagements play out like intricate, four dimensional games of Rock-Paper-Scissors; constantly balancing unit cover, sight lines, suppressing fire, and reloading becomes imperative.  Remember, it's turn-based.  So a lot of the fun is in anticipating enemy attack patterns, taking the time to think, and methodically moving your squad to maintain support for each other.  All the information you need is readily available and the different skill sets of each squad member are easy to apply to battlefield conditions.  It's wonderful...until it seems to defy itself.  The AI in this game will occasionally make you RAGE.  Untimely misses, logic defying lines of site, and inability to modify which tiles are enroute to a location will drive even the most sedate players nuts.  That, and the camera control can be utterly obnoxious.None of the issues with this game have ever made me not want to pick it back up again.  The strategy is engaging and you feel a direct influence from your research and engineering decisions.  It is an absolute keeper and would be of special interest to any thinking man's game collection.

Posted: August 3, 2014
												Just, amazing. To be honest, it was more fun naming the soldiers after people you knew (liked or hated) and treated them the same way I would IRL. For example, i was starting a new run, and a friend had just♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off. Created a new soldier, named him ******* (I want to hide the real name in case he reads this), and just had him essentially dance as fodder in front of a few a sectoids. The game had, of course, the biggest replayability factor in the world, since there was always that lust for a better run. Also, there is no such thing as a perfect run in this game. Unless you are able to protect every soldier, make the most efficient use of all your base, not lose a single country, human during a terror mission (which I think actually is impossible), all while not dying yourself due to starvation, you have officially become a gaming god, and please, notice me senpai. All in all, an amazing strategy game which can draw the player in without the use of too immersive a story line. SIDENOTE: At the end of the Mothership Mission, I don't actually know exactly what the developers were thinking... were they trying to make the game end in a tragic way? Personally, I felt no attachment to the soldiers, which i guess would be one area they could have improved on. The soldiers themselves (being hand-crafted by you, usually) have no integrated storyline, so you will usually never feel any attachment unless you name them after people you know.

Posted: June 21, 2015
												Simple answer: Yes. XCOM is a game that is worth the money.Key features:. Command, customise, and control squads of troops on highly tactical mission’s vs aliens.. Build your base up with various different facilities such as research labs and engineering labs.. Take equipment from aliens and use it to research more advanced weapons, armour, and equipment for your squads. (Energy weapons). Missions are generated based on the actions you take.. Enables you to play through several times with several different difficulty settings and modifiers (random stats for each squad member)XCOM is one of the few games I have actually bought because I felt the developers deserved the money for such a fun and interesting game. If you’re looking for a turn based strategy game where squad members have different classes and abilities this is the game for you. The soldier’s accuracy is based on what weapon he/she has, the range of the target, and what cover the target it is in. This comes down to giving the player a percentage chance (55% chance of hitting target and doing this amount of damage). Also, XCOM 2 is coming out in November and it is going to be even better.

Posted: June 13, 2015
												This game is about taking risks.On the strategy layer the player manages the base building, research, soldiers and much more. There are a lot of things to keep track of and the game does a wonderful job by presenting the base in an ingenious “ant-farm” view. The complexity of the base and amount of things to manage increase each simulated month and the player is forced to make hard decisions what to prioritize. The game excellently builds up tension leading to a great finale.Core of the game is the tactical layer. The turn-based ground combat has a superb presentation and feels just right. Here the game really shines. Every misstep can mean death for a soldier and the failure of the mission and in turn more death and failures in following missions. But time is of the essence to collect the resource “meld” or disarming bombs, etc.  The best way to play this game is with iron man mode enabled (= no reloads), which means all decisions are final.  Never did I experience so much tension, drama and relief in any other game.

Posted: July 2, 2014
												What's not to love about this game?You play as a squad of men (and women) who are brave enough to face the alien menace.This game deserves multiple playthroughs because of the large amount of different ways it could be played and the story seems to never get boring... also you can change your troops names to your friends names so you can make your friends fight the aliens and maybe even die to them!

Posted: December 21, 2013
												As someone who is very fond of the likes of Final Fantasy Tactics and Tactics Ogre, I picked this up with little trepidation.In short, this is a turn-based strategy game in which you control a team of up to 6 soldiers in battles against alien invaders. It's quite easy to pick up while the aliens are ruthlessly efficient at murdering your poor soldiers. It's not a resource intense game to run (score if, like myself you rely on a laptop for your PC gaming fix) thankfully. Due to the small amount of soldiers you command compared to previous titles, you really have to think strategically in order to outsmart your extra-terrestrial foes. Using less important members of your squad as bait just isn't an option. I've sank quite a few hours into this as I feared I might. The aliens are nicely varied and require different strategies in order to be vanquished. The level and mission design is less so but this isn't a big problem. There are issues, however. These range from slightly irritating such as the frame rate dropping to single figures when a beserker moves to aliens spontaneously appearing behind your squad. There's also a high number of bugs, reportedly though I've only had to reload a level once. Overall, I'd consider this to be one of the best games I own. With the expansion out, there's no reason whatsoever not to pick this up if you enjoyed the older games, or have even a vague interest in using your noggin instead of the usual run-and-gun approach.

Posted: February 8, 2014
												PSA: I will often use XCOM and X-COM in the same sentence. Just for those unfamiliar....        XCOM = Enemy Unknown & X-Com = UFO Defense / TftDX-COM: UFO Defense. A strategy title that, to this day, is still hailed as one of the best - if not the best - strategy games of all time. Firaxis certainly had some big shoes to fill when they announced that they would be rolling out a remake of this classic. Does it live up to the hype? Why, yes actually.XCOM: Enemy Unknown gives an impressive updated look to X-Com. The graphics are fantastic and I enjoy the art style they went with. Many of the enemies of old are still here, Sectoids, Chryssalids, Ethereals, Mutons, the Cyberdisc and even Snakemen (reimagined into the covert unit Thin Men). All the units look great and play as you might expect them too from previous games. There does come a time to nitpick unfortunately in a review and this is it. With a series as complex and enjoyable as X-Com it must be done.Base BuildingThis has been completely streamlined in XCOM from how it used to be in X-COM. Instead of having a topdown view as we are used to from X-Com we have a side shot of an underground honeycomb styled base. This isn't as big as a blow as many might be thinking as multiple bases no longer exist in XCOM as well as base defense. That's right folks, one base and no longer needing to defend it from the alien invaders.Funding & Research I chose a broad term to cover a few things here, mainly country funding, manufacturing and research. Funding used to primarily be based on performance in X-COM. Missed a ship/landing site/terror mission/failed?Well - too bad Sir - the aliens are winning. In XCOM: EU they have added the addition of satellites into the game to give you a more hands on approach to dealing with countries and their 'panic' level in the situation room. Should a country's bars fill completely into the red they will withdraw funding and side with the alien invaders. Satellites bring that bar back down but require time, funds and the building of satellite arrays in your base. Satellites can be shot down, but even playing on the highest difficulty I have never had it happen.Manufacturing and selling produced materials, equipment and alien tech was a huge part of X-COM and it has now been removed. Research also feels much more easy, the tech tree less elaborate and not requiring near as much risk in high ranking alien captures to reach end game.Soldiers, Combat & InventoryMany people have a large number of gripes with how these particular topics are handled. While I do enjoy the streamlined process of combat, I do miss the solider management, more complex combat and inventory management. Gone are the days of having a set number of 'Time Units' (TUs), now we have a two-action system for soldier combat. Usually comprised of moving a short distance then firing/item use or one action abilities (firing first, item use first, sprinting a longer distance, special skill use in some instances).Soldiers come in four flavours: Assault, Support, Heavies and Snipers. There is a reason for this....FOUR MAN SQUADS! Yup, that's right, you start with a four man squad and work your way up to six (with Officer Training). No more fifteen+ man squads of rookie cannon fodder. This can pose a number of problems if a certain class is in the infirmary or K.I.A: 1) Assault: This is your front line trooper. Able to dodge enemy reaction shots, auto fire in close proximity in the enemy turn and has excellent mobility and health. If this trooper goes down capturing aliens does get slightly more difficult.2) Support: No longer will you have revives, smoke grenades or any decent heals. This is the medic class.3) Heavies: Suppressing fire and of course, the one use only Rocket Launcher. This makes dealing with the packs that enemies now travel in incredibly easier with AoE damage and cover destruction.4) Snipers: Well, sniping. An incredibly powerful unit that can use team member's forward spotting to shoot aliens from across the map (with Line of Sight).The aliens themselves now travel in packs and seem to have smaller numbers. If you should happen to find an alien 'unit' a cinematic will play giving that unit a free chance at movement. Usually this means the unit will move into cover, but at the end of a turn this can give the aliens a free advantage to rush or flank your troops, essentially decimating them. No longer will you spend hours combing a map hunting for that one alien hiding in a corner somewhere at least....right? Finally we come to the inventory and to be honest it doesn't look good. No longer can soldiers interact with alien/friendly corpses, weapons or items on the battlefield.Why? Because the inventory system no longer exists. Ammunition is now unlimited, grenades/rockets are one use (without a specific +1 perk), medkits have a limited amount of charges, many of the accessory items such as flares (No more night fighting!) and grenade types are now gone, alien weapons/equipment/tech can only be acquired from a successful mission and ONLY if the alien has been stunned for capture. This means if a mission is going badly you can't pack up your stunned alien with it's equipment, hop in the skyranger and take off. This goes the same for soldier salvage.Mind ControlAny fan of the original X-COM understands and dreads that which is mind control. Many a time has the hapless soldier been immediately mind controlled out of the carrier only to fire a rocket/lob a grenade into the skyranger on the next turn to kill his defenceless teammates. Not so in XCOM. Mind control is a much more short range affair and seems to really require much more obvious Line of Sight to the player. Due to these shorter map distances it's incredibly easy now to take out the offending psionic and free your unit on the next turn in most circumstances.All-in-all XCOM: Enemy Unknown is watered down slightly and streamlined for the modern crowd of gamers. Part of this is most likely due to it being ported onto consoles (or ported from consoles to PC, I don't recall which at the moment), the generally low complexity of most modern AAA titles and the lack of difficulty which helped make the original so memorable.Is it worth the money? Certainly! Especially now that it has been out for a bit and tends to go on sale every Steam Sale.Is it as good as the original? No, but it stands proud and the developers have done an amazing job modernizing what is surely one of the greatest games ever made.

Posted: September 26, 2015
												I highly Recommend this game for the following people:-Fans of Turn-Based, Grid-Based Strategy games-People who Like Strategy/Tactical games-People who like the retro "roswell" aliens stylizationI Have Never played the original games, and will not be comparing it to the games from the 90'sPros:-It's a turn-based, Grid-based Strategy game, which is a rare beast nowadays, and it's a good one at that-Lot's of Soldier Customization-- 4 Classes (+ a 5th class with Enemy Within Expansion) that each have their own Skill/ability tree--- classes are: Sniper (Long range, uses sniper rifle), Heavy (Demo and area control expert, uses LMG and Rocket launcher), Assault ( High Crit/Short range/Multi-shot unit, uses shotgun or Assault rifle), and Support (Healer/cover unit, uses Assault rifle)-- Lots of ways to customize the look of the soldiers-- Many Armor Types, 3 weapon tech levels, 5 base weapon types (6 with EW expansion), and lots of items that can be carried- Interesting, varied enemies, many of which can be captured -> Interrogated -> autopsy for new technology- Customizable base, which makes up the "Strategic Layer"-- Interesting facilities which you can build in the base, including:--- The Foundry, where you can build cool things, invent new tools, and improve existing weapons (better crit rate, more ammo space, etc...), though it is a little bland compared to the amount the Enemy WIthin expansion adds--- The Officer Training school, which betters your troops in various ways--- the Labratories (Where you research cool things)- Good Tactical Gameplay --Well Designed cover system, with destroyable cover of varying durablity-- Accuracy System and Flanking system (The names are kind of self-explainatory) where height, distance, and line of sight matter; and can effect damage, crit rate, and accuracyCon's:-Story is very predictable-No Steam Workshop/Mod Tools, though there is a sadistic mod called the "Long War"-While the game does have a large amount of maps, which have decent variety, you will still end up going thru most of them in a playthrough, and will definitly start feeling repetative by the second playthrough- Overwatch action wasn't implemented in the best way, and everyone will fire on the first alien that comes into view instead of taking turns (In case there are more aliens, which there always are)- Once you get good at the game, you'll realize that there is one strategy which is signifigantly better than all the others, which makes the game start to feel bland after awhile.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												Two things can be said about the X-COM universe: the aliens are always evil and it’s grand daddy to turn-based tactical strategy games.For many older players, the mere whisper of X-COM: UFO Defense is enough for them to wet their pants without a shred of embarrassment. Well, XCOM: Enemy Unknown has changed the series besides losing the hyphen in X-COM. Graphical enhancement comes to mind. And a bit of gameplay freedom lost in favor of streamlined design, as fans of the original would probably point out. Be prepared for little grey men, psionics, UFOs, and pretty much every beloved sci-fi staple in existence.Let’s be realistic: compared to most strategy games, XCOM: EU has a flexible, dynamic campaign that is a wonder to the genre. When compared to the original, maybe not so much, but today we aren’t reviewing that game. So this game works primarily by a milestone campaign. You must reach certain milestones to progress, but in-between you are free to play as you see fit. You can choose to help certain nations out, or not. Take a pick of missions for a choice of reward. Spend your cash on soldiers or ships. Still, those milestones must be reached or you are unable to go on. You race to stay one step of the alien invasion and falling behind means a slow death by lack of funding. No funding means you can’t keep fighting the good fight. So the ability to make plenty of choices is there, but the game isn’t completely freeform.Developer Firaxis Games spared no expense on bringing XCOM to the modern era. The graphics are as good as can be expected for a squad tactical game. Aliens burst into viscera with a satisfying punch. Lasers (of course there are lasers!) and explosions feel as good as any action game. The animation prowess going into the Thin Man give him an exceptional amount of character. Slow motion camera work often captures the action in grisly detail. However, the responsiveness of the controls are questionable, most notably with the jetpack and grapple. Soldiers are also known to fire off in a different direction and still hit their target. The game isn’t perfect, but being turn-based does tone down many of the problems into mere annoyances. Except certain areas are not as random as they should be (looking at you, UFO assaults); that’s a problem that doesn’t go away.Let’s talk about the most important part of all tactical games — the combat. XCOM is fairly action-packed, as far as turn-based gaming goes. Your soldiers can move in leaps and bounds across the map, relying on each using two actions per turn. The selection of gadgets are interesting and diverse, ranging from grappling hooks to alien grenades. There’s even a mechanized unit that can replace a squad member. The class system by itself is a bit shallow and constricting. However when combining various equipment, psionics, gadgets, and other squad members, XCOM’s freedom gives you room to exercise your tactical genius. Just not too much room, especially since most weapons are class restrictive.Surprisingly, XCOM: EU has a ranked multiplayer mode. While co-op might have been a better direction, the competitive (1v1) system is well-designed and doesn’t feel like just a tacked on bullet point. And the multiplayer aspect is much needed, as the game has slim DLC options and a lack of modding tools. Ouch.Overall, XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a worthy addition to both the series and the strategy genre. Make no mistake (if you do, a rampaging Muton will surely cut you down), XCOM’s limited, streamlined strategy is a cornerstone of its design and it shows.Side note: If you’re playing the game for the first time, I don’t recommend choosing any difficulty higher than Normal. Trust me!

Posted: November 25, 2013
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a great, modern version of a cult-classic from the '90s. The earth is getting attacked by an alien invasion. The nations of the world found the XCOM to deal with the invaders - and you are the commander.The gameplay is divided into two parts - the strategic base building game, were you deal with developing new weapons, deciding what countries to protect with satelite surveillance or shooting down UFOs. The other part is the tactic mode - you send a squad of 4-6 elite soldiers to deal with the invaders. Turn based you move carefully, kill some invaders and try to take prisoners for further interrogation. Your soldiers progress in an RPG like manner in four classes: Storm, Heavy, Support and Snipers. Be carefull who you move first - one wrong move can kill a soldier you invested hours in.XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a game of decissions - do you buy a laser weapon or the better armor? When multiple cities get attacked at once - you have to decide which to defend, risking the other city and nation to get lost on you forever. You are the only chance for earth to repel the invasion. Use it - and have fun in a game I already spend 50 hours in.

												This game has returned... and it has wrought itself upon my schedule.  The classic XCOM hath returned, bringing all the glory of the original, with a more well constructed story. Posted: February 10, 2015
												As a fan of the original games I found Enemy Unknown and the expansion Enemy Withing very fun and enjoyable. There are a few similarities with the games such as both being turn based and the aliens being the same for the most part but that is where the similarities end. Unlike the original there is not as easy to keep all the nations happy and you are bound to lose a nation or two before you can think about ending the alien threat. Also unlike the original you can only make one base, meaning you have to pick and chose what you research and manufacture more carefully. In combat you start off with a small group of four and can upgrade to six and though that number seems small it forces you to play smarter and using the skills for your units more than in the orignal. With all games with RNG you can get into some critical situations and either hit an enemy when you only had a 10% or feel you heart sink as your best sniper misses the life saving shot though he had a 95% chance to hit. Those who think this game is too easy are also in luck as there is a mod called the Long War mod which makes the game that much harder and more fun. If you like strategy games then I recommend you give this game a shot.

Posted: May 30, 2014
												Okay, so I gave the remake a good, honest try that extended past the hour of bull hooey on Danny's computer....I won't bother going over an exhaustive list of the differences between the two games because honestly, the remake is different enough to warrant being its own game *inspired* by the original. The premise is the same, the missions are nice, but I don't think that it's either fair (or possible) for the remake to 'stand up' against the original-- simply put, I don't think that a younger audience would be able to deal with the old interface, graphics, and flat-out-butt-kickin'-nonsense that was XCOM: UFO Defense.A couple of key notes here: 1) The class base system is nice but almost completely random. You'll find yourself particularly attracted to some, not liking others, and winding up with a mixed bag of both. The game does absolutely nothing to help here, making you purchase rookies like they're going out of style to find the right grab bag of combinations that you want. A mixed squad of the base classes *can* be nice, but only if you play a certain way.2) This is no longer the nuanced 'laser or plasma' debate: flat out, plasma wins because laser needs to be reloaded. Don't ask, don't tell-- the younger generation is going to miss out on all of that. Maybe even for the best.3) The tutorial will run you on rails so hard you'll check for scorch marks in your crotch. You have been warned.4) Stats? What stats? The class base system overrides stats so completely you'll never notice them, randomized or no.5) The game is trying to tell a story, a sequential story which can be exploited. Unless you're playing the tutorial, in which case, enjoy hell.6) The game has limited the strategic elements of the game and has narrowed it down to a tactical level. Nice, if you like that kind of game. Far less grand strategy (if you could even say that of the original) because all of your things are in a single base with a well-thought out, fairly streamlined interface.7) For those of you who want to complain about ammo management: they did it, it's done, it's not bad. You have to reload WAY more often than in the original but it adds a tactical dimension not otherwise noticed (except for those who played small-squad games).8) For those who want to complain about reaction skill removal: overwatch is a great mechanic and actually makes sense to those who couldn't/didn't/wouldn't do the math from the original. Dumbed-down isn't always stupid, it's functional.9) For those who want to complain about the interceptions: no person in their right mind played a game that deliberately required them to send up multiple Interceptors who didn't lose before the first year. Yeah, it's not as hardcore as the original, see 8.10) For those who want to complain about the inability to purchase certain items, *cough*personnel*cough*, etc etc: it makes the plot decisions more interesting.All in all Firaxis has done a great job re-envisioning XCom. It's fun, it's fast, and it's not even close. 8/10

Posted: April 5, 2013
												If ever a game has been deserving of a remake / spiritual successor, it has to be X-COM: UFO Defense. It's a classic turn-based strategy game with a great sense of mystery and dread, regarded by many to be one of the best strategy games ever made.XCOM: Enemy Unknown (what happened to the hyphen?) is an excellent modern interpretation of that fantastic game, featuring great turn-based tactical combat, fun character progression, a beautiful musical score and above all, that same sense of wonder, dread and emotional attachment to your troops. XCOM: Enemy Within further expands on this amazing game with a bigger tech tree, a new soldier class and plenty of new enemies to fight, as well as a multitude of new maps to fight them on.. if the XCOM-project isn't destroyed from within. A must-play for any strategy gamer!

Posted: December 21, 2013
												In 1994, a stratgey RPG titled: X-COM UFO Defense was released on the PC. It was a hit, and the series continued, it eventiually got very far away from its turn-based RPG roots (See XCOM: The Buereu). Now, Firaxis has brought everything back to the start with a reboot of the series. It is definatley a triumphant return. The game has been very changed, and even those who played X-COM to death will have a new experience in XCOM. Without getting into every detail, the one thing this game does is simplify the experience. Each unit has infinite ammo packs, there is only ever one XCOM base, and so on. This serves not only to say that this is a modernized version of the classic game, but also as a completely new one. Now, the best part of the game is the customization options. If you get both of the DLCs, the game has a number of different voices, races, hair styles (even Guile hair!) to choose from, allowing you to make a team of whoever you want, and not just having generic soldiers. Personally, my team was Hewiki "Stoneshot" Ignika, Raida "Radio" Justice, James T "NotaRedShirt" Kirk, Barry "Magnum" Burton, Jill "Sandwich" Valentine, and Shaquille "Slam-Dunk" O'neil. When you give your soldiers names, themed armor, and everything else, the game manages to make things personal. When a soldier gets critically wounded, the game will make you freak out. Somehow, the game makes you care for these soldiers, and that is the strongest point of the game. However, the game also has some serious problems. It's pretty hard to care for your soldiers when one of them gets hit, and then falls through the floor, you kind of get taken out of the experience. In my experience though, it hasn't ever crashed, just had some problems with registering flanking, aim calculations, and clipping. Major problems with clipping. All together, with the amazing experience and the replayability the ghame has, with the buggyness in mind, 9.5/10 Pretty Amazing

Posted: October 20, 2013
												Easily one of the very best games in my collection, and one of the least expensive. As a guy who hates going through a game a second time, I am working towards the end of my second playthrough on classic iron-man and looking forward to my third one (on impossible, hopefully).The blend of micro- and macro-management is really fun and forces you to plan your funding strategies ahead (at least until you get full satellite coverage). The turn-based combat in itself is quite awesome, the action camera proving itself really immersive. Gameplay is both simple and ramified while the level design is well thought (while randomly generated). The entirety of the game is focused on making the fight for earth *your* fight for earth, and you can customize everything (even more with the dlcs) for your own enjoyment (and perhaps easier recognition of your soldiers while on mission).Understanding all the game mechanics can be hard at first and requires a lot of thought, but is well worth the time spent.Perhaps the only con I see for this game is the lack of real choice you have to make on the scenario. You can research all projects, complete the foundry, obtain full satellite coverage, have all your soldiers fully upgraded and geared all in the same playthrough. If I were to ask for an addition, it would be to force the player to make strategic choices (not only on what to research first, but on what to research at all), and challenges (why not adding some sort of automated earth defense system that you would have to deploy on earth, and the possibility to save countries that have left the X-COM project). XCOM : EW seems to deal in some way with this, I can't wait to buy it !Unlike most games, the challenges offered (classic/impossible mode, iron-man, and second wave options) are both challenging and not irritating. However higher difficulty modes are mostly based on modifying in-game values such as your soldier's base hp, costs of items/research projects... etc (even if the ai is slightly better) which basically force you to use overwatch more and be more cautious. I've yet to see a game showing additional mechanics and forcing the player to swap for totally different strategies on higher difficulty modes.In two words, GET IT !

Posted: November 26, 2013
												The addition of the Enemy Within expansion rekindled my love for the game!If you ever enjoyed any of the 1994-1995 XCom titles, you should definitely check this one out. While taking a new approach to the mechanics, it stays true to the Original XCom spirit.About the expansion:While I'm not finding myself enjoying MEC play all that much, I totally love upgrading my soldiers with various genetic twinks that make superman look like a wuss. Map pool has also been updated and together with more story missions it keeps the levels interesting for a longer time before boredom kicks in.There are still some kinks left in the game, like shooting through walls and the camera being an.. well..♥♥♥♥♥♥. in some levels. But the major annoyance from launch have since been fixed/changed. No more teleporting aliens right into the middle of your squad.I'm a bit torn about the general pace of the game. Unlike in the original XCom titles you rush through research and the missions in a blaze. It may be a good or bad thing, depending on your preferences. You definitely don't have to "grind" through a hard month anymore but you don't feel outclassed and out gunned, fighting against a superior enemy while slowly crawling up to a level playing field either.A Second Wave option for a longer game, which basically quadruples research times is available after you beat the game once though. Base and item management have been simplified to the levels of Ant farm and non-existent. Good if you didn't enjoy that part of XCom, bad if you did.All in all, I would recommend this game to everyone!

												Modernized version of the classic UFO Defense with some substantial added elements (counting in Enemy Within). 'Modernized' not only meaning Unreal Engine 3, but also some simplified mechanics both in and out of combat to make the game more appealing to the current audience and to make the game flow more nicely. It works, though I do for example miss having multiple bases and an action point/time system rather than just having two actions per turn.I originally got this game right at launch, but was immediately turned off by the simplicity of the combat (I was expecting something along the lines of Jagged Aliance 2 if not the orignial X-Com) and it seemed very unbalanced. Picked up the Complete version in the last sale and somehow I loved it straight away. No idea what changed, it just grabbed me.This game with the DLC is in my opinion a worthy reboot. Posted: July 13, 2014
												Um excelente jogo de estratégia que faz uma justa homenagem ao original dos anos 90 e atualiza a franquia com maestria.O jogo articula momentos de administração de recursos, pesquisa e construção com as missões, onde a ação estratégica se dá por turnos no combate a invasão alienígena. A mecânica é bem semelhante ao jogo original.Como pontos positivos da nova versão temos melhores gráficos e uma linha narrativa cinemática mais detalhada. Além disso a interface é um pouco mais fácil e auxilia o jogador iniciante.O jogo tem momentos bem difíceis, obrigando a fazer uso recorrente do save/load. Mas não chega a uma dificuldade impossível e frustrante da série original, que praticamente impede de chegar ao fim.Para os fãs de estratégia, recomendo!

Posted: July 12, 2014
												In XCOM: Enemy Unknown, you are waging war against an Alien Force invading Earth. You have to utilize limited resources to manage base construction, as well as scientific research and engineering projects to advance your team of soldiers into what is eventually a sophisticated military unit using hyper advanced technology.From time to time you are called upon to defend Earth from the invading Aliens, whether it be alien abductions in a major city or a UFO sighting. This is where the meat of the game is. You pick and choose soldiers who level up over time and assume roles like Sniper, Rocketeer or Medic, with permadeath mechanics involved.The game is really fantastic if you like turn based strategy games. There's a certain tense anxiety that comes from being pinned down by incredibly advanced, extremely dangerous aliens and hoping that one of your soldiers can pull of a shot that will shake up the situation and turn it into your favor. If you like the game, pick up the Enemy Within expansion as well, which is a comprehensive expansion pack that adds Mechs, Augmentations for soldiers and a new enemy faction.Shoutout to the Long War mod. If you feel like you've mastered the game, try Long War. It is a VERY expansive mod for XCOM: Enemy Unknown and XCOM: Enemy Within. It adds enormous amounts of content as well as makes an already difficult game relentlessly and extremely difficult. In my opinion, the Long War mod completes this already very fantastic game.

Posted: October 31, 2014
												I have played "XCOM: Enemy Unknown" some time ago on my friend's computer. Finished it then for the first time, enjoyed a lot and decided that I want to have it to be able to play again at any time. Got it recently and played it again, this time on "Iron Man" mode. On Normal difficulty it took about 40 hours.I liked about this game following:1) Enormous replay value;2) "Ironman" mode which comes with a DLC and if enabled "forces" you to enjoy playing interesting game instead of the "perfect" one (where you do not loose a battle);3) Really great gameplay in tactical combat as well as in base management;4) Very nice graphics with most of the cutscenes made on a game engine, which is very good because in every cutscene involving soldiers you will see your soldiers and not predefined dummies (as it happens in many other games);5) As a result it is very enjoyable to customize your characters;6) Minor but very important thing is that all soldiers as well as other characters in the game come from various countries which makes it look like you are fighting a real world wide thread (in contrast and for example, in majority of the hollywood movies alliens or any other foes always have Los Angeles as a highest priority, like it is a centre of the world :) );7) Interesting story line, creative weapons, really distinct aliens as well as other design choices are really well thought and well made.List of advantages is not by any means full but big enough to provide an overview of reasons why one may want to buy this game.In order to be fair I will provide a list of disadvantages, though I think none of them significant enough to discourage one from playing this game. Never the less, here are those things which may have been better:1) Some minor interface bugs;2) Lack of difficulty levels between "Normal" and "Classic". Normal is very good if you playing reasonably well. On Classic however, it turns into the game where you struggle to survive. It is drasticly more difficult. Having difficulties between those two would be great. It can be partially solved by Second Wave options which as far as I know would require one to have appropriate DLC;3) Story line is quite linear and you do not really affect anything storywise except its pace. Having several endings or alternative scenarios of game progression would be great, but having said this I also know that story is not that important at all, as this game primarily about gameplay in two modes Base Management and Tactical Battles. Therefore, story serves its role as a background for everything you do.That is possibly it. List of disadvantages is more like a list of suggestions on how developers can make really great game even better.Thus, if you are into tactical turnbase combat and management in between then XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a great game for you as it is for me. It virtually provides unlimited replay value and it worth each pence or cent or any other currency you will have to pay for it. I would totally recommend it! :)

Posted: October 15, 2014
												(NOTE: Despite my short playtime on Steam, I have owned and played the PS3 version since 2012).I have never played the original XCOM games, I just downloaded the demo, not knowing that the XCOM series existed. I got so addicted to the demo, I replayed it several times. Then I got the full game for Christmas. This game defines fun. The story may seem shallow, but guess what, that why you must create your own story. I mean, you can customize your own soldiers, even their names. Try naming them after your loved ones, and you'll get attached to them. That's the thing about XCOM, it doesn't trivialize death; it even has a memorial for your lost soldiers. Haven't played multiplayer, but singleplayer alone justifies the price tag. There are some lags here and there but they're minor. Come on, buy it NOW.

Posted: October 18, 2014
												Visually stunning but hardly the best game in the Xcom franchise, still enjoyable once you work past its faults. If you have played previous Xcom games the first thing you will notice is how annoyingly streamlined this game is. Anything you could do tandemly in previous Xcom games has been reduced to one instance at a time. No researching multiple things no launching multiple Interceptors or Skyrangers. Gone are the multiple independant bases, tho you can station interceptors at various fixed locations around the globe. Instead of having soldiers with stats and using those to determine how you outfit them, there are now fixed classes. Soldiers are (seemingly) randomly promoted to a class after their first mission (or automatically once you buy the foundry upgrade). Time units are gone so there is no more deciding what to do, you can either take an action which will end the turn for all classes except Heavy that have taken the skill that allows them to take a second action if their first action was to shoot. Otherwise you can move and take an action or sprint which ends your turn. Unless you are an Assault using Run & Gun which will allow you to sprint and fire your weapon. Time Units let you do whatever. move and shoot, shoot and move, shoot, throw a genade and move etc. The real problem I had with the streamlining of soldiers was the sniper. In the original Xcom if your soldier had the sort of stats that fit a sniper you could eventually work them into that position while still using them in other capacities if you needed to. In this itteration of the game BOOM your soldier is a sniper they will only ever be a sniper and snipers for me were dead weight through the first part of the game. They only really start becoming useful later on when you unlock a bunch of technology and manage to get them sufficiently promoted, selecting the appropriate skills. When the game says Alien Activity what it really means is you havn't run into a scripted event yet. They start off cool but they get old sorta fast. Effectively what happens is you walk to a point where the game spawns in aliens and it does so with a quick but not quick enouhg (when you hit the 30th+ time) in game cut scene where they go from standing around  apparently gossiping to dashing for cover. Where as previous games Alien Activity meant there was an alien somewhere on the map actially doing something with or without you there to watch it doing said thing. That said I'm not 100% sure how terror missions work because you still get the same spawn in effect but civilians in areas you can't see will die if you don't make your way to them fast enough. I don't quite get how a 9GB+ game can't seem to acomplish the same depth a game managed to decades ago and clocking in at only around 30MB. Still it really does look nice and if you never played the original Xcom you probably won't even know what you're missing. At the end of the day this is probably as close to a revival of Xcom as we can ever really hope for.

Posted: July 14, 2015
												PROS-Cross platform-Challenging -Replayability (different decisions, different difficulty settings, etc.)-Somewhat engaging story-line, even extra content you don't need to progress but is still interesting, like autopsies and other research projects-You can play it one-handed (easy pizza access)Just one annoying thing: Sometimes the auto-targeting puts your POV at an odd angle that does not allow you to see your enemy's hit points very well. Easy to get around if you just exit out of firing mode and go look manually, but it's still kind of inconvenient to have to do that.Definitely would recommend though, well worth the money.

Posted: May 18, 2013
												Like squad based strategy? Like kicking alien♥♥♥♥♥♥all over the earth? THEN PLAY THIS GAME!No, seriously, it's a good game. That said (and since the topic was raised), the only problem I had with it was a tiny oversight that somewhat negatively impacted the feeling of realism, it's missing that one thing, that tiny titbit of detail, that would make it seem as real as any ol' alien encounter today is (and y'all know it is). I am, of course, talking about the lowly Anal probe. Yes, indeed, the extra-terrestrial past time of cavity exploration, by way of some very novel and creative implements. Even though we all know it as the stock trade of those little baldheaded grey perv... visitors, it seemingly doesn't even have a proper cameo anywhere in the game.Tsk tsk... I'm sure they'll fix it with another expansion. Thought it was going to be "Enemy Within", alas it was not. Lack of bum probes aside, don't let a tiny oversight like that dissuade you from buying,this game is money well spent, and with the current sale it would literally be half the money(I paid) well spent.

Posted: June 22, 2015
												This game is very good, especially the Enemy WIthin add-on, which adds a load of new things to XCOM: EW. I'm just going to say, singleplayer is phenomenal, a decent story with a cliche yet cool ending, very fun gameplay, nice character customization (Made my entire squad characters from the Devil May Cry series and had fun doing it, even giving them certain traits I feel their actual characters had), a very cool menu for your in-between battles, and a whole host of other really cool things.I don't want to put anyone off, but for me, it's best you guys ignore multiplayer exists. It is horribly broken flawed, hell, even the leaderboards are♥♥♥♥♥♥poor. Not even the regular leaderboard hackers you see at the top are messing with it. Even funnier, someone with the name "XCOM LEADERBOARDS ARE BROKEN" is at the very top of it. God knows how long it has been there.Story timeFirst game for me: We start off at a semi great start, one of my guys dies after inflicting damage on what I assume was their main man, a decked out human, and killing a Thin Man. And the worst part is he was in my support's smoke. I chalked it off as bad luck (probably was), so then they have my support completely trapped and it was my turn. Luckily I had the Grappling Hook armor and I grappled on top of the building that he was inside along with my dead soldier, to join my sniper. The sniper moves so he can get in a better position. Next, a pretty buggy thing happened. His team apparently couldn't see my sniper, not after I killed 2 of his sectoids. After this, his remaining soldiers (the damaged human and what I assumed was his support) decide to go up the latter. My sniper couldnt use overwatch because he already shot, so I put my support in overwatch, who was not that far away from the ladder. The first soldier goes up the ladder (with 2 health) and for some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t reason my support didnt shoot him. So as you can guess, his soldier completely destroys my sniper. At this point, I am completely screwed, because his other soldier then climbed up with him, who wasnt injured at all, and threw down smoke (didnt make a difference in the long run). After their turn was up, I shot and killed his main because I didnt stand a chance anyways with my injured support. Next his soldier shot me point blank, didnt die, shot back, got a critical for 7 damage and ALMOST killed his soldier, but then I shot and got ded. Riperoni my vailiant soldier, heroes never die, they only respawn.In short, RIP multiplayer, Yay for singleplayer

Posted: February 2, 2015
												Five out of five for this game. XCOM provides a fun and fairly simple strategy game experience that is backed by an amazing and replayable storyline. It's rare to find a game with a good story that you can replay and still have a different story experience. I found myself getting attached to characters and feeling some emotions I haven't felt since I went through the Mass Effect series. Aside from a great story experience that allows you to save the world the way you feel is best, the gameplay is really fun. It's simple enough that you won't get confused, but fun and versatile so you won't get bored of it. The campaign progression (research, mission choices, etc.) is like a game in itself outside of combat. You have to strategize on and off the battlefield to be succesful in this game. My only complaint deals with the multiplayer. Playing against friends with teams you've customized is a blast, except for when the game freezes or glitches in some other way. I've only had this happen in multiplayer and it's not a huge issue, just one worth mentioning. If you see this game on sale, snatch it up, because this game is a great investment even at full price.

Posted: February 6, 2016
												When I first played this game (about 3 years ago), I had a great feeling, as if I was a mastermind of a giant war operation. That was fun. Few years later, Enemy Within came out. I didn't see anything in it, so I passed. At first. Then I heard about a mod, called Long War, that made the game harder and... better. I thought I'd give it a try. I bought Enemy Within and Slingshot, downloaded the mod...I've played Long War for about 8 months. Sure, there were long breaks from XCOM, sometimes months long. But I'm still going. The game is mostly same strategy, sure. But instead of feeling like a great asskicking mastermind I feel like... an insignificant distraction for alien forces. Every mission feels like a punch in the gut, and I'm lucky if every solder survived that mission. The funding from the Council is usually no enough, the soldiers are consantly panicking and sectoids are using same genetic thech we're using, so now they've got 5 points of health and a random ability. XCOM 2 came out couple of days ago, right? I heard they made it harder then Enemy Unknown. Yeah, right. I'll still will try to beat EU with Long War mod. It will take time. Weeks, months, hell, maybe years. But it's too damn good to throw away like that. So, in short, if you don't have the money to buy XCOM 2, like me, buy this one. Then install the Long War mod (after you finished the game, because it'll be impossible for new players), and pretend to use guerilla tactics. It's one of the best games out there, and you won't find such a rewarding expirience even in Dark Souls.

Posted: February 9, 2014
												A fantastic example of how to do turn-based grid movement well. XCOM is an interesting and rather unique take on strategic combat. Feeling like a combination of turn-based RPG (the Fire Embled kind, not the Final Fantasy kind) and RTS, the gameplay is fluid, quick-paced and brutal. The management of panic levels, research and engineering on a relatively strict budget adds a managerial level of complexity to the game in addition to the combat. With a whole assortment of randomly generated side missions, you can lose so much time to this game however that is what I like about it. Great fun and a great experience.

Posted: March 29, 2013
												An extremely well done remake of the original XCOM - ENEMY UNKNOWN from 1992. Great atmosphere! Very nice music, story-telling cutscenes, intuitive controls, balanced tutorial and tips. I LOVE THE IRONMAN mode when You cannot load previous position and You can only progress forward. It adds GREAT new level of difficulty - making Your tactics-MASTERY very important and so You learn it quick ! :)

Posted: November 1, 2013
												A very fun and addicitng game that is actually quite challenging and unforgivable of your mistakes. You have to manage your team well as well as your financial health. Making hard decisions and prioritizing your goals are all part of the challenge. I had quite an enjoyable time playing this game. The only negative things I say about this game is the controls and camera angles/views are quite wonky at times, especially when there's a building with more than one floor. Another thing to note is that this game is not really a story-driven game so don't expect a strong, in-depth plot. Otherwise, this is a stellar sci-fi based strategy game! * This game has grown on me. It is MY favourite game!*Remember, we will be watching!

Posted: November 27, 2013
												A solid and fun RTS game! If your looking for a good game that will soak up several hours of your time then I suggest this! As a fan of all of the original XCOM games, I have to say I really did enjoy it. It lacks some of the indepth management from the older games (such as buying ammo) and sleeks in down to more of a base building sim on that side of the game. The main focus is the RTS missions where you combat the aliens with all of your various goodies that you have researched and unlocked during the game. It's always fun to play just a bit longer to see what new weapons/armor/items you can unlock while researching the aliens. Highly reccommended!

Posted: June 25, 2013
												One of the greatest, most addictive and most fun games I've played in the last years. This is the kind of game that gives you a set of rules, a list of resources and a series of tech trees and let's you play with them, always forcing you to prioritize something, never being able to being good at everything and constantly elevating the level of challenges as you progress. It creates a constant panic environment where you are pressed to make compromises and you swear everytime you suffer any loss. Just DON'T play anything under "classic" difficulty.Problems: stupid teleporting bug still present which can ruin your perfect ironman game, the game story is not horrible but it is a bit underwhelming, at high difficulties losing a substantial number of squad members late in the game effectively means game over.Nor better nor worse than the original, just different (and incredibly good).

Posted: November 26, 2013
												The addition of the Enemy Within expansion rekindled my love for the game!If you ever enjoyed any of the 1994-1995 XCom titles, you should definitely check this one out. While taking a new approach to the mechanics, it stays true to the Original XCom spirit.About the expansion:While I'm not finding myself enjoying MEC play all that much, I totally love upgrading my soldiers with various genetic twinks that make superman look like a wuss. Map pool has also been updated and together with more story missions it keeps the levels interesting for a longer time before boredom kicks in.There are still some kinks left in the game, like shooting through walls and the camera being an.. well..♥♥♥♥♥♥. in some levels. But the major annoyance from launch have since been fixed/changed. No more teleporting aliens right into the middle of your squad.I'm a bit torn about the general pace of the game. Unlike in the original XCom titles you rush through research and the missions in a blaze. It may be a good or bad thing, depending on your preferences. You definitely don't have to "grind" through a hard month anymore but you don't feel outclassed and out gunned, fighting against a superior enemy while slowly crawling up to a level playing field either.A Second Wave option for a longer game, which basically quadruples research times is available after you beat the game once though. Base and item management have been simplified to the levels of Ant farm and non-existent. Good if you didn't enjoy that part of XCom, bad if you did.All in all, I would recommend this game to everyone!

Posted: October 20, 2013
												Easily one of the very best games in my collection, and one of the least expensive. As a guy who hates going through a game a second time, I am working towards the end of my second playthrough on classic iron-man and looking forward to my third one (on impossible, hopefully).The blend of micro- and macro-management is really fun and forces you to plan your funding strategies ahead (at least until you get full satellite coverage). The turn-based combat in itself is quite awesome, the action camera proving itself really immersive. Gameplay is both simple and ramified while the level design is well thought (while randomly generated). The entirety of the game is focused on making the fight for earth *your* fight for earth, and you can customize everything (even more with the dlcs) for your own enjoyment (and perhaps easier recognition of your soldiers while on mission).Understanding all the game mechanics can be hard at first and requires a lot of thought, but is well worth the time spent.Perhaps the only con I see for this game is the lack of real choice you have to make on the scenario. You can research all projects, complete the foundry, obtain full satellite coverage, have all your soldiers fully upgraded and geared all in the same playthrough. If I were to ask for an addition, it would be to force the player to make strategic choices (not only on what to research first, but on what to research at all), and challenges (why not adding some sort of automated earth defense system that you would have to deploy on earth, and the possibility to save countries that have left the X-COM project). XCOM : EW seems to deal in some way with this, I can't wait to buy it !Unlike most games, the challenges offered (classic/impossible mode, iron-man, and second wave options) are both challenging and not irritating. However higher difficulty modes are mostly based on modifying in-game values such as your soldier's base hp, costs of items/research projects... etc (even if the ai is slightly better) which basically force you to use overwatch more and be more cautious. I've yet to see a game showing additional mechanics and forcing the player to swap for totally different strategies on higher difficulty modes.In two words, GET IT !

Posted: July 12, 2014
												In XCOM: Enemy Unknown, you are waging war against an Alien Force invading Earth. You have to utilize limited resources to manage base construction, as well as scientific research and engineering projects to advance your team of soldiers into what is eventually a sophisticated military unit using hyper advanced technology.From time to time you are called upon to defend Earth from the invading Aliens, whether it be alien abductions in a major city or a UFO sighting. This is where the meat of the game is. You pick and choose soldiers who level up over time and assume roles like Sniper, Rocketeer or Medic, with permadeath mechanics involved.The game is really fantastic if you like turn based strategy games. There's a certain tense anxiety that comes from being pinned down by incredibly advanced, extremely dangerous aliens and hoping that one of your soldiers can pull of a shot that will shake up the situation and turn it into your favor. If you like the game, pick up the Enemy Within expansion as well, which is a comprehensive expansion pack that adds Mechs, Augmentations for soldiers and a new enemy faction.Shoutout to the Long War mod. If you feel like you've mastered the game, try Long War. It is a VERY expansive mod for XCOM: Enemy Unknown and XCOM: Enemy Within. It adds enormous amounts of content as well as makes an already difficult game relentlessly and extremely difficult. In my opinion, the Long War mod completes this already very fantastic game.

Posted: July 13, 2014
												Um excelente jogo de estratégia que faz uma justa homenagem ao original dos anos 90 e atualiza a franquia com maestria.O jogo articula momentos de administração de recursos, pesquisa e construção com as missões, onde a ação estratégica se dá por turnos no combate a invasão alienígena. A mecânica é bem semelhante ao jogo original.Como pontos positivos da nova versão temos melhores gráficos e uma linha narrativa cinemática mais detalhada. Além disso a interface é um pouco mais fácil e auxilia o jogador iniciante.O jogo tem momentos bem difíceis, obrigando a fazer uso recorrente do save/load. Mas não chega a uma dificuldade impossível e frustrante da série original, que praticamente impede de chegar ao fim.Para os fãs de estratégia, recomendo!
