Posted: January 12, 2015
												Believe Everything you hear about the game. It's Awesome. Buy the bundle you will want ALL the goodies.-Control a Squad of Soldiers who each level up and are assigned specialties by the game,-Build a Base and manage resources, manufature equipment and armor, place fighter jets around the globe and intercept alien spacecraft.-Isometric turn based combat that can be clunky to use, but the action in the game makes you forget about the controls RIGHT AWAY, and there is A LOT of action.-Fight Many different xenomorph variants that have different stats and surprising abilities.-Soldiers subject to permadeath, Lose them and lose their abilities. Posted: November 25, 2013
												I never quite got into the original XCom as did others; I enjoyed the game but never to the point where I wanted to, say, write fanfic about it. It was a fun, but flawed, classic with as many good points as bad. Still, I was as excited as the next grognard when I heard that Firaxis was rebooting the series. My opinion of this newest title, however, is similar to that of the original: it is a classic, albeit somewhat flawed, game. Despite the moans of many, I find the removal of action-points an acceptable compromise towards making the game more accessible and less tedious than the original. The game moves more quickly now, advancing to those memorable firefights at a more rapid pace. But the game feels suspiciously hollow, with numerous missing features. Customization is shallow, the maps and missions are repetitive, and the aliens feel toothless lacking the ability to assault the XCom base. These gaps seem purposeful, probably to be filled in with DLC. The end result is a game which offers an often memorable experience but not one which drags me back to play it more than once.

Posted: June 26, 2016
												I played Enemy Unknown a few years back when it was part of PlayStation Plus's monthly offerings, but never got around to all the DLC. At some point apparently I picked up the game with all its DLC from a Humble Bundle or something, so I decided to play it all again. The two character additions, Zhang and Annette were fun little add-ons, and the entire EXALT/Progeny arcs were fairly entertaining. I guess if I had one major compliment towards the game, it would be that it does a bangup job making me care about my characters. By the end, I was again very deeply attached to my characters, remarkable since it was the second time I had played with these kind of blank, empty, controllable soldiers! In fact, I think I felt more attached to this randomly generated crew than I felt towards many "actual" characters in recent similar games turn-based titles. Conversely though, if I had to pick something negative about the game to harp on, it would be that the story backdrop, supporting "characters" and the writing attached to both aspects is pretty much poop. They're not offensively bad, and they don't really take away from the experience, but they're definitely poop inasmuch as it's a pretty trite alien invasion story. Hopefully when I get around to finishing XCOM 2 this fall, I'll get to see an improvement all around!

Posted: January 26, 2014
												XCOM EU: Shoot aliens, dissect/torture them for science/tech, build up base, shoot more aliens+flying saucers, harvest their guns/metals/corpses for bigger/shiny guns, turn humans into Professor X, conquer enemy base/temple ship.XCOM EW: Shoot more aliens, shoot humans, run for meld, curse the random meld locations, defend base, send out 007-wannabes, save 007-wannabe's bacon from fire, put additional heart/spring legs to humans, build mech-warriors, watch mech punching each moving thing with satisfaction, cry when mech get run-down by zergs cause you thought he is invicible, see 5-6 puny humans attempting to punch thru a sectopod's armor with toy guns/grenades, and besides those stuff, the general XCOM EU stuff is still here (build up base, farm resources, and cursing human councils for being stupid).Bla bla bla: Good game, good time, good fun. Respectable remake of the old XCOM.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown places you as commander of a project dedicated to stopping the overwhelming alien menace flooding Earth in 2015. It is an excellent strategy game, in that you must effectively manage limited resources to build your underground base, launch satellites to protect member countries, and research technology projects. This management extends to limited troop assets in the field who must protect one another, save civilians, and take down increasingly challenging and well-equipped enemies. My favorite feature is the balance between third-person bird's eye view in the field, and over-the-shoulder and cinematic close-ups for critical hits, psionic attacks, and 'dash' movements.

Posted: August 15, 2015
												Rebirth of a popular back in the day tactical action game, involving Alien invasions on earth. Great looking top down, turn based, Alien repellent. Earth is once again invaded by Aliens, and you are given the chance to fight and eliminate them. Research different technologies from killed Aliens, construct weapons, tools and armor to aid your troops in combat. Level your troops and equip them with gear, build and expand your underground base, and stop the invasion. Take part in missions all over the globe to combat Alien invaders, in challenging turn based tactical combat. Great quantity of Alien enemy, weapons, armor and maps available. Game has good visuals, story, voice acting and animations, is a challenging experience even on easy. A bit of a downside that you can't co-op it with your friends vs. the Aliens.

Posted: April 7, 2013
												Firaxis stayed true to the original XCOM formula. The result is an old-school turned based tactics game that uses new tech and gameplay features only to enhance the XCOM feel rather than diminish it.This game is very challenging and the aliens are always upping the stakes throwing bigger and better stuff at you while you stuggle to keep up in tech and resources. This plateaus off though near the end game but you'll still run into missions that are hard even then.One of the best improvements is that soldiers can rank up and have classes and perks. This is a simple way to make each of your guys unique and have a role in the squad.A few downsides are that you only have one base and the game ends somewhat abruptly after the last mission. Interceptors don't matter very much but is it cool when they do shoot down a UFO like they are supposed to.This game is very fun and I'm glad as hell they didn't dumb this down for casual gamers or the console crowd.

Posted: October 16, 2012
												Approaching this as someone who still places X-Com: UFO Defense in his top 5 O.A.T., I was rather skeptical.  Especially after the debacle of the demo version; suddenly I worried that they'd completely missed the point (despite all their boasting about how they totally nailed it) and created something that felt more like Mass Effect 2 than X-Com.  It's true, there are some modern vidcon clichés that bother me, and there are times where the course of events feels a bit too railroaded compared to the more "organic" development of progress in the original game.  At the same time, to view the game from another angle, when was the last time I enjoyed a tactical combat game this much?  Front Mission 3, maybe?  While at first I stubbornly resented the absence of a larger, more generally versatile squad, I came to realize that the class-based tactics are not only what set this game apart, but what really make it shine and furthermore what make it a sequel/remake thing actually worth playing.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is the latest in a series of strategy games about an invading Alien force. The game is quite fun and one of the best strategy games I've played in a while. There is a turn-based strategy element to it. You and the aliens take turns issuing orders to your squad. Inbetween missions, you do some strategy on a wider scale. You make some choices about facilities and skills your soldiers take. Some of these choices can be difficult to make because there is no chance to change them down the road. Overall, very fun. It is nice to finally see a real expansion instead of just a bunch of DLC like the rest of the industry. I'm not sure the expansion is worth the $30 they are currently charging for it, but it looks like it has a good amount of content and I think it will be worth it at around $5.I'd recommend picking this up for less than $10.I will update this review to be more in-depth at a later time.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a shining example of how a series can be freshened up, but still be as good as the classics. Many games have changed their core principles in order to earn an extra buck with a different audience, but XCOM keeps it real.The XCOM games have always delivered a unique experience where players manage resources outside of the battlefield, but also successfully carry out demanding missions on the ground. These situations keep you invovled, and you are always struggling to fight the imminent apocalypse. Keeping track of your pool of soldiers, the amount of money you have, ongoing research and development projects, panic levels, and aircraft never gets old.While XCOM has a fantastic turn-based strategy system for the actual combat, just as much of the strategy is in keeping the XCOM Project funded by different nations throughout the world; Put one nation's needs above another, and you'll be losing their support. In addition to that, you have the ability to increase the resources gathered monthly by launching satellites above certain nations. You protect these satellites with the aircraft you keep in the hangar, which can be equipped with a variety of weapons. The game does have it's shortcomings, however. Enemies may randomly spawn during a mission, and I'm left wondering about some of their design choices. For example, the unmanned weapons platform that can replace a soldier in your squad is criminally inaccurate, and it lacks the ability to use cover. The UFO vs. XCOM aircraft system is weak, and the skill tree decisions you make when a soldier is promoted are generally unbalanced, making one choice better than the other. In the end, XCOM delivers a great turn-based strategy experience on the field and  strong-yet-flawed project management off the field.

Posted: October 14, 2012
												It's very rare I recommend triple A games, I simply don't think they need my voice to add to their profits. However firaxis have done the impossible and taken a much loved nostalgia riddled game and brought it into 2012. This game has almost completely evolved and built on what the original was while only trimming away unnessecary quirks and baggage. Something that every previous attempt at an X-COM sequel has failed to do. (And there have been quite a few). Your units will live and die by your tactics and stratagy, this game brutely punishes carelessness. The games Ai is smart enough to flank and fallback on harder difficulties.Almost completely evolved yes, but sadly not quite. The alien movements within the geoscape is a static scripted system. Which is a far cry from the originals aggressive AI that would attempt to win the game from you by expanding and performing missions to gain presence and power within the world.There are clearly defined points in the game where if you do not choose to progress. The aliens cannot win, they are frozen and must await your completion of key missions before the AI and script will advance to the next stage.This has a profound effect on replayability. Because of the lack of unpredictability in alien movements on the world map. Every playthrough runs through exactly the same script. But worse than this, is the fact that with a little thought you can easily make the game unlosable, regardless of the difficulty setting.A great tactics game sadly hampered by the scripted plot and alien geoscape scripting.

												A pretty good remake of the classic game. The only real change I would like to see is the return of having more than one squad and base. Other than that, it's a decent enough title.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												I'd like to start off by telling you that i'm not used to writing reviews of games. I try my "best" to be sceptical of phenomenons in the gaming space, and not to buy in to the hype all too often. 2012's XCOM: Enemy Unknown appeared on many gaming sites top 5, and i dare say, even more often it ended up as their Game of the Year.If there's just an ounce in you, that enjoys the feeling of outsmarting things, whether it's an computer controlled AI, or another person (Even though i personally think the Multiplayer is somewhat undercooked in regards to singleplayer), you owe it to yourself to check out this game. I think it's pretty safe to say, that if you enjoy Firaxis other titles such as Civilization for instance, there is a pretty good chance you'll enjoy this aswell, but it doesn't have to be that way either. I've played it around 40 hours, and just with Civilization, i find the main issue with the game being that life takes too much time away from playing it.The difficulty levels in this game are good enough to encourage anybody to give this game a try, but fret not, hardcore players, as the Ironman mode coupled with the Impossible difficulty will leave you challenged to say the least.If this is the first&/last review i ever write, then i'll still be pretty satisfied, because this game really is a fantastic one, and i can only hope i've convinced one of you to give it a shot.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												XCOM: Enemy Unknown does a brilliant job of updating the classic X-COM franchise and bringing it into the 21st century, streamlining various processes for an easier-to-grasp challenge without losing complexity or depth. The game appears simple at first but, as you whittle the hours away, upgrading your base and purchasing upgrades, the game steadily grows in challenge. Unless you're playing on some of the higher difficulties (which the game itself notes are completely unfair), the game's challenge is always fair, and any mistakes you make are almost certainly your own - with some occasional missteps from the game's pathfinding and unruly glitches sometimes souring the experience.Even with the missteps, however, Enemy Unknown remains a great game, with addicting pace, fun gameplay, and fair difficulty.

Posted: November 27, 2013
												Enemy Unknown has its flaws and suffers from a tiny bit of "consolization" in terms of scope, depth, and interface, but it's still quite an accomplishment. After years and years of disasterous attempts to bring the X-com game style back into the limelight, this is most definitely the most successful. Though I personally don't think all of the changes to the original formula were good ones, XCOM stands on its own as a great game on its own merits.Enemy Within gets an even higher recommendation from me! It's a glorious example of Fraxis' ability to make "classic" expansion packs, while everyone else is lost in a sea of DLC. Instead of adding another world or story or anything, Enemy Within just makes the game more... everything. The additional game mechanics serve to further set it apart from any pre-established formula, while the rest is simply hundreds of little details that desperately needed a boost, such as map variety (the maps are numerous enough now that their presculpted nature is actually a joy), equipment variety (the game puts more "toys" in to give a better feeling of choice and playstyle), and soldier personalization (both in terms of abilities and appearance). My favorite thing of all, though, is a simple option (that I highly recommend!) at the beginning of the game which allows you to randomize the available abilities characters get to choose from. This is AWESOME and they clearly put a lot of thought into making it balanced, allowing interesting combinations without giving game-breaking overpowered situations or taking away vital skills that define the class types. It really gives each character more personality as you begin to use them for what you know they can do, not just their class types, and you don't need to rank a soldier up very far to begin defining a unique role. A few example of this that I've done, all with characters with only four or five abilities:- A sniper who gets massive bonuses if she's on a rooftop and has supressive fire abilites- A heavy weapons guy who acts as my team's best medic (usually a support role)- A grenadier support character who can carry multiple, more powerful grenades in addition to extra smoke grenadesSo, overall, I'd recommend the game! But now that Enemy Within is out, I can't imagine wanting to play without it.

Posted: October 20, 2013
												Easily one of the very best games in my collection, and one of the least expensive. As a guy who hates going through a game a second time, I am working towards the end of my second playthrough on classic iron-man and looking forward to my third one (on impossible, hopefully).The blend of micro- and macro-management is really fun and forces you to plan your funding strategies ahead (at least until you get full satellite coverage). The turn-based combat in itself is quite awesome, the action camera proving itself really immersive. Gameplay is both simple and ramified while the level design is well thought (while randomly generated). The entirety of the game is focused on making the fight for earth *your* fight for earth, and you can customize everything (even more with the dlcs) for your own enjoyment (and perhaps easier recognition of your soldiers while on mission).Understanding all the game mechanics can be hard at first and requires a lot of thought, but is well worth the time spent.Perhaps the only con I see for this game is the lack of real choice you have to make on the scenario. You can research all projects, complete the foundry, obtain full satellite coverage, have all your soldiers fully upgraded and geared all in the same playthrough. If I were to ask for an addition, it would be to force the player to make strategic choices (not only on what to research first, but on what to research at all), and challenges (why not adding some sort of automated earth defense system that you would have to deploy on earth, and the possibility to save countries that have left the X-COM project). XCOM : EW seems to deal in some way with this, I can't wait to buy it !Unlike most games, the challenges offered (classic/impossible mode, iron-man, and second wave options) are both challenging and not irritating. However higher difficulty modes are mostly based on modifying in-game values such as your soldier's base hp, costs of items/research projects... etc (even if the ai is slightly better) which basically force you to use overwatch more and be more cautious. I've yet to see a game showing additional mechanics and forcing the player to swap for totally different strategies on higher difficulty modes.In two words, GET IT !

Posted: October 17, 2015
												XCOM! I actually forgot I had this! Well Ill keep it short for you. Do you like chess? The strategy of planning each move? The brain power it takes to anticipate your opponent's every step? Well if you do, then welcome to XCOM. The closest thing XCOM has to chess is the intense, turn-based style of waiting. Yes, I know, "Waiting? That sounds HARDCORE!" Well your right! Between the 3-4 animations that loop for each person and alien, you, the gamer, get to experience HOURS of "Edge of your seat" action.Next theres the strategy! The worst part of turn based strategy games (As everyone knows) is figuring out how your enemies will react to your movement. XCOM takes that annoyance away from you. Half way through an operation they will just drop aliens literally anywhere. Thus removing the hassle of trying to use tactics to kill your opponents. So XCOM has obviously revolutionised Turn based strategy games. Obviously 10/10.

Posted: October 12, 2015
												SO GOOD!...SO TERRIBLE! SO FRUSTRATING! The thing about Xcom is that the mechanics themselves are fantastic, they really are. The turn based squad strategy is fun, the overall research/building strategy is fine. The problem lies only in two elements: 1. Difficulty settings. 2. Random Number Generators. Let it be said, if you're fairly casual with strategy and you play this game casually on "normal" setting, the game is absolutely fine. No problems there. This review is not for you then, just ignore. That's just not for me. I recommend the game on this basis, that it works fine on normal and that the basic mechanics are well done. If you're very serious about strategy, you'll almost certainly find "Normal" difficulty too easy and "Classic" fitting in general (at least if you're only planning one playthrough). Sounds great, right? Could have been except for one thing: the variance on Classic. Everything is a roll of the dice, which is fine, but the variance is insane. You can do everything right and still lose the game in one brief moment of bad luck. I'll illustrate the problem with this one scenario that actually took place for me: Turn 1. Your squad arrives in the woods. You move them into defensive positions just in case you're being charged right off the bat. They're all in cover, they're all in Overwatch (guarding). Three aliens attack, the squad takes down the first one. The second one uses a skill that automatically deals 1 damage, it hits one guy. *BREAK* Let me here say that one damage is nothing, it really is nothing. So, the guy who got hit with the whopping 1 damage rolls a dice and panics. He panics by turning to his right and trying to execute his friend standing right next to him because... well, who knows. It's the standard panic reaction in this game. He rolls another dice and misses from point blank range. Just can't hit. Well, fine you think, but alas. Behind him is a seasoned veteran, a captain who has seen many battles. He rolls a dice too, he also panics. Now, he has taken 0 damage, he has merely seen one dude take one damage. Well, he handles panic in the same way and decides to execute one of his friends. He chooses your best solider (and medic) and nails her right in the back of the head with a critical hit, killing her instantly. End turn one. Turn 2. Bring up menu, quit game. Things like this just happen, they just do. You can restart the mission whenever they do, but it wears you out. Or it did with me. Worst thing is, they could fix everything wrong with this game so easily. 1. rebalance panic. 2. remove critical hits. Just those two things would limit the variance to a degree where the game would feel hard but fair. It's really all they needed to do and then the game would probably be a 10.

Posted: October 24, 2015
												This is not your dad's XCOM. A typically slick Firaxis entry, this is a re-imagining of the original that takes the bulk of the source and transports it into a sleek, cruel, narrative-led shell. The principles of XCOM are all here with some additions, subtractions and lot of careful streamlining. While some stand-out elements are missing (goodbye fully destructible environments), a lot of the things you would expect to miss are shown up as unpleasant memories that make the forefathers difficult to return to (weight-based equipment management, I'm looking at you!). It's a polished, shiny, occasionally eerie version of an old treasure that does everything it can to entice newcomers while somehow keeping the vast majority of the grognards happy as well. Only a few games genuinely earn a $30+ price tag, but I would not hesitate to recommend this at any time, let alone during a sale.

Posted: May 4, 2015
												So, this is my first time playing an XCOM game. I thought I'd give myself a challenge and try an Iron Man game on Classic difficulty. And a challenge I got! This game is brutal!Enjoying it thoroughly though. I think at 24 hours I've already got my money's worth, and I'm sure I'll be spending a lot more time with it in the future.*EDIT after 150 hours*Finally completed the game on Classic mode. After over a dozen of restarts and letting go of the Ironman requirement I'd set for myself...My overall opinion of the game hasn't changed much. Both the tactical- and strategy-layers are engaging and play very well.I do have some criticism as well though: I don't like the difficulty progression in this game. It starts out extremely hard. Your soldiers have paper-armour and pee-shooters for weapons. While the aliens you face use highly accurate plasma weapons. But you can catch up with the aliens fairly quickly and the game gets easier from there on out.In the last few missions my squad was completely overpowered. Most aliens didn't even get a shot off before I killed them...Still, I am looking forward to playing the game again. And this time I WILL beat Ironman!

Posted: June 16, 2016
												(played on the xbox. Just have this game so excuse the play time)The story of the Xcom. A commitee by the worlds leading powers to stop the alien Invasion.We started so young.After our groups first mission went off without a hitch. gunned down the sectoids. and won the mission. Cue Several Missions of success. One normal downed UFO mission. We thought that was all it was. A normal mission. My squad consisted of Jana "Strobe" Becker the heavy, She was a killing Machine, Never letting the alien of the hour getting away from the Contact point. She played Suppresion and covering fire. She was one of our best operatives.We had Amadi "Road Block" Manana. He was Flanking and Assualt. His nickname was acuurate. He almost never missed. You could rely on him.Both armed with Frag Grenades and body armor. They didnt need anything else.We had two snipers, That was all we needed. Daniel "Snake eyes" Lynch and Kaito "Stalker" Yamazaki.We had the best team XCOM could buy. We were unstoppable.Lynch was relativley new. only 5 missions under his belt while Kaito and the rest of the team had ten to 11 missions. We were sent to A downed large UFO aircraft. We dispersed, did our thing until we wandered right into an ambush, We had our two heavy's take point and suddenly a muton walked through the door. We all went for cover. Lynch and Kaito went  back behind cover .Amati ended up behind the Muton, facing the rest. Amati fired. hit for 4 damage. Jana fired as well. Missed. Muton went for Jana, Between the damage she took from the mission and random chance. She was killed. Amati Panacked. Lynch and Kaito went for the kill. Lynch hit for 2 damage and Kaito missed. This game is brutal and has a big learning curve, and you know what?I love it.You're the Commander of the Xtraterrestrial COMbat Unit, other wise known as X-COM for short, a multinational organization which composes itself of the finest soldiers, pilots, tacticians, scientists, and engineers that money can buy. You must mange your resources like in an actual war, and make decisions on what to do, whether to keep your countries and funding on your side, or to have your soldiers survive. My first playthrough ultimately ended up in losing Canada and caused me to go about at a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ standstill wondering what I should do because I'm too low on funds at the moment to ultimately gather anyone their satellites.As I said, this game is ♥♥♥♥ing brutal, and if you want a challenge on a play-by-play basis for turn-based combat and frustrating 90% hit misses? Posted: October 23, 2012
												A brilliant re-make of one of the greatest strategy games of all time.  The game has two main parts,  the base/resource management mode and a very intense turn-based combat mode.   The latter of the two is what really makes this game shine.You start the game with your base, and world view where you will manage your units, weapons, facilities and resources.  You search the globe for the alien threat.   This part of the game falls a bit short and can become a bit monotonous.  XCOM truly shines when you locate some aliens and send your team out to clear the site.The turn based combat is spot on, with a few minor tweaks to the original gameplay, although it still captures same the nail-biting intesity.   Your soldiers start out pretty weak, but will level up and accquire more powerful weapons as they complete more missions.  The game has 'permadeath' for your soldiers, so it really hurts when they are lost.Can you rid the world of the aliens?I give this a 97% on the Yeti scale.

												A challenging and engaging turn based strategy game that will make you feel invested in the fates of your soldiers, your base and humanity's survival. I highly recommend it for any level player, but be forewarned, that if you make a bad call, you will pay for it in the game, no matter the difficulty setting. Happy alien blasting!

Posted: March 8, 2014
												XCOM has proven to be one of the freshest, and most challenging games I've played in recent memory. Being a huge fan of grid-based tactical combat games, this particular title oozes with a classic feel, while still offering new gameplay mechanics and a modern graphical facelift. While the game isn't necessarily the most original (mankind must stop oncoming alien threat to save the Earth from certain destruction), it handles its subject matter with a pretty large level of depth, pages upon pages of information on each successful research project embarked upon, or every alien autopsy completed. The permadeath factor is unnerving and really keeps you on edge, where a single mistake can mean the life or death of one of your best soldiers. This constant threat keeps you from ever feeling like you're unstoppable on the battlefield, a prize I feel that far too many games give out freely. You earn your success in this game, and you'll find yourself patting yourself on the back after every successful operation. Fans of games like Fire Emblem and Advance Wars, be sure to pick this up for one hell of a great time. It's time to show those aliens who's boss, like Will Smith in Independence Day: Welcome ta Erff.

Posted: November 1, 2013
												A very fun and addicitng game that is actually quite challenging and unforgivable of your mistakes. You have to manage your team well as well as your financial health. Making hard decisions and prioritizing your goals are all part of the challenge. I had quite an enjoyable time playing this game. The only negative things I say about this game is the controls and camera angles/views are quite wonky at times, especially when there's a building with more than one floor. Another thing to note is that this game is not really a story-driven game so don't expect a strong, in-depth plot. Otherwise, this is a stellar sci-fi based strategy game! * This game has grown on me. It is MY favourite game!*Remember, we will be watching!

Posted: August 29, 2014
												If you are a kid this game will make you a man.Every decision you make in the battlefield will have consequences and most of the time deadly.You may start with a full equiped squad and seconds later find yourself left with only one alive,because you were flanked or mispotitioned and now you have to fight with what is left like a real soldier you have to readjust your strategy constantly.Tension is amazing in this game and consider that i never liked squad based games.Pros -Battles with real tension-Maybe the best artificial inteligence i have seen in any video game-If you don't use tactics you are dead-Great visuals and sounds accompanied with amazing physics-Even though story is almost non existent you will be quite eager to learn more about this unknown enemy as the game progresses-Gameplay is solid and addicting-Very nice set of upgrades and base management-Very challenging and unforgiving but never frustrative-Lots of maps and each one is well designed-One mistake in the battlefield and the odds can turn against you which makes every encounter awesomeCons-Camera issues-Poor soldier progresion system-Repetitive objectives-<90% missed> shots happen way too frequently-Poor tutorialOverall 9.5/10 a true masterpiece!

Posted: June 30, 2014
												I bought the XCOM Complete Package on Summer Sale and I would have definitely paid full price for this awesome game. I really liked Civilization V and come from an RPG/Strategy/Turn-based games background mostly. If you have a thing for Aliens, military infiltration games and simulators you will love XCOM.My first experience was playing Enemy Within directly, which adds several elements that make this game even more wonderful and I can't think of living without them in my gameplay so I advice you do the same.I've spent quite some nights developing my XCOM HQ, building facilities, upgrading weapons, aircrafts, soldiers, slaining aliens and overall getting the grip of intelligent positioning and careful selection of the units I take to each mission.I don't think I know anyone that regrets their XCOM experience and I don't think you will, just be prepared to hand over your life to 2K one turn at a time.Still... one thing to have in mind. There are some bugs on the tutorial which, if your particullarly affected like I was, will not let you go further in the game, so try playing it, understaing the initial bits of the story and how-to's and if you get to the point in which it's bugged, just disable tutorials and start over, you won't really need it.

Posted: November 1, 2014
												XCOM: Enemy unknown is a turn based strategy game that puts you and your soldiers up against aliens of various types.  you start off with basic soldiers that you would expect to see today and through reverse engineering alien tech you get better weapons, armor, and more.the game has strategy outside the combat as well as you must build your base, shoot down UFO's and keep countries happy or they will withdrawl from the Xcom project.graphically the game is good  and  I enjoy the sound design and dialog though  the sound effects eventually do get repetitive.the story is pretty good but feels like it ends a bit abruptly.  there are many strategies  to win as there are different classes of soldier.overall the game is enjoyable. is it worth $60? only if you are a turn based strategy fan as you will probably get multiple playthroughs out of it but even novice players should pick it up for under $5-$10 as the stoy can last 10 hours.

Posted: October 3, 2013
												If you don't own this already, there's something wrong with you. But don't worry. It's on sale right now so you can repent for your gaming sins.You might as well pre-order the Enemy Within DLC while you're at it.If you're not familiar with XCom... it was a game released back when I was a babby. It was really buggy and impossibly hard yet incredibly good fun, an intriguing mix of turn-based strategy and financial management.Aliens are here and they're not gonna sit around and let filthy, smelly humans wander around unmolested.Good news! The nations of the world are willing to fund the XCom project, a military outfit headed by you to counter the alien threat.Bad news! The aliens have plasma weaponry and humans are squishy.In the same style as the original, humanity starts at a major disadvantage. It's up to you to throw dispensable jarheads at the aliens 'til humanity can invent technology capable of stopping them... and then, you know, figure out how to turn the tables and stop them murderizing everyone.The standard difficulty is difficult enough that you're gonna die within a month until you get to grips with it. Then it's still pretty dámn difficult. Of course, if you want a challenge you can opt for classic difficulty to make it as hard as the original. And then there's impossible mode. Like you're ever gonna finish it on classic.Anyways. One of the best games ever with plenty of replay value. But of course, you already own it, 'cos you're a true gaming badáss, right? Not some alien hugging nooblord...

Posted: April 1, 2015
												3 Playthroughs ive gone through. So many tears, over the fallen, so much mourning, Its like a Game of Thrones, that you play with your own children, whom you helped develope. You offer them the best armor, Weapons, and gadgets that you could afford Only to see your son/Daughter get their life taken away by that god damn Thin Man.. Curse them... you scream.. as you realised that no matter how hard you try they will never come back... all that time you spent nurturing them was all for not. (Spoiler)It was the Final Mission assault on The Temple Ship, my Six Soldiers were ready, A support Named CJ, A Support Named Texas Tan(Had to put myself in to feel the game truly), A Heavy named Taylor , A Sniper named Robert, A Support Named Kola, and assault named Ben. All of them Battle Harden, of the 6 half of them were Psionic, Robert, Tayor, and Kola. I fitted them with the best gear that I had to offer, They went in to the mission like any other, assuming their kill count would signifigantly raise. They battled the many enemies that the Temple Ship had to offer, upon reaching the Final Room where the Supreme Etheral floated, I had the feeling in my gut this wasnt to be a easy battle, the battle began with 2 dead Muton Elites, being shot in the head by Robert, with a double tap skill. then came the minor Etherals taking over Ben's and Kola's Minds, both had succumbed to the dark powers of the etheral only to fire apon their own brothers, critically wounding Texas and CJ, It was the last choice I had either kill CJ and Myself, or Kill the Supreme Etheral, i took the shot and killed the Etheral but without knowledge, the cutscene came and Robert Gave his Life to save The Earth, but when the cutscene was in action it still had Me and Cj Critcally wounded on the ship with robert thus ending the lives of half the squad on the Temple Ship. After that gameplay I realised that This game took me through so many turns and twist, you never really have every little plan down to the detail produced visibly. Id like to say 100/10, mainly cause this game had it all, the terrible chance that you could miss the 99% shot, or make a 5% shot, the times where your newly recruited squaddies decide to blow a hole through your medic's Head out of sheer panic. the cutscenes that made you either crap your pants out of fear of loosing a soldier or a new type fo alien in which you slowly begin to hate and overwhelmingly hate further. 10/10.

												This is a very good game that is faithful to the original in terms of the original's positive aspects and aspirations, but actually manages to change a lot more than initially meets the eye. This is also a hard game, and you may want to tone down the difficulty until you get the hang of things. Replay value is better than one might think, but it is not the game's strong suit. Thus, unless you loved the original games, you may not want to pay full price. As I loved the orininals, I have no regrets paying full price.

Posted: March 25, 2014
												Having fond memories of the original classic I can only say this remake does the original justice. I was a little dubious to begin with thinking no re-make (and a few have been attempted the "UFO trilogy") would stand up to the original. Aspects such as squad creation and progression down to tech research and engineering all are standard formats most people know, but crafted alongside a great alien invasion story and turn based tactics I would say its a must buy for anyone into strategy games with RPG elements. For those who recall the original and are wondering what is missing, main aspects are multiple base creation, allocating equipment Deus Ex style alongside more specific equipment slots. Also aspects such as squad members becoming more accurate with certain weapons the more they used them to a standard aim ability, and a limit to high ranking soldiers based on the number of soldiers you had in anyone base. But overall these are minor issues compared to new aspects of the game not in the original. I hope this review has been of some help to gamers out there!

Posted: April 2, 2016
												Xcom is widely known to be an exceptional game.I would agree absolutely with that general concensus that this is a really decent tactical strategy game.  I can almost see what this is based on and where it has come from.  This version too exhibits some really nice additions which allows me to say with absolute confidence that technology made this game better.  In saying that there are issues with this game's quality and its design, and irronically Firaxis are getting no better at making games that are flawless... and that is worth saying as these are integral parts of the game I can  see that don't work/don't give enough feedback/ or just are buggy as hell, and it doesn't feel like it will get fixed at all.The beauty of Xcom Enemy Unknown is that is has so many sides to it.  It is in everyway, like Divinity : Dragon Commander, where you manage your ship, build stuff, get reserach, monitor stuff, build more stuff  in between tactical battle mode.  This design is brilliant can offer so much depth I think, and Dragon Commander went a step further in many cases.  I will add that Xcom's implementation of that is no different and allows you to do all sorts, though from what I can see, if you dont get this stuff by a certain time in the game, the game seems to suffocate your operation... not sure about that exactly,  but it felt like I 'nearly' did and it cost me at some point throughout the game.  Whats more, as Dragon Commander's Political exploits are generally not required in your 10th game, alot of the stuff on here is not time draining and does NOT keep you from getting into what XCom is all about.  Combat.Combat is decent and has reasonable depth and certainly does not get overloaded with stuff.  Its seamless, nice to do and leaves you little to worry about in your decisions.  improvements of weapons are worth it, improvement of the skills of each soldier is worth it , and when you get to a stage in the game where some of you soldiers get 'extra skillls'?  It's definately worth it.  However when its late game and your waiting to 'get paid', battle mode does feel like a chore sometimes, it restricts progress.Each of the classes to some extent feel like they are worth using, though the best ones at the start feel weak at the end, and the weak classes at the start feel OP at the end.What adds to this is the camera system, when an order is made, the camera follows your soldier, or some cinematic view is taken.  This is not something I would comment as being essential, but as it doesn't break anything and it looks good, gives  the game a nicer feel, it defeintely is good overall and gives the game a nice sheen.Now what I don't like about Xcom: Firaxis, have had a few gmes I have played with certain bugs and broken functionality, Xcom is no different.  As amazing as Xcom looks, and runs, Firaxis clearly didn't get the engine right.. There is a serious issue with the selection of parts of the map that you are not looking at ... for example, I can be looking at the interior of a ship and then click inside to move, and the system will think I the roof tile (above)or lower floor(below), potentially screwing up tactics(yes which is the difference between something going horribly wrong!)and the game (Diablo Hardcore characters and poor connection come to mind, and yes you can play hardcore on this - no saves!). I guess there is a cure, if you are pretentous enough to challenge that assertion, as you will need to look carefully where the point is and where the path fidning trail is.  This generally means, you have to zoom out, rotate the view blah blah... all in all its a bit of BS.. waste of time and does takes from the game. This should not happen if you are not zoomed to another 'layer' in my oppinion, and I think that is just logical.  I think if Firaxis thought about this issue, then they could have included an undo move button function, but they didn't... There are other issues with seeing the range of your units and what they can attack as it is not clear at all what you can attack and what you can until you move that unit...Also as far as i can see, you cannot pick your squad, i.e. if I want to train up a bunch of noob soldiers instead of using vets , then I can't, it's simple... Well, I could of course make sure (the vets) all take mortal wounds last match so they are off in the infirmary nursing wounds, but nothing more from looks of it.  Then in addition to that, when they are removed from the squad without wounds, the equipment stays on the soldier... Sometimes those soldiers dont show up in the team for the next mission, so you have 1 soldier with no gear (perhaps returning from the infirmary)and another one in the barracks that you have to track down and strip of their gear, and you CAN'T switch them... makes for boring cheese and bad design if you ask me... and yes, some equiptment mid game is damn expensive, so it is important that this works!Science is a let down, like supcom2, once you researched everything, you have wasted money on labs and scientists are in-effect worthless, it is very dis-empowering, and as much as your squad is powerful enough and the rest is justifiably left up to you to be a good strategist, it still makes for something of an empty concept... Civ and Alpha Centurai had post science qualifications.. I think they could have added those in to make an intersting endgame of sorts, making science a worth while endeavour.The story was alright I guess and the game flows much like Unreal 3, so its not complicated, but its good, and the art design definately complements that with the idea of who the alien race really is and where your going.There are some bad parts to this game , and as many people will rave blindly with the 'horde', I feel its nesscessary to point out Xcom is NOT perfect.  However, as a game, I spent 50+ hours  on this and I could play it again.  It was generally fun to play, so I would say most of the hype is infact justified.I will add, that I would definately consider gettin Xcom 2 at near full price as I liked this one so much.

Posted: May 15, 2015
												I absolutely love this game. I could spend way more than a hundred hours on it and I probably will eventually.  The strategy feels real, the player is in complete control of his forces in the battlefield during intense battles. Throughout the game the player has the ability to choose his own preferred methods of upgrading his units. The more you play the easier it gets because you can use your research to jump past certain technologies allowing you to progress at your own speed. Making the game absolutely feel like the player has gotten his full moneysworth. The DLC Enemy Within is also worth buying because of the new mechanics and care added to the game. It's a little odd that the characters have their entire bodies replaced, but that is the way it works in this universe.

Posted: November 23, 2013
												XCOM:Enemy Unknown is one of my personal favorite games. The gameplay is diverse and impressive and you can find yourself immersed after playing the game for only a few hours. You will become emotionally invested in your squad and the people in it, and you'll try your hardest to help out as many people across the world as you can. Firaxis has managed to create a game almost infinitely replayable, and they've managed to create a game that you'll WANT to play an infinite amount of times. The graphics on this game are also very impressive, if your computer can handle them. Textures are very detailed and the sound design is top notch. Ambient noises, such as the aliens chilling sound effects, resonate as you try to take your unit safely across the map. In conclusion, XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a must have game if you're a fan of the strategy genre. Even if you aren't, I recommend you buy this game just because it's so immersive and fun. 10/10

Posted: December 28, 2013
												XCOM is a very playable tactical combat game that rises to greatness because of its attention to detail. It perfectly nails the 1950’s mysterious alien invasion vibe while still being taken seriously. Very strong voice acting for the several key NPCs along with stellar music and ambient sound effects create a nearly palpable mood, both during missions and back at base.Graphical details also contribute to the believability of it all, with expertly crafted combat zones ranging from sunny forests to urban jungles. Then there’s the ant farm style headquarters that lets you build deep into the ground and zoom in to observe the fine details of your labs, workshops, and other facilities. You can even see your specific soldiers resting, training, or healing in the barracks.Gameplay wise, there’s two separate parts: strategic global management and tactical combat. First, on the management side, you have to build your base, launch satellites, and prepare yourself for attacks. This is all done through menus although the game wisely spruces things up with cutscenes and the graphical ant farm base, which both greatly reduce that “spreadsheet game” feel other games suffer from.In conclusion, XCOM is an atmospheric alien invasion simulator with decent strategic elements and very addictive combat. It truly is a great game partly because of the attention to detail and partly because of its uniqueness. It does get dragged down by its unexplained and unbalanced strategic side, arbitrary difficulty, and turn-based quirks. Still, if you are willing to put up with the frustration, XCOM may turn you into a mastermind of massive alien murder.The Good-Wonderfully detailed combat zones-Simple yet diverse combat-Very tense battle situations-Great close-up cameras during battle-Strong character and alien design-Immersive ant farm base design-Very atmospheric music and sound effects-Strong voice acting and dialogue from key NPCs-Lots of little stylistic touches everywhereThe Bad-Unexplained strategic mechanics-Ideal build prioritization limits freedom-Arbitrary difficulty-Questionable alien discovery system-Turn-based quirks-A bit too random in missions and rewards-Only a few mission types, locations repeat-Unfulfilling last mission and ending

Posted: September 5, 2014
												XCOM enemy unknown is the best modern turn based strategy game. It has an excellent blend of base management and gritty tactical combat. It's a lethal game, where a tactical blunder means a dead squad member or a mismangement of resources leads to the loss of a country's support. XCOM starts off brutally difficult, with your soldiers clearly mismatched. However, as the game goes on, your soldier's training and equipment clearly outpaces the alien army. The disparity between your progression and the enemies makes the endgame start to drag, and the final battle is anticlimatic. XCOM enemy unknown (and I daresay it's essential expansion, enemy within) is a fantastic game that captivated me. It took me 3  days to complete the game the first time in 25 hours. If you're looking for a challenge, XCOM is the game to get
